webTitle: Wayward Shoaib told suspension will stay

fields.headline: Wayward Shoaib told suspension will stay
fields.standfirst: Shoaib's ban will not be suspended say ICC. To make matters worse he will miss one-day against Sri Lanka after returning early in the morning after a night out hours before Pakistan played Australia last Friday.
fields.trailText: Pakistan's tearaway paceman Shoaib Akhtar, fresh from being ruled out of the forthcoming Test series against Sri Lanka because of his illegal action, has been banned from a one-day international for misconduct.
fields.body:
Pakistan's tearaway paceman Shoaib Akhtar, fresh from being ruled out of the forthcoming Test series against Sri Lanka because of his illegal action, has been banned from a one-day international for misconduct.

The Pakistan Cricket Board announced yesterday that Shoaib would miss Sunday's opening one-day game against Sri Lanka "after he was found guilty of a night out" before last Friday's second one-day final against Australia.

"Shoaib returned to the team hotel in the morning of the second final in Sydney," said the board's chairman Tauqir Zia. "He has been banned for Sunday's match and the board will also impose a heavy cash fine on him."

The news came as a double blow for Shoaib, who had hoped that the International Cricket Council would this week lift his Test ban.

The ICC president Jagmohan Dalmiya yesterday confirmed that the suspension would be discussed at the body's executive board meeting tomorrow and Thursday. But Dalmiya said that only the procedures by which Shoaib was banned - and not the bowler's action itself - would be assessed, and his suspension would not be overturned.

"How can the ICC announce its decision to ban Shoaib from Test cricket when they haven't reviewed the case?" asked the furious Pakistan coach Intikhab Alam. "In Australia he bowled with a new action. The ICC advisory panel needs to look at the fresh videos before passing judgment."

The Sri Lankans also threw their support behind Shoaib. "I don't see anything wrong in his bowling action," said the captain Sanath Jayasuriya.

In December the ICC's advisory panel banned Shoaib from international cricket but Dalmiya intervened to allow him to play in the one-day series in Australia. The main concern about Shoaib's action is the way he bowls his bouncer, a delivery not permitted in limited-overs matches.

Pakistan will continue to contest the ban.

 South Africa have picked the veteran left-arm spinner Clive Eksteen for their two-Test series against India starting next week.

webTitle: Maddy drums up yet more enthusiasm

fields.headline: Maddy drums up yet more enthusiasm
fields.standfirst: Leicestershire's batsman is dead set on not being a forgotten man
fields.trailText: Paul Weaver on Darren Maddy, England's in-house enthusiastic zealot. And, incidentally, England's have enriched their style of training. They now play football.
fields.body:
Every England tour comes up with a Lord Lucan - or four. He will start his journey wearing the glossy smile of a game-show host and after two or three months he cannot be traced without recourse to sniffer dogs and genetic fingerprinting.

He might be the party's sixth fast bowler. More often it is that ultimate Sancho Panza, the No2 wicketkeeper. Bob Taylor, one of the best glovemen produced by England, had the misfortune to be the contemporary of Alan Knott.

In the West Indies a few years ago Keith Medlycott disappeared as successfully as a Nazi war criminal in Brazil. At first he was recognised as a player. Then some thought he might be the scorer or baggage handler. After a while he was dismissed as a hanger-on. Ultimately he vanished as completely as Claude Rains in HG Wells's The Invisible Man.

In South Africa this winter the prize might go to Gavin Hamilton, who in his single Test made a pair and failed to take a wicket, then was injured before the one-day series.

Another strong contender would be Alex Tudor, a fast bowler of genuine potential, despite his Bambi legs, but one who will find himself at the back of the grid next summer behind not only Dean Headley and Chris Silverwood but also such non-tourists as Steve Harmison and Ed Giddins.

Unlike these two, Chris Adams has played in all the Tests and most of the one-day internationals before immersing himself in invisible ink. Graeme Swann has also receded into misty memory.

And then there is Darren Maddy. This most ardent of players made his England debut against New Zealand in the final Test of last summer, scoring 14 and five at the Oval. On this tour he has played in two Tests and two one-dayers without making any stronger impression.

When he revealed yesterday that he was about to go shopping for a set of drums it was difficult not to infer that he felt the need for a good percussion instrument with which to reinforce his claims.

Rather like Adams, Maddy needed to make an impression on this tour because back in England Alec Stewart, Graham Thorpe and Mark Ramprakash are all plotting inter- national returns; two of them, perhaps all three, will play next summer.

Maddy, 25, a highly successful batsman at England A level, is an outstanding fielder who for Leicestershire, at least, has shown a decent technique, a fierce concentration and an ability to biff the ball. But what has impressed the England management most is his enthusiasm, his pure zeal.

"It's just nice to get another opportunity. It's been a long time. I've been doing a lot of hard work on my game. On a long tour it can get away from you. I always felt I would get another chance."

In the Tests Maddy came into the side only because of injury. In the one-day series it has been only because of the poor form of Adams. He did not bat in his first triangular-series match and scored a robust 22 in his second, against South Africa in East London on Friday evening.

As for the drums, Maddy is the latest in a number of budding musicians to emerge from the England dressing room, following Mark Butcher (vocals and lead guitar) and Alan Mullally (guitar).

"I'm not in the same class as Butch, who could be a pro. But I'm reading a book on playing the drums and I hope to have a lesson here as well as taking a set home with me. There is a bit of music in my family and I've been following a number of bands around Leicester in recent years, and Big Al [Mullally] has also got me listening to U2."

Yesterday football, rather than cricket, was the topic of conversation as the rain poured down. Bafana Bafana, the South Africa national side, are the toast of the town after beating Ghana 1-0 in the quarter-finals of the African Nations Cup on Sunday, despite being down to 10 men.

As if to mark this famous victory, England scorned the soggy nets and played football instead. Darren Gough and Nasser Hussain caught the eye but Maddy, competitive as ever, scored twice.

fields.headline: Zola suffers indignity of reserves
fields.trailText: Kingsmeadow Stadium, home of non-league Kingstonian, was not a venue the Chelsea striker Gianfranco Zola could have envisaged playing at when he arrived in England just over three years ago.
fields.body:
Kingsmeadow Stadium, home of non-league Kingstonian, was not a venue the Chelsea striker Gianfranco Zola could have envisaged playing at when he arrived in England just over three years ago.

But the former Italian international, who was the Football Writers' Association player of the year in his first season here, was given a clear indication that he needs to fight for his future at Stamford Bridge when he was required to play in a reserves' match in the Surrey suburbs last night.

Zola, who is 33, has been a shadow of his former self in recent weeks, struggling to reproduce the form with which he first graced the Premiership when he arrived from Parma late in 1996.

With George Weah, who joined Chelsea from Milan last month, and the £10m summer signing Chris Sutton Gianluca Vialli's favoured partnership in attack at present, with Tore Andre Flo seemingly next in line, Zola has dropped down the pecking order.

He has scored only two goals in 32 league and cup appearances this season and started only three of the last 11 first-team games. His last Chelsea goal came during the 5-0 victory over Manchester United on October 3.

He was at least on the bench at White Hart Lane on Saturday, where Chelsea won 1-0, but he did not get on, unlike Flo, and last night he was named in the side which took on Charlton's reserves.

On a damp, windy evening Zola was left in no doubt that he faces a battle to prove to Vialli he still possesses the scoring ability to help Chelsea chase a top-three league finish and play a part in their Champions League campaign.

Lucrative matches against Lazio in cauldrons of noise must have seemed a distant dream last night as he strove to rediscover his confidence.

 Edmundo, the controversial Brazilian striker, looks set to quit Vasco da Gama after losing the captaincy to his great rival Romario. Edmundo admitted yesterday that he refused to play in Vasco's 2-1 defeat at Palmeiras on Saturday after discovering Romario had been given the armband.

The pair fell out a year ago when Edmundo spotted a caricature of himself on a toilet door in Romario's Rio de Janeiro night-club. Witnesses to Saturday's incident said he stormed out of the dressing-room shortly before kick-off looking "extremely upset".

"This isn't about vanity," Edmundo said later. "But the captain has to be someone who knows the players, has control and authority. Everyone knows we do not get on. If they had given the captaincy to [Mauro] Galvao or anyone else, I wouldn't have had a problem."

The spat came as no surprise to Brazilian pundits, who forecast fireworks when Vasco signed Romario before Fifa's World Club Championship last month. The two strikers have not been on speaking terms for a year but an uneasy truce held during the tournament, as Manchester United discovered to their expense. But watching Romario outscore him in recent games, then win the armband, was too much for Edmundo, who joined Vasco last June after an unhappy 18 months in Italy.

"I asked Vasco not to take away the rights I had acquired, to shoot penalties and be captain," Edmundo said. "It was like going home and finding someone sleeping in my bed."

Edmundo missed the penalty in the shoot-out that cost Vasco the club final against Corinthians.

webTitle: Reed in hot water over goal salute

fields.headline: Reed in hot water over goal salute
fields.trailText: Mike Reed yesterday became the latest high-profile Premiership referee to fall foul of the authorities when he was asked to explain why he greeted a Liverpool goal at Anfield on Saturday with a clenched-fist salute.
fields.body:
Mike Reed yesterday became the latest high-profile Premiership referee to fall foul of the authorities when he was asked to explain why he greeted a Liverpool goal at Anfield on Saturday with a clenched-fist salute.

The Premier League has asked the Birmingham official to submit a written report. Reed has publicly admitted making the gesture seconds after Patrik Berger scored Liverpool's second goal in the 3-1 win over Leeds United.

It is believed the Premier League decided to ask Reed for his expanation of the incident after receiving several complaints from Leeds supporters who construed his action as possibly a sign of bias in favour of the Merseyside club.

Reed insisted yesterday he was definitely not a Liverpool fan, that his actions were instinctive and that he was doing no more than congratulating himself on a sound piece of judgment.

"Yes, it is true, I did punch the air, but I wasn't doing it in celebration of the goal but in triumph as I had allowed Liverpool to play on after they could have been awarded a free-kick," said Reed.

"Vladimir Smicer was fouled in the build-up to the goal but as he still managed to get away I decided to play an advantage.

"He went on to pass the ball to Berger, who scored. I didn't raise my arm or anything like that. My fist was clenched but it was down at my side. I was simply pleased with myself for having made what turned out to be the right decision."

Although Reed admitted it was an unorthodox form of celebration which he would not seek to repeat, he said he was "comfortable" with his actions.

"Everyone is delighted when a referee does play the advantage and it pays off," he added. "The referee does love to see the ball in the back of the net after he has waved play on because it proves he was right."

However, the Premier League spokesman Mike Lee said that such displays of emotion from match officials should not be encouraged.

"We understand the emotions involved but such gestures are open to misinterpretation and cannot be encouraged.

"We have asked Mike Reed to provide us with a written report of the incident and we are seeking to view the video evidence. We will consider the matter in the light of that information."

Reed's actions were yesterday defended by the former Premier League referee Roger Milford, who said he himself had acted in a similar manner on many occasions.

"I would have done what Mike did; in fact I did it many times," he said. "Mike is involved in the game and he is happy that he has done something right. It wasn't done with any malicious intent, it was done through pure love of the game."

The chairman of the Leeds United Supporters' Association, Ray Fell, also exonerated Reed. "Some might say that it was silly of the referee to do what he did, but it was a good goal and I don't think anything the referee did have much effect on it," he said. "Liverpool had a good day and we were well beaten."

Ten days ago one of Reed's colleagues, Rob Harris, was suspended for a month for his part in the incident during the FA Cup fourth-round tie between Tranmere Rovers and Sunderland when the First Division club briefly had 11 men on the pitch despite having had a player sent off.

webTitle: Ferguson faces transfer battle as Monaco hang on to Djetou

fields.headline: Ferguson faces transfer battle as Monaco hang on to Djetou
fields.trailText: Any move by Manchester United to sign the Monaco defender Martin Djetou will be resisted by the French club until at least summer.
fields.body:
Any move by Manchester United to sign the Monaco defender Martin Djetou will be resisted by the French club until at least summer.

Sir Alex Ferguson is lining up an offer for the Ivory Coast stopper but Monaco, 10 points clear at the top in France, do not want to lose the highly rated Djetou.

Monaco's spokeswoman Genevieve Berti-Banide said: "Martin's contract runs until 2003 and we want him to stay until then at least."

But in recent years Monaco have had to sell several leading players and Berti-Banide admitted: "In football you can never be 100% sure about things."

Meanwhile, Ferguson insists Jordi Cruyff will not be leaving United before the end of the season after reports linking the Dutch forward with Liverpool.

Even though Cruyff's contract expires this summer, when he can move on a Bosman free transfer, Ferguson says: "Jordi is going nowhere. He's one of the 25 players in our squad for Europe. You never know when he might be needed."

 Jorge Cadete aims to make a home debut for Bradford at the end of the month after his move from Benfica was delayed after his medical was put back.

 Dion Dublin is back in light training with Aston Villa after breaking a bone in his neck in December. His progress has amazed John Gregory, who said: "They have told him that if his neck hurts he must stop, but he is super-fit."

webTitle: Cold war erupts again as Russia claims 'snub'

fields.headline: Cold war erupts again as Russia claims 'snub'
fields.trailText: England yesterday found themselves in a diplomatic row with the Russians, nostalgically flavoured with Cold War insults and intrigue.
fields.body:
England yesterday found themselves in a diplomatic row with the Russians, nostalgically flavoured with Cold War insults and intrigue.

The dispute that made the Russians see red concerned Wembley, and the last international match at the old stadium. Moscow claims the Football Association invited Russia to be England's farewell opponents in a friendly on May 31, then dropped them and, worse, invited their rivals Ukraine.

"You should not always trust English officials," the Russian Sports Express muttered after sourly splashing the allegations on its front page.

But English officials strenuously denied any snub. They claim they merely sounded out Russia as possible opponents, along with other countries, before plumping for Ukraine in England's final home game before Euro 2000.

Not for the first time in history that did not tally with Russia's version of events. "It was the FA who proposed to us playing the match in the first place," said the executive director of the Russian Football Union, Alexander Tukhmanov. "We agreed right away and sent our confirmation, but then they changed their mind. We're disappointed how the English Football Asociation handled the whole thing."

And after the intrigue, the insult. "I can only think that they just didn't want to face a strong team before the Euro 2000 finals," Tukhmanov added.

It may appear slightly imperialist but it is standard FA practice to dangle before a variety of prospective opponents the carrot of a game against England. So it may be a simple case of Russia mistaking an inquiry for an invitation.

Certainly that is how the FA sees it. "We never confirmed the game to the Russians," said a spokesman, Adrian Bevington. "We were in contact with a number of countries as a normal course of practice. We then considered what options were available to us and went down the route of the Ukraine. It was the only deal ever agreed."

And as for allegations that England are running scared in choosing Ukraine, Bevington added: "Ukraine haven't qualified for the finals but they're very respected. I think they had the best record of the non-qualifying teams so they present exactly the challenge we're looking for."

 Meanwhile, only 14 weeks after a double fracture of the right leg, Celtic's Henrik Larsson is now counting the days to resuming his career with Celtic. His recovery has been described by medical experts as "little short of miraculous". The Sweden striker may even return in Celtic's under-21 side next week.

On Thursday the Swedish FA's medical team will fly to Glasgow to check his recovery, believing he has "more than an even chance"of playing in Euro 2000.

fields.headline: Brown defiant in Welsh deadlock
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and Gordon Brown's 11th hour refusal to blink over the Welsh budget crisis last night condemned their former cabinet colleagues, Alun Michael, to the near-certainty of defeat in a no confidence motion in Cardiff tomorrow.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and Gordon Brown's 11th hour refusal to blink over the Welsh budget crisis last night condemned their former cabinet colleagues, Alun Michael, to the near-certainty of defeat in a no confidence motion in Cardiff tomorrow.

As opposition parties in the Welsh Assembly combined to warn that there was no way back for Mr Michael, the embattled first secretary in Wales, the one hope of averting another devolution crisis lay in the possibility of a last minute deal with the Liberal Democrats.

The stage is now set for tomorrow's vote and a 31-28 defeat for Labour. Some Welsh politicians predict that Rhodri Morgan, narrowly defeated by Mr Michael for first secretary last year, will soon emerge in the post, possibly in a Lib-Lab coalition on the Edinburgh model. Four-party power-sharing has also been mooted.

Yesterday the Lib Dems' assembly leader, Mike German, went to London in the hope of seeing the chancellor to argue for the cast-iron guarantees Labour's critics have been seeking to underpin £1.2bn of EU funding for west Wales and the valleys.

But Mr Brown echoed Downing Street's accusation that Mr Michael is the victim of "silly games.

"The opposition have got their facts wrong," he told reporters and Mr Michael was right to say that his £8bn Welsh budget for 2000-2001 is adequately funded to match the first tranche of EU funds, promised over a six year period at the Berlin summit.

Plaid Cymru's acting leader Ieuan Wyn Jones said Plaid had repeatedly challenged Mr Blair since the assembly elections to make good his promise that he would not let Wales down. "We are seeing New Labour abandoning Wales with its patronising view of farmers and its refusal to acknowledge the rural crisis. "

Mr German, who could end up in an assembly cabinet, said his party is determined to make devolution work and is looking for four-party power-sharing for the benefit of Wales.

webTitle: Smoking as addictive as heroin, say doctors

fields.headline: Smoking as addictive as heroin, say doctors
fields.trailText: Nicotine is as addictive as heroin or cocaine and smokers should be seen as seriously dependent on drugs, according to a report published today.
fields.body:
Nicotine is as addictive as heroin or cocaine and smokers should be seen as seriously dependent on drugs, according to a report published today.

The Royal College of Physicians' tobacco advisory group called for cigarettes to be regulated like other drugs, either by the Medicines Control Agency or a nicotine regulatory authority.

Any such body could restrict the number of additives and amount of nicotine included in cigarettes.

Smokers who want to quit should be provided with nicotine replacement therapies such as gum and patches through the NHS, the report said. One person in four is a regular smoker, and only about 2% of those who try to give up succeed.

Manufacturers should also be banned from using the words "light" or "mild" on low tar cigarettes because the terms were misleading and simplistic. Cigarettes should be subject to emission controls in the same way as motor vehicles, the report added. Legal restrictions should be imposed on the harmful chemicals produced by cigarettes, including carbon monoxide.

The RCP also called for the establishment of an independent expert committee to examine the options for nicotine regulation and report its findings to health secretary Alan Milburn.

RCP president professor Sir George Alberti said: "At a time when smoking still causes one in every five deaths in Britain, measures designed to achieve further reductions in smoking are clearly important and, if successful, will realise substantial public health benefits. It is time for nicotine to become a major public health priority in Britain."

Health minister Yvette Cooper welcomed the report. The government has already launched a major anti-smoking initiative following publication last year of a white paper.

Billboard and television advertisements urging people to quit began in the New Year and the government has pledged to reduce the number of people who smoke from 28% in 1996 to 26% by 2005 and to 24% by 2010.

Clive Bates, director of the anti-smoking group ASH, said: "The RCP is saying that society should wake up and recognise it has a deadly and pervasive addictive drug syndrome covering a quarter of the adult population. We should stop pretending that cigarettes are just some innocuous or quirky lifestyle habit."

fields.headline: Pinochet campaigners win legal battle
fields.trailText: General Pinochet's opponents won a significant legal battle today when the high court said it would consider a case that may see the Chilean ex-dictator stand trial on torture charges.
fields.body:
General Pinochet's opponents won a significant legal battle today when the high court said it would consider a case that may see the Chilean ex-dictator stand trial on torture charges.

Three judges granted a request from six human rights groups and the Belgian government to seek a judicial review of the basis for home secretary Jack Straw's decision that Pinochet, 84, was medically unfit to be extradited to Spain.

The groups argued in court that while the medical reports remained secret they were unable to mount a meaningful challenge to Straw's decision.

"This is a victory for fundamental fairness, and for the rights of Pinochet's victims not to have their quest for justice terminated on the basis of secret evidence examined behind closed doors," said Reed Brody of New York-based human rights watch, which is involved in the court action.

"The plane can go back to the Bahamas," he added, referring to the Chilean jet that had flown to Britain to pick up Pinochet.

The judicial review means that whatever the outcome there could now be appeals up to the House of Lords, Britain's highest court. But there is still the possibility that matters could be cut short. If the reports are released it is possible that, having seen them, the human rights groups and the Belgians might agree that Pinochet is not fit to stand trial and may drop any extradition moves.

Spanish judge Baltasar Garzon, who secured Pinochet's arrest in London in October 1998, is seeking the general's extradition on torture charges dating from the latter part of his 1973-1990 rule of Chile. More than 3,000 people died or disappeared after Pinochet ousted socialist president Salvador Allende in a violent coup.

fields.headline: Section 28 - what the papers say
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText:
The Sun
A great victory for common sense has been won by the House of Lords.
fields.body:
The Sun
A great victory for common sense has been won by the House of Lords.

There wasn't a parent in the land who wanted to see the safety net of Clause 28 taken away. No one outside the pink lobby wants children to be taught that homosexuality is a natural foundation for family life.

Tolerance of gay private lives is one thing. Allowing schools to promote homosexuality is NOT on voters' agendas

Whoever persuaded a family man like Tony Blair that the law needed to be meddled with?

The Express

The very notion behind Section 28 - that it is possible to 'promote' homosexuality - is as ludicrous as it is bigoted..It is a vital sign of our maturity as a society that we scrap such foul prejudice from the statute book. The real purpose behind Section 28 is to say that, as a society, we regard homosexuals as poisonous and that instead of treating them as we ought any other human beings, we favour the legislative equivalent of spitting at them on the street. Those who voted against repeal deserve condemnation. Their behaviour shows that bigotry is alive, well and represented in Parliament in the 21st century.

Daily Mail

Ironically the unelected Lords have given a demonstration of democracy at its best. For they have responded to the clear wish of the majorityTo [the Lords'] enormous credit, they have shown that even the government's clumsy tinkering, and the influx of Tony Blair's placemen, has not lessened the Upper House's capacity for independent thought and action. Despite Labour's bid to emasculate them, the Lords have shown they are truly representative of the people. It would be outrageous if the 'people's government' rejected their wisdom.

fields.headline: Highlights of the Lords debate
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText:
The Bishop of Blackburn
Since 1988 the national curriculum for schools has been introduced and education Acts passed which have placed what we are concerned about firmly in the hands of the governing bodies of the schools. In a situation in which parental choice largely decides which schools flourish--at least numerically in pupil numbers--it seems hard to conceive of school governors pursuing a policy which promotes homosexuality. However, I hope that they will take every step to prevent bullying based on sexual orientation. In other words, whatever happens to section 28, the desire of the vast majority - the so-called "silent majority" - of parents and, indeed, of society at large for SRE to be based on heterosexual marriage as the norm will not be met. The confusion will remain.

The Bishop of Blackburn
Since 1988 the national curriculum for schools has been introduced and education Acts passed which have placed what we are concerned about firmly in the hands of the governing bodies of the schools. In a situation in which parental choice largely decides which schools flourish--at least numerically in pupil numbers--it seems hard to conceive of school governors pursuing a policy which promotes homosexuality. However, I hope that they will take every step to prevent bullying based on sexual orientation. In other words, whatever happens to section 28, the desire of the vast majority - the so-called "silent majority" - of parents and, indeed, of society at large for SRE to be based on heterosexual marriage as the norm will not be met. The confusion will remain.

However, I am well aware and, indeed, fully share the concern of those in this House and outside who say that, irrespective of the legal position under which our schools now operate, the government's desire and intention to repeal section 28 will send out signs and signals. As a Christian leader I believe that signs and signals are most important. The signs and signals in this case are that homosexual relationships have parity with heterosexual relationships and marriage, as understood and practised for generations as the Christian tradition has understood that.

Lord Whitty (junior minister at the department of the environment)
As the right reverend Prelate said, my right honourable friend the secretary of state for education, is currently engaged in very detailed discussions with the Churches and other faiths on this issue. However, I realise that that guidance may not be quite sufficient to reassure people. Therefore I would hope that the right reverend Prelate and others who support his amendment would recognise that some further discussions are needed on this. My right honourable friend the secretary of state for education stands ready to talk to the right reverend Prelate and other colleagues to take this further and to see what should be the balance between primary legislation and guidance in order to reassure people.

The central problem is that most of the concerns expressed relate to schools, whereas section 28 does not really apply to schools. We are here debating this in a local government bill context, whereas most of the issues relate to education. The issue of the repeal of section 28 ought, logically, to be separate from the safeguards that are in place to ensure that children receive appropriate sex and relationships education in schools. Unfortunately they have become enmeshed in the whole of this debate.

Lord Quirk
Of course, in a free society we should all be free to take risks with any activity that is legal, from smoking to bunjee jumping. Smoking is a good example, because with smoking no one is left in any doubt as to what is dangerous and why, and as to what are the risks.

So it is a puzzle to me, and I think to many outside this House, that issues of sexual health and sexual education are seriously neglected. One only has to contemplate our remarkable figures, a European record in this particular sport at least, on teenage, and indeed pre-teenage, pregnancies to feel that there is something grievously amiss with our health education and perhaps to wonder why our sex education has become so solidly fixated upon AIDS. AIDS is a terrible threat in all conscience, but one which needs to be put in the context of a broader, more balanced and more fundamental tackling of sex education.

Lord St John of Fawsley
It has been the consistent position of the universal Christian Church that all sexual acts outside marriage are wrong. There is no difference in that regard between heterosexual and homosexual acts. I subscribe to that tradition and it certainly rules out such fantasies as homosexual marriages in church.

It may seem harsh but that is the teaching of the Church. It is difficult because not everybody can, or desires to, live a celibate life. But those problems are best dealt with in the secrecy of the confessional or in private counselling and not in the glare of the public forum. I hope that whatever the result of this debate, it will not hinder those who are working in that field in bringing comfort to those who are in difficulty.

Lord Longford
My reaction to homosexuals is simple enough, and I speak as one who has promoted "homosexualism", if you like, among the gay lobby. Forty years ago, when I promoted the Wolfenden report - no one else would touch it - the late Lord Boothby referred to me as the unpaid leader of the homosexual lobby. That report was in favour of homosexuals not being prosecuted if they were over the age of 21.

Nevertheless, as the noble Lord has just said, homosexuality is against Christian rules, as is any sex outside marriage. Homosexuality can have terrible, tragic results. Whatever else it does, it deprives people of the supreme joy of marriage and children. Helping a young person to become a homosexual means that he will never be married and never have children. That is a terrible burden to inflict on a child, although it is no worse than the behaviour of a heterosexual man who has five mistresses. I do not say that one is worse than the other. They are both against the rules. They are both sinful.

Baroness Young
I have said publicly on many occasions that, like the right reverend Prelate the Bishop of Blackburn, I believe that marriage is best; that marriage is the right way to live.

The right reverend Prelate did not say this, but I believe also that there is no moral equivalence between homosexual and heterosexual relationships. As a teacher and a parent I feel that we need to set in front of children an ideal by which they should live. They may not live up to it; I do not live up to ideals either. But I have an idea of how I ought to live. That is what we should strive for. That is what we should put in front of children. To say to children that there are alternatives in life which are equally valid is not right. One needs to be careful what one says to vulnerable children growing up uncertain of the way. What one says to adults and what adults do is a completely different matter and the two points should not be confused.

Baroness Gould
It is unfortunate that what should have been a mature debate about a civilised society, recognising diversity and determining ways of eradicating discrimination, has, in some quarters, been conducted in a tone of hysteria that itself promotes homophobic views and encourages prejudices and harassment. The debate so far has generated more heat than light, at a time when light was what was required. What also appears to be clear from some of the press reports over the weekend is the fact that there are some people who do not want to see that light - who want to keep a restraint on local government, who ignore the need for equality and democracy, who have no desire to achieve equality of treatment for all young people and who do not want clarity for teachers and parents over what can and cannot be discussed. It is that clarity that we must have: the confusion has to be removed. I believe that the amendment brings us nearer to establishing the principles upon which that clarity can be achieved.

webTitle: Government to change tack on section 28

fields.headline: Government to change tack on section 28
fields.standfirst:
More about section 28
Highlights of last night's Lords debate
fields.trailText: The government is to consider new moves to change the law on homosexuality and sex education in schools after its attempts to repeal section 28 were defeated in the House of Lords last night.
fields.body:
The government is to consider new moves to change the law on homosexuality and sex education in schools after its attempts to repeal section 28 were defeated in the House of Lords last night.

An amendment, moved by Baroness Young and passed with a majority of 45, killed off moves to repeal the controversial clause which prohibits the 'promotion' of homosexuality.

The government will concentrate its efforts on replacing the clause with a new amendment which would legally oblige schools to promote marriage and families. It will also say that schools should not promote any kind of sexual activity or orientation among children, and must act against bullying based on sexuality. Homosexuality would not be specifically mentioned.

Ministers plan to table a new amendment in the Commons, where the government's majority would ensure it was passed. It would then return to the Lords, where - on the basis of last night's vote - only 23 peers would need to switch sides in order for it to get a majority.

The alternative would be to make the repeal of section 28 a separate bill, which could be forced through parliament despite the objections of peers. But such a move could take more than a year, forcing the issue into the sensitive pre-election period.

Peers voted by 210 to 165 last night to back Baroness Young's amendment after an impassioned debate in which she argued that there 'is not a moral equivalence between heterosexual and homosexual relationships' and that children should be set ideals by which they should live.

Lord Alli, the openly-gay Labour peer, said the debate was about 'the morality of hate'. He added: 'I believe that hate exists because we teach our children to hate.'

Education secretary David Blunkett and ministers in the Lords are now talking to religious leaders and moderate opponents of reform in the Lords to try to find a compromise formula.

The government claims that section 28 - introduced under Margaret Thatcher's administration - prevents teachers from acting against the bullying of gay pupils.

However, the move to repeal it has sparked vociferous opposition from church leaders and family groups, who argue it would undermine the family and lead to children receiving inappropriate information.

Local government minister Hilary Armstrong said today the government was "very disappointed" at the vote, but would press on with its plans.

The Lords' defeat of the government's plan to repeal a law banning local authorities from promoting homosexuality will not affect a similar repeal move in Scotland.

fields.headline: Not the people's paper
fields.standfirst:
David McKie on the power of the Daily Mail, section 28 and the 'forces of non-democracy' at work in Britain today
Plus: Reality check
fields.trailText: David McKie on the power of the Daily Mail, section 28 and the 'forces of non-democracy' at work in Britain today
fields.body:
"The Lords speak for democracy" says the headline on the Daily Mail's triumphant leader comment on the government defeat in the Lords last night, when peers rejected its attempt to repeal the law that's become known as section 28 on teaching on homosexuality in schools.

I think there maybe a misprint here. What happened last night had less to do with democracy than with its polluted cousin, DMocracy. Democracy means the power of the people; DMocracy means the power of the Daily Mail.

Votes in the Lords have nothing to do with democracy, with the power of the people, since the people have no say at all on who sits in the Lords.

Because of the deal which the government made with the then Tory leader in the Lords, Lord Cranborne and others, last year, a minority of hereditary peers still sit and vote in the Lords simply because of the beds they were born in. The rest are there because party political leaders chose to put them there as life peers. That has nothing to do with the power of the people either.

The recent report of the Wakeham commission means that if further changes are made - which they may not be for a good many years - the present "interim" chamber will be replaced by another in which members elected by the vote of the people will form only a small minority. That won't be the power of the people either.

That is why the rules say, and will continue to say, that the most the House of Lords can do is to impede and delay what an elected government wishes to do in its legislation. The forces of non-democracy are allowed to tell the forces of democracy that they'd like them to think again. They cannot except in very exceptional cases deny them their way for good.

DMocracy has little to do with any of that. DMocracy is the power of a successful, ruthless and brilliantly edited tabloid newspaper to try to impose its will on an elected government - especially when that government is formed by a party it does not support.

In particular, in our present political context, it means trying to whip up agitations against liberal reform and defend by all available means the bastions of rabid illiberalism.

This government lives in constant fear of DMocracy. That is why the chancellor's efforts at redistribution are rarely admitted in public: he has to do good by stealth in areas where the Mail is opposed to him.

Policies on Europe in general and the euro in particular have to be carefully tailored to avoid the kind of deluge of denigration from the Mail, the Sun and the rest which would wreck Tony Blair's chances of ever winning a referendum. And so on.

This has nothing to do with democracy either. It may well be true, as the Mail claims this morning, that the Lords in this case reflected the views of the "silent majority", though it isn't by any means clear if the "silent majority" felt so strongly about this subject before the ferment over section 28 was whipped up by Cardinal Winning in Scotland and after that by the Mail and its allies in England.

But the system of democracy we have chosen to use in this country is not designed to bow an obedient knee to any popular agitation which appears to have the support of the majority, silent or otherwise.

We have a parliamentary democracy. We choose MPs to represent us in parliament, from whom our governments are formed. They then have the right to arrive at the judgments which seem best to them, as this government and a majority of its supporters have done on section 28.

If we think they have got things wrong, we throw them out at the next election. No amount of spurious philosophising in the Tory tabloid newspapers about the people's will and the Lords as the people's voice makes any practical difference to that.

Reality check

Last week in this slot I noted that spin doctors were anxious to see the government's policies sympathetically aired in soap operas and were prodding scriptwriters accordingly. I imagined a scene in which one of the more sympathetic characters in the Archers spoke warmly of the speech Tony Blair was then due to make on the state of our agriculture.

So much for satire. The Archers that very night did exactly that, in exchanges between Pat and Tony Archer in which Pat was relentlessly upbeat about Blair's performance and told Tony off for being negative when he dared to mention the plight of the pig farmers.

And when Tony bemoaned the fate of the debt-ridden Grundy family, Pat responded by praising the government's plans for better labelling. Tune in tonight to hear Jolene's impassioned attack on the House of Lords for its saving of section 28.

webTitle: Contract talks, Initial bids and Inevitable speculation

fields.headline: Contract talks, Initial bids and Inevitable speculation
fields.trailText: PAINFUL CONTRACT-IONS
fields.body:
PAINFUL CONTRACT-IONS

Six months after locking himself in his bedroom, the Fiver can today exclusively reveal that Stanley Collymore has one foot poking out of the door and into the corridor at the top of the stairs. This is largely because his mum is grabbing hold of it and shouting, "Stanley, you are joining Leicester City, and that's the end of it." It is still, however, a most significant development.

The end of Stanley's six-month sulk had looked as far away as ever yesterday, Martin O'Neill claiming that a deal to take him to Leicester had foundered on Villa's demands for a fee. Today however, it has been reported in the local press (not all local press mind, just in Leicester) that an appearance-based fee of £500,000 has been agreed between the two clubs and that Stanley is now discussing terms with those Foxy Foxes.

So Foxy are they, in fact, that Stanley is not expected to be given a signing-on fee (he was demanding £1m from Fulham) and the terms of his contract will be performance related. This will presumably involve punishments for missing training, press conferences, six yard sitters and the like. Whether Stanley's mother will introduce a 'No pudding before you've finished your broccoli' clause however, remains to be seen.

RUMOURS UNLIMITED

Ronaldo set to become a Saint. Graham Taylor signs Zinedine Zidane. All the usual transfer nonsense from all the papers in one place - every morning at Football Unlimited.

HATS OFF TO DICK'S CASH

Dick Advocaat, manager of Rangers, was today given a large sack of money by club chairman David Murray. "Yoinks! Now for a feast!" cried Dick, before being informed that he wasn't allowed to spend it all on liquorice bowler hats and that he had to spend it on players instead. "I suppose I'd better make a bid for brilliant Ukrainian international striker Sergei Rebrov, then," harrumphed Advocaat.

Sergei (or Serhiy, as people who try to kid on they know how to spell things in Ukrainian would have it) looks likely to leave Dynamo Kiev at the end of the season, and has already been mentioned in the same breath as Arsenal, Chelsea, Barcelona, AC Milan and 12 million quid. But Rangers are the only club to have put in a concrete bid for him so far. "I'm not going to say at this time what we have offered for Rebrov," straight-batted Murray, "but the fact we have bid for him is a clear sign of our intent to build a better team."

The bid for Rebrov won't be the end of Advocaat's spending, either. "It seems everybody wants to talk about balance sheets and profits," continued Murray, "but all I'm interested in is the improvements we can make to Rangers Football Club." As Rangers already expect to add Sunderland's Allan Johnston, Paul Ritchie of Hearts and AZ Alkmaar defender Fernando Ricksen to their side, expect the Ibrox club to "improve" from 'first' to 'very first' next year.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"The important thing for us is that Gazza gets back to 100% fitness... we could do with somebody like him to have a presence on the field and get us going." - Don't you pity Bryan Robson sometimes?

JIMMY (AND MAN IN THE) MAC

The Fiver, fiddling with its patented Transfer-Logic-O-Matic machine, put in a few names and came up with this: George Graham leaves Leeds to join a club who could do with a striker like, say, Leeds' Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. Jimmy leaves Leeds the following summer, with both sides blaming each other, moves to Spain and scores loads of goals for Atletico Madrid, a club which can't pay his wages. Graham, who's spent the entire season moaning about the lack of quality strikers for sale, steps in, buys Jimmy for a knock-down fee and takes that long-awaited poacher to White Hart Lane.

It's such a load of far-fetched rubbish that the Fiver has since burned the Logic-O-Matic, renounced all cog-based machinery and abandoned plans to become the next Trevor Bayliss. But just look at what George had to say about Jimmy today. "I know all about Jimmy, about his strengths and what he can do," Graham told the Evening Standard, with small flecks of foam appearing at the corners of his mouth. "If he is available then he is the type of player we should be looking to bring to Tottenham."

Available is the key word. Money's a bit tight at the Estadio Vicente Calderon, with Atletico's one-of-a-kind president Jesus Gil undergoing investigations over alleged financial misdemeanours (including the invention of phantom transfers: "Yes, Mr Bank Manager, we did buy Dean Windass last week. Yes, £15m, that's right..."). Which means that Jimmy - who is owed £200,000 - could be an asset which is ready to be stripped. It could also mean that a strategically placed pay-per-view telly deal could keep him at the club. Whatever the developments, we're sure George will keep abreast of them.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Spanish international Luis Enrique, rumoured to be on his way out of Barcelona in the summer, watched Liverpool beat Leeds on Saturday. According to Teamtalk, he went to the Liverpool shop afterwards and bought a replica shirt.

Gianfranco Zola is a target for Fulham, reports the Daily Mail. His career with Chelsea looks like coming to a close, but he is happy in London and may consider dropping down a division.

Marc Overmars has hinted that he may leave Arsenal at the end of the season. "I don't want to lie and say I'll stay at the club until my career is over," the Dutch winger told the official Arsenal magazine.

Newcastle are the latest club to show an interest in Wimbledon keeper Neil Sullivan.

Chelsea will sign Ipswich keeper Richard Wright for £5m this summer, claims the Express.

Aston Villa's Benito Carbone may move to Fiorentina at the end of the season.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Wales will start their World Cup qualifying matches away to Belarus on September 2 or 3. Other fixtures: Wales v Norway (Oct 7); Poland v Wales (Oct 10 or 11); Armenia v Wales (Mar 24, 2001); Wales v Ukraine (Mar 28); Wales v Poland (Jun 2); Ukraine v Wales (Jun 6); Wales v Armenia (Sep 1); Norway v Wales (Sep 1); Wales v Belarus (Oct 6).

Leicester's Neil Lennon and Gerry Taggart have been excused from Northern Ireland's friendly against Luxembourg later this month to prepare for the Worthington Cup Final.

Stephen Glass, Newcastle's Scottish international midfielder, has handed in a transfer request. "I'm disappointed at the lack of first-team opportunities since Ruud Gullit left the club," said Glass.

Ipswich have signed Toulouse's 21-year-old midfielder Patrice Maurel on loan until the end of the season, according to the French second-division club's general manager Didier Couecou.

Fears that Southampton defender Patrick Colleter broke his leg in Saturday's win over West Ham at The Dell have proved unfounded. Colleter suffered heavy bruising on his right thigh and will miss the upcoming match at Sheffield Wednesday.

Charlton have pulled out of a £1m deal to sign 20-year-old Jamaican international Ricardo Fuller after failing to agree terms with the striker. Fuller scored five goals in three reserve games while on trial at the Valley.

Venezia have sacked coach Luciano Spalletti for the second time this season after the Venice club lost 5-0 to AS Roma on Sunday. Spalletti had initially been sacked by Venezia in November only to be reinstated just three matches later. Sunday's defeat, which left his club third bottom of Serie A, was only his ninth game in his second spell.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Football Extra (3.15am)

Including the one-goal thriller at Victoria Park.

Channel 4: Gazzetta Football Italia (1.25am)

So finally they've realised it's not on at midnight.

Sky Sports 1: Inside Scottish Football (6.30pm, 9pm, 11pm SS2, 1.15am)

This is on four times tonight. Celtic fans should camp under the sofa.

You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm, 2.15am)

If you were being constantly mocked by a US television presenter with a name like Lionel Bienvenu, things would have come to a pretty pass, wouldn't they? Well, according to Fiver reader Steven Feline, this is happening to none other than McCaff on Fox TV. Steven derives no pleasure from this, though: "Do I have to move to Tristan Da Cuna to escape him?"

British Eurosport: Football (10.15pm)

African Nations Cup quarter finals. And hopefully some adverts for isotonic bockwurst.

Sky One: Dream Team (6.30pm, 11pm)

Not a refuge for bit-part actors last seen supping ale in the Rovers Return. No, sir.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)

Featuring some Scottish Cup football. If Celtic can keep a lid on their stadium this time, of course.

webTitle: Nicotine addiction - what the report says

fields.headline: Nicotine addiction - what the report says
fields.trailText: • Nicotine addiction is comparable to heroin or cocaine addiction
fields.body:
 Nicotine addiction is comparable to heroin or cocaine addiction

 One in five deaths is caused by smoking

 Cigarettes should be regulated like other drugs by the Medicines Control Agency or a nicotine regulatory authority

 The number of additives and other ingredients in cigarettes should be controlled by such a body

 NHS should pay for nicotine replacement therapy, such as patches or gum, for smokers who want to give up

 The words 'light' and 'mild' should be banned from the packaging of low tar cigarettes because the terms are misleading and simplistic

 An independent expert committee should examine the options for nicotine regulation

fields.headline: Why hijack?
fields.standfirst: The possible motives examined
fields.trailText: • The most popular theory is that hijackers are trying to get the release of Ismail  Khan, nicknamed the Lion of Herat for his resistance to the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan in the early 80s. He was jailed  by the present Taliban regime after being betrayed by another  opposition commander.
fields.body:
 The most popular theory is that hijackers are trying to get the release of Ismail Khan, nicknamed the Lion of Herat for his resistance to the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan in the early 80s. He was jailed by the present Taliban regime after being betrayed by another opposition commander.

However, after 25 hours of negotiations, the only request made by hijackers so far is for food, water and medication. Essex assistant chief constable John Broughton, who has been briefing the press was adamant that no demands or threats have been made. He said: "Obviously I have to be careful about what I say here as I would not want to jeopardise anyone's safety, but at this time, they have not made any specific requests or demands that I am aware of." Meanwhile the Afghan opposition, the northern alliance, has disassociated itself from the hijacking, calling it an act of terrorism against innocent people.

 A conspiracy theory mooted in an online chat group is that the hijackers are working for the Taliban in an effort to discredit the opposition, the northern alliance. The Taliban has condemned the hijackers as terrorists and says it will not negotiate with them or accept any of their demands. A statement said the Taliban believed the hijackers were "closely connected" to the main opposition commander, Ahmed Shah Masoud.

 In Afghanistan itself, some relatives of the hostages have told the BBC World Service that this might be an opportunity for the passengers to get asylum and escape from a poor, devastated country in the grip of a hardline Islamist regime. According to this theory the pilots were in on the escape or even instigated the flight.

This would not be the first time that a plane has been hijacked as a desperate resort to escape a repressive regime. In August 1996, seven Iraqis seized a Sudan Airways Airbus A310 fleeing Saddam Hussein. The plane landed at Stansted. The hijack ended after eight hours of tense negotiations. The hijackers were jailed for at the Old Bailey for between five to nine years each but they were later cleared by the court of appeal in December 1998. Human rights campaigners hailed the appeal decision as a precedent for refugees fleeing brutal regimes. The court held that the judge at the men's trial had wrongly prevented the jury considering their defence that they acted under "duress of circumstances".

Delivering his ruling at the time, Lord Justice Rose said: "If Anne Frank had stolen a car to escape from Amsterdam and had been charged with theft, the tenets of English law would not have denied her the defence of duress of circumstances on the ground that she should have awaited the Gestapo's knock at the door."

fields.headline: A warning from Stansted
fields.standfirst:
The hijacking of the Afghanistan aircraft is a reminder that conflicts are exported as readily as arms

fields.trailText: For Afghanistan the Ariana hijack is a case of the biter bit, while for Britain it is a reminder that other peoples' troubles can at any time land on your doorstep.
fields.body:
For Afghanistan the Ariana hijack is a case of the biter bit, while for Britain it is a reminder that other peoples' troubles can at any time land on your doorstep.

The details of how and why the warring factions of the Hindu Kush brought their fight to Essex are inevitably misty, but the evidence suggests that the Christmas Eve hijacking to Kabul of an Indian Airlines plane by Kashmiri militants began the process.

The Taliban government did not urge the hijackers to unconditionally surrender and allowed them to flee after India agreed to release three prisoners. The Kabul authorities now find themselves in the same situation New Delhi was in then, with a hundred or so of their citizens held hostage in a foreign country, and facing demands they release a prominent opposition leader.

With an inconsistency they refuse to acknowledge, they have said they will not negotiate, and look to Britain to get them out of a mess which some would say they brought upon themselves. But, however the Stansted hijack ends, it will not be cost-free for Kabul, which must lose prestige, and at the least will learn that terror tactics can cut both ways.

Over the years since the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine seized an El Al plane in July, 1968 - the first hijack which involved taking passengers hostage - the tactics for dealing with such situations have evolved into something of a science, one at which Britain is supposedly adept. This may be one reason why the Ariana plane ended up in Stansted.

The other is that, if the hijackers are connected with Ahmad Shah Masood, the northern leader who has stood out against the Taliban, they presumably want western sympathy and would be more amenable to British negotiators than, say, to Russian ones. The approach at Stansted will be modelled on what has worked before, which is to negotiate endlessly but make no significant concessions, and be ready to storm the plane expertly if killing begins.

Such tactics do not always work. But they usually do, and, together with constant intelligence work, the now familiar array of security procedures at airports, and less visible ones on board, they have made hijackings less frequent and less lethal than they used to be.

There is also no direct equivalent today of the need to bring their grievances to the notice of the west which motivated Middle East hijackers years ago. But hijacking can still be an effective technique in regional struggles, and it has cropped up from time to time on the sub-continent, which includes its fair share of places which either encourage terrorism or are vulnerable to it, or both. They are what Professor Adrian Guelke, the author of a judicious study of terrorism, calls "black holes".

There is an especial cluster of such zones in the inner Asian lands. In south Asia, the unfinished war in Afghanistan and the troubles in Kashmir and the Punjab are tinder for proxy struggles between India and Pakistan waged by ruthless intelligence agencies and fought out by young men for whom violence has often been the only education.

Some may therefore see an Indian or Iranian hand in the Ariana hijack, which could be true. But there does not have to be an outside backer - the militants are not always well controlled by their patrons, and in any case have powerful beliefs, and plans of their own.

Do the increasingly fraught developments in inner Asia mean that the outside world is going to suffer more violent spillage, as the west did in the 70s? The answer is that a full scale repetition is unlikely. Western countries are not targets in the way they were before, while south Asian countries are now likely to take more precautions. It is possible that the Ariana hijack may end up as a deterrent for all involved.

But there are worse things than hijacks, and their absence in the future will not mean that all is well. The Pakistani journalist Ahmed Rashid, author of a new book on the Taliban, sees Afghanistan's disarray exercising a malign effect on a region wider than just south Asia, including Iran, Russia, and China, as well as Pakistan and India. He charges that the west, and the United States in particular, has done far too little to try to rescue a situation for which it bears much responsibility.

While Pakistan is also blameworthy, the fighters of Afghanistan were armed and encouraged by the west when it suited us. Helped by other states such as Saudi Arabia, they have exported their anger, courage and skills around the entire region. That has sharpened the Indo-Pakistani confrontation, with its new nuclear dimension, contributed to the disaster in Chechnya, almost started a border war between Afghanistan and Iran, and turned Afghanistan itself into a state which barely deserves the name.

The fact that legitimate aspirations to autonomy and independence are also involved makes these developments even more dangerous. What is legitimate and what is illegitimate both deserve the world's attention. Let the Ariana hijack end peacefully, if it can be managed, but let it also serve as a warning.

Taliban by Ahmed Rashid is published by IB Tauris

webTitle: 'Ladies and gentleman, there's a young man on board who has a gun pointed at my head'

fields.headline: 'Ladies and gentleman, there's a young man on board who has a gun pointed at my head'
fields.standfirst: In the wake of the hijacked Afghan aircraft landing at Stansted airport, Timothy Kinahan tells  Sally Weale  about his own 11-hour ordeal as a passenger on board a seized plane
fields.trailText: In the wake of the hijacked Afghan aircraft landing at Stansted airport, Timothy Kinahan tells  Sally Weale  about his own 11-hour ordeal as a passenger on board a seized plane
fields.body:
Few people have to live through a hijack drama. The closest most of us come is the television broadcasts and newspaper headlines. But just that word - hijack - is guaranteed to send a chill down the spine, whenever it happens, wherever it happens.

The consequences for those whose lives are caught up more intimately in these modern-day tales of terror can be grave - some die, others live with memories and fears that haunt them for years to come. Like Uli Derickson, the chief flight attendant on the TWA airliner which was hijacked in 1985 shortly after it left Athens for Rome. Derickson was among those held hostage for 17 days; she witnessed the murder of US navy diver, Robert Dean Stethem and, years later, was still undergoing psychotherapy.

By comparison, the hijack experience of the Reverend Timothy Kinahan, a protestant minister from Belfast, was - thankfully - relatively minor. It was seven years ago - almost to the day. It was scary at the time; then it became the stuff of dinner-party conversation - an anecdote to surprise and entertain. But still, more than most of us, he probably has a degree of insight into the fears of those victims of the latest hijack drama to hit the world's headlines.

In Kinahan's case, there were no shots fired, no passengers killed, no tricky demands for the release of political prisoners. But for 11 hours, he didn't know if he would live or die. He didn't know if he would ever see his wife and child again. His wife, suspecting she was pregnant with their second child, didn't know if she would ever have the opportunity to tell him the happy news.

Kinahan, 46, rector of St Dorothea's Church, was on his way to visit an orphanage in Ethiopia with three members of his congregation. They had boarded flight LH592, a Lufthansa Airbus, in Frankfurt and were bound for Addis Ababa via Cairo. About 45 minutes into the journey they noticed the plane bank steeply and seem to turn around, so that - Kinahan thought - passengers would get a particularly fine view of the Alps.

In fact, the aircraft had been commandeered by a 20-year-old Ethiopian hijacker, with a ski-mask over his face and gun in his hand. He took a flight attendant hostage and barged his way into the cockpit, where he put his pistol to the pilot's head and ordered him to change direction and fly to New York

The first the passengers knew about the drama was when an announcement was made first in German. Kinahan, a non-German speaker, listened uncomprehending but saw one of the flight attendants go pale. Then it was repeated, this time in English. "Ladies and gentlemen, there's a young gentleman on board who does not want to go to Cairo and he has a gun pointed at my head," the pilot told passengers.

"It was scary," Kinahan recalled yesterday. "We were stunned. There was no panic. There was no screaming, no abject terror. I can remember some tears in the beginning, but our anxiety was not for ourselves, but for those we would leave behind.

"We didn't talk very much for an hour. Then we began to relax quite a bit when nothing happened. There was a great mutual support. At least we did not have crazy gunmen running up and down the aisles threatening us."

The only time they saw the man who was to bring terror to the flight was as he was making his way to the toilet where he assembled the gun which had been smuggled aboard hidden in his hat. The 104 passengers were ordered to remain in their seats and stay calm. There were prayers and anxious moments during a refuelling stop at Hanover - someone in the aircraft had rigged up a listening device so he could hear negotiations as they happened and reported them on to fellow passengers.

"When negotiations were happening there was huge uncertainty sitting on the ground, surrounded by troops and telephoto lenses. The beginning, the first few hours, until we were happily out of Hanover and on our way to America, were the most anxious. We didn't know if we were going to Cuba or Moscow.

"Rumours were running wild as to who it was, we just didn't know the truth. But once we were in the air, we were all able to relax a bit. We were playing cards and scrabble."

After two or three hours of negotiations the Airbus took off and flew on to New York - there were more prayers on the approach to John F Kennedy airport. "We were told that if we stayed calm and did as we were told, nothing would happen. The crew were superb - extremely reassuring."

Once the plane touched down, the hijacker surrendered. There was enormous relief; cheers rang through the aircraft, there were hugs and kisses and tears, until a US SWAT team stormed the plane hunting for possible accomplices. The passengers were ordered to put their heads between their legs while each of them was checked for another half an hour. It was possibly the most terrifying time of the whole ordeal.

The hijacker Nebiu Demeke was sentenced to 20 years in prison, despite the discovery that his gun was nothing more dangerous than a starter pistol, capable of firing only blanks, and his unconditional surrender to the FBI at JFK airport.

His threats at the time had sounded real enough - at one point during the refuelling stop at Hanover he said he would kill one flight attendant every five minutes if his demands were not met.

"The captain was fantastic. He was the hero of the occasion," said Kinahan. (Pilot Gerhard Goebel, it later emerged, played a central role in resolving the crisis, managing to engage the hijacker's trust. He even promised to give him his sunglasses in return for the gun. And at the end of the drama they did the swap. The hijacker left his balaclava and a note saying thank you.)

It's an incident that Kinahan has chosen to put behind him. But when he hears of hijacks, there's a frisson of recognition. "There's a certain sort of 'Oh gosh, I've been there'. I feel for them. Particularly in this case given their long ordeal and here we have people with a political agenda which can be somewhat more uncertain."

It has not stopped Kinahan flying. After a glass of wine, a debriefing by the FBI and a stopover in a New York hotel, Kinahan and his colleagues flew directly on to Addis Ababa.

He continues to fly to Ethiopia every 18 months or so to pursue his charity work. He makes a couple of other flights every year. Having survived one hijack, does he ever worry about the risk of it happening again? Not really. He's a practical sort of man - he's been anxious during internal flights in Ethiopia, which at one time were targeted by hijackers rather more frequently than most other flights elsewhere. But otherwise no.

"Statistically it's freakish. The number of hijacks per flights is so infinitesimal. You have to put things behind you and put it down to experience."

fields.trailText: Thousands of passengers were stranded at Stansted airport yesterday after more than half the scheduled flights were cancelled or delayed. Airlines warned customers to expect more delays today.
fields.body:
Thousands of passengers were stranded at Stansted airport yesterday after more than half the scheduled flights were cancelled or delayed. Airlines warned customers to expect more delays today.

Up to 16,000 people travelling on more than 150 flights to and from Stansted faced delays and cancellations. The airport's managing director, John Stent, said a limited service was operating, using part of the runway unaffected by the security operation surrounding the hijacked plane, which landed at 2am.

The airport authorities, who handle some 400 flights daily, cancelled all flights until 7am, when a limited departure service began operating.

Many flights were transferred to nearby Luton and Cambridge airports because aircraft were too large to use the shortened runway in use for much of the day. Hundreds of passengers on internal flights were transferred to Heathrow to British Airways services.

About 2,000 passengers, unaware of the hijacking, arrived at Stansted for departures early yesterday.

Mr Stent advised passengers planning to travel today to contact their airline before leaving home.

The Stansted authorities confirmed that 30 aircraft were stranded on the ground waiting to leave yesterday, causing disruption to about 150 flights.

fields.headline: Jailed warlord who inspires loyalty
fields.standfirst:
More about the Stansted hijack

live ITN video feed from the hijacked aircraft
fields.trailText: Hostages released yesterday said the six young hijackers, armed with pistols and knives, are loyal to Ismail Khan, a leader of one of the many Afghan opposition factions who have fought against the Taliban.
fields.byline: Jason Burke  in Islamabad and  Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
Hostages released yesterday said the six young hijackers, armed with pistols and knives, are loyal to Ismail Khan, a leader of one of the many Afghan opposition factions who have fought against the Taliban.

One hostage released in Tashkent, who gave his name as Najib, said they were from Afghanistan's Tajik ethnic minority and spoke a dialect of Persian. Ismail Khan is Tajik and speaks Persian.

Khan, 58, has been in jail in Kandahar - the southern desert city which is the headquarters and spiritual home of the Taliban - since being betrayed by another opposition commander in 1997.

He is seriously ill and is held in harsh conditions. The Taliban have refused him medical attention in the past.

Hostage-taking is a traditional tactic in disputes in Afghanistan. "My feeling is that they are some of [Khan's] former troops who saw how successful the Indian [airlines] hijack was and thought they would have a go themselves," one former mujahideen commander, now based in Pakistan, said yesterday.

Khan is a veteran of the resistance war fought by the Afghans between 1979 and 1989. A former Afghan army officer - and conservative Muslim - he joined the mujahideen after Soviet and Afghan forces massacred an estimated 25,000 people in Herat, where he was based, during the first uprising against the then communist government in 1979.

He led a counterattack, recaptured the town and seized the local garrison's armoury.

Sometimes described as the Lion of Herat, he led a series of successful raids against Russian troops, including an attack on the Shindand air base in 1985, destroying more than 20 MiG planes.

"He [Khan] is an excellent commander who did very well against the Russians in the Jihad years," a spokesman for the Taliban in New York said yesterday.

In the years that followed the departure of the Soviets and the collapse of their puppet regime, Khan joined a mujahideen group, the Jamiat-e Islami resistance, establishing a fiefdom in the west of the Afghanistan.

Ismail Khan's rule was famous for its tolerance and stability. Most warlords at the time were known merely for their violence and rapacity. However, Khan was a popular leader who inspired strong loyalty in the men who fought for him.

He became a significant political figure in 1987 when he organised a conference of the disparate mujahideen factions to agree on the future structure of the country and demand the unconditional surrender of Russian forces.

After the defeat of the communist regime led by Najiballah in 1992 and the withdrawal of Soviet forces, Khan strengthened his position as unopposed warlord in the Herat region.

He was credited with beginning the post-war rebuilding process in the area and in 1994 held another "shura" or conference of mujahideen political and religious leaders to decide on the government of the country.

However, his political ambitions were thwarted by the emergence of the Talibans, created and developed by the ISI, the Pakistan intelligence service.

In September 1995 Khan's troops were unable to hold back the Taliban onslaught and Khan fled to Iran and thence - with Iranian backing, according to western diplomats - to opposition controlled areas in northern Afghanistan. It was from one of these enclaves that he was captured by the Taliban when he was betrayed by a fellow opposition commander.

Mullah Mohammed Omar, the cleric who leads the Taliban Islamic militia, yesterday blamed Ahmed Shah Massoud, the most powerful of the many opposition leaders in Afghanistan, for the hijacking . Massoud's spokesmen denied any involvement.

fields.headline: Calm and calculated approach that aims for peaceful solution
fields.standfirst:
More about the Stansted hijack

fields.trailText: If there was a manual for would-be international hijackers, the page referring to Britain would warn prospective hostage-takers that they should head elsewhere. Past experiences have shown that British negotiators have calmly controlled hostage situations and the fact that there is a designated London airport, Stansted, shows that the country is always prepared.
fields.body:
If there was a manual for would-be international hijackers, the page referring to Britain would warn prospective hostage-takers that they should head elsewhere. Past experiences have shown that British negotiators have calmly controlled hostage situations and the fact that there is a designated London airport, Stansted, shows that the country is always prepared.

Stansted receives hijacked aircraft because it is the smallest of the capital's three airports, it is relatively isolated and it can keep the hijacked plane well away from the main terminal building.

Airport authorities at Stansted and police have built up a team trained to deal with such situations. Essex police undertake regular exercises simulating hijacking situations.

The police negotiators leading the talks successfully ended another hostage drama at the airport in August 1996. Det Chief Insp Win Bernard, 45, led eight hours of tense talks by a team of six, to end the hijacking of a Sudan Airways Airbus 310 by seven Iraqis fleeing Saddam Hussain. Negotiating mainly with the captain of the airliner over a radio link from the control tower, he managed to ensure that all 186 passengers and 13 crew got off safely.

The six hijackers were jailed at the Old Bailey for between five and nine years each but they were later cleared by the Court of Appeal in December 1998.

Professor John Potter, a leadership lecturer at the University of Exeter with expertise in hostage negotiations, said: "Britain has a reputation for being able to deal with these situations with calm and expertise. Doubtless a lot of places will have been relieved to see the aircraft head for Stansted. Whether that was as a result of direct recommendation from the authorities in those countries visited by the aircraft or the desire of the hijackers themselves is unclear, but it is a reputation which Britain has to accept."

The assistant chief constable of Essex, John Broughton, explained: "It is not the United Kingdom's policy to let [hijacked] aircraft take off again once landed."

The representative of the Afghan government in Europe, Gen Rahmatulla Safi, told reporters at Stansted that the hijackers, who are critics of his government, had made a big mistake coming to Stansted.

"The hijackers were foolish to come to Britain because the forces that they are dealing with are absolutely professional. We are leaving it to the British authorities," he said. "The hijackers are so stupid. The forces that are dealing with the hijackers are the most well-known in the whole world. I am fully confident in the British official people that are involved. They are highly educated, their standards are high. I hope they will do as much as they can. They are very professional."

Yesterday's negotiations with the hijackers were begun in English until interpreters were brought in. Police tried to keep the situation as calm as possible, negotiating quickly for a generator to be brought on board for air conditioning to work in the plane and by mid-afternoon food was taken on for the hostages. The softly, softly approach reaped some reward with the release of five hostages at about 11.30am, four of them from the same family, and the release of another three at 2.40pm.

Professor Paul Rogers, a terrorism expert at the department for peace studies at the University of Bradford, said: "The key aim is to achieve calm, to reassure the hijackers that nothing dramatic is going to happen and persuade them that there is plenty of time to achieve a negotiated settlement to the situation."

Despite the likely presence of crack police and special forces squads at Stansted, the prospect of armed intervention would only arise when the lives of the passengers and crew were directly threatened.

Prof Rogers added: "Everybody thinks of the likes of the SAS becoming involved but the truth is that armed intervention almost never happens - it is very much the last resort when it comes to a resolution.

"That only happens when the hijackers are killing or are likely to kill."
