fields.headline: Yahoo swamped by hackers
fields.standfirst: Widespread concern about websites' vulnerability to hackers
fields.trailText: Yahoo, the world's most popular website, showed itself powerless to prevent computer hacking when cyber vandals rendered it inaccessible for three hours last night.
fields.body:
Yahoo, the world's most popular website, showed itself powerless to prevent computer hacking when cyber vandals rendered it inaccessible for three hours last night.

The internet directory, visited by 40.4 million people in December, was paralysed by hackers who sent a flood of electronic requests from around 50 computers to the site. The tactic, known in the industry as a "distributed denial of service attack", swamped Yahoo's servers with so much fake traffic that genuine visitors couldn't use its search engine and email services.

Industry experts were surprised that the massively protected site, worth around $93bn, could be penetrated by hackers. Elias Levy, of California-based security firm, SecurityFocus.Com, said: "It basically says nobody is safe, if Yahoo can be taken down with all the resources behind them."

Yahoo's president and chief operating officer Jeff Mallett reported that the hackers failed to break into Yahoo's internal computer network or gain access to any internal files or data - including private information about the millions of users who have Yahoo email accounts.

The site has never suffered an attack on such a scale before. Yahoo is rated as one of the most robust websites, accessible 99.3% of the time, according to web monitoring company Keynote Systems. Keynote reported that Yahoo was completely inaccessible within the United States but was 59 percent accessible internationally.

One of the few internet companies to be making a profit, Yahoo refused to reveal how many potential users it lost. Industry experts calculated that Yahoo could have missed out on many as 100 million page views at the cost of $500,000 in lost revenue from advertising and e-commerce.

The markets reacted calmly, with shares in the company closing at $354, up 50 cents, in Nasdaq trading on Monday.

Last year, the loss of service on online auction house eBay for 22 hours led to a costly upgrade of the site's technical infrastructure, which resulted in a 26% drop in the company's share price.

There is growing concern in America about the ease with which computer hackers can penetrate corporate and government computer systems. The FBI suffered a similar "denial of service" attack on its own website last April, which rendered its site inaccessible for several days.

Denial of service attacks are relatively simple to orchestrate, with hackers, often in their teens, downloading free hacking programmes from sites easily accessible across the internet.

The FBI's national infrastructure protection centre expressed anxiety "about the scale and significance of these reports". Weak-points in websites' structure were "widespread, well-known and readily accessible on most networked systems," it added.

The attack coincided with a San Jose conference meeting focused on denial of service attacks, sponsored by the North American Network Operators group. Russ Cooper, editor of NTBugTraq said: "I would assume that whoever did it was doing it to impress those people who were getting together to talk about them."

webTitle: Nutrition aids may pack a late punch

fields.headline: Nutrition aids may pack a late punch
fields.standfirst: Richardson rues ignoring warnings to stop taking supplements
fields.trailText: Richardson rues ignoring warnings to stop taking supplements.
fields.body:
Mark Richardson, the latest British athlete to test positive for the banned anabolic steroid nandrolone, last night admitted he had ignored advice to stop taking nutritional supplements.

David Moorcroft, the chief executive of UK Athletics, issued a warning last year, after the sprinter Dougie Walker's positive test for nandrolone, that athletes should stop taking the supplements. "With hindsight I wish I'd never taken any supplements," Richardson said. "I have not taken any since the results of my test and if I am cleared I wouldn't take them again. And I would advise any other athlete out there not to."

A report by UK Sport on the spate of nandrolone-positive tests concluded last month that "athletes should use these products with great caution, if at all".

Richardson says that in the two-hour period before giving his positive urine samples he had gulped down a concoction of supplements. They were acetyl-glutamine, designed to boost the immune system Promax-159, a protein-rich substance which he took as a liquid meal and Viper, an isotonic energy drink which replaces lost fluids after training.

"Every athlete takes supplements," said Europe's top 400 metres runner. "I followed all the guidelines and took all the precautions. Everything I took was approved by Dr Malcolm Brown, the British athletics medical officer, and I checked them against the list we were issued with by UK Sport.

"Yet I still find myself in a situation. If it can happen to me it can happen to anyone."

All three products were purchased from Maximuscle, the north London-based company which leads the British market in sports supplements. The company does market substances which contain drugs banned in sport but they are clearly labelled.

There is no evidence to suggest the products Richardson used contained anything illegal. However, like Walker, the hurdler Gary Cadogan and the boxer Jon Thaxton, Richardson appeared in the company's catalogue endorsing its products. All four now stand accused of taking nandrolone.

Zef Eisenberg, Maximuscle's managing director and the author of a book on anabolic steroids, has always denied his company's products were to blame. However, he has promised Richardson he will retest the products concerned to ensure they were not contaminated.

The market for nutritional supplements is largely unregulated but it is worth an estimated $3bn (pounds 1.9bn) worldwide. Sales of similar supplements in the United States increased by more than 1,000% during 1998-99 after the baseball player Mark McGwire admitted using a supplement that contained androstenedione, another banned bodybuilding substance.

Nandrolone continues to haunt athletics. Its presence in over-the-counter dietary supplements means it is difficult to know whether athletes are cheating. Many believe that the positives are indicative of mistaken use, that athletes have violated regulations unknowingly.

Don Catlin, the head of the drug-testing laboratory in Los Angeles, said athletes often did not realise what they were taking because ingredients were not always listed.

"As far as labelling goes it is free-for-all," he said. "Labelling doesn't always indicate what is in the capsules. Sometimes nothing. Sometimes with banned substances in it. It's a buyer-beware situation."

fields.headline: What is happening in Lebanon?
fields.trailText: Israel calls it a security zone, but to most of its inhabitants it is   occupied territory: a broad swathe of land controlled by foreign soldiers and   their client militia.
fields.body:
Israel calls it a security zone, but to most of its inhabitants it is occupied territory: a broad swathe of land controlled by foreign soldiers and their client militia.

South Lebanon has been a battleground in the wider Israeli-Arab conflict since the first Palestinian guerrilla bases were established there in the late 1960s. The savage Lebanese civil war of the 70s saw direct Israeli intervention, culminating in the invasion of 1978. Under intense international pressure, the Israelis consented to the deployment of a United Nations 'peacekeeping' force, UNIFIL, in South Lebanon. The multinational force is there to this day, at an annual cost now approaching £100m. It does valuable humanitarian work but has proved capable of little more than monitoring the conflict.

By the early 1980s the mostly Christian militia calling itself the South Lebanon Army (SLA), strongly reinforced by Israeli military 'advisers', had established control of the land south of the Litani river- roughly 10% of the country. In 1982 the Israelis invaded again, seizing the entire southern half of Lebanon, besieging and capturing Beirut, and forcing the expulsion of the Palestine Liberation Organisation.

After the 1982 invasion and its attendant horrors - notably the massacres in the Sabra and Chatila refugee camps - the southern occupation zone settled into a grisly pattern of guerrilla raids and Israeli retaliation. Although the PLO had gone, the struggle to 'liberate' the territory was taken over by locally based groups, including the Amal militia of Sunni Muslims and, more importantly, the Iranian backed Shi'ite fighters of Hezbollah.

In 1984 the leadership of the SLA passed from the crazed ex-Lebanese army major Sa'ad Haddad, to the more urbane but equally ruthless Antoine Lahad, who is still in charge. By that time the Israeli army was deeply entrenched in the 970 square kilometre enclave. There were frequent exchanges of fire; even more frequent landmine attacks against the Israeli army and the SLA, and regular revenge air and artillery strikes against alleged guerrilla strongpoints north of the occupation zone.

The Hezbollah tactic which particularly inflames Israeli opinion is the firing of Russian Katyusha rockets over the border into northern Israel itself. The frontier town of Kiryat Shmona is particularly vulnerable, and residents frequently spend their nights in deep bunkers. In 1994, after several salvoes of rockets landed in Kiryat Shmona, Israel launched a brutal counter offensive known as Operation Grapes of Wrath, which involved systematic shelling and air strikes of targets as far north as Beirut. It was called off only after Israeli artillery targeted a Fijian-garrisoned UNIFIL compound at Qana, killing more than 100 Lebanese civilians sheltering there.

Now the rockets and shells are flying again, and terrified civilians on each side of the border are once again in their bunkers. Last month the SLA second in command, Aqem Hashem was assassinated, and last week a 20-year-old Israeli soldier was killed. Ironically, the latest fighting comes as Israel prepares at last to abandon its ill-named 'security' zone. Prime Minister Ehud Barak promised in last year's election campaign to pull Israeli forces out of South Lebanon. The presence there of conscript soldiers, and the death of around 20 of them each year, is deeply unpopular with most Israelis.

Israel has hinted that the withdrawal may happen even earlier than Barak's deadline of July this year. Syria, which has a large military presence in Lebanon, will then be expected to guarantee the security of Israel's northern border.

That suggestion has put Damascus in a quandary. It does not want to be drawn into the wild lawlessness of a territory which has known no effective civilian government for 20 years. It certainly does not want to be seen as Israel's policeman, but it cannot afford to allow a power vacuum to develop on its own, as well as Israel's, borders. There is little likelihood, in the event of an Israeli pullback, of Hezbollah meekly laying down its arms, or of the SLA, which has some 2500 men under arms, submitting to the rough justice of the neighbours they have fought and brutalised for so long.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: • Actor Kevin Kline is set to make his debut as a feature director when he takes the reins of The Palace Thief for Fine Line Films later this year. Based on the novella by American writer Ethan Canin, it spins the Mr Chips-style study of a prep-school teacher re-assessing his life and making peace with his past. Neil Tolkin has adapted the script and Kline is expected to star as well as direct the project. "The reason Kevin's so perfect for (The Palace Thief) is that is has a classical vibe to it, which he has to," Fine Line president Mark Ordesky tells Variety, "but he brings such a modern sensibility to it."
fields.body:
 Actor Kevin Kline is set to make his debut as a feature director when he takes the reins of The Palace Thief for Fine Line Films later this year. Based on the novella by American writer Ethan Canin, it spins the Mr Chips-style study of a prep-school teacher re-assessing his life and making peace with his past. Neil Tolkin has adapted the script and Kline is expected to star as well as direct the project. "The reason Kevin's so perfect for (The Palace Thief) is that is has a classical vibe to it, which he has to," Fine Line president Mark Ordesky tells Variety, "but he brings such a modern sensibility to it."

 Sara Karloff, daughter of Frankenstein star Boris, is suing Universal Studios for $10m in unpaid royalties. Ms Karloff alleges that the studio has used her father's image on its promotional material and then cynically tweaked the images in order to avoid paying royalty fees. Boris Karloff, who rose to fame in Frankenstein, The Bride of Frankenstein and The Mummy, died in 1969. Sara Karloff is his sole surviving heir.

 Salman Rushdie's 11-year isolation at last looks to be drawing to a close. According to a report in Yahoo news, the author of The Satanic Verses is considering braving the Islamic fatwa - which was recently suspended by the Iranian government, albeit not lifted - to act in a movie. Rushdie, who has recently been negotiating with director Neil Jordan over an adaptation of his novel The Ground Beneath Her Feet, has been offered a supporting role in an as yet untitled vampire movie. "Maybe I'll do it, as long as I get to bite someone beautiful," the author is quoted as saying.

 Buoyed by the success of family film Stuart Little, Columbia Pictures are already planning a sequel. Stuart Little - an expert wild mouse tale that blends live action with CGI visuals - has already made $128.5m from domestic audiences since its release last Christmas and opens in the UK this July. The sequel may well be before the cameras by the summer, with a view to a Yuletide release in 2001.

fields.headline: In at the deep end
fields.standfirst: At 23, Clare Connor suddenly finds herself in charge of a struggling England team. But Tanya Aldred argues that if anyone can cope with the pressure, Connor can.
fields.trailText: When Clare Connor spoke to Wisden before the tour of Australia and New Zealand, she said she was thankful England had experienced a torrid time against India last summer, because "the winter tour will be really tough".
fields.body:
When Clare Connor spoke to Wisden before the tour of Australia and New Zealand, she said she was thankful England had experienced a torrid time against India last summer, because "the winter tour will be really tough".

"Really tough" now looks like an optimistic understatement. After a series of catastrophic results in Australia, Karen Smithies, who had been named England captain until next winter's World Cup, abruptly resigned. Connor, her deputy, suddenly found herself charged with the daunting task of resurrecting England for the five one-day internationals against New Zealand.

At 23, Connor is even younger than Smithies was when she took over the captaincy from Helen Plimmer. That was back in the days when ladies played in skirts. Now it's completely different, with a support structure that includes more money, better coaches, extra promotion. But all this brings increased pressure for results, at a time when England are going backwards. Smithies's appointment in 1993 was instantly followed by victory in the World Cup. fields.headline: Une amiti qui cote cher
fields.standfirst: What do French youngsters make of the allegations about secret financial deals between Mitterrand and Kohl?
fields.trailText: Secondary French
fields.body:
La nouvelle fait grand bruit: le groupe pétrolier français Elf-Aquitaine aurait versé plus de 100 millions de francs afin de financer la campagne électorale d'Helmut Kohl en 1994. Ce serait, d'après un proche collaborateur de François Mitterrand, l'ancien président français lui-même qui aurait demandé à Elf de faire ce geste envers un 'grand Européen'. L'amitié qui liait les deux hommes était bien connue mais cette affaire de financement occulte du CDU jette le discrédit sur un homme considéré au-dessus de tout soupçon. L'ex-chancelier allemand dément ce qu'il qualifie d' inventions pures et simples et de mensonges et assure que cette affirmation n'est rien d'autre qu' un appel au meurtre politique. Il certifie qu' il n'a jamais été question d'argent entre lui et François Mitterrand. Nous avons demandé à trois jeunes Français ce qu'ils pensaient de cette affaire et, plus généralement, comment ils percevaient les relations franco-allemandes.

Quels sentiments vous inspirent les révélations concernant l'aide apportée par F. Mitterrand à H. Kohl?

Virginie, 18 ans, lycéenne: En politique, le financement occulte de partis est monnaie courante. Mitterrand et Kohl étaient de vieux amis. Ils partageaient les mêmes convictions: pas étonnant que Mitterrand lui ait donné un coup de pouce de 100 millions pour qu'il reste au pouvoir!

Nadia, 19 ans, étudiante: Rien n'est sûr mais c'est louche! Pourtant, à l'époque, Kohl n'avait pas besoin de ça puisque les Allemands allaient certainement voter pour lui. On est tous tombés de haut car on le croyait irréprochable.

Mathias, 18 ans, lycéen: Ça ne m'étonne pas. Il y a tellement de magouilles en politique. Mitterrand et Kohl étaient unis comme les doigts de la main. Ensemble, ils ont fait de l'Europe ce qu'elle est aujourd'hui. Mitterrand avait tout intérêt à ce que Kohl reste en place.

Globalement, comment définiriez-vous les rapports franco-allemands ?

Virginie: Les relations économiques France/Allemagne ont toujours été bonnes. L'Allemagne, pendant longtemps, a tiré la France vers le haut. Depuis Chirac et Jospin, on parle moins de l'Allemagne et plus de l'Angleterre. Entre Français et Allemands en général, les relations sont plutôt bonnes, grâce aux échanges scolaires et jumelages, même si le nombre de Français parlant allemand diminue puisque tout le monde parle anglais!

Nadia: Je me sens plus proche des Anglais, même si, avec la crise de la vache folle et l'embargo, les relations diplomatiques de la France sont meilleures avec l'Allemagne qu'avec l'Angleterre.

Mathias: Très bons. En fait, l'amitié de Mitterrand et Kohl a permis aux deux pays de se rapprocher. L'Europe s'est en partie construite grâce à la France et à l'Allemagne. On ne peut pas dire que les Anglais aient fait beaucoup d'efforts de ce côté-là.

Comment percevez-vous les Allemands, avec leurs qualités et leurs défauts, par rapport aux Français ?

Virginie: En vacances en Tunisie, j'ai vu que les Allemands étaient sans-gêne, comme si tout leur était dû. Ils arrivent en terrain conquis! Ils sont souvent distants, réservés, et pas très raffinés, contrairement aux Français. Et qu'est-ce qu'ils picolent ! Néanmoins, ils sont plus ouverts aux nouveautés, en musique, par exemple. Ils ont organisé des fêtes telles que la techno parade et la love parade bien avant nous.

Nadia: En général, les Allemands sont riches et savent profiter de la vie. Ils adorent faire la fête avec un bon gueuleton de choucroute et saucisses. Ils ne sont pas sexy pour un sou!

Mathias: Je les vois stricts, rigoureux, bosseurs, écolos, et respectueux des autres. En général, ils sont sympas. Quand ils sont bourrés, ils ne deviennent pas agressifs et bagarreurs comme les Anglais.

Comment pensez-vous que les jeunes Allemands réagissent au souvenir de la Seconde Guerre Mondiale?

Virginie: On ne peut pas leur reprocher les fautes qui ont été commises par les générations précédentes. Ils sont gênés d'en parler car il faut toujours qu'ils justifient ce qui s'est passé. On n'oubliera jamais mais il ne faut pas leur jeter la pierre. D'ailleurs, en France, il y avait pas mal de collabos pendant la guerre, mais ça, on n'en parle jamais...

Nadia: Ils n'aiment pas en parler, le sujet reste tabou. Notre génération n'y pense plus vraiment mais celle de nos parents ou grands-parents, oui. On entend encore des gens les appeler 'les Boches', comme pendant la guerre. Fait inexplicable, des partis néo-nazis refont surface en Allemagne. Ils n'ont pas tiré les leçons de l'histoire?

Mathias: Ils ont honte et veulent donner une image positive et saine de leur pays et montrer que le passé est loin, qu'il faut tourner la page sans pour autant oublier. J'estime qu'ils n'y sont pour rien. C'est Hitler le responsable. Ça aurait pu arriver dans n'importe quel autre pays. Regardez ce qui s'est passé au Kosovo !

Glossaire/Glossary

ce sont des bosseurs they are hard workers
donner un coup de pouce à qqn/qch to help someone/ something
sans-gêne inconsiderate
faire un bon gueuleton to have a good blow-out
jeter le discrédit sur qqn to bring s.o. into disrepute
jeter la pierre à qqn to reproach someone
un jumelage (entre deux villes) twinning
c'est monnaie courante en politique it's common in politics
picoler (fam.) to booze
pas sexy pour un sou not in the least sexy
ils sont unis comme les doigts de la main they are very close

fields.headline: L'échec de la vertu allemande
fields.trailText: Beginners' French
fields.body:
L'Allemagne traverse, à l'heure actuelle, une passe difficile. L'un des proches collaborateurs de François Mitterrand, l'ancien président de la République Française, affirme que ce dernier a demandé au groupe pétrolier français Elf-Aquitaine de verser quelque 100 millions de francs au parti chrétien-démocrate (CDU) pour financer la campagne électorale d'Helmut Kohl en 1994.

L'ex-chancelier allemand, qui a été à la tête de l'Allemagne pendant près de 25 ans, nie les faits. Il affirme que ces accusations sont fausses et que François Mitterrand ne lui a jamais donné d'argent. Il dit que ces mensonges sont, en fait, un "appel au meurtre politique".

Cette allégation n'a pas été formellement prouvée mais d'autres révélations montrent que le CDU a bénéficié, à plusieurs reprises, de dons douteux et que certains membres du parti ont reçu des pots-de-vin. Les trois jeunes Français que nous avons interrogés à ce sujet ne semblent pas trop étonnés. Il faut dire qu'en France, les cas de financements occultes, et donc illégaux, de partis politiques sont nombreux.

Quand ils sont interrogés sur les rapports franco-allemands, les trois jeunes gens estiment que la France entretient de bonnes relations avec l'Allemagne, sur le plan économique, politique et social. François Mitterrand et Helmut Kohl, qui étaient de très bons amis, ont contribué à la réconciliation de leurs deux pays, autrefois en guerre.

D'ailleurs, les jeunes considèrent que c'est grce à ces deux personnages, et à leurs aspirations européennes communes, que l'Europe est devenue ce qu'elle est aujourd'hui.

Glossaire/Glossary

devenir to become
douteux dubious, questionable
entretenir des relations avec qqn to have dealings with someone, to be in touch with someone
être à la tête de to be at the head of
un mensonge a lie
un pot-de-vin a bribe
à plusieurs reprises on several occasions
traverser to go through

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: The papers are full of rumours. Fans of Liverpool, Spurs and Fulham may get excited, but it's a worrying day if you're an Arsenal supporter.
fields.trailText: The papers are full of rumours. Fans of Liverpool, Spurs and Fulham may get excited, but it's a worrying day if you're an Arsenal supporter.
fields.body:
Teamtalk Spanish international Luis Enrique, rumoured to be on his way out of Barcelona in the summer, watched Liverpool beat Leeds on Saturday. He went to the Liverpool shop afterwards and bought a replica shirt.

Daily Mail A cash crisis at Atletico Madrid could see Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink return to England for a reunion with George Graham. Hasselbaink, who is top scorer in Spain with 20 goals, is believed to be owed £200,000 by Atletico and has a clause in his contract allowing him to leave on a free transfer if he is not paid. Madrid may be prepared to cash in now, and Graham and his goal-shy Spurs are waiting. Graham is also believed to be interested in Atletico's Argentinian midfielder Santiago Solari.

Gianfranco Zola could be set for a move to Fulham in the summer. Zola's career at Chelsea appears to be coming to an end, but rumours suggest that the Italian is happy in London and may favour a move into the First Division.

Daily Star Marc Overmars has hinted that he may leave Arsenal at the end of the season. The Dutch winger, who has been linked with a move to Barcelona, told the official Arsenal magazine, "I don't want to lie and say I'll stay at the club until my career is over."

The Sun Bobby Robson wants Wimbledon keeper Neil Sullivan before the end of the season. Sullivan is available on a free transfer at the end of the campaign, but the Dons may be willing to sell him now.

The Express Chelsea will sign Ipswich keeper Richard Wright for £5m this summer. The deal has been thrashed out in advance and the clubs are finalising terms.

Aston Villa's Benito Carbone has held talks over a possible move to Fiorentina at the end of the season.

Wimbledon are poised to move for Belgian striker David Paas. Dons boss Egil Olsen has been told there is no money for new signings, but Paas, who plays for Harelbeke in the Belgian first division, would be available on loan until the end of the season.

The Mirror Graham Taylor wants to take Colin Hendry on loan from Rangers until the end of the season. The Scottish international defender is still out of the picture at Ibrox, and Taylor sees him as the solution to Watford's defensive problems.

fields.headline: The naked and the naughty
fields.standfirst: John Mills was the rock that the playboys of the acting world leaned on - and he photographed all of their rascally antics. A new book of family snaps captures their lives in intimate detail.  Fiachra Gibbons met him
fields.trailText: John Mills was the rock that the playboys of the acting world leaned on - and he photographed all of their rascally antics. A new book of family snaps captures their lives in intimate detail. Fiachra Gibbons met him
fields.body:
John Mills is not a man you associate with laddish behaviour. This, after all, is one of the great actors of the 20th century, a knight, a rock-solid family man, a good egg - and Hayley's dad to boot.

So it's a shock to discover what he once got up to with his Zippo. "I was quite famous for lighting farts," says Sir John, who will soon be 92. "You lie on your back with your legs in the air. One time at David Niven's when I clicked the lighter, the flame was like a Bunsen burner - a foot long and blue. Sensational. Niven laughed so much he had to be taken to hospital."

Mills did not limit such antics to frivolous showbiz soirées. During the shooting of Scott of the Antarctic - where the crew got frostbite - his gift was a lifesaver. "We were stuck on top of the Jungfrau and the weather closed in on us for four days." It looked pretty grim. "So I did a terrific one and it put the whole unit right. I'd had some grapes for lunch and they worked a treat."

We would have been none the wiser about this had Mills's son Jonathan not uncovered an amazing hoard of 10,000 transparencies under the water tank in the star's attic. They are, like Mills himself, a national treasure.

Johnnie Mills knew everybody in film and theatre, and photographed them all at play. The images are collected in a remarkable book called Still Memories, laced with his wise, warm, sometimes wickedly gossipy captions. His eyes are fading now - he has to feel his way around his front room in the Buckinghamshire village of Denham - but Mills was blind to nothing in his heyday.

They are all there: Flynn and Fairbanks; Noel Coward - Mills's fairy godfather; Olivier wiggling his bare bottom on a balcony in the south of France; and "sexy" Rex Harrison being roguish with a statue in his backyard in Beverly Hills. In between there's steady Jack Hawkins, dear Dickie Attenborough, Trevor Howard and Stewart "Jimmy" Granger, who could be "tricky" with the ladies.

Mills's enduringly happy marriage to the writer Mary Hayley Bell was the rock of normality around which the stars orbited. Mary, Johnnie and their Leica were fixtures at premieres and house parties where partners changed as often as hairstyles. There were often tears before bedtime and the Millses could always be relied on to do the decent thing.

Take this despatch from the Italian Riviera in 1948. "Jimmy Granger fell in love with Jean Simmons, which ended his marriage to Elspeth March. In the spring we drove to Portofino with them but, after a week, Jimmy became his usual tricky self and we had to leave with Jean in the back, sobbing all the way home."

Or a similarly terse caption to a photo of "Me, Rex and girlfriend" in Hollywood the previous year: "There was usually a scandal in the news, and while we were there one of Rex's ex-girlfriends committed suicide. It was never made clear why, but it was quite a story at the time."

Mills and Niven were big buddies too. Niven had shared a flat with Errol Flynn and, while he could never compete with Flynn's famous hands-free piano technique, some things rubbed off. "What I remember most about Niven's house in Beverly Hills was the pool's changing room. On the men's side he had this see-through mirror. We spent quite a lot of time in there, depending on the female guests of the day, of course_"

Olivier, though, was his real chum. "The funniest man I ever met, and I've met some funny ones." Once at Niven's place at Cap Ferrat, near Monaco, Prince Rainier and Grace Kelly came calling as Olivier emerged from the sea sans swimming trunks. "Rainier and the Princess were standing right in front of him so he just bowed gracefully. Perhaps his best entrance ever."

Mills - who, with touching modesty, still regards himself as a song-and-dance man who got lucky - was one of the few people to whom Olivier was close. It was he Olivier called backstage before his legendary Richard III at the Old Vic in 1944 to confide his fears "that 'I'm in for a fucking awful flop'_ and then we went out and sat in the stalls and it was like watching the ghost of Edmund Kean."

Every now and then, Johnnie and Mary and their talented brood would catch a meteor as it rose or fell. Like the night Montgomery Clift came to tea. Mill's eldest daughter Juliet, then 16 and starstruck by the Leonardo DiCaprio of his time, was besides herself. "Monty loved to drink and we were trying to be keep the cocktails away, but he was already well primed before he arrived," says Mills. "He was chatting away about acting when he suddenly got up off the settee, climbed up the back, dived head-first onto the floor and stunned himself. We gave him a glass of cold water and a wash and he became quite normal again. So there we were, conversation again flourishing, Monty sitting by the fireplace chatting to Juliet, when he stood up and toppled into the fire..."

Life changed for the Millses after Mary wrote Whistle Down the Wind. Dickie Attenborough and Bryan Forbes filmed it and it turned Hayley, their second daughter, into a star. From then on, they worked as a family unit, with Mills sacrificing his own career to protect his children.

Mills has a wonderful, conspiratorial smile. He was not cast as Puck in his school play for nothing. His stare alone holds the camera in focus, just as he held audiences rapt in Great Expectations, Hobson's Choice and Ryan's Daughter. Eighty-two years later there's still something of the woodland sprite about him, a twinkle in his sightless, shockingly blue eyes. He's off to Barbados in the morning.

"Sometimes I can't believe my life," says Mills. "But it's not the film or the theatre I'm most proud of - it's them." He points to photographs of the dynasty lining the piano that he can no longer really see. There's Juliet, Hayley, Jonathan and the second generation of actors and pop stars led by Crispian Mills.

"Have you heard Kula Shaker?" he asks. "They're rather good, aren't they?"

 Still Memories is published by Hutchinson, price £20.
fields.bodyText: John Mills is not a man you associate with laddish behaviour. This, after all, is one of the great actors of the 20th century, a knight, a rock-solid family man, a good egg - and Hayley's dad to boot. So it's a shock to discover what he once got up to with his Zippo. "I was quite famous for lighting farts," says Sir John, who will soon be 92. "You lie on your back with your legs in the air. One time at David Niven's when I clicked the lighter, the flame was like a Bunsen burner - a foot long and blue. Sensational. Niven laughed so much he had to be taken to hospital." Mills did not limit such antics to frivolous showbiz soirées. During the shooting of Scott of the Antarctic - where the crew got frostbite - his gift was a lifesaver. "We were stuck on top of the Jungfrau and the weather closed in on us for four days." It looked pretty grim. "So I did a terrific one and it put the whole unit right. I'd had some grapes for lunch and they worked a treat." We would have been none the wiser about this had Mills's son Jonathan not uncovered an amazing hoard of 10,000 transparencies under the water tank in the star's attic. They are, like Mills himself, a national treasure. Johnnie Mills knew everybody in film and theatre, and photographed them all at play. The images are collected in a remarkable book called Still Memories, laced with his wise, warm, sometimes wickedly gossipy captions. His eyes are fading now - he has to feel his way around his front room in the Buckinghamshire village of Denham - but Mills was blind to nothing in his heyday. They are all there: Flynn and Fairbanks; Noel Coward - Mills's fairy godfather; Olivier wiggling his bare bottom on a balcony in the south of France; and "sexy" Rex Harrison being roguish with a statue in his backyard in Beverly Hills. In between there's steady Jack Hawkins, dear Dickie Attenborough, Trevor Howard and Stewart "Jimmy" Granger, who could be "tricky" with the ladies. Mills's enduringly happy marriage to the writer Mary Hayley Bell was the rock of normality around which the stars orbited. Mary, Johnnie and their Leica were fixtures at premieres and house parties where partners changed as often as hairstyles. There were often tears before bedtime and the Millses could always be relied on to do the decent thing. Take this despatch from the Italian Riviera in 1948. "Jimmy Granger fell in love with Jean Simmons, which ended his marriage to Elspeth March. In the spring we drove to Portofino with them but, after a week, Jimmy became his usual tricky self and we had to leave with Jean in the back, sobbing all the way home." Or a similarly terse caption to a photo of "Me, Rex and girlfriend" in Hollywood the previous year: "There was usually a scandal in the news, and while we were there one of Rex's ex-girlfriends committed suicide. It was never made clear why, but it was quite a story at the time." Mills and Niven were big buddies too. Niven had shared a flat with Errol Flynn and, while he could never compete with Flynn's famous hands-free piano technique, some things rubbed off. "What I remember most about Niven's house in Beverly Hills was the pool's changing room. On the men's side he had this see-through mirror. We spent quite a lot of time in there, depending on the female guests of the day, of course_" Olivier, though, was his real chum. "The funniest man I ever met, and I've met some funny ones." It was he Olivier called backstage before his legendary Richard III at the Old Vic in 1944 to confide his fears "that 'I'm in for a fucking awful flop'_ and then we went out and sat in the stalls and it was like watching the ghost of Edmund Kean." Every now and then, Johnnie and Mary and their talented brood would catch a meteor as it rose or fell. Like the night Montgomery Clift came to tea. Mill's eldest daughter Juliet, then 16 and starstruck by the Leonardo DiCaprio of his time, was besides herself. fields.headline: Catfka for kids
fields.standfirst: When Nicholas awakes  one morning after troubled dreams, he finds himself turned into a cat... Satoshi Kitamara's Me And My Cat? is a colourful take on metamorphosis
fields.trailText: When Nicholas awakes one morning after troubled dreams, he finds himself turned into a cat... Satoshi Kitamara's Me And My Cat? is a colourful take on metamorphosis
fields.body:
Me and My Cat?

By Satoshi Kitamura

Published by Andersen Press

Price £9.99

Age 3+

"Late one night an old lady in a pointed hat came in through the bedroom window..."

It's a fabulous beginning (don't miss it; it comes before the title page) to a tale of a boy and his cat who are magicked into changing places. The resulting chaos is related both in words and pictures; the story is wonderfully quirky, and has a beautifully unexpected ending.

Role reversal is given a whole new treatment, and as well as being extremely funny there is also a real appreciation of the feelings of a mother whose son suddenly thinks the radiator is irresistible and who is potty about the cat's toilet. It's a great book to share with your favourite child (and cat); not only is it delightful to read aloud, but there's so much to look at in the pictures that bedtime may get very late indeed.

Oh - there's a lovely detail for the grown-ups. Check out the pictures on the walls of Nicholas's house. FUN!

fields.headline: Saatchi plans new Hammer horrors
fields.trailText: Hollywood tried to drive a stake through its heart with ghouls like Freddie Kruger, but last night fresh blood brought Hammer Films crawling out of its coffin.
fields.body:
Hollywood tried to drive a stake through its heart with ghouls like Freddie Kruger, but last night fresh blood brought Hammer Films crawling out of its coffin.

A consortium led by the advertising executive Charles Saatchi - a man whose fondness for gore has made the artist Damien Hirst a rich man - yesterday bought the fading film company famous for its cheapo vampire flicks.

With their creaky sets, creakier scripts, and incomparably creepy stars in Ingrid Pitt and Christopher Lee, Hammer Horrors were as much a part of late 1960s Britain as mini skirts.

Saatchi and two high-profile partners - music mogul Rob Dickins, and Neil Mendoza of Forward Publishing - have plans for at least one TV series, and remakes of classic Hammer movies such as The Curse of Frankenstein and the Quatermass Xperiment.

Saatchi and his partners hope to cash in on the revival of teen horror genre through the blockbusting films of Wes Craven, the "caliph of cringe", and the huge worldwide success of the low-budget Blair Witch Project.

The Hammer studios have had a long, lingering near-death, with Saatchi involved in one previous failed revival bid. An American company recently tried to use the name for a series about a couple of vegetarian vampires, Mr And Mrs Dracula.

Hammer Films was the most successful film company in the history of British cinema. With its emphasis on sex, blood and gore in vivid colour, Hammer was laughed at by the critics but lapped up by the public. It was a phenomonen in America, where it hooked a generation of children weaned on the Munsters and eager for something more gothic.

Between its inception in 1935 and 1983, when its last production, the Hammer House of Mystery and Suspense series, was shown, Hammer filmed more than 250 movies and TV programmes.

Director Tim Burton recently confessed that he made his latest film, Sleepy Hollow, in Britain in part as a homage to the Hammer genre.

"Most of the formative moments of my childhood were spent in front of the TV watching Hammer Horror double bills," he said.

Raquel Welch made her movie debut in the Hammer sci-fi movie, One Million Years BC, in which she was called on to grunt in 100 different ways. Joanna Lumley was also a Hammer girl, dying horribly in the Satanic Rites of Dracula.

Hammer chief executive Terry Ilott said: "We've got TV series in discussion with more than one broadcaster, and we've been approached by US producers about a number of possible remakes."

He revealed that among those being considered for roles were the definitive Dracula, Christopher Lee - now starring in BBC's Gormenghast - and Ingrid Pitt, the star of Vampire Lovers.

He said the Hammer name might also be used in computer games. "We've been in negotiation properly for this deal since last year," he said. "Since we started, horror has definitely become the flavour of the month, with so many things happening, from the Blair Witch Project to Sleepy Hollow."

With their creaky sets, creakier scripts, and incomparably creepy stars in Ingrid Pitt and Christopher Lee, Hammer Horrors were as much a part of late 1960s Britain as mini skirts. Saatchi and two high-profile partners - music mogul Rob Dickins, and Neil Mendoza of Forward Publishing - have plans for at least one TV series, and remakes of classic Hammer movies such as The Curse of Frankenstein and the Quatermass Xperiment. Saatchi and his partners hope to cash in on the revival of teen horror genre through the blockbusting films of Wes Craven, the "caliph of cringe", and the huge worldwide success of the low-budget Blair Witch Project. The Hammer studios have had a long, lingering near-death, with Saatchi involved in one previous failed revival bid. An American company recently tried to use the name for a series about a couple of vegetarian vampires, Mr And Mrs Dracula. Hammer Films was the most successful film company in the history of British cinema. With its emphasis on sex, blood and gore in vivid colour, Hammer was laughed at by the critics but lapped up by the public. It was a phenomonen in America, where it hooked a generation of children weaned on the Munsters and eager for something more gothic. Between its inception in 1935 and 1983, when its last production, the Hammer House of Mystery and Suspense series, was shown, Hammer filmed more than 250 movies and TV programmes. Director Tim Burton recently confessed that he made his latest film, Sleepy Hollow, in Britain in part as a homage to the Hammer genre. "Most of the formative moments of my childhood were spent in front of the TV watching Hammer Horror double bills," he said. Raquel Welch made her movie debut in the Hammer sci-fi movie, One Million Years BC, in which she was called on to grunt in 100 different ways. Joanna Lumley was also a Hammer girl, dying horribly in the Satanic Rites of Dracula. Hammer chief executive Terry Ilott said: "We've got TV series in discussion with more than one broadcaster, and we've been approached by US producers about a number of possible remakes." He revealed that among those being considered for roles were the definitive Dracula, Christopher Lee - now starring in BBC's Gormenghast - and Ingrid Pitt, the star of Vampire Lovers. He said the Hammer name might also be used in computer games. "We've been in negotiation properly for this deal since last year," he said. "Since we started, horror has definitely become the flavour of the month, with so many things happening, from the Blair Witch Project to Sleepy Hollow."

webTitle: Hollywood takes over at Berlin film festival

fields.headline: Hollywood takes over at Berlin film festival
fields.trailText: Hollywood talent looks set to swamp home-grown European hopes at this year's Berlin film festival, as the celebrity line-up was confirmed last night.
fields.body:
Hollywood talent looks set to swamp home-grown European hopes at this year's Berlin film festival, as the celebrity line-up was confirmed last night.

The guest list runs like a veritable Who's Who of Tinseltown players, with Robert De Niro, Al Pacino, Denzel Washington, Matt Damon, Gwyneth Paltrow, Mel Gibson, Tom Cruise and Leonardo DiCaprio all jostling for the limelight. Europe, meanwhile, will be represented by Jeanne Moreau, Gallic rocker Johnny Hallyday and The Beach's British production team of Danny Boyle, Andrew Macdonald and John Hodge.

Six American-backed pictures - including Anthony Minghella's The Talented Mr Ripley and Paul Thomas Anderson's Magnolia - are in contention for the prestigious Golden Bear award for best film, to be decided by a jury headed by the actress Gong Li. This year's festival will also present honorary lifetime achievement awards to De Niro, Moreau and the Japanese director Kon Ichikawa.

 The 50th Berlin film festival begins tomorrow and wraps with a final presentation ceremony on February 20.

fields.headline: Hanks snaps up crime story
fields.trailText: Tom Hanks has moved with shark-like speed to snap up the movie rights to a true-crimes article that hit the news-stands only yesterday. The article, titled A Cold Case, traces a dogged New York DA's 30-year investigation of the murder of a Manhattan restaurant owner. Written by staffer Paul Gourevitch, it is published in the February 14 issue of the New Yorker magazine.
fields.body:
Tom Hanks has moved with shark-like speed to snap up the movie rights to a true-crimes article that hit the news-stands only yesterday. The article, titled A Cold Case, traces a dogged New York DA's 30-year investigation of the murder of a Manhattan restaurant owner. Written by staffer Paul Gourevitch, it is published in the February 14 issue of the New Yorker magazine.

Hanks has acquired the rights to the story in association with his production company Playtone, which he set up with partner Gary Goetzman at the end of 1997, as a first-look spin-off from the actor's regular deal with Universal Studios. According to Variety, Hanks outbid two other studios and won the rights for A Cold Case with a hefty six-figure sum.

Paul Gourevitch won critical plaudits for his book on the Rwandan crisis, We Wish to Inform You That Tomorrow You Will Be Killed With Our Families, two years ago, but the New Yorker article is the first piece of journalism that the writer has sold to Hollywood. Hanks is expected to produce the picture and star as the tale's investigator hero.

fields.headline: Spielberg has a kidney removed
fields.trailText: The film director Steven Spielberg has had a kidney removed after doctors discovered an "irregularity" during a routine medical examination - but, as befits the master of special effects, he slipped in and out of hospital before Hollywood was any the wiser.
fields.body:
The film director Steven Spielberg has had a kidney removed after doctors discovered an "irregularity" during a routine medical examination - but, as befits the master of special effects, he slipped in and out of hospital before Hollywood was any the wiser.

A spokesman for Spielberg said yesterday that the operation had been a complete success and the director was making a good recovery following surgery in the Cedars-Sinai medical centre in Los Angeles.

Spielberg, who is 52, is recuperating from the operation at his home while working on scripts. His spokesman said that the prognosis was for a full recovery.

Spielberg, the Oscar-winning director of such films as Schindler's List, Saving Private Ryan and Jaws, is due to receive the lifetime achievement award from the Director's Guild of America in Los Angeles next month.

The director, who is married to the actress Kate Capshaw, set up his own studio, DreamWorks SKG, with Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen in 1994. He is a regarded as the man with the golden touch and hundreds of jobs depend on his good health.

An Iranian born man named Anoushirvan Fakhran has been arrested three times by police in Fairfax, Virginia, for impersonating a "Jonathan Taylor Spielberg", a supposed nephew of the film director, and could be deported if convicted of a felony charge.

fields.headline: England wants 10-yard rule for dissent
fields.trailText: The Football Association is to press Fifa to introduce a rule allowing referees to move a free-kick forward 10 yards to punish players who dispute a decision or kick the ball away.
fields.body:
The Football Association is to press Fifa to introduce a rule allowing referees to move a free-kick forward 10 yards to punish players who dispute a decision or kick the ball away.

The rule, which has long been applied successfully in both codes of rugby, has been on trial in Jersey for 18 months and has been adopted in the Auto Windscreens Shield this season. The FA will now ask Fifa, at a meeting of its lawmaking international board this month, for it to be incorporated officially in the rules.

Failing that, the FA is so keen on the idea - not least after the scenes at Old Trafford 10 days ago when Manchester United players vainly but intimidatingly harangued the referee Andy d'Urso after he awarded a penalty to Middlesbrough - that it will volunteer to extend the trials more widely next season.

"In our view it has been a complete success and it is now a question of whether the board will change the law worldwide," said David Davies, the FA's executive director. "We have been behind this change all the way. Our information is that it has improved the level of sportsmanship."

The United players were admonished even by their manager Sir Alex Ferguson as well as being more widely condemned.

Charlie Tostevin, senior FA vice-president in Jersey, endorsing the success of the experiment there, said: "It's absolutely superb. Support has been almost unanimous from referees, players and club officials." It commands such respect - or fear - that the rule is enforced no more than once in six games, he said.

"Imagine what damage the likes of David Beckham could do if free-kicks were being moved 10 yards nearer your goal," Tostevin added - except that Beckham is more than likely the one arguing.

webTitle: Ministers suffer heavy defeat on Section 28

fields.headline: Ministers suffer heavy defeat on Section 28
fields.standfirst:
Ministers suffer heavy defeat on Section 28

Section 28 explained
fields.trailText: The government last night suffered a heavy defeat in the Lords over plans to reverse laws banning local authorities from promoting homosexuality, despite its attempts to push a compromise obliging schools to promote marriage as the "fundamental building block of society".
fields.body:
The government last night suffered a heavy defeat in the Lords over plans to reverse laws banning local authorities from promoting homosexuality, despite its attempts to push a compromise obliging schools to promote marriage as the "fundamental building block of society".

An amendment tabled by the former Conservative leader of the Lords, Baroness Young, to retain the controversial section 28 was passed by 210 votes to 165, a majority of 45.

A handful of Labour peers also rebelled against a government whip to oppose plans in the local government bill for repeal of the clause, which have already set Downing Street on collision course with church leaders and family campaigners.

Following committee stage confrontation, ministers will now seek to replace bald proposals for the scrapping of the clause with a compromise measure designed to reassure those who fear that the removal of a law barring "promotion" of homosexuality will inevitably lead to "proseltysation" over gay lifestyles.

They hope to build on a defusing amendment proposed yesterday by the Bishop of Blackburn, the Rt Rev Alan Chesters, which would place a legal duty on schools to promote marriage in sex education lessons.

The amendment, later withdrawn by the bishop but supported by many Labour and Liberal Democrat peers and by local government minister Lord Whitty during the debate, also underlines the right of pupils to grow up free from physical or verbal bullying over sexual orientation, and from pressure to have sex. The mainstream gay and lesbian campaign group Stonewall last night made clear it could live with such a change.

Though it was not put to the vote, ministers believe it could win over some who opposed repeal of section 28 last night.

The amendment also chimes closely with the underlying principles of government guidance on sex education, disclosed yesterday by the education and employment secretary David Blunkett.

Teachers would have no role in promoting any sexual orientation, Mr Blunkett said. The guidance, to be published before Easter, would set out that "pupils should be taught about the importance of marriage, family life, love and stable relationships in bringing up children".

The bishop's amendment says that "marriage should be promoted as the fundamental building block of society and of family life and as the proper context for the nurture of children".

Many Labour peers, however, last night supported the scrapping of section 28. Lord Alli, the only openly gay peer, accused supporters of the clause of having the same "morality of hate" as the bomber who blew up a gay pub in Soho, central London.

"If you want to know how such evil exists in society, it's because we teach our children to hate," he said.

Lady Young, who last week unveiled a collection of material she claimed was "propaganda" used by local authorities and health authorities to "promote" homosexuality, argued that there was no moral equivalence between homosexual and heterosexual relationships.

She told peers: "To say to children there are alternatives in life which are equally valid is not right and one needs to be very careful what one says to vulnerable children, growing up, uncertain of the way."

Lady Young said she supported the Bishop of Blackburn's aim in promoting marriage, but his amendment failed to prevent councils from promoting homosexual relationships.

The bishop withdrew his committee stage amendment after Lord Whitty said the government would debate the issues with the church before the bill's report stage.

Lord Whitty said: "Society as a whole does include the gay community, whether you approve of their behaviour or not. It does include an awful lot of people who depart from the ideal of marriage.

"The law has an obligation to treat adults equally and to treat children fairly so that they understand this complicated world. I believe the way forward is to engage in a wider discussion and decide whether we can put a form of words on the statute book."

fields.headline: 'Bolshie' governor of open prison suspended
fields.standfirst: Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: The governor of Sudbury prison has been suspended and a disciplinary investigation ordered into his behaviour, the prison service announced last night.
fields.body:
The governor of Sudbury prison has been suspended and a disciplinary investigation ordered into his behaviour, the prison service announced last night.

The dramatic move is thought to have been taken after the governor, Nigel Salter, repeatedly clashed with a senior prison service manager over the running of his jail.

Mr Salter, whose open prison in Derbyshire has been highly praised, has been suspended, it is believed, because he was "too bolshie" in his attitude towards his temporary area manager, Ian Lockwood, over a series of minor but important issues about the running of the jail.

Prison service sources put the dispute down to a personality clash lasting many years.

The suspension of prison governors is extremely rare. They have one of the few occupations left in the public sector which commands a large degree of autonomy, going back to Victorian times.

But they have seen that independence eroded over the last 10 years as the prison service headquarters has gradually asserted a much stronger central managerial influence.

The suspension of Mr Salter is the first since Michael Howard and Derek Lewis clashed over the then home secretary's decision to suspend the governor of Parkhurst high-security prison after the breakout there in the early 1990s.

The prison service last night confirmed that Mr Salter had been suspended last Friday pending a disciplinary investigation but emphasised that it did not involve matters of a criminal nature.

A deputy governor has taken over the day to day running of the prison.

It is believed that the clash between Mr Salter and Mr Lockwood covered a series of management and personnel issues at the prison, which holds 500 inmates, including 63 serving life terms. Some 75% of the inmates at Sudbury are serving time for drug related or violent offences.

Matters came to a head over Mr Salter's plans for the temporary release of inmates over Christmas. He wanted to interpret the rules to get the prison roll down as low as possible. But Mr Lockwood told him that he had interpreted the rules too liberally and instructed him to the change the policy.

Mr Salter is believed to have obeyed the area manager, but not without an argument.

After a series of such incidents, Mr Lockwood complained to the prison service deputy director-general, Phil Wheatley who ordered an investigation under the internal code of discipline.

None of the incidents is believed to individually involve a breach of prison service regulations but their cumulative effect appears to have sparked a clash between the two men.

It is believed that an official complaint was made which alleged that the accumulation of incidents amounted to a series of question marks against Mr Salter's professional judgment as a governor.

It is the first time that matters of judgment have been the subject of a disciplinary investigation in the prison service.

But the decision to suspend Mr Salter is still something of a mystery.

Only last week the prisons minister, Paul Boateng, threatened to use such unprecedented action against governors of "failing prisons" but it is widely recognised that the Sudbury governor has done a very good job since he arrived there in 1992.

Sir David Ramsbotham, the chief inspector of prisons, published a glowing inspection report in 1998 and said that Sudbury was "a thriving establishment carrying out good work with prisoners".

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.trailText: Eating disorders | Winslet no Jones
fields.body:
How utterly depressing to discover that some male reporters covering the Shipman trial bought ties bearing a syringe and tourniquet design from an entrepreneurial colleague for the sum of £11.

Hidden so as not to prejudice the case, the ties came out when Shipman was found guilty according to the Daily Telegraph. So when we read those reports of how Shipman systematically murdered 15 of his women patients little did we know that some of their authors had one hand on their notebook and the other in their pockets fumbling with their sartorial "joke".

 On the subject of eating disorders is it any wonder that Kate Winslet passed up the chance to play Bridget Jones in the film adaptation of Helen Fielding's best-seller? We may identify with some of Jones' anxieties but who would actually want to be her?

 Poor old Mick Jagger. According to the News of the World, he has to pay for sex these days. The paper says his recent honky tonk with Brazilian model Luciana Morad cost him £10m. And NoW calculates that "even if his night of passion with Luciana went on for five hours . . . it still cost him £555 a second." Mick's money is not going to a prostitute, however, but the mother of his child. Under US law Morad was entitled to £25.5m. The rocker agreed to pay the model an out-of-court settlement towards the upkeep and education of their son Lucas. Has no one told him a packet of condoms is a lot cheaper?

 With so many issue-based "weeks" around it's hard to take those issues seriously. However, to mark world eating disorder week therapists will be available 24 hours to talk to sufferers of various conditions from 8am this Saturday until 8pm the following Saturday. For advice and information, ring the Centre for Eating Disorders national helpline on 0181-959 2330.

webTitle: Industry in a spin: what makes a best-selling soundtrack?

fields.headline: Industry in a spin: what makes a best-selling soundtrack?
fields.trailText: The Beach is likely to make as much of an impact on the music charts as the box office charts. Boyd Farrow unravels the synergy of film and soundtrack
fields.body:
In a few weeks' time a song called Pure Shores by All Saints will be blaring out from every in-store DJ booth, car stereo and pub jukebox. Every person who owns two lips will be humming the tune as they work, rest and aerobicise. And when Pure Shores is eventually knocked off its number one spot it will probably be replaced by the soon-to-be equally ubiquitous Voices by Dario G, featuring Vanessa Quinones. You see, both these songs feature on the soundtrack of The Beach, a movie that looks set to make more of an impact on the music charts than the box office charts.

These days it's as important for a movie to have a hit soundtrack as it is to have, well, Leonardo DiCaprio in the starring role. And the creative team behind The Beach know this better than most. After all, they made Trainspotting, a movie that got Middle America mainlining on Leftfield and Underworld and put the careers of Lou Reed and Iggy Pop, not to mention Blur, back on track.

Of course, Leo comes to the party with an proven track record himself: Baz Lurhmann's Romeo + Juliet gave Des'ree her finest moment with "Kissing You" while Titanic boasted the far more dubious distinction of turning skeletal Canadian warbler Celine Dion into a Streisand for the '90s.

Soundtracks are one of the most powerful marketing tools available to movie producers - think The Bodyguard, Pretty Woman and Dirty Dancing - and there is an almost forensic attention to detail when selecting individual tracks. Sometimes it is the film's director who obsesses about the music featured (stand up Martin Scorsese and Quentin Tarantino) sometimes the movies themselves inspire the soundtrack, such as in the case of The Full Monty, but far more often it is a corporate decision. After all, the movie soundtrack is a booming industry in its own right and the multimedia titans that own film studios also own record companies. Madonna enjoyed a number one hit, not to mention a career boost, with Beautiful Stranger, from Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me. Seldom was a song more ironically titled: Austin Powers was produced by New Line Cinema, part of the AOL Time Warner empire which also bankrolls her own record label Maverick.

Equally ironic is the fact that Trainspotting was financed by PolyGram Filmed Entertainment - which, until it was folded into Universal, was part of the world's biggest record company. Yet the Trainspotting soundtrack was provided by PolyGram's then rival EMI. This embarrassing lack of synergy occurred when PolyGram rejected the offer to put out the soundtrack for Shallow Grave (the Trainspotting production team's previous film) and so EMI jumped in. As a reward for its support, EMI was given worldwide rights to the Trainspotting soundtrack - which grossed nearly £10m worldwide and even spawned a sequel to the soundtrack.

In a way EMI is even set to benefit from the soundtrack of The Beach. Since the film's backer, 20th Century Fox, is the only Hollywood studio that doesn't own a record label, The Beach's soundtrack has been licensed to WEA/SIRE, part of AOL Time Warner. Last month AOL Time Warner agreed to buy EMI.

So what makes a best-selling soundtrack? As far as the music/movie giants are concerned, the ideal spin-off album is the one that reaches out to the broadest possible audience. This is why the soundtrack to the Austin Powers sequel embraced Burt Bacharach crooning with Elvis Costello as well as Lenny Kravitz singing American Woman, for Californian teens, and Mel G reinterpreting Word Up for teens everywhere else. And it's why Wayne's World blended acts such as Black Sabbath and Eric Clapton with Red Hot Chili Peppers and Rhino Bucket. And why the Romeo + Juliet soundtrack included Stina Nordenstam and the Butthole Surfers.

It also explains why the Notting Hill soundtrack, which ran the gamut from the Spencer Davis Group to Boyzone, sold almost 400,000 copies in the UK in 1999, making it last year's biggest-selling soundtrack album. The shrewdly compiled soundtrack leapt ahead of the marginally less eclectic ones for Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, Austin Powers and The Matrix, which featured the parentally challenging Prodigy and Marilyn Manson.

But while getting fun young mums and trendy dads to buy movie soundtracks is part of the script, movies are a good way of introducing younger audiences to record companies' back catalogues. Ideally, every teen movie should feature a song originally made famous by a rock dinosaur sung by a group so fresh that even www.cd.com hasn't heard of them. Clueless, the first movie to give literature a high-school makeover featured The Muffs' version of Kids in America and World Party singing All the Young Dudes. Last year's teen smash 10 Things I Hate About You featured the group Letter To Cleo singing Cheap Trick's I Want You To Want Me.

But even hip movies need to ensure they get maximum media exposure: cue the telegenic All Saints. And rubbing up next to hipness certainly won't hurt All Saints. The gals' own movie, Honest, directed by Dave Stewart, is released later this year after which the group will have a whole soundtrack as well as a movie to promote. Pure synergy.

fields.headline: Young, gifted and very rich
fields.standfirst: Once, ambitious undergraduates spent their time amassing work experience and polishing their CVs. Now you're an underachiever if you haven't launched a successful business before sitting your finals. As a fund backing student start-ups becomes the latest stock market sensation,  Emma Brockes meets the new campus entrepreneurs
fields.trailText: Once, ambitious undergraduates spent their time amassing work experience and polishing their CVs. Now you're an underachiever if you haven't launched a successful business before sitting your finals. As a fund backing student start-ups becomes the latest stock market sensation, Emma Brockes meets the new campus entrepreneurs
fields.body:
In June 1997, a rumour went round Oxford that the budget for one of the big college's summer balls was a quarter of a million pounds. To anyone not involved, the idea that a committee of students, whose business experience turned on selling mugs through Young Enterprise and balancing tabs at the bar, could be put in charge of a such a major sum was hilarious. In February 2000, there is a rumour going round about two first-year students who are poised to float their online revision service on the stock market next month for a figure 10 times the ball budget. This time, however, nobody is laughing.

The small but growing number of students setting up companies from their college bedrooms is beginning to make the activities of the ball committee look like Fisher Price finance. There can scarcely be an undergraduate alive who has not been grinding their teeth over the fortunes of Student-Net.co.uk, the online service founded by four finalists at Nottingham Trent university that attracted a £10m investment from a US firm of venture capitalists last month.

Hardly a day seems to go by without a report of some new bright spark making his first million before passing his A levels. CyberBritain.com, the fastest growing online network in Europe, has a 17-year-old chief executive. And last week, Oxygen, a firm of financiers set up to fund student business ideas, was valued on its first day of trading at a mind-boggling £240m, more than double the annual turnover of Nottingham Trent university.

This is more than another breathless chapter in the saga of the e-commerce boom; it marks a very real shift in the culture of student life, where not long ago even the most ambitious undergraduate was content to chisel the perfect CV out of captaining a university club, doing work experience at Goldman Sachs and honing his self-importance in the union debating chamber.

"When I was at college, ambitious students saw university as a time to burnish their CVs by being president of the debating society, and so on," says John McLaren, the 48-year-old non-executive director of Groupe Chez Gerard, which owns a string of restaurants across Britain. "Then, the key skill for a student was to position yourself at the moment of graduation so that you got an A-stream job where you could move up a monolithic system." McLaren did this by getting a summer job at a demolition company and embroidering it with the same canny self-promotion as his fellow students.

Today, it seems, you are an also ran if you haven't made your first million by the time you graduate. "In the current economic climate, when the cost of education has risen substantially, everybody who goes to university views it as an investment in themselves," says Alan Edmondson, 22, one of the founding members of Student-net, a sort of web version of the student union handbook. He and the other three - Peter Atalla, the 21-year-old who came up with the idea, Michael Haycock, 23, and John Woodcock, 22 - are among the first generation of students who have had to pay for their degrees and it has had a galvanising effect on their productivity. "Students in America have long had to work their way through college, which teaches them a certain business discipline," says McLaren, and so it is now in Britain.

With the help of the £10m capital injection from IMPG, a Nevada-based venture capitalist, the four Student-net founders have opened two offices in Nottingham, two in London and are taking on 15 new people over the next fortnight. Edmondson's attitude towards his staff is revealing. "Since we've started employing people ourselves, we've realised how valuable we are in the marketplace," he says. "I interviewed someone today who was a law graduate with a 2:1 and a masters in business, but he didn't have a clue."

Edmondson's casual self-assurance comes from an industry in which there is no received wisdom to accumulate and no rites of passage to slog through; this is a gold-rush panic in which youth is valued above experience. "It wasn't seriously possible to start a business when I was at college," says McLaren. "Without computers and the internet, what could you do apart from a glorified paper round? And where would you go for funding, because the bank sure as hell wouldn't lend a student the money."

Step forward Oxygen, or rather, Emma Edelson, the 26-year-old daughter of Michael Edelson, the Manchester United director with whom she set up the company to specialise in financing student projects. Members of the board include PR executive Matthew Freud and Keith Harris, former chief executive of HSBC Investment Bank. From an initial investment of £1m in five start-up companies, it floated on the stock exchange last Friday for £240m. "It isn't a case of students thinking, oh my god, I've got all this studying to do and my business to set up," says Edelson. "It generally grows out of having fun and spotting a gap in the market."

Since starting six months ago, Oxygen has received more than 100 business plans, half of them from students. Some package their ideas professionally, others ignore the protocols and pitch themselves, shakily, over the phone: both are acceptable. "The problem for students with business ideas has always been that unless you have a business plan and partnership agreements, you will not be taken seriously," says Edelson. "You don't have the time or knowledge to find out how everything works."

The difference in today's climate, is that students with no practical experience in running a business, will still be courted for the value of their unrefined ideas. "There is a shake-up in people's attitude to age generally," says McLaren. "The fact that they have seen 23-year-olds successfully run internet companies, has shown how little age should be a determinant in giving people responsibility."

Benjamin Cohen is 17. When he was 13, he was diagnosed with ME and was forced to spend long periods of time confined to his home in north London. "I hadn't been into the internet much before that, but I started using it as a way of keeping in touch with the world. I realised how powerful it was for reaching people at low cost."

Cohen, like a lot of teenage programmers, began idly constructing a website around his interests. With a £150 loan from his father, he bought the domain name JewishNet.co.uk and when he stumbled across the email address for the chairman of the Durlacher Corporation, a colleague of his father's and the financial backer behind the hugely successful Soccernet, Cohen secretly sent him a précis of the site. Durlacher phoned the boy's father and advised him to broker a deal. In eight weeks time, JewishNet will be floated on the Alternative Investment Market and Ben Cohen will start revising for his A levels.

The manner in which Cohen came to be the chairman of two sizeable companies (the other being CyberBritain.com, a rudimentary search engine that is none the less growing faster than any other online network) at 17 years old, is typical of a student business ethic that views work as the natural extension of recreation. "A lot of the ideas that come in have been conceived at the pub over a drink," says Edelson.

'Now that the whole concept of a monolithic career is starting to go, what matters more is personal networks," says McLaren. The combination of youth and success isn't new, of course, but it has been more common in acting or writing, areas that tolerate a certain amount of precocious immaturity. For the student entrepreneurs, however, there can be no allowances made for youthful caprice. Shareholders require a level of constancy that it is hard to imagine a first-year student putting up with. "The thought of having all this potential money on our shoulders puts us under huge pressure," says Rose. "Once the venture capitalists have invested, they're going to want to see something more than just Jordan and me running the company."

Rose and Mayo are having an untypical first year at university. Rose, studying politics, philosophy and economics at Oxford's Lady Margaret Hall, is woken by the phone each morning at 9am. He goes to lectures during the day, writes business plans at night, and spends one day a week, usually a Thursday, in London with Mayo - who is reading economics and management at Hertford College. On March 20, during the Easter holidays, the pair plan to launch their on-line revision service, revise.it, built out of the proceeds from the sale of their last company. On a typical day in London, they will attend their first meeting at 10am and have subsequent meetings - with fundraisers, advertisers and marketing managers - every hour until 7pm.

"Our general self-confidence has helped and we have motivated each other," says Rose. "But there are loads of young people who have cool, creative ideas. The only difference is that our idea came at a time when we had the summer after A levels to work on it."

There is more to it than luck, however. Two years ago, translating a student business idea into a bona fide company would have been almost impossible, as Robert Jenkins found to his cost. When he was a second year economist at Jesus College, Cambridge, he had an idea. The 19-year-old was already a seasoned entrepreneur, having speculated his student loan on the stock market and made enough money to fund his degree. But when he made a tentative pitch to City financiers, he was laughed out of the room. "I approached a few venture capitalists and they wouldn't really open the door to a student. I didn't know how to present a business plan or anything."

Jenkins retreated, licking his wounds, and after graduation worked for Deutsche Bank for nine months until he had gained the right skills to resubmit his idea - an investment web service he is wary of detailing before the launch. At 22, he has been taken on by Oxygen and is preparing to launch yellowturtle.com in March with a business partner who is still at university. "If I had been able to launch this service three years ago, it would have blown everything else away," he says regretfully. "It is still a solid idea, but back then it was revolutionary. You have to do this things when you think of them, because in a year or two, they won't be competitive."

"There is a certain window of time for these entrepreneurs to make their mark," says Emma Edelson. "The capital valuations are crazy and I'm pretty sure the bubble will burst."

Getting in quick has its disadvantages. Apart from trying to juggle management meetings with Descartes essays, Rose has been the target of some snide comments in the college laundry room. "Someone said, 'oh, I don't think internet millionaires did their own washing.' We're having to cut down significantly on social life, but hopefully when we get backing, we'll be able to bring in a manager."

"Certain members of staff didn't take it particularly pleasantly that the boss was 17 years old," says Cohen. His diffidence triggers a rare concession to the fact that he isn't 45. "I'm having to make decisions that I don't really want to." Like what, exactly? "Like, how many desks we should have and what colour the walls should be. Sometimes I think it's pressure I don't really need."
