webTitle: Haider minister asked to sup with the EU

fields.headline: Haider minister asked to sup with the EU
fields.standfirst:
Business resumes at all-union level

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Austria's new social affairs minister - a member of Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party - has been invited to a European Union meeting in Lisbon this week, it was confirmed last night.
fields.body:
Austria's new social affairs minister - a member of Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party - has been invited to a European Union meeting in Lisbon this week, it was confirmed last night.

Signalling that the EU is now going to play by the book in dealing with a member government that includes the controversial party, Portugal - holder of the union's rotating presidency - announced that Elisabeth Sickl, the minister, would be asked to Lisbon.

But a three-day visit to Vienna by Portugal's president, Jorge Sampaio, early next month was postponed indefinitely "because of the situation in Austria and in accordance with the European Union's position".

The informal Lisbon meeting on Friday was seen as a test of whether multilateral EU business would be affected after Austria's 14 partners froze bilateral contacts with Vienna in response to the Freedom party's inclusion in the coalition government.

Limited sanctions now in force include refusing to back Austrian officials running for posts in international organisations and downgrading contacts with Austrian ambassadors in EU capitals.

Until last night, no one was certain that normal EU activity could go ahead, especially since informal meetings such as the forthcoming Lisbon gathering occupy a grey area, with ministers attending by invitation of the presidency.

Some EU member states, including Belgium, had raised the idea of not inviting Austrian ministers to informal meetings, but a majority of the 14 appear to believe that a clear distinction must be maintained between bilateral and EU business.

Chris Patten, the EU's external affairs commissioner, alluded to some of the difficulties when he said last night: "What's happened in Austria in the last few days has been difficult for a number of member states, partly because of their historic memories and partly because of their nervousness about the consequences for their own political development of irresponsible populism.

"So it's understandable that member states have acted as they have. But the European Union is an organisation of rules and laws and treaties, and we in the [European] commission act as the guardian ... of that legal framework."

Britain, meanwhile, angrily denied that it shared any political common ground with Mr Haider and said it backed European efforts to isolate the new government in Vienna.

"There is absolutely nothing in common between Mr Haider and Tony Blair," insisted the foreign office minister for Europe, Keith Vaz. "Not in a thousand years is there going to be anything in common between the two gentlemen, or the programmes of his party and the Labour party."

Mr Vaz was responding to weekend comments in which the Freedom party leader said Britain had been "more moderate" than its EU partners in responding to Austria's new government.

The silence of British ministers for several days gave the impression that the government was less than happy with the bilateral sanctions, which followed an impassioned appeal to Mr Blair from the Austria's head of state, President Thomas Klestil. For London, it would have been politically impossible to refuse to participate in the show of protest.

fields.bodyText: Austria's new social affairs minister - a member of Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party - has been invited to a European Union meeting in Lisbon this week, it was confirmed last night. Signalling that the EU is now going to play by the book in dealing with a member government that includes the controversial party, Portugal - holder of the union's rotating presidency - announced that Elisabeth Sickl, the minister, would be asked to Lisbon. But a three-day visit to Vienna by Portugal's president, Jorge Sampaio, early next month was postponed indefinitely "because of the situation in Austria and in accordance with the European Union's position". The informal Lisbon meeting on Friday was seen as a test of whether multilateral EU business would be affected after Austria's 14 partners froze bilateral contacts with Vienna in response to the Freedom party's inclusion in the coalition government. Limited sanctions now in force include refusing to back Austrian officials running for posts in international organisations and downgrading contacts with Austrian ambassadors in EU capitals. Until last night, no one was certain that normal EU activity could go ahead, especially since informal meetings such as the forthcoming Lisbon gathering occupy a grey area, with ministers attending by invitation of the presidency. Some EU member states, including Belgium, had raised the idea of not inviting Austrian ministers to informal meetings, but a majority of the 14 appear to believe that a clear distinction must be maintained between bilateral and EU business. Chris Patten, the EU's external affairs commissioner, alluded to some of the difficulties when he said last night: "What's happened in Austria in the last few days has been difficult for a number of member states, partly because of their historic memories and partly because of their nervousness about the consequences for their own political development of irresponsible populism. "So it's understandable that member states have acted as they have. But the European Union is an organisation of rules and laws and treaties, and we in the [European] commission act as the guardian ... of that legal framework." fields.headline: Famous son elicits mixed feelings
fields.standfirst: Home town  'Jörgl' is hero and villain to ex-neighbours
fields.trailText: Bad Goisern has quite a lot to be proud of, according to its tourist office. Take for instance the  Goiserer - its prized handmade mountain boots - or Gerhard Pilz, the world champion tobogganer who hails from this sleepy town a four-hour train ride from Vienna.
fields.byline: Kate Connolly  in Bad Goisern, northern Austria
fields.body:
Bad Goisern has quite a lot to be proud of, according to its tourist office. Take for instance the Goiserer - its prized handmade mountain boots - or Gerhard Pilz, the world champion tobogganer who hails from this sleepy town a four-hour train ride from Vienna.

But there's one figure notable for his absence from the tourist brochure. What about Jörg Haider, born here half a century ago?

"That's a personal question," the tourist officer says curtly. "You know our history isn't a secret, but we're not going to shout about Jörg. It's a hot topic." Instead she writes down the Haider parents' address on a paper and slides it across the counter along with a guide to Bad Goisern. "All you need to know is in there."

Several similar encounters later and it is clear that most people in this spa town do not see "Jörgl" as he is known, as local boy made good but as someone whose reputation threatens to damage the local tourist industry.

"I've known Jörg from Bad Goisern for over 40 years now," writes Werner Huemer in the local paper, the Ischler Wochenblatt. "And maybe that's why I didn't vote for him or his party "

Only the elderly landlady in the pub at the train station has a good word to say about Goisern's most famous son. "Jörgl? He's a good boy," she says affectionately. "I just wish they'd let him have a chance to prove himself instead of creating all this fuss. After all, we voted for him and there was nothing undemocratic about it."

He comes back occasionally, she says, sometimes by train, other times by helicopter.

The local men in their lederhosen sit having a midday beer and chuckling over the headline in Austria's most popular tabloid: "Clinton sharply rebukes Haider."

"Remember that tyke running around in his shorts?" Gerd remarks. "Now the so-and-so has the world wrapped round his little finger."

Goisern is not sure how to react to the attention it has been getting recently. The hot stories in the local paper concern a fire in the carpentry workshop "next to Elisabeth and Franz's house" and a woman who broke her husband's nose during a fight.

The beer drinkers indicate the wooden house where Mr Haider's parents live, 50 metres up the icy street. Garden shoes and a snow shovel stand at the back, a Japanese saloon car at the front. It's the smartest in the street with its net curtains and painted shut ters with little cutout hearts. "No free mail" reads a sign on the letterbox.

A small figure with wispy hair, pink-rimmed glasses and carrying a yellow plastic wash bowl potters down the street: "Nein. No interest," Dorothea Haider says. "I don't speak to anyone any more."

Locals say she runs the local Freedom party seniors' club. Her husband Robert, who joined the Nazi party in the 20s when it was still illegal, is an invalid. But the head of the local Social Democratic Youth, Kerstin Butinger, says in his fitter days he was known to tour the pubs in Goisern saying: "Just you wait, the Third Reich will come again."

Town officials are keen to spread the message that Goisern is not a so-called "brown" Nazi town. The Social Democrats have 21 seats in the local parliament, Mr Haider's Freedom party have just nine.

But the editorial in the Ischler Wochenblatt flirts quite happily with Haider's idea of creating a Third Republic.

Postcards in a newsagent at the bottom of the ski run - which attracts German, Dutch and Italian tourists - carry colourful "Ski Heil" slogans.

Across the valley in Bad Ischl the boys have been inspired by Mr Haider's success. According to one local, law students have recently resurrected Albia, a fraternity of male uniformed students who fence and drink beer. Mr Haider led the group in his youth.

"They're very proud of him," one man said. "They study law because Haider did and they almost see it as their duty to follow him in everything. Now they're even more fired up by his recent success."

fields.headline: Racists and hypocrites
fields.standfirst:
We call Haider a neo-Nazi because he wants to keep out the world's poor. So do we, of course
The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: We call Haider a neo-Nazi because he wants to keep out the world's poor. So do we, of course
fields.body:
"If you compare our programme with the programme of Tony Blair, you will find a lot of similarities." Jörg Haider

Globalisation is seen as a purely economic process. But politics inevitably accompanies globalisation. And in the rich countries, the appearance of Jörg Haider is the open face of this inadmissible, and until now unarticulated, politics.

The leaders of Europe issue ultimatums, stand on their dignity, deny the legitimacy of this neo-Nazi, this xenophobic, anti-Semite chauvinist. They have to do so, because Haider has a far wider constituency than they wish to acknowledge. He represents the beneficiaries of modest privilege against the masses of the poor, the wretched, the outcast of the earth.

The migrant - or in a more recent incarnation, the asylum seeker - has been the spectre on whose wretched fate the triumphal progress of the right in Europe has been founded. How swiftly the words "asylum seeker" become invaded by all the negative associations formerly evoked by immigrant. How quickly the attribute "bogus" attaches itself to the idea of the persecuted and marginalised.

The Financial Times states the facts: "At the start of the 19th century the ratio of real incomes per head between the world's richest and poorest countries was three to one. By 1900 it was 10 to one. By 2000 it had risen to 60 to one."

What could be more natural than that those impoverished by this process should seek to follow to its source the mysterious agent of their dispossession? And what could be more predictable than that those who have gained from these events should seek to prevent them from doing so?

The noses of the poor are always pressed against the TV screens of our windowpane. At the touch of a button they can still be made to disappear. It is only when our control becomes less remote, when gaunt, hungry faces from elsewhere appear on our streets, that a more authentic reponse emerges.

After all, Europe has contributed spectacularly to the global disturbance of regions and peoples; has, since colonial times, been an agent of vast uprootings, has exported its own migratory spirit, has sought to snuff out all alternative ways of answering need, has filled the world with economic migrants, many of them from within its own borders. The economies of almost every country in the world have been profoundly influenced by western international financial organisations, by transnational companies, by the diktats of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, by our "democratic institutions", in which those whose lives are wrecked by them have no say.

It is the business of western politicians to ensure that the advantages which its peoples have gained should not be cancelled, while at the same time declaring their abhorrence of xenophobia and racism. They dare not state whose side they are really on. They fret and fume, seeking to halt people at the frontiers of Europe under the pretence of "the maintenance of good race relations". What this really means is that the fragile and always threatened privilege of Europe must be defended against the poor; the overwhelmingly black poor.

Internationalists are now set against racists. The struggle between rich and poor takes on the aspect of race conflict, because that is its most obvious characteristic. The majority of the downtrodden, the oppressed and humiliated are non-white. What used to be called "embourgeoisement" of majorities in Europe and America - of which Tony Blair is the triumphant apostle - has been allied to the pauperisation of majorities in the rest of the world.

The European left scarcely distinguishes itself from a right whose faith in global laissez-faire is matched only by an hysterical defence of evaporated sovereignties and atrophied national powers. Those who set the monstrosity of globalisation in train, seek in vain to dissociate themselves from the further effects of their actions.

Internationalists confront racists. The identity of internationalists is less clear than that of their opponents, for they, too have been suppressed by all the right-thinking, Right-thinking politicians of Europe, along with the racists who have nevertheless made all the running. Internationalists - some people in the movements for environment and global social justice, some anarchists, some imaginative socialists (if that hasn't become a contradiction in terms), and the majority of human beings, the three billion who, according to Lawrence Summers, "live on less than two dollars a day".

J örg Haider has articulated the issue. This is his real crime. The only thing that distinguishes him from his colleagues in Europe is a lack of tact, a refusal to genuflect to pieties in which few of the leaders of Europe exhibit the remotest belief. How does his response to the "threat" from the poor differ from that of those now talking of "sanctions" against Austria? The wondering peoples of Asia and Africa can be forgiven if they cannot detect the distinction.

The Financial Times expresses its astonishment at a "ruthless populist who has blatantly exploited anti-immigrant sentiments to gain support". But it advises against ostracism of a coalition between conservatives and far right in Austria, on the grounds that "a programme may be formed that is at least economically sound". We all know what that means.

"Mr Haider's brand of hate has no place in the councils of Europe," scolds the Guardian. The politicians of western Europe exaggerate: for in the smiling face of Haider they may read the lineaments of their own policies. And they do not like it.

Perhaps our own leaders should pay attention to the readers of the Sun. On the day when Europe was denouncing Austria, the Sun devoted half a page to letters under the heading Labour Lunatics Have Lost Control of Asylum. A few phrases: "How on earth do we know who we are letting in anyway? We could be welcoming murderers and rapists." "Whatever government is in power seems to have no answer to the mass immigration of people into this country." "Far from fleeing tyranny, most come here for the better life." "If they are so hard done by here they should consider returning to their own country." "Now from April all asylum seekers will be housed and fed. New Labour? Or Monster Raving Loony Party?" "Surely they should not receive any benefits or money for five years until they have put something into the country." "Our benefits system is the attraction. Other countries are not the soft touch we are." "When is Jack Straw going to say no to more asylum seekers?" "The cure for this is to announce to the world that there is no free money or housing in this country." "When the late Enoch Powell spoke against Britain's immigration policy most of us called him racist. But comparing the situation now, with asylum seekers costing us zillions of pounds to keep, and the vast majority of them bogus, it makes you think he had a point" "When is the Labour government going to stop giving money hand over fist to asylum seekers?"

Politics is stranded, archaic, overtaken by the consequences of globalisation. Epic shifts in the world cannot be managed within the creaking ideologies we have inherited; and the shadow of a single integrated economy darkens the disintegrating societies it has created. The world is the site of a civil war in which all humanity is caught up, the war of the rich against the poor, against which conscience objects in vain. Haider knows whose side he is on. The other politicians of Europe know also. But they don't say.

Jeremy Seabrook writes on south Asia

webTitle: For the far right the key is to get a foot in the door

fields.headline: For the far right the key is to get a foot in the door
fields.standfirst:
Europe's fear: What if moderation doesn't pay?

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: What has alarmed governments in the rest of Europe about the entry into Austria's coalition government of Jörg Haider's Freedom party is the threat of contagion.
fields.byline: John Hooper in Vienna, and correspondents in Europe
fields.body:
What has alarmed governments in the rest of Europe about the entry into Austria's coalition government of Jörg Haider's Freedom party is the threat of contagion.

Mr Haider is the most successful, yet among the most extreme, representative of a comparatively new breed of far right European politician: media-wise populists who, while espousing profoundly reactionary ideas, have abandoned much of the ideological baggage of older neo-Nazism.

The archetype is Gianfranco Fini, suave leader of Italy's National Alliance, which is descended from Mussolini's blackshirts. He has succeeded in re-packaging his party as "post-fascist" and legitimate.

Others include Christoph Blocher of Switzerland's People's party; dapper Bruno Mégret, of France's National Republican Movement whose smiling manner belies the fact that he was once the chief racist theoretician of Jean-Marie Le Pen's National Front; and Pia Kjarsgaard, head of the seemingly moderate Danish People's party, who recently proposed that the entire family of any immigrant convicted of a criminal offence should be deported.

In Belgium, there is Filip Dewinter whose Vlaams Blok combines anti-immigrant rhetoric with separatism.

Leaders of Europe's new hard right insist that they are ready to respect the rules of democracy. Few are openly anti-semitic and they shun public association with the hooligan-skinhead fringe, even though they count on it for votes. None aspires to rebuild the corporatist states moulded by Hitler and Mussolini. Indeed, several claim to have embraced the neo-liberal ideas of 80s conservatism.

The differences between them are considerable, in particular over Europe. But what they have in common, and what links them to others like Umberto Bossi of Italy's secessionist Northern League who does not otherwise fit the far right mould, is a deep antipathy to Europe's growing ethnic variety.

In Belgium, for example, Mr Dewinter and his followers take care not to attack Jews and to underline the claim that they are not fascists of the old school.

"There are a lot of foreigners in Belgium, about 10-12%," Mr Dewinter said last summer. "We want to organise a halt to immigration in our country. In fact, we want a policy of national preference, preference for our own people."

But he added: "We are certainly not a fascist or anti-democratic or a racist party." Immigrants who chose to adopt Flemish nationality would be welcome in a Flemish state. "For the rest, those who are unemployed, who are here illegally, who committed criminal acts, they have to go back to their own country."

Until the rise of the Freedom party, the far right's quest for respectability could be viewed with some optimism.

The cooler the rhetoric and the longer the far right played by the rules of democracy, the more power it acquired. And the more power it got, the greater the incentive to be moderate and play by the rules.

In Spain, Manuel Fraga was able to transform the People's Alliance into a mainstream conservative party whose successor, the ruling People's party, has democratic credentials that no one questions.

Mr Fini in Italy has reaped some success from heading in much the same direction. In 1994, his National Alliance held power briefly in a coalition headed by the media tycoon, Silvio Berlusconi.

The fast growing Danish People's party - which campaigned in last year's general election against immigrants and against joining a single European currency - goes out of its way to stress that it is a constitutional party and wants to play a full and cooperative role in government. It won 7.4% of the vote and 13 seats in parliament.

Its apparent inoffensiveness has won it support from people who would normally vote conservative or even Social Democrat - a recent poll, for example, showed that 30% of the members of one of Denmark's largest trade unions were DPP sympathisers.

The question which Jörg Haider raises for the far right is whether the lengthy, often painful, process of reinvention is really necessary. He has achieved more success than any other far right leader in modern Europe while remaining far more overtly extreme.

The only other party in Europe to have succeeded on a similar scale is Christoph Blocher's Swiss People's party - now the second strongest political force in the country with 22.5% of the vote. It still has a moderate wing led by its single minister in the four-party cabinet, the federal council.

But the moderate wing has almost been wiped out by Mr Blocher's rise in eastern Switzerland during the past decade, fuelled by virulent opposition to closer political ties with the EU.

The lesson for the far right seems to be that the most important thing is not so much whether you are a hawk or a dove, but a cuckoo.

Additional reporting by Ian Black in Brussels, Peter Capella in Geneva, Rory Carroll in Rome and Jon Henley in Paris

"There are a lot of foreigners in Belgium, about 10-12%," Mr Dewinter said last summer. "We want to organise a halt to immigration in our country. In fact, we want a policy of national preference, preference for our own people." But he added: "We are certainly not a fascist or anti-democratic or a racist party." Immigrants who chose to adopt Flemish nationality would be welcome in a Flemish state. "For the rest, those who are unemployed, who are here illegally, who committed criminal acts, they have to go back to their own country." Until the rise of the Freedom party, the far right's quest for respectability could be viewed with some optimism. The cooler the rhetoric and the longer the far right played by the rules of democracy, the more power it acquired. And the more power it got, the greater the incentive to be moderate and play by the rules. In Spain, Manuel Fraga was able to transform the People's Alliance into a mainstream conservative party whose successor, the ruling People's party, has democratic credentials that no one questions. Mr Fini in Italy has reaped some success from heading in much the same direction. In 1994, his National Alliance held power briefly in a coalition headed by the media tycoon, Silvio Berlusconi. The fast growing Danish People's party - which campaigned in last year's general election against immigrants and against joining a single European currency - goes out of its way to stress that it is a constitutional party and wants to play a full and cooperative role in government. It won 7.4% of the vote and 13 seats in parliament. Its apparent inoffensiveness has won it support from people who would normally vote conservative or even Social Democrat - a recent poll, for example, showed that 30% of the members of one of Denmark's largest trade unions were DPP sympathisers. The question which Jörg Haider raises for the far right is whether the lengthy, often painful, process of reinvention is really necessary. He has achieved more success than any other far right leader in modern Europe while remaining far more overtly extreme. The only other party in Europe to have succeeded on a similar scale is Christoph Blocher's Swiss People's party - now the second strongest political force in the country with 22.5% of the vote. It still has a moderate wing led by its single minister in the four-party cabinet, the federal council. But the moderate wing has almost been wiped out by Mr Blocher's rise in eastern Switzerland during the past decade, fuelled by virulent opposition to closer political ties with the EU. The lesson for the far right seems to be that the most important thing is not so much whether you are a hawk or a dove, but a cuckoo. fields.headline: Step by step
fields.standfirst:
Pet shop boy floats job agency

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: An entrepreneur who made two fortunes by selling the Majestic Wine retail chain and Pet City is about to float an online recruitment company for more than £400m.
fields.body:
An entrepreneur who made two fortunes by selling the Majestic Wine retail chain and Pet City is about to float an online recruitment company for more than £400m.

Giles Clarke (above), 46, owns 5% of Oslo-based StepStone, which plans a retail offer in London and Oslo in early March.

It has a presence in eight European firms including the UK, France and Germany, and hopes to raise £60m to fund expansion into the remaining four European Union markets.

Mr Clarke, who became chief executive in September, said StepStone was aspiring to become the leading cross-Europe career portal.

It has a database of 40,000 advertisements and 170,000 CVs, and attracts 1.8m user sessions a month. Blue-chip customers include Andersen Consulting, Coca-Cola and Microsoft, which typically pay an annual subscription to advertise on the site.

In 1999 turnover was £7m, making it the market leader in Europe, Mr Clarke said.

The portal is marketed through ISPs, and an offline advertising campaign is planned.

Mr Clarke co-founded and sold Pet City to American group PetsMart for £150m. He also served as executive chairman of Majestic Wine before selling the chain for £15m in 1989.

webTitle: Freeserve in talks for sporting stake

fields.headline: Freeserve in talks for sporting stake
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Freeserve
Planetfootball
fields.trailText: Freeserve is understood to be negotiating to buy an option on shares in Sports Internet that could eventually give it a stake of around 10%.
fields.body:
Freeserve is understood to be negotiating to buy an option on shares in Sports Internet that could eventually give it a stake of around 10%.

Freeserve's chief executive, John Pluthero, is understood to have met Sports Internet deputy chairman and major shareholder Peter Wilkinson to discuss ways for Britain's largest internet service provider to cement its relationship with Sports Internet, which operates the Planetfootball.com websites.

Mr Pluthero has said he is keen to increase Freeserve's content and analysts believe that Sports Internet's portfolio of football and betting websites, which have a loyal following, would be attractive to him. Freeserve already takes Planetfootball content and the most likely way the two firms will further their partnership is by Freeserve taking an equity warrant.

Sports Internet already has a deal with Yahoo to drive traffic to its sites and is thought to have attracted the interest of BSkyB which is investing heavily in sports-related internet companies.

Mr Wilkinson worked closely with Mr Pluthero on the launch of Freeserve and has been credited with devising the strategy which would allow it offer internet access for free while making money from telephone calls. Sports Internet was set up by former Leeds United chief execuitve Chris Akers.

Shares in Sports Internet climbed 5p to 752p; Freeserve slipped 6% to 798p.

webTitle: 'I love the Dome, I'm proud to be repair man'

fields.headline: 'I love the Dome, I'm proud to be repair man'
fields.standfirst:
First day with the new family for former No 6 at Disney
The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: There is no such thing as a good day in "the worst job in the world", as Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the former Disneyland whizz kid who has been handed the poisoned chalice of running the dome, discovered yesterday.
fields.body:
There is no such thing as a good day in "the worst job in the world", as Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the former Disneyland whizz kid who has been handed the poisoned chalice of running the dome, discovered yesterday.

Mr Gerbeau - PY to his friends - turned up at the dome to headlines proclaiming him as the world's best-paid janitor. "Honestly, I wanted to come here to join the dome family," he told the Guardian. "I love the dome."

His first act was to tick off the dome's board for portraying him as the architect of the relaunch that resurrected the loss-making Disneyland Paris in the mid-90s. He said it was "unfortunate" that that impression had been given.

"Marketing was one of the areas l want to work on ... I never said I was the saviour of Disneyland Paris. I am not a one-man band. I was lucky to be a part of a great team."

Mr Gerbeau, 34, a former professional hockey player, faced further embarrassment with claims that he was nothing but a "repair man" and too green to fill the shoes of the former chief executive, Jennie Page. She formally resigned yesterday, five days after she received a "resign or be sacked" ultimatum.

"If I thought it would fail I would never have come," he insisted. People could call him what they liked, but he "felt proud about being a repairman ... I get a kick out of making things work," he said.

"I have a lot to offer from my experience working with Disney. I do not think there is anything wrong with the dome. The contents are fantastic - it is the most exciting place in Europe right now and we have got to tell the world about it. I want to make it the hottest ticket in town."

Mr Gerbeau said he had been "given a carte blanche" by the dome board, but would not be drawn on whether that also meant a blank cheque.

"I will not make changes for the sake of it. I am not an axeman. I am a team player," he said. Unpopular zones would not be closed, because he believed "it was all great". Instead he would be reviewing the way the dome is run and promoted rather than overhauling its contents.

Nor was he worried by the political interference which his predecessor had long complained of. "I was appointed by Bob Ayling of British Airways [the dome's chairman] and I am here to do a business job. Politics does not come into it."

Contrary to claims by the dome's operators, the New Millennium Experience Company, who at the weekend insisted that it was at first hoped that he might work alongside Ms Page, Mr Gerbeau said he was always going to replace her.

"There was never any question of me working with Jennie Page ... although I respect very much the job she has done," he said.

He was equally dismissive of suggestions that Disney might have been happy to see the back of him when he left 18 months ago to do a masters degree in business administration.

"It was my dream to do an MBA, so when I wanted to leave I sat down with my chief executive officer and he helped to pay me through," he said. "I have an excellent relationship with the whole Disney family, and have many very close friends there."

His mentor and former boss Phillipe Bourguignon, the man who in reality saved Disney's skin, said Mr Gerbeau was "one of most talented young executives I have ever met. He puts the visitor first. He is the right man for the job at the right time. I believe that he will make a major contribution to the dome."

Gilles Pelisson, the present chairman and chief executive officer of Disneyland Paris, said Mr Gerbeau was "top of the league" and a sad loss to their organisation.

Mr Gerbeau will be paid £100,000 if he lasts the year, with a similar bonus if he makes the dome's break-even target of 10m. He is separated from his wife, but hopes to bring his three-year-old daughter, Clemence, to see the dome soon.

He said the twin handicaps of being French and a Disney man in a country that had an ambivalent attitude to both, did not worry him.

"Every country has their things, but I think the British people should be very proud of this dome."

But Stephen Bayley, the dome's former creative director who left in protest at the direction the attraction was taking three years ago, said even "an alleged whizz kid like Gerbeau has his work cut out. He may be Capitaine Fantastique but he will get no more money and there is no time to do anything meaningful with the content. I hate saying it, but there's a bad smell now. Good luck to him, but is a bit like asking a leading heart surgeon to revive a dead cat."

Meanwhile, in a bid to heal the acrimony over the handling of Ms Page's sacking, and possibly to stop any embarrassing legal action, Tony Blair's official spokesman said the prime minister wanted to speak to the woman who brought the dome in on budget to express his admiration for her.

webTitle: Swedish fashion and Dixons tipped to click on the digital shopfront

fields.headline: Swedish fashion and Dixons tipped to click on the digital shopfront
fields.standfirst:
Bricks and mortar outlets stand to lose 40% in revenue

E-finance: special report
E-Insight
fields.trailText: Dixons and Swedish fashion chain Hennes & Mauritz are the non-food retailers most likely to succeed in the e-commerce arena, according a report published yesterday by E-Insight, a specialist e-commerce consultancy.
fields.body:
Dixons and Swedish fashion chain Hennes & Mauritz are the non-food retailers most likely to succeed in the e-commerce arena, according a report published yesterday by E-Insight, a specialist e-commerce consultancy.

Kingfisher will be a close runner-up, taking its Woolworth, B&Q and Superdrug shops on to the net, it says. WH Smith, Marks & Spencer and Boots, on the other hand, have far less chance of success.

Tesco, which announced last month that its online grocery shopping business was the biggest in the world with annualised sales of £125m, and Asda come out as the food retailers with the greatest e-commerce potential, while rivals Sainsbury, Safeway, Somerfield and Morrisons lag the field.

According to the report, all traditional high street retailers that push into selling services online are likely to find life difficult. Retailers could lose up to 40% of their revenue as their electronic sites begin to cannibalise their bricks-and-mortar outlets.

Online retail spending is set to grow from £2.6bn to £75bn in the next eight years but few companies are going to make much money out of it, the report says. Established retailers are also likely to lose out as price wars break out on the electronic front.

The result will force all retailers to put even greater pressure on their suppliers to reduce costs. This will happen at a time when the suppliers "have not established e-business savings strategies for themselves".

The report forecasts that by 2005 there will be 40m devices in British homes able to access "digital shopfronts" via the internet or digital television. Half of these will be personal computers.

"Growth in home PC ownership will still be the foundation for e-commerce market growth," the report says. Home internet use in Britain is expected to double in the next three years to about 20m, compared with 19m in France and 26m in Germany. Annual online spending per internet household will reach £900 by 2003 and £3,000 by 2008.

Alan Taylor, E-Insight's chief executive, said that the online food-based market would grow more slowly than the consumer goods market. He expected online spending on groceries would reach only £4bn by 2005.

He warned food retailers against assuming they would be the most successful in a mature e-commerce environment. "The lesson for the manufacturers is not to ignore the minnows. They may become big fish," he said.

E-Insight stresses that retailers will have to run the online businesses as stand-alone operations, with their own strategies and product lines. Online retailers and their suppliers will have to develop new relationships, working together rather than trying to negotiate each other down.

The report shows that the buying public is only prepared to buy online if there is a big saving.

Mr Taylor said that current online consumer spending in Britain only accounted for about 1% of overall national consumer spending. But he estimated that by 2008, when about 22m British households would have a PC, e-commerce would account for about 20% of consumer spending.

webTitle: UN snubbed by Britain on return of treasures

fields.headline: UN snubbed by Britain on return of treasures
fields.standfirst: Elgin marbles: special report
fields.trailText: The government is to boycott a new United Nations convention on returning stolen cultural artefacts to prevent Britain having to return the Elgin marbles to Greece.
fields.body:
The government is to boycott a new United Nations convention on returning stolen cultural artefacts to prevent Britain having to return the Elgin marbles to Greece.

The decision, announced yesterday by Chris Smith, the culture secretary, will mean that Britain will clash with the UN over complaints from many African and Asian countries as well as Greece that the retention of their treasures is one of the last remnants of cultural imperialism.

It will also fuel speculation that Tony Blair is determined to take a hard line over the 184-year controversy surrounding the acquisition of the Elgin marbles by the British Museum after it became clear before Christmas that he had ruled out reopening the issue before the next election.

Ministers are said to fear that returning the marbles could lead to other galleries and museums having to return masterpieces.

Britain's decision is in line with the rest of the European Union and the United States which are refusing to sign the new convention because of the treasures they hold in their top museums, from the Louvre to the New York Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Countries that have backed the resolution include Afghanistan, Bolivia, Cambodia, Canada, China, Egypt, the Congo, Haiti, Hungary, Macedonia, Madagascar, Malawi, the Marshall Islands, Mongolia, Morocco, Nigeria, Peru, Syria and Togo.

Mr Smith, whose department was unable last night to expand on the issue, said yesterday in a reply to Labour MP Stephen Pound: "After a lengthy inter-departmental consultation, I have concluded that the UK should not become a signatory to the Undroit convention due to conflicts with our current law.

"In order to implement the convention, changes to our limitation periods and to our personal property would be required, resulting in a special regime for cultural objects and arguably a less generous position for original rightful owners of objects which are later stolen."

Mr Smith has promised to consider options for alternative legislation which could implement some of the provisions.

Mr Smith's position looks at odds with the convention itself which calls for bilateral negotiations between countries over the return of works of art rather than ordering any country to hand over the antiquities.

It does however commit the UN to an inventory of works of art which would be a big process.

The government has been embarrassed by the revival of the row over the Elgin marbles, triggered originally by a decision of the Commons culture, media and sports committee to look at the issue again this year.

The British Museum also angered the Greeks when the Guardian revealed that it lent out the Duveen galleries - which house the marbles - for costume parties, including people who wished to dress up as ancient Greeks and Egyptians.

It also came under fire when it was forced to release documents at a symposium last December which revealed that the marbles had been damaged when they were inexpertly scraped and cleaned 60 years ago. The museum covered this up at the time and had refused to make public the documents.

MPs are likely to press Mr Smith for a full explanation for the government's decision, particularly when the culture, media and sports committee looks at the issue.

The British Museum also angered the Greeks when the Guardian revealed that it lent out the Duveen galleries - which house the marbles - for costume parties, including people who wished to dress up as ancient Greeks and Egyptians. It also came under fire when it was forced to release documents at a symposium last December which revealed that the marbles had been damaged when they were inexpertly scraped and cleaned 60 years ago. The museum covered this up at the time and had refused to make public the documents. MPs are likely to press Mr Smith for a full explanation for the government's decision, particularly when the culture, media and sports committee looks at the issue.

fields.headline: Connex purges top brass
fields.standfirst:
Clear-out ordered as record tells against train operator in commuter franchise bi
d
More about transport
fields.trailText: A clear-out of management at the top of the troubled Connex train company has been ordered in an effort to secure a new franchise for London commuter services from the shadow strategic rail authority.
fields.body:
A clear-out of management at the top of the troubled Connex train company has been ordered in an effort to secure a new franchise for London commuter services from the shadow strategic rail authority.

Industry sources suggested last night that the company's French chief executive, Antoine Hurel, was being recalled to Paris, and that his senior colleague, Geoff Harrison-Mee, would also be replaced.

Mr Hurel is expected to be given another job at Vivendi, the French multinational which owns Connex. His company has been widely criticised for introducing a tough, uncompromising style of management since Connex started operating services four years ago after rail privatisation.

It is not certain whether even this clear-out will save Connex from the axe. The SRA is unhappy with the company's performance, one of the worst on the rail network.

Political pressure on the company is also mounting from the government and influential backbench MPs, such as Gwyneth Dunwoody, chair of the Commons transport committee.

The junior education minister, Malcolm Wicks, has called on the SRA to remove Connex's franchise. As MP for Croydon North, at the heart of the Connex network, Mr Wicks speaks on behalf of thousands of long-suffering commuters. He says the recent strike by train drivers was the "latest nail in the coffin for Connex", and that "all the evidence suggests that we need a new operator".

Ms Dunwoody, powerful ally of the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, has also demanded that the Connex franchise be taken away.

Connex last night would not respond to suggestions that big changes were planned at the highest level. But an official announcement about Mr Hurel's departure is said to be imminent.

The company has just presented to the SRA a £1bn plan for a new 20-year franchise. It includes new rolling stock, and the reopening of two lines. But critics say it does not go far enough and is full of promises which it will find difficult to deliver.

The SRA says that it will take a tough line with rail companies that fail to carry out promises during the lifetime of the new franchises. The authority will carry out reviews every five years and impose penalties on defaulting companies.

Another rail operator, Great North Eastern Railway, yesterday unveiled its plans for a 20-year franchise on the east coast main line between London and Edinburgh. They bear a close resemblance to the plans already announced by Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Trains, which is competing to take over the franchise.

Christopher Garnett, GNER's chief executive, said that the company would in crease its 2,800 workforce by another 1,000 by 2004 and introduce 25 new tilting trains, capable of speeds of up to 140mph.

The downside of the plan is that GNER will have to rely on Railtrack's ability to modernise the line for high-speed trains. Although trains will be able to travel between London and Edinburgh at speeds of 125mph, they will not be able to travel at 140mph for another 10 years.

The company, the SRA and Railtrack will have to negotiate about who will have to pay for a £2bn update of the line.

fields.headline: Shipman case police investigate 175 deaths
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: Police in Manchester are to investigate another 39 deaths - bringing the total under investigation to 175 - following the conviction last week of Harold Shipman for the murder of 15 women patients.
fields.body:
Police in Manchester are to investigate another 39 deaths - bringing the total under investigation to 175 - following the conviction last week of Harold Shipman for the murder of 15 women patients.

Detectives suspect the total could rise again over the next few weeks.

A spokeswoman for Greater Manchester police said: "We have had new complaints relating to patients from Dr Shipman's practice. These will all be investigated."

Inquiries will continue at an incident room at Ashton-under-Lyne police station and will be led by Det. Supt. Bernard Postles, whose investigations helped convict Shipman. He was given 15 life sentences last week after the jury at Preston crown court had deliberated for six days at the end of a 57-day trial.

"We have to take all complaints seriously," added the spokeswoman. "The file has not been closed. Some complaints have been passed on to the crown prosecution service but we cannot confirm how many."

Shipman killed 15 mainly elderly women by giving them lethal injections of morphine. Most died at home but one was murdered as she lay on a bed in the treatment room in the doctor's surgery. Shipman later altered records to make the deaths appear consistent with his victims' medical records.

After the trial, it emerged that police had maintained four lists of possible victims, each graded according to the strength of the evidence.

The A list included the first 15 victims. The B list contains the names of 23 former patients in connection with whose deaths the crown prosecution service is considering charges. A decision is expected by the end of the month.

The other two lists refer to deaths under investigation. The total grew by 10 the day after the verdicts were announced and has now grown again, with police suspecting new names will be added as other relatives make contact.

Some of the new inquiries are thought to relate to deaths as far back as the 1980s, before Shipman set up his one-man practice in Hyde, Greater Manchester.

The growing number of complaints will add to the dilemma facing Mr Postles and his team who want to help relatives of possible murder victims achieve justice.

Their best hope is that Shipman will make a clean breast of any other killings and so avoid the need for any other legal action. But they also know admissions of guilt are unlikely after Shipman's firm denials of all involvement during his two weeks in the dock at Preston.

They also know that, if more charges are laid, a second trial could cost millions and that there would be great difficulty in finding a jury unaffected by the reporting of the first trial.

Shipman is in Manchester prison where he is likely to remain for two weeks before being transferred to Wakefield jail. He was visited by his wife, Primrose, at the weekend.

With the help of regulations rushed through by ministers after the trial, West Pennine health authority has removed Shipman from its list of doctors.

His salary payments, which continued through his time on remand and in court, have ceased and the health secretary, Alan Milburn, also stripped Shipman of his NHS pension.

Mrs Shipman may be forced to sell their house, thought to be worth £90,000 and may have to rely on her children for financial help.

The youngest of their four children, Samuel, 17, lives at home. The eldest, Sarah, 32, was apparently estranged from the family for several years, but attended the trial periodically. Christopher, 28, works in the south of England.

Two books on the case have now been published, one produced by the Manchester Evening News, the other by a press agency in the city.

webTitle: Cigarette maker sues insurers to recover damages

fields.headline: Cigarette maker sues insurers to recover damages
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: Three of Britain's biggest insurers are in the line of fire following the decision by US cigarette manufacturer Liggett to launch a massive lawsuit seeking to recover its bill for compensating smokers.
fields.body:
Three of Britain's biggest insurers are in the line of fire following the decision by US cigarette manufacturer Liggett to launch a massive lawsuit seeking to recover its bill for compensating smokers.

The company is suing 32 insurance companies and has put America's 53 state guarantee funds on notice that it is seeking to recover all its defence and indemnity costs, past and future. One expert in the field said the cost could easily run to several hundred million dollars.

Royal Insurance, Zurich and Commercial Union are believed to be among those underwriters which provided insurance cover for Liggett but the tobacco company's decision to mount an action raises the possibility of much larger lawsuits from the biggest tobacco companies - British American Tobacco and Philip Morris.

Neither of these companies yet intends to take action. But stock market pressure might force them to reconsider if their share prices continue to sink in response to smoking litigation in America.

Paul Hodges, an analyst at Schroders, who has long predicted that the tobacco companies would eventually turn on their insurers, said yesterday: "Over the past three years we've had compelling evidence of substantial insurance coverage. We have been waiting for one of the tobacco companies to step up on to the roster - the question now is what will the others do. I think it is overwhelmingly in their shareholders' interests that they should now proceed."

BAT and Philip Morris argue that the wording of their insurance policies is complex and it is not clear that they would be covered for smoking-related payments.

One worry for the tobacco groups is that the existence of insurance cover can encourage judges and juries to increase the size of damages awards. Already, one judgment has talked of the existence of "tens of billions of dollars" of insurance coverage which provides an additional target at which litigants can aim.

Despite an industry-wide smoking settlement agreed in late 1998, the tobacco companies face a series of lawsuits in the US courts which have tended to drive down their share prices. An action in Florida, which could cost $500bn if successful, is expected to be settled towards the end of this year and if, as expected, the tobacco companies win it could provide some relief to their share prices.

fields.headline: Russians push into the hills
fields.trailText: The Russian campaign in Chechnya sought to build on the capture of the capital, Grozny, yesterday when Russian forces pursued guerrillas fleeing towards the southern mountains. They were trying to destroy the rebels before they were able to return to protracted partisan warfare.
fields.body:
The Russian campaign in Chechnya sought to build on the capture of the capital, Grozny, yesterday when Russian forces pursued guerrillas fleeing towards the southern mountains. They were trying to destroy the rebels before they were able to return to protracted partisan warfare.

A day after Vladimir Putin, Russia's acting president, declared that Grozny had finally been "liberated" five months into the war, the Russian air and ground assault concentrated on the approaches to the rebels' mountain redoubts in the south. They also targeted the flat lands of western Chechnya, where many rebels were thought to be hiding.

The Russian war spokesman, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, claimed that Russian forces had cut off fleeing fighters south-west of Grozny and killed 300 yesterday and on Sunday. The Chechen president, Aslan Maskhadov, conceded that his forces had sustained heavy casualties when retreating from Grozny last week.

The sudden breakout from Grozny has brought the war back to many of the small towns and villages of western Chechnya, with roads closed yesterday to the capital from neighbouring Ingushetia because of air strikes and ground battles in the region.

The area had been relatively quiet under Russian occupation for months, but many of the guerrilla fighters who had abandoned Grozny took shelter in its surrounding villages and forests.

Events on the ground belied the both sides' propaganda claims; the return of the war to western Chechnya contradicted Russian assertions that Russian-occupied areas were under full Russian control and safe for civilian life, while the rebels' predicament also betrayed a sense of panic in their ranks.

President Maskhadov tried to put a brave face on the losses, in what was one of the heaviest blows to his forces since the war started in September. He said a group of 2,000 forces had successfully escaped from Grozny and that a smaller group of several hundred had suffered casualties.

But guerrilla morale appears to have been dealt a blow by the death of several key warlords and commanders during the past week. Russian television showed the number-one warlord, Shamil Basayev, having a foot amputated in a field hospital under local anaesthetic. The commander's face was pocked with shrapnel marks.

The grim film appeared to have been released by the Chechens to counter rumours that Mr Basayev had been more heavily disabled.

The Russian defence ministry said yesterday that 15 lorries transporting Chechen fighters into the southern mountains had been intercepted and destroyed near the village of Gekhi, south-west of Grozny.

For the moment, there is no doubt that the Russians have chalked up successes in recent days. Yesterday, the Russian justice minister, Yuri Chaika, said an amnesty being offered to surrendered rebels should be extended.

He put the figure of seized guerrillas at more than 500.

webTitle: Deserter is adopted by the enemy

fields.headline: Deserter is adopted by the enemy
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: It was only when he was issued with a metal name tag to hang around his neck that Andrei, a teenage conscript from St Petersburg, began to suspect he might be on his way to fight in Chechnya.
fields.byline: Amelia Gentleman in a village near Grozny
fields.body:
It was only when he was issued with a metal name tag to hang around his neck that Andrei, a teenage conscript from St Petersburg, began to suspect he might be on his way to fight in Chechnya.

Even then, officers refused to tell him or anyone else in the unit where they were going. They were dispatched to a base in the heart of the separatist state, but their final destination only became clear when they started being trained for an attack on the region's capital, Grozny.

By this time, Andrei, 19, had realised that the war was not for him. Late one night he left his tent and walked out into the darkness, with no plan but to get as far away as possible from the fighting.

Ten weeks later, he remains in hiding at a village in the centre of Chechnya, adopted by a local farmer, uncertain of how he is to return home.

He lives as a virtual prisoner, unable to walk the streets of the Russian-occupied village for fear of arrest; tall and blond with distinctive Russian features, he stands out immediately from the dark-haired villagers. The family who took him in are unwilling even to let him meet their neighbours, for fear someone might inform on them.

And yet, despite these restrictions, Andrei claimed yesterday that his new existence was a vast improvement on life in the army. "We were barely trained how to shoot," he said.

During the six months he served before being sent to Chechnya, he was taken only twice to the firing range, where he was given just 18 bullets to practise with. The conscripts spent their time gathering potatoes, until an officer struck a lucrative deal with a local businessman for the soldiers to provide free labour in an asphalt factory.

"When we arrived in Chechnya, our officer told us: 'A soldier must die, that is his role in life - he must die for his officers, especially in times of war.' I already hated the whole system," he said.

Russian behaviour towards locals also fuelled his desire to desert. He said senior officers made trips to Grozny and returned with looted belongings.

He told no one of his decision to leave, and walked through the night - risking being shot by his own army - until he came to a deserted house in a nearby village. He lit a fire and went to sleep, and was found, tear-stained and hungry, by a local farmer who took pity on him. Obviously extremely fond of the young soldier, the farmer has invited him to stay permanently.

Andrei needs false papers to escape across the border to Ingushetia. And if he returns to St Petersburg, he will need a new identity to avoid punishment for desertion. Soldiers who desert during war face the death penalty, but because Russia insists on referring to its campaign in Chechnya as an "anti-terrorist operation" rather than a war, Andrei may only face several years in a military detention unit.

Alternatively, he said he was seriously considering remaining in Chechnya, with the farmer and his four daughters.

A message has been sent to his family, trying to reassure them he is safe and neither a prisoner of war nor a hostage. But in the light of the horror stories of Chechen abductions, which are broadcast repeatedly on Russian television, his family will need some persuading.

One of the village elders claimed Andrei was the eleventh Russian deserter to end up in the village; the rest had been helped to escape. Andrei was the first to ask to stay.

webTitle: Blair knows the Kilfoyleite tendency represents reality

fields.headline: Blair knows the Kilfoyleite tendency represents reality
fields.standfirst:
He insists that he leads 'one nation'. But this claim is completely untrue

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: For New Labour, it is an article of faith that Britain is not a divided country. Class differences not only don't matter, but in some sense do not exist. There is no cleavage between rich and poor, north and south, country and city.
fields.body:
For New Labour, it is an article of faith that Britain is not a divided country. Class differences not only don't matter, but in some sense do not exist. There is no cleavage between rich and poor, north and south, country and city. "The whole country is our core constituency," Tony Blair said at the weekend, anguish vying with anger in his reaction to the sincere disillusionment of his former loyalist, Peter Kilfoyle MP. Mr Blair insists that this is one nation, and he the leader of all the people.

Unfortunately, this is completely untrue. England - never mind the Celts - is a country of several economic nations. The divisions between them are getting larger not smaller. There may not yet be significant political divisions, but the economic facts are scarcely disputable. Disposable household income is less than £9,000 in the north, more than £10,500 in the south-east. The number of people on less than 40% of national earnings rose by more than a million, to a record 8.4m, in Labour's first year. The rich have been getting richer, and the poor relatively much poorer, and they continue to do so. The mosaic of economic differences throughout Britain is startling, multi-faceted, and not remotely congruent with the presumption that this is a seamless single nation.

When Mr Blair talks his one-nation rhetoric, therefore, he is describing aspiration not truth. It may be a commendable aspiration, but it is pursued by a tactic that offends Mr Kilfoyle and many people like him. For New Labour's purported liquidation of class politics involves appealing more to the upper than the lower half of the nation. This is what it thinks it has to do. It wants to prove itself not by declaring victory for Labour's own historic class but by appropriating its old class enemy, and clutching the middle class to the bosom once defined by politicians who had no doubt that they were socialists.

In this it has been pretty successful in a remarkably short time. It has purloined the proprietorship of capitalism from the party of the right: so much so that only a hard-right neo-Thatcherite could make a case for saying that British business was unsafe in Labour's hands. It is also determined to remove patriotism from exclusive possession of the Conservative party, which is the upside case to be made for the caution with which it is handling the European issue.

This combination of tendencies may even be responsible for the foul calumny uttered by Jörg Haider over the weekend, that he is partly following a Blairite line. "Tony Blair has studied our programme and knows there are a lot of similarities," he lied. Although he has been flattered as a political master by virtually every continental politician, this is an endorsement Mr Blair could do without.

None the less, Mr Kilfoyle catches him on a tender spot. The minister resigns to launch an Exocet at New Labour's proudest flank. He cannot tolerate this re-working of Labour into a prospective one-nation party, being done from the top downwards. A generalised discontent at the grass-roots is massing for the same reason. At the least there is bewilderment, at the most an increasingly alienated cynicism, which is likely to express itself by many people who voted Labour last time staying at home when they get the chance to vote again next year. That is by far the greatest electoral danger Mr Blair faces. In his heart he knows he has more to fear from the Kilfoyleite tendency, because it represents a genuine perception, than from the manoeuvrings of a mistrusted opportunist like Ken Livingstone.

The strange thing is that the cynicism is exaggerated. It is far from fully justified. The Labour programme has been more redistributive than it looks. That means it has done things for the Labour heartland vote - its traditional class support - the merits of which the recipients do not fully credit. The national minimum wage has improved the lives of perhaps two million people. The working families tax credit and the new deal have done a lot for the have-nots of this divided society. Increased public spending on health and education represents a serious investment in the lives of those at the bottom end, as well as regions which depend on the public sector as the most important generator of economic activity.

In my opinion it has been excessively risk-averse in its quest for fiscal prudence, and could have done more for more people whose quality of life remains heavily dependent on public money. It has hazarded, in particular, the support of its traditional constituency by talking a language that often sounds punitive, and is plainly directed at a different audience. It is not yet prepared to tackle the ideological centralism that has been the treasury-imposed consensus among governments of all colours for decades, which fathers the kind of alienation increasingly felt in Kilfoyle's Liverpool and many other parts of England beyond the M25.

But the real record, if one takes any long view, is not bad. What is bad is more the perception. And what creates the perception, as much as anything, is the way in which Blairism chose to try to prove itself as a one-nation, all-embracing political movement which pretends the nation is not divided and insists that it, the great new party, can represent all of the people all of the time. To this end, it has consistently underplayed its interest in social justice. Only by diminishing, even excluding, its old constituency did it think it could make itself acceptable to a new one.

It is led by politicians who are deeply believing capitalists, supported by a cohort of MPs who mostly belong to the same camp. So that part of the nation is at last secure.

Great differences will never be eliminated, nor should they be. That's the nature of a free economic society in a competitive world. But it's a matter of degree. The first precondition is to admit that alienation is grave and divisions do exist. The next is to address them with more sensitivity than was possible when the party was still concerned to establish its business credentials. fields.headline: It's the sex inspector
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: I should have thought that Chris Woodhead's personal experience in those days long ago when he was an ordinary schoolteacher might have persuaded him to keep tactful silence on the subject of sex education.
fields.body:
I should have thought that Chris Woodhead's personal experience in those days long ago when he was an ordinary schoolteacher might have persuaded him to keep tactful silence on the subject of sex education.

Asked at Exeter university last year what he thought of the government's plans to criminalise sexual relations between teacher and pupils, Woodhead replied that such relations could be "experiential". This reply so impressed his former wife Cathy that she broke her long silence about Woodhead's affair with his former pupil, Amanda Johnston. When the story of this affair broke some years ago - in the News of the World - Woodhead insisted that their affair did not start until Amanda left school.

In March last year, after reading her former husband's historic reply at Exeter, Cathy Woodhead revealed - on the front page of the Mail on Sunday - that she found out about the affair several months before Amanda left school, when she was still being taught English by the future chief inspector. Mrs Woodhead's version was backed by a host of friends and former teachers at the school, and everyone who knew anything about it, except the secretary of state for education, David Blunkett, who replied to Cathy Woodhead's revelations by denouncing her for making them.

Against this impressively honest and truthful background, up pops the chief inspector once again with his views on sex education: this time in an impromptu statement from his office. He has, he insists, come across no evidence to suggest that the controversial section 28 has a negative influence on homophobic bullying in schools. Whoops! As Lord Tope pointed out in the House of Lords last Thursday there is "ample evidence" of precisely that negative influence. Lord Whitty, for the government, agreed with him. "Chris Woodhead does not seem to reflect the views of teachers," he said. "Forty-four per cent of them felt that they had difficulty in meeting the needs of gay and lesbian pupils" and 28% felt that section 28 "may leave them open to legal proceedings".

Baroness Thornton then referred to a 1997 report of the Institute of Education, and added: "I cannot believe that the chief inspector is not aware of this report and its comments." The truth is that Mr Woodhead is notoriously long on prejudice and short on fact.

The point about section 28 is that it criminalises the promotion of gay sex but not heterosexual sex. So it discriminates. In normal circumstances the repeal of such an obviously discriminatory law might be greeted with profound relief.

But circumstances are not normal. So ideologically weak has the government become that the forces of reaction, sensing another victory, have rallied behind this relic of discriminatory Tory junk. Almost every day, the Daily Mail waxes hysterical with homophobia, and in Scotland the great monopolist Brian Souter of Stagecoach, who made a fortune from Thatcher's bus privatisation, has put up half a million pounds to maintain in law one of the Thatcher government's most despicable prejudices.

But wait. Who is this I hear on the radio teaming up with this reactionary gang? It is the bishop of Liverpool, who is introduced as "Tony Blair's favourite bishop". The bishop makes the sensitive point that our genitalia have been constructed so as to discourage homosexuality. I would like to have heard more from the bishop on the subject of genitalia, but he was cut off. His sophisticated argument - "God made us this way, and that should be the end of the matter" - reminded me of an old Flanders and Swann song about cannibalism, where the cannibal's refrain went like this:

People have always eaten people.
What else is there to eat?
If the Jiu Jiu had meant us not to eat people,
He wouldn't have made us of meat.

 It is surely high time the Tory party got to grips with their celebrated and long-standing member in Hyde - Dr Harold Shipman. What about expelling him for five years from the party?

 Here's another in my occasional Great Leaps Forward series in which I cull facts from Hansard to demonstrate the enormous strides towards progress taken by the New Labour government - especially in those fields in which the traditionally more progressive ministers are in charge. In the House of Lords on February 11, that former leftwing firebrand, Lord Bassam of Brighton, was asked about prison suicides. He revealed that in 1997, the year New Labour came to office, 85 people killed themselves in prison. This figure went up to 96 in 1998 and 107 (just under two a week) in 1999. The main minister in charge of prisons is another former leftwing firebrand, Paul Boateng.

webTitle: 'Morality of hate' attacked by gay peer

fields.headline: 'Morality of hate' attacked by gay peer
fields.standfirst:
Section 28 debate: Young leads opponents of repeal.

Section 28 explained
fields.trailText: Feelings ran high last night inside and outside the House of Lords as peers clashed over government moves to scrap the law preventing councils "promoting" homosexuality.
fields.body:
Feelings ran high last night inside and outside the House of Lords as peers clashed over government moves to scrap the law preventing councils "promoting" homosexuality.

As protest groups demonstrated in Parliament Square Lady Young - former Tory leader of the Lords and chief supporter of retaining the controversial section 28 of the local government bill - argued that there was no "moral equivalence" between gay and heterosexual relationships.

Later in the debate Labour's Lord Alli strongly endorsed abolition of the clause, accusing its supporters of having the same "morality of hate" as the bomber who blew up a gay pub in Soho, London.

Earlier the Bishop of Blackburn, the Rt Rev Alan Chesters, withdrew a proposed amendment to promote marriage in schools after assurances from junior environment minister Lord Whitty that the government would debate the issues with the church before the bill's report stage.

The former Conservative minister, Lord St John of Fawsley, criticised the stand taken against homosexuality by Scottish Catholics' leader Cardinal Thomas Winning. "Cardinal Winning has spoken out in an unapettising way, which I as a Catholic do not agree with."

Lady Young claimed she knew section 28 "has been effective in stopping local authorities from promoting homosexuality in schools. The centre of this debate is children, children in schools, children who in my opinion ought not to be treated as if they were adults and in a position to make an informed choice about alternative lifestyles, about which they cannot possibly have the experience to judge.

"I believe that there is not a moral equivalence between heterosexual and homosexual relationships. I believe we need to set in front of children an ideal by which they should live." Labour's Lady Gould of Potternewton said a recent poll revealed 70% of 18 to 24-year-olds thought section 28 ought to be repealed. She said: "What should have been a mature debate has been conducted in some quarters with a hysteria which has encouraged homophobia."

Labour's Lord Davies of Coity said he felt so strongly that section 28 should not be repealed that he was going to vote against the government for the first time. "This is a question of conscience, a moral issue, not a political one."

The former Conservative home secretary, Lord Waddington, said: "We have a duty to ensure that young boys, who are often confused about their feelings, are not the target of homosexual propaganda." He described the homosexual lobby as "moral bullies" rather than an oppressed minority.

Labour's Lord Alli , the only openly gay peer, compared "hate" engendered by section 28 with last year's nail bomb attacks in black and Asian areas of London and a gay pub in Soho. "This is indeed a debate about morality. For me it is about the morality of hate. I believe that that hate exists because we teach our children to hate."

He read a letter he said he received from a gay 15-year-old who had suffered homophobic bullying and now said he wished he was dead. "Is it so wrong to be gay?" he asked. "I don't think that any child should have to suffer that level of indignity. I love this country because we fight injustice. We have a responsibility, a moral responsibility, to fight hate and the crimes of hate."

webTitle: Waddington expounds the Lego legover theory

fields.headline: Waddington expounds the Lego legover theory
fields.standfirst: Section 28 explained
fields.trailText: Lord Waddington, near the start of the Lords' debate on section 28 inquired: "Who cannot see, from their knowledge of anatomy, that sodomy is an unnatural act?"
fields.body:
Lord Waddington, near the start of the Lords' debate on section 28 inquired: "Who cannot see, from their knowledge of anatomy, that sodomy is an unnatural act?"

This is the "Lego legover" theory of human sexuality. It is perfectly moral provided the pieces fit together snugly.

The problem with the theory is that it would make incest legal. And, while we are at it, shoplifting, too. After all, hands are well equipped for that purpose.

Lord Waddington went on to say immediately, "of course, it is wrong to be intolerant of homosexuality", so provoking that rarest of sounds in the peers' chamber - sarcastic laughter.

In a way his speech was quite refreshing, a fine example of beautifully polished, well-chamfered, traditional British bigotry, as much at home in the smoking room of a gentleman's club as an old leather armchair.

"Far from gays being an oppressed minority, there is now a gay triumphalism abroad," he told his fellow peers.

No doubt the gay triumphalists would be highly delighted with a leaflet published recently by a south London health authority, which offered advice on "cottaging etiquette", and which caused Lord Waddington particular distress.

Cottaging etiquette is a field long neglected by the experts. "Dear Mr Morgan, if a single tap on the cubicle door is ignored, is it courteous to knock again? Or should I wait for the occupants to emerge? Also, I feel I should send a handwritten note of thanks afterwards. However, many of the people I meet seem rather unwilling to give me their names and addresses."

The peers largely agreed that section 28 made little or no sense. But the bishop of Blackburn pointed out that it was "a sign and signal", which as all Christians knew, was very important.

Lord St John, whom I often think of as the thinking man's Dale Winton, made a teasing speech, in which he pointed out that all sexual acts outside marriage were wrong, at least according to the Universal Christian Church, which is what the rest of us call Roman Catholicism.

"These problems are best dealt with in the secrecy of the confessional, not in the glare of the public hall," he said.

This would of course be a perfect solution for unhappy Labour MPs. They could confess what they really thought secretly, to a priest, without having to vote against the dogma of the Universal Tony Blair.

Next came Lord Longford, addressing us briefly before he beetled off, perhaps to be at the side of Harold Shipman in Strangeways.

The problem is that around half of what his lordship says is quite inaudible. This is because of his extreme age.

But he could try speaking a little slower. Presently it all comes out like a stream of consciousness full of rocks.

"Too clever by half, yes, that was Cranborne's grandfather ... gay lobby referred to Lord Boothby as unpaid leader of the homosexual lobby, I've got homosexual medals [sic] ... homosexism [sic] is against Christian rules, deprives people of the supreme joy of having children [sic] ... maybe not homosexism, having five mistresses, sinful, sinful, hmmm, sinful, I'm not saying one is worse than the other ... I know two young men, one serving 10 years for attempted buggery [sic - can you still go to prison for that?] leanings, leanings, should be resisted, hmmm ..."

After which, Lord Russell, son of the philosopher, made a speech which implied that he, almost alone among his peers, lived on the same planet as the rest of us.

Being homosexual, he said, was no more a "choice" than being right or left-handed. But most gays saw section 28 as a "badge of inequality, and if they listened to this debate, they would be unlikely to change their minds."
