webTitle: A coroner's verdict on the dangers of cannabis

fields.headline: A coroner's verdict on the dangers of cannabis
fields.trailText: Your leader on drugs control (February 7) is a reflection of what informed opinion has been aware of for many years, and ignored by two generations of judicial authority for too many of those years.
fields.body:
Your leader on drugs control (February 7) is a reflection of what informed opinion has been aware of for many years, and ignored by two generations of judicial authority for too many of those years. As the coroner, for more than a decade, for the southern district of Greater London, dealing with 4,000 reported deaths per annum, I have yet to come across a death directly caused by or directly connected with cannabis.

A recent parliamentary reply covering the last decade fully supported that conclusion. However, cigarettes are responsible for in the region of 100,000 deaths per annum, alcohol directly causative of over 5,000 and, from my experience, a major contributor to very many more. fields.headline: Rationality and the dome
fields.trailText: All the evidence shows that in the case of new and innovative products and services, consumers behave anything but rationally. The dome (Dome to get Disney touch, February 7) is something new: neither a theme park nor a trade show, it is both fun and educational, it celebrates both the past and the future.
fields.body:
All the evidence shows that in the case of new and innovative products and services, consumers behave anything but rationally. The dome (Dome to get Disney touch, February 7) is something new: neither a theme park nor a trade show, it is both fun and educational, it celebrates both the past and the future.

Consumers have no reference points when trying to evaluate it, and for the vast majority of us no amount of advertising and public relations is likely to be effective. A minority of consumers (usually between 2% and 5%) will buy into almost anything that is new, invariably doing so as soon as it is launched. It is these "innovators" who would have been trooping through the turnstiles in the early weeks.

With any sort of innovation, though, the rest of us are sceptical: perhaps 15% to 20% will never adopt the product, but the cautious majority will hold back. The principal persuasive element - as we tend to block out the 1,400 or so commercial messages we are subjected to each day - is personal recommendation. This is where the "innovators" make their mark: even as management heads roll at Greenwich, there are likely to be around 280,000 enthusiasts telling family, friends and colleagues of their "one amazing day".

Experience suggests that visitor numbers will continue to decline marginally in February, before recovering to January's levels in early spring. By May or June the dome is likely to have achieved break-even, with momentum building throughout the summer. By the end of the year we can expect a further surge caused by the dome's forthcoming scarcity value.

Robin Croft
Business School, University of Glamorgan
rcroft@glam.ac.uk

 The idea that public money is being used to promote commercial interests is quite disturbing, but until Saturday I had not realised that this is the Millennium Dome's main purpose. One of the main culprits was the Manpower-sponsored Work zone, which used an installation piece of hamster cages and Post-it notes to represent the transition from the oppressive dark-ages of the nine-to-five job for life, to the new post-Fordist model of a flexible labour market, where people don't have a career so much as a portfolio of work experiences.

This exhibit gave no thought whatsoever to alternative models of work and production (eg co-ops, LETS) and merely peddled the same rhetoric about the need for people to gain transferable skills in order to fit into the new hi-tech economy (of call centres and data entry, no doubt).

Paul Kent
London
P.A.Kent@qmw.ac.uk

 Why does Mr Blair blame Jennie Page and others for the fact that millions of people, possibly the majority of us, decided the very concept of the dome was a sheer waste of public money and are not prepared to waste more of our hard-earned cash on expensive entry tickets and fiendishly expensive travel just to see a lot of gimmicky exhibits? It is time Mr Blair accepted the responsibility for his own "folly" and sacked himself.

Eileen Mayho
Carnforth, Lancs
eetc.mayho@virgin.net

 It took an hour's queuing to see the Body zone at the dome the other weekend with our daughters, a wait we justified to ourselves because we felt it would be educational. We were right. Putting my three-year-old to bed that night, she asked me: "Mum, do I have escalators in my legs?"

Cecily Engle
London

fields.headline: Selection of the fittest
fields.trailText: Is it possible for the Guardian to report on the selection of women as Labour parliamentary candidates without referring to them as "Blair babes" or similar hackneyed and derogatory terms? It seems not.
fields.body:
Is it possible for the Guardian to report on the selection of women as Labour parliamentary candidates without referring to them as "Blair babes" or similar hackneyed and derogatory terms? It seems not.

Kevin Maguire's critique of advice sent to Labour women parliamentary applicants (Party dress, February 4) manages to work the term "android Blair babes" into the second paragraph. Lucy Ward's more serious attempt at the subject of party support for women standing for selection was headlined Babes in boyland (G2, February 7).

As a woman member of Labour's national parliamentary panel I am glad to receive advice and support on the tricky process of selection. Of course, this advice will be a mix of hints and tips from current MPs, party members who help with training and staff like the national women's officer, Rachel McLean. I, like other women panel members, am perfectly capable of selecting the advice I need from the range of hints and tips given.

Perhaps you would like to subject the advice given to male parliamentary panel members to the same scrutiny? You would find that it contained a similar mix of input on what and what not to wear, ways to answer difficult questions on sensitive subjects and how to manage the formal and informal parts of the selection process. In fact, pretty much what any advice and training for a lengthy interview and selection process might be expected to contain.

Barbara Keeley-Huggett
Sale, Cheshire

 So the Labour party has issued guidelines for potential women candidates. Is it not equally true that dress "guidelines" affect men as well as women? Dress guidelines for men are simple. Wear a dark suit, a reasonable tie, and clean your shoes. Oh, and if you must have a beard, make sure it's tidy.

Surely the guidelines for women are equally simple. The faster women start blending in with men the faster they will gain credibility within traditional male enclaves. Start wearing dark trouser suits and Doc Martens and stop wearing dangling earrings and lipstick - and for God's sake drop the handbag.

As for the Labour party attracting more women candidates - as soon as women stop bleating on about "work life balances" and get out there into the workplace and join in with the rest of the workforce, the quicker they will be taken seriously.

Liz King
Whitley Bay, Tyne and Wear
liz@lizking.co.uk

webTitle: Smoking out a reply from Ken Clarke

fields.headline: Smoking out a reply from Ken Clarke
fields.trailText: Martyn Day writes (Comment, February 3) "The only reason the Guardian journalists were able to gain access to the archives [of BAT] was as a result of legal activity in Minnesota. The very prospect of Imperial Tobacco or Gallagher being forced to take the steps through the British courts would be laughed at by the British judiciary."
fields.body:
Martyn Day writes (Comment, February 3) "The only reason the Guardian journalists were able to gain access to the archives [of BAT] was as a result of legal activity in Minnesota. The very prospect of Imperial Tobacco or Gallagher being forced to take the steps through the British courts would be laughed at by the British judiciary."

These words brought to mind correspondence I exchanged with Kenneth Clarke in 1993 over Mark Fisher's "Right to know" bill when, as a government minister, he wrote: "I am afraid that I think that Mark Fisher's proposals go far too far. The so-called freedom of information legislation in America has mainly benefited commercial competitors, private investigators and sections of the press. I am afraid I would proceed more cautiously than Mark Fisher wishes to do."

Given the latest revelations over BAT's apparent complicity in illegal smuggling activities worldwide, it would be interesting to know, does Kenneth Clarke still hold those views?

David W Miller
Radcliffe-on-Trent, Notts

fields.headline: Hillary, flying solo
fields.standfirst: She's out to prove she can do it by herself
fields.trailText: The official news that Hillary Clinton will stand for the US senate this November is hardly news at all, except perhaps to those who rashly predicted last summer that she would be frightened off by New York's rough-and-tumble politics. The First Lady is no quitter, a fact for which her husband has reason to be thankful; she does not lack courage, nor staying power.
fields.body:
The official news that Hillary Clinton will stand for the US senate this November is hardly news at all, except perhaps to those who rashly predicted last summer that she would be frightened off by New York's rough-and-tumble politics. The First Lady is no quitter, a fact for which her husband has reason to be thankful; she does not lack courage, nor staying power.

And while the past six months of virtual candidacy have hardly been an unmitigated success - Mrs Clinton has in that period lost her opinion poll lead to Rudy Giuliani, New York's acerbic Republican mayor - the pull of high elective office and, for the first time, a national platform entirely in her own right was always likely to be too strong to resist. Mrs Clinton, like many a woman who has both helped create and been overborne by a famous man, who has fought to make her mark in professions - law and politics - dominated by men, who has tried to balance the challenges of family and child-raising with those of a career set against masculine measures of achievement, wants badly to prove her independent worth, to the voters and perhaps also to herself.

She was, she said in announcing her candidacy, surprised at how little voters seemed to know about her before she became First Lady, and what she herself, not Bill or anybody else, stood for. To this end, she has published a pamphlet and video entitled Hillary: The Real Story. Her campaign will emphasise her work in education, adoption, and fostering; her commitment to a higher minimum wage, help for working couples, and improved healthcare; and her record in championing civil rights at home and development abroad.

The dilemma for Mrs Clinton, flying solo, is that the contest may nevertheless be decided not on such issues but by old perceptions and prejudices fomented during her often unhappy, always turbulent times in the White House. Mr Giuliani, exploiting this weakness, demands an end to the "Clinton era", a reminder of her partner's personal misdeeds and the various political scandals and failures to which she has been linked. White women voters, who might have been expected to understand the difficulties facing a woman trying to make it on her own, are especially critical - in part, polls indicate, because Hill did not dump Bill over Monica. That is a heartless verdict, and one which might profitably be reconsidered before election day.

fields.headline: A day of reconciliation
fields.standfirst:
Disarming need not mean defeat

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: If not now, when? If the IRA will not disarm now, when - if ever - will it? That's the question Northern Ireland's increasingly exasperated people must be asking themselves. After all, the pressure on the provos has surely never been greater. Yesterday saw John Hume, the Nobel laureate and leader of the nationalist SDLP, add his own statesmanlike weight to the chorus demanding IRA guns. He said "a gesture" from the provos might break the current impasse.
fields.body:
If not now, when? If the IRA will not disarm now, when - if ever - will it? That's the question Northern Ireland's increasingly exasperated people must be asking themselves. After all, the pressure on the provos has surely never been greater. Yesterday saw John Hume, the Nobel laureate and leader of the nationalist SDLP, add his own statesmanlike weight to the chorus demanding IRA guns. He said "a gesture" from the provos might break the current impasse.

The Unionists would not walk out of the process; Peter Mandelson would not have to suspend the newly-established executive. A simple act of disarmament would get everything back on track. As if to underline the need for decommissioning, Sunday night saw a reminder of the bad old days: a bomb at Mahon's hotel in the Fermanagh town of Irvinestown, put there by the rejectionists of the Continuity IRA. In this kind of atmosphere, how can the IRA possibly keep hold of its arms?

A clue can be found in the rubble of that hotel. For far from showing why the guns have to be handed over right now, Sunday night's attack shows why even those republicans who consider themselves pro-peace are wary of decommissioning. They fear that such a move will split the IRA: hardliners will regard the handover, timed to satisfy Unionist and British demands, as a surrender, and they will bolt. Some may go to the Continuity IRA, others to the Real IRA - the group behind Northern Ireland's worst-ever atrocity, the 1998 bombing of Omagh. In other words, Sunday's explosion serves as a reminder of what can happen if decommissioning is handled wrongly: if weaponry is forced out of the hands of the IRA before that organisation is sufficiently unified to take that step together. One republican raised an other alarming thought at the weekend: how would the moderate wing of the IRA, once it had given up its guns, "persuade" the rejectionist rebels, who were still armed, to come on side? It would hardly be a balanced debate. Put simply, an IRA split is a danger for all who fear a return to violence and bloodshed.

What is needed instead is a context in which republicans can move on arms together. That is not as remote a prospect as it may sound. Indeed it was clearly signalled in the IRA's weekend statement, which agreed that disarmament was a "necessary objective." The way to do that is to remove the symbolic edge - of surrender - and replace it with one of equivalence. If IRA decommissioning can be presented as part of an overall programme of demilitarisation, then it will soon lose its sting. "Only defeated armies hand in their weapons," say the republicans, insisting that since they were never defeated they will not act as if they were. But a situation where all sides "stood down" from the war would be very different. Then the IRA could act like an army ending a war.

Before writing this off as some provo scheme, one should recall the Hillsborough Declaration agreed by Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern last April. That proposed a "national day of reconciliation" in which all sides would make a gesture towards the other: perhaps London would announce a reduction in troop numbers just as loyalist paramilitaries and the IRA handed in some weaponry. There is a balance to that idea, and it could be arranged in time for the May deadline set out in the Good Friday agreement. The IRA will never disarm if that action means defeat and surrender. The task for politicians now is to cast it as something quite different: a symbolic end to a war which nobody won.

fields.headline: The business of teaching
fields.standfirst: Once a high-earning banker, now a teacher: Sarah Allen talks to Phil Revell about life after the City
fields.trailText: Once a high-earning banker, now a teacher: Sarah Allen talks to Phil Revell about life after the City
fields.body:
Each morning Sarah Allen leaves the digs in Cambridge where she is both nanny and home tutor to five children. She drives north to Burrowmoor primary school in March where she's on teaching practice, school experience being an essential part of the one-year teaching qualification she's following at Homerton College.

"Its very different," she says. Something of an understatement really. Last year, Sarah was a high-flying account executive with Gartmore, an investment bank in the City of London. When she eventually qualifies as a teacher, she will earn a fraction of the salary she commanded at Gartmore and during her training she's not earning anything at all.

Sarah joined Gartmore on leaving Exeter University. Her degree was in German and she was looking for an opportunity to use her languages and the chance to experience the bright lights of the city.

"I loved living in London," she says, "but long term, I don't think it's what I wanted to do." Gartmore had an education business partnership with St Paul's Way secondary school in the East End of London. In their lunch hour, Gartmore staff would regularly visit the school to mentor older children and help younger pupils with reading skills. Sarah joined the lunchtime group and found something to replace the excitement of million-pound deals.

"She was a star," says Jim Friedenthal, who coordinated the project at St Paul's. "Very calm." Sarah worked with one boy whose confidence had been shattered by reading problems. "He hated reading," says Jim. "He'd tense up and clench his fists - expecting it all to go badly wrong. She had a tremendous effect - we stopped worrying about him."

Sarah considered teaching as a career whilst at university, but not for long. "Quite frankly, the reason I didn't go straight into teaching was because it was seen as a cop-out. I was persuaded by my family and my peers that I could do something better."

But the contact with St Paul's convinced Sarah that teaching was a job worth doing, an opinion that closer contact with the realities of the role hasn't eroded. "People don't understand the skills needed," she says. "Including me. I thought that a lot of teaching was just applied commonsense. But if you watch a good teacher performing, you see real management skills in action."

Her resignation at Gartmore didn't come as a complete surprise to the company. "People thought 'Good for her' - it was what she wanted to do," says company spokesman Peter Yandle. Sarah applied to Homerton to do the post-graduate certificate in education and her new career became real with the first posting to Burrowmoor.

She's still getting used to the different rhythms and expectations of the job. A typical day at Gartmore saw her journey across London to begin a hectic round of business calls and meetings punctuated by lunch with a high-profile client. Sarah was very much the high-flier, with a business suit - "no padded shoulders, though" - and ambition to match. Sarah has registered for the fast-track programme that offers some teachers the possibility of a rapid rise through the career structure. "I am ambitious... learning the management skills, having further training... I see that as a very positive thing," she says.

Other contrasts with her life in the City are more mundane. "You're more constrained by the job," she says. "You can't have a cup of coffee, eat a Kit-Kat or go to the loo during the lesson." Chance acquaintances who would have been "very impressed" with her City role clearly see teaching in different terms. "It's not really seen as a serious career option - and I'm sure that's what puts some people off." Sarah has no regrets about the move and the teaching practice at Burrowmoor is "going really well". This time next year, she'll have a class of her own.

Asked whether the company are concerned about losing any more staff to the education sector, Peter Yandle was untroubled.

"I don't think we're expecting a flood of people leaving to become teachers," he says.

fields.headline: Snap decisions
fields.standfirst: The A-level photography syllabus has been saved from drastic changes by teachers and photographers
fields.trailText: The A-level photography syllabus has been saved from drastic changes by teachers and photographers
fields.body:
The government has backed down from controversial plans to introduce a watered-down A-level photography syllabus this year, after a storm of protest from teachers and practitioners.

Although the subject will be studied as part of a new-look art and design (photography) course from September, the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority has agreed to the critics' key demand that students should be able to sit a written paper covering aesthetic, historical and technical theory.

The 11th-hour climbdown has been welcomed by art colleges and universities, which had backed a high-profile campaign for an academic component to be retained. Practitioners also feared that ministers were trying to downgrade the subject, despite burgeoning public interest in arguably one of the most important visual arts. GCSE photography was quietly scrapped in 1998 and campaigners feared it might suffer the same fate at A level.

Behind the scenes, the outcome represents a victory for one man - a photography teacher at a Hertfordshire comprehensive school - who singlehandedly took on the establishment and won.

Ashley la Grange, head of photography at Rickmansworth School, first learned of the proposals in last February in correspondence with an examining board. Mr la Grange, who has taught photography in the UK for 13 years since moving here from his native Zimbabwe, was alarmed to discover that they appeared to be going ahead after a supposed "consultation". As part of the government's shake-up of A levels this year, most exam syllabuses were being revised and brought up to date. But on contacting other figures in the photography world - including universities and colleges - Mr la Grange soon discovered that no one else seemed to be aware of the plans.

When not dashing between the school's darkroom and pool (he also teaches swimming), Mr la Grange set about enlisting the support of leading lights in the photographic world to press ministers for a proper review of photography teaching within the context of the needs of higher education and the workplace. They did not dispute the fact that it was time to update the syllabus - they simply wanted to have a say in it.

To say the list of supporters makes impressive reading is an understatement. They included veteran photographers Eve Arnold and Don McCullin, as well as representatives of the top galleries, museums and colleges; Royal Photographic Society chief executive Barry Lane; the V&A's curator of photography, Mark Haworth-Booth; the Royal College of Art's professor of photography, Olivier Richon; Photographers' Gallery director Paul Wombell; Martin Parr of photo agency Magnum; the London College of Printing's Julian Rodriguez; the University of Westminster's Andy Golding.

The multi-million pound photographic industry, represented by giants such as Kodak, also added its weight to the campaign, arguing that a review of the A-level syllabus was in any case essential because of the arrival of digital photography.

"Every single person I got hold of agreed to back the campaign and not one had been involved in the consultation," says Mr la Grange. The supporters signed a letter of protest to Nick Tate, chief executive of the QCA, which was despatched at the end of May. The response, recalls la Grange, was a deafening silence.

But over the following weeks, the publicity machine began to roll as the trade press became interested and Labour MP Austin Mitchell - a keen snapper himself - started to ask awkward questions. Behind the scenes, senior government education adviser Lord Puttnam was alerted to the plans and was privately extremely concerned. His worries were never publicly aired, but as chair of a government committee on creative education and chairman of the advisory board of the newly reopened National Museum of Photography, Film and Television in Bradford, he was alarmed at any prospect of the subject being "downgraded".

The QCA's fightback was weak, however. It claimed that people were getting "hung-up" about the change of title and said the changes were being brought about because of "dwindling numbers" taking A-level photography. In fact, the Assessment and Qualifications Alliance points out that although numbers for the Associated Examining Board course dropped off from a peak of 1,600 in the mid-90s because of the withdrawal of the GCSE course, they have since held up at a very respectable 1,000-plus every year.

In November, Mr la Grange was invited by the QCA to a meeting to discuss photographic qualifications in general, which include many vocational qualifications such as City & Guilds, NVQs and GNVQs. By the end of the year, there was light at the end of the tunnel and the QCA officials seemed to acknowledge that they were much better informed than they had been before. The breakthrough came when they wrote to examining bodies to tell them they could offer students an optional written paper.

Rob Taylor of the QCA said: "We're recognising the concerns that have been raised. This is being taken forward within a wider review of all the photography qualifications that are available." Already, the AQA has welcomed the move and has confirmed - with great enthusiasm - that it will offer students the written paper.

Andy Golding, head of photography at the University of Westminster, added: "This is very welcome news. Balance is vital within these courses, and it is essential that students coming on to our very popular degree courses have more than just a practical grounding in the subject."

A victorious Mr la Grange said: "We may have lost the title, but we have won all the arguments. It was essential that the academic element was retained. This will ensure that candidates studying this syllabus will have a broad-based understanding of the subject in its full context and be able to make informed decisions about their future direction in the subject."

Camera competition

The Guardian, in association with Agfa and Jessops, next month will be offering schools the chance to win up to £9,000 worth of digital cameras and equipment in a big photographic competition. The best entries will be displayed on Education Unlimited and judged by Guardian picture editor Eamonn McCabe. Full details can be found in our educ@guardian supplement on March 21.

webTitle: Why no one wants to talk about it

fields.headline: Why no one wants to talk about it
fields.standfirst:
All secondary schools have to cover sex education, but how is up to them. One thing's for sure: they're keeping quiet about section 28
Read the latest guidelines
fields.trailText: All secondary schools have to cover sex education, but how is up to them. One thing's for sure: they're keeping quiet about section 28
fields.body:
Schools are turning us down by the minute. One council press officer contacts every likely comprehensive in the borough. She phones back a couple of hours later. "Sorry, no luck. It's just too sensitive an issue." A headteacher says he'd love to see his school in the newspaper, "but this subject is too dangerous... every which way we lose." Another whispers that the Daily Mail is on the rampage, as if she expects the phone to be bugged.

If anybody wants evidence of the damage caused by section 28 of the Local Government Act 1988, this paranoia is it. All we have asked is whether the Guardian could come in to discuss sex education with a group of pupils. One by one, the headteachers tell us that, off the record, they consider sex education terribly important, but if they are seen to encourage an overly liberal or broad approach to the subject, they could create havoc. They can see the headlines already, a return to the reactionary hyperbole of yesteryear - loony lefty school promotes poofters; sack the pornography pushers.

It's surprising that Tony Blair didn't foresee a problem in scrapping section 28 - introduced by Margaret Thatcher in 1988 to stop local authorities "promoting homosexuality" as a way of life, and misinterpreted by many people as meaning that telling children homosexuality was an alternative to heterosexuality was now out of bounds. He seems to have been unaware that homophobia is the last legitimate prejudice.

Hence the fierce and diverse opposition from the likes of Cardinal Thomas Winning, who called homosexuality a "perversion" and likened the gay lobby's campaign to bombardment by Nazi war planes; Brian Souter, the owner of Stagecoach, who has donated £500,000 to the save section 28 campaign; and Peter Kilfoyle, who is alleged to have cited the proposed scrapping of section 28 as a reason for leaving the front bench.

For once, Blair seems to have misjudged the mood of Middle England.

At last a school agrees to see us. Step forward the heroic Hodge Hill in Birmingham, a 1,300-strong, multicultural, inner-city comprehensive. Trevor Edinborough, the gently spoken headteacher, seems a little twitchy. He takes us into a cell-like room to explain the terms. By all means talk about sex education, he says, but please don't mention the section. "We could upset a lot of parents." I can't help thinking of Fawlty Towers.

I tell him I'm more interested in finding out what sex education actually involves these days, and how important pupils feel it is. He looks relieved. "For us this is a central part of the curriculum and it will grow. It's very much at the heart of the work we do with young children."

Sex education is optional in primary and junior schools and compulsory in secondaries. But it is a long way from being a structured part of the national curriculum. Schools have to do something, anything, and it is up to their board of governors to decide what exactly. Trevor Edinborough says he would like to see the government provide a proper framework for schools to build their courses round. John Bennett, the health education, citizenship and community education director for Birmingham local education authority, believes this will only happen once section 28 is scrapped.

Bennett says that in some areas of sex education, progress has been made. "When we did it at secondary school, it was straight biology. Now you do a lot of the basic biology in primary school." He tells me about a television series he made in which 5- to 7-year-olds were introduced to the correct names for body parts used in reproduction, the 7- to 9-year-olds watched a live birth, and the 9- to 11-year-olds were discussing the intricacies of relationships.

He's right. It is a far cry from my school days in the mid-seventies. We were given a biology teacher who drew a couple of organs on the blackboard and then retired with post-traumatic stress. The hardest kid in the year fainted when we were shown a film of childbirth. We were 14 at the time. A few months later, he got a classmate pregnant. When the girls were away from school for a few days, we didn't ask questions.

Jane Bonner is Hodge Hill's personal health and social education teacher. In the old days we would have called her a sex education teacher, but she patiently explains that her specialism involves rather more than sex. She introduces me to a group of 10 14- to 15-year-old pupils working together on a project based on the novel Junk, in which two 14-year-olds run away together, end up in a squat and are forced to confront drugs, violence, sex and the whole shebang.

Although the group is mixed, they have segregated themselves into boys at one end of the table, girls at the other. One by one, they explain why sex education is important.

Derek Evans says: "It's about how to be in a relationship. The pressures of growing up - you know, like periods for girls and puberty and peer pressure."

Susan Lenihan is typical of the girls - she talks in a quiet, considered way. "It's about much more than sex. It prepares you for life, the problems with relationships, and what you can get out of them." The group are relaxed with the word "relationship". A word we would have dismissed as poofy at school in the seventies. Intermingled with "relationship" are "contraceptive", "unwanted pregnancy", "responsibilities".

Noel Smithen is ladsy and funny with a touch of the Ali Gs. He talks a lot, makes his mates giggle, and veers between the sensible and ridiculous. "There never used to be so many teenage pregnancies, because people didn't know much about it, because people weren't taught about it." The group tend to say "it" rather than "sex".

"No, that's not true," the rest of the group chorus. "Just because we know about it, doesn't make us more likely to do it."

But Noel is on a roll. "After a lesson listening to sex this and sex that, and you go home and you're with your girlfriend you probably want to try it out don't you?" The group erupts into laughter.

Derek Evans seems a more representative voice. "If you didn't have the knowledge, then you'd be out of school doing what you can, getting girls under 16 pregnant and you'd have the police involved, you'd never be able to grow up properly because you'd have a child, you'd never be able to go out and enjoy yourself. Some parents wouldn't accept it and they'd put you out on the street." The group nod at the devastating scenario.

Afterwards, John Bennett tells me there are many important myths to dispel. He says it's certainly not true, as Noel suggests, that there are more teenage pregnancies these days, but the figures are not as encouraging as they could be.

"In the 1970s, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands had about the same rate of teenage pregnancies - around 70 per thousand. We've reduced our rate to about 53 per thousand, while the Dutch have reduced theirs to about eight or nine per thousand."

How did they manage it? He talks about a multi-agency approach involving the Catholic and Dutch Reform churches, the government, the education authorities, and how sex education was made more explicit and access to services was improved. Most telling is the fact that while the average age of first intercourse continues to decline by a year a decade in Britain (currently between 16 and 17), the Netherlands has steadied itself round the 18 mark.

I ask the pupils whether they would prefer to be taught as a single-sex group. All but one say yes. "Some girls don't feel comfortable with boys around them, and boys can be immature," says Iyesha Williams.

The teacher, Jane Bonner, interrupts to say they will be doing some single-sex work in the future where it will be easier to look at more controversial topics in depth. She talks about the areas they cover in the Child Development GCSE - abortion, IVF etc. "In social education we don't have the time, or rather we don't make the time, to look at one subject in detail."

Ashley Francis is one of the few boys taking the GCSE. "In Child Development we learn about every aspect, whereas in Social Education some aspects are left out because of the feelings of other people." Ashley is a sensitive, clued-up boy. He says one of the good things about sex education is "You don't just talk about your feelings about relationships, but how other people feel as well - what your girlfriend may be scared about as well as what you may be scared about."

The group is open, mature and easy with each other. So open that David Bromley admits: "I didn't know much about all this before we started."

We move on to homosexuality, and the debate becomes more heated. None of the children feels they shouldn't be taught about homosexuality, but Noel sums up the feeling when he says: "I don't think it should be discussed that much because it's a minority." They argue that attitudes have changed over the years - because of programmes like Jerry Springer, we are more tolerant of difference.

A recent survey by the lesbian and gay pressure group Stonewall revealed that 64% of women thought section 28 should be repealed, while only 43% of men did. And it is when the school group discuss homosexuality that there is the most noticeable difference in gender attitudes. The girls are far more tolerant, though even most of them think homosexuality is "unnatural".

Iyesha says: "It's important to talk about gay sex to tell people about the dangers." None of the group appears to be aware that in Britain last year more people contracted Aids through straight sex than gay sex.

The longer we talk about the gay issue, the more the prejudices emerge. The same prejudices we hear in the adult world, on telly, in the newspapers. Derek has strong views. He delivers them perfectly reasonably, without a hint of the ferocity that so often accompanies bigotry. "I think it's sick, to be honest. Man and woman were brought together by God for man and woman, not just for two men or two women. There was something on the news about two gay men adopting a child, and then you get people at school saying 'who's your mum?', and the kid says 'it's Bill'." Everyone agrees that it is unfair for gay men to adopt, that the child would be ridiculed at school. It's hard to disagree with them - no one knows better about bullying at school than schoolkids.

Trevor Edinborough didn't want us to talk about section 28, the political issue. But he knew as well as I did that if we were talking about sexuality, we would also end up talking about homosexuality, the human issue. Not promoting, not proselytsing, but talking. As most teachers do at some point most weeks.

If anything, the pupils' conversation shows what a a sham the whole section 28 debate really is. Promote homosexuality? Pervert a bunch of schoolkids? Who are they kidding? The best any realistic teacher could hope is to damp down the prejudices of the majority.

Meanwhile, there's no stopping Derek. "I don't know how anybody could do it, actually. I don't know how anybody could be attracted to the same sex. I think they should all be shot or something." The girls tut. "It's up to other people to do what they do," says Susan.

I ask again whether they think we are more open about homosexuality these days. Yes, definitely, they answer. Does that mean it would be easier to admit you are gay in school than years ago? No, says Noel with surprising softness. "You can discuss it now, but if you come out and say you're this or that, you might as well just leave the school."

John Bennett, the health education, citizenship and community education director for Birmingham local education authority, believes this will only happen once section 28 is scrapped. Bennett says that in some areas of sex education, progress has been made. "When we did it at secondary school, it was straight biology. Now you do a lot of the basic biology in primary school." He tells me about a television series he made in which 5- to 7-year-olds were introduced to the correct names for body parts used in reproduction, the 7- to 9-year-olds watched a live birth, and the 9- to 11-year-olds were discussing the intricacies of relationships. He's right. It is a far cry from my school days in the mid-seventies. We were given a biology teacher who drew a couple of organs on the blackboard and then retired with post-traumatic stress. The hardest kid in the year fainted when we were shown a film of childbirth. We were 14 at the time. A few months later, he got a classmate pregnant. When the girls were away from school for a few days, we didn't ask questions. Jane Bonner is Hodge Hill's personal health and social education teacher. In the old days we would have called her a sex education teacher, but she patiently explains that her specialism involves rather more than sex. She introduces me to a group of 10 14- to 15-year-old pupils working together on a project based on the novel Junk, in which two 14-year-olds run away together, end up in a squat and are forced to confront drugs, violence, sex and the whole shebang. Although the group is mixed, they have segregated themselves into boys at one end of the table, girls at the other. One by one, they explain why sex education is important. Derek Evans says: "It's about how to be in a relationship. The pressures of growing up - you know, like periods for girls and puberty and peer pressure." Susan Lenihan is typical of the girls - she talks in a quiet, considered way. "It's about much more than sex. It prepares you for life, the problems with relationships, and what you can get out of them." The group are relaxed with the word "relationship". A word we would have dismissed as poofy at school in the seventies. Intermingled with "relationship" are "contraceptive", "unwanted pregnancy", "responsibilities". Noel Smithen is ladsy and funny with a touch of the Ali Gs. He talks a lot, makes his mates giggle, and veers between the sensible and ridiculous. "There never used to be so many teenage pregnancies, because people didn't know much about it, because people weren't taught about it." The group tend to say "it" rather than "sex". "No, that's not true," the rest of the group chorus. "Just because we know about it, doesn't make us more likely to do it." But Noel is on a roll. "After a lesson listening to sex this and sex that, and you go home and you're with your girlfriend you probably want to try it out don't you?" The group erupts into laughter. Derek Evans seems a more representative voice. "If you didn't have the knowledge, then you'd be out of school doing what you can, getting girls under 16 pregnant and you'd have the police involved, you'd never be able to grow up properly because you'd have a child, you'd never be able to go out and enjoy yourself. Some parents wouldn't accept it and they'd put you out on the street." The group nod at the devastating scenario. Afterwards, John Bennett tells me there are many important myths to dispel. He says it's certainly not true, as Noel suggests, that there are more teenage pregnancies these days, but the figures are not as encouraging as they could be. "In the 1970s, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands had about the same rate of teenage pregnancies - around 70 per thousand. We've reduced our rate to about 53 per thousand, while the Dutch have reduced theirs to about eight or nine per thousand." How did they manage it? He talks about a multi-agency approach involving the Catholic and Dutch Reform churches, the government, the education authorities, and how sex education was made more explicit and access to services was improved. Most telling is the fact that while the average age of first intercourse continues to decline by a year a decade in Britain (currently between 16 and 17), the Netherlands has steadied itself round the 18 mark. I ask the pupils whether they would prefer to be taught as a single-sex group. All but one say yes. "Some girls don't feel comfortable with boys around them, and boys can be immature," says Iyesha Williams. The teacher, Jane Bonner, interrupts to say they will be doing some single-sex work in the future where it will be easier to look at more controversial topics in depth. She talks about the areas they cover in the Child Development GCSE - abortion, IVF etc. "In social education we don't have the time, or rather we don't make the time, to look at one subject in detail." Ashley Francis is one of the few boys taking the GCSE. "In Child Development we learn about every aspect, whereas in Social Education some aspects are left out because of the feelings of other people." Ashley is a sensitive, clued-up boy. He says one of the good things about sex education is "You don't just talk about your feelings about relationships, but how other people feel as well - what your girlfriend may be scared about as well as what you may be scared about." The group is open, mature and easy with each other. So open that David Bromley admits: "I didn't know much about all this before we started." We move on to homosexuality, and the debate becomes more heated. None of the children feels they shouldn't be taught about homosexuality, but Noel sums up the feeling when he says: "I don't think it should be discussed that much because it's a minority." They argue that attitudes have changed over the years - because of programmes like Jerry Springer, we are more tolerant of difference. A recent survey by the lesbian and gay pressure group Stonewall revealed that 64% of women thought section 28 should be repealed, while only 43% of men did. And it is when the school group discuss homosexuality that there is the most noticeable difference in gender attitudes. The girls are far more tolerant, though even most of them think homosexuality is "unnatural". Iyesha says: "It's important to talk about gay sex to tell people about the dangers." None of the group appears to be aware that in Britain last year more people contracted Aids through straight sex than gay sex. The longer we talk about the gay issue, the more the prejudices emerge. The same prejudices we hear in the adult world, on telly, in the newspapers. Derek has strong views. He delivers them perfectly reasonably, without a hint of the ferocity that so often accompanies bigotry. "I think it's sick, to be honest. Man and woman were brought together by God for man and woman, not just for two men or two women. There was something on the news about two gay men adopting a child, and then you get people at school saying 'who's your mum?', and the kid says 'it's Bill'." Everyone agrees that it is unfair for gay men to adopt, that the child would be ridiculed at school. It's hard to disagree with them - no one knows better about bullying at school than schoolkids. Trevor Edinborough didn't want us to talk about section 28, the political issue. But he knew as well as I did that if we were talking about sexuality, we would also end up talking about homosexuality, the human issue. Not promoting, not proselytsing, but talking. As most teachers do at some point most weeks. If anything, the pupils' conversation shows what a a sham the whole section 28 debate really is. Promote homosexuality? Pervert a bunch of schoolkids? Who are they kidding? The best any realistic teacher could hope is to damp down the prejudices of the majority. Meanwhile, there's no stopping Derek. "I don't know how anybody could do it, actually. I don't know how anybody could be attracted to the same sex. I think they should all be shot or something." The girls tut. "It's up to other people to do what they do," says Susan. I ask again whether they think we are more open about homosexuality these days. Yes, definitely, they answer. Does that mean it would be easier to admit you are gay in school than years ago? No, says Noel with surprising softness. "You can discuss it now, but if you come out and say you're this or that, you might as well just leave the school."

webTitle: Plans take shape on performance pay

fields.headline: Plans take shape on performance pay
fields.standfirst: John Carvel reports on the latest moves in the salary battle
fields.trailText: John Carvel reports on the latest moves in the salary battle
fields.body:
There can be little doubt now that performance pay will be introduced into teaching from September, as the government intended. The question is whether the scheme is being rushed so fast for political reasons that it will not work as well as it could have done to invigorate older staff and provide incentives for the best young graduates.

In spite of continuing opposition from the National Union of Teachers, it is not realistic to imagine large numbers of hard-up staff refusing the offer of an extra £2,000 a year to carry on with the job they are doing anyway.

The leadership of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers is enthusiastic about the latest formulation of the plan. The National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers remains sceptical about the bureaucracy involved, but thinks it would be daft to prevent members earning more money. It would be an exercise of amazingly principled restraint by NUT members to forswear big pay increases being seized by their colleagues from other unions.

The first stage of the government's plan involves the creation of a higher salary band for teachers on the current classroom maximum of £23,193 (rising to £23,958 from April as a result of the annual settlement announced last week).

To reach this higher salary scale, they will have to pass a "threshold" assessment to prove their professionalism. There are about 220,000 teachers in England at the current maximum and David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, has said he expects a majority to pass the test - although not necessarily in the first year.

Those who reach the higher scale will be able to progress eventually to a maximum of £30,000 a year without having to take on management responsibilities.

So far, so good. But the scheme will be discredited if procedures are not put in place to make sure that the right teachers pass the threshold. If too many wrong decisions are made and grievance builds up among staff, Blunkett risks an exodus.

The assessment procedure has been taking shape over the last few days as confidential drafts were discussed with the teacher unions. The latest version seen by the Guardian showed eight standards that teachers will be required to meet, covering "professional characteristics, knowledge and understanding, teaching and assessment, pupil outcomes and wider professional effectiveness." Heads will be expected to refuse the performance uplift if a teacher fails to pass under every heading. Decisions will be monitored by spot checks from a team of government assessors.

Some of the criteria look quite vague: for example, teachers will be expected to show they are "effective professionals who challenge and support all pupils to do their best".

Others are more hard-edged. The most controversial will be the requirement that pupils "attain good marks or grades in any relevant national tests or examinations, or school based assessment... relative to pupils' prior attainment and in the context of national levels of achievement." Individual teachers will be knocked back if their pupils do not progress as fast as the average for their type of school.

Although they will be allowed to plead special circumstances, such as high pupil turnover or absence during tests, it is strange that a teacher should be judged against results to be expected from the school as a whole, rather than the standard that could reasonably be expected from the relevant class.

Ministers cannot delay the scheme because the Treasury has already offered £1bn over the next two years and there is a political imperative to have something in place by the next election.

But they cannot be sure how heads will judge their staff. Some may be keen to reward as many as the assessors permit. Others may be fearful of the impact on school budgets two years down the line when the government stops funding the scheme from the centre. How can ministers be sure there is fairness across the country, with the desired proportion of teachers reaching the higher grade? Will a day's training for every head be enough to gear up the system?

The juggernaut is rolling. But there was menace in the warning last week from the School Teachers' Review Body. "We have concerns about the pressures of the introductory phase," it said. "The extent of the training necessary should not be underestimated. In all this we are conscious of how much the handling of the initial phase will determine the longer-term success of the new arrangements."

The timetable

February: government consultation paper on how teachers can cross the pay threshold

March/April: scheme finalised and application forms sent to schools

June 5: deadline for teachers to submit applications

July 31: deadline for heads to send decisions to consultants handling the scheme

September 1: first teachers get £2,000 uplift

Autumn term: assessors continue vetting heads' decisions: extra pay for successful applicants backdated to September 1.

fields.headline: Trouble in the ranks
fields.standfirst: Last week's decision by Labour students not to field a candidate in the NUS presidential elections breaks an 18-year tradition.  Andrew Pakes spells out why, while below John Carvel gives another view
fields.trailText: Last week's decision by Labour students not to field a candidate in the NUS presidential elections breaks an 18-year tradition. Andrew Pakes spells out why, while below John Carvel gives another view
fields.body:
With only nine weeks to go before the National Union of Students' conference, the election campaign is raging, but this time there will be no Labour candidate in the presidential race.

Education has been through a revolution in recent years with the mass expansion of student numbers, the increase in part-time learners, the incorporation of colleges, cuts in staff pay, the introduction of tuition fees and removal of the grant.

Even if policy hasn't always lived up to political rhetoric, these changes have re-introduced a social mission to tertiary education. Post-16 education is now about the learning age and pushing aside the barriers to participation.

Sadly the union has failed to live up to this challenge. Even as current union president, I have been unable to get the student movement to work together. The NUS has become dominated by petty student politics and infighting among political factions. Yet most student activists don't see their role as political.

For example, there has been public outcry at the government's decision to repeal Section 28 on how homosexuality was discussed in schools. The student movement has been largely silent. It is shocking that so many student activists did not take to the campaign and display disgust at such a prejudiced backlash. Surely, it is a basic role of the student movement to take notice of an issue that has a real impact on the lives of so many young students.

Or take the minimum wage. If it wasn't for the work of Labour students in the NUS, and associated colleagues in trades unions, no one in the student movement would have led the campaign against age differentials.

Labour students have become trapped in a cycle of fighting to win the presidency and forgetting to campaign among students. While the student movement becomes more right-wing and apolitical, the union's national executive committee is drifting to the left.

This reality gap is bad for the NUS and is failing students. In an average week too much of my time is spent being threatened by small political groups pursuing their own agendas.

The union needs to re-invent political debate and overhaul its structures if it is to modernise and involve more students. The expansion in part-time study, short courses, and franchise students have eroded the traditional student identity. Students spend less time on campus and have fewer opportunities to attend union meetings; many don't even view themselves as students.

The union is based on a federal membership system and each college union decides whether to affiliate to the national body. With increasing methods of study the union now needs to adopt individual membership to allow students to participate directly. Students' unions will remain the core unit of the student movement but the NUS needs to widen its appeal. Imagine the changes once the government reaches its target of one in two young people attending university.

Labour students are not standing for president this year because we want to free both the NUS and ourselves from the obsession with student politics. Labour students got involved in the NUS because we had a political agenda to change society and modernise the national union. In 1982 when we took over the presidency there was no women's officer, further education officer or black students campaign and the political discourse was dominated by ideological dogma.

Labour Students still have a vision for modernisation and reform but none can be achieved while there is distrust over the president's motives

Too many are people involved in the NUS for their own benefit and too cynical to have any concept of what they want to achieve. Labour students want to fight for a political national union, help build Labour clubs on campus, and engage in a debate with the Tories and Liberal Democrats instead of the endless war of words with the Socialist Workers, Socialist Action, Trotskyists and other groups on campus who will never win elections outside of the union. Labour students want to be part of a wider coalition of student activists leading the call for modernisation.

Last week in the Ceredigion by-election we saw Labour come fourth at the polls. The rightwing Tory threat is still real. At the next general election there will be a clear choice between Labour and the Conservatives; students need to understand that choice. It isn't about believing Labour is always correct but sharing Labour's values and arguing for change where you disagree. If the Conservatives are returned to power they will devastate the education system and oversee a return to inequality.

The NUS must modernise and change if it is to survive. Labour students will still stay active in the union, but now we want freedom from the constraints of the presidential office and the opportunity to fight for the left and centre left once again.

 Andrew Pakes is president of the National Union of Students.

Another take

Andrew Pakes's explanation of why Labour students will not be running a candidate for the NUS presidency may leave readers wondering whether the next generation of Blairite politicians have taken leave of their senses.

Why on earth would they stand aside from a contest for the only job in the student movement with a national profile? If New Labour students cannot win student elections, why should they have any credibility in the wider world?

The probable answer is that they are standing aside because they know they would lose the vote and do not want to embarrass Tony Blair by demonstrating student disaffection with New Labour.

Labour control of the union dates from 1982 and was a reaction to the Thatcherite control of national governments.

Pakes won with slender majorities in 1998 and 1999. Now that the government is encountering mid-term difficulties, a Labour student candidate would probably be trounced by the hard left. Far better then to swing the dwindling Labour vote on campus behind an alternative anti-Trot candidate.

It did not have to be like this. The NUS took a wrong turn when it decided to campaign against means-tested tuition fees, while supporting the government's move to scrap the maintenance grant. It found itself opposing the payment of £1,000 by better-off students while agreeing to the loss of up to £2,000 a year for poorer ones. That did not fit snugly with a policy of widening access to higher education and fighting hardship.

Pakes has managed to row back from that position, and a period without control of the top NUS job may help Labour students to get back in touch with campus grassroots.

In the long run, Pakes is unlikely to be the last of the line of Labour presidents.

fields.headline: Bridging loans
fields.standfirst: Labour wants Britain, like the US, to profit from its academic research. But its latest plans are treading on a few toes
fields.trailText: Labour wants Britain, like the US, to profit from its academic research. But its latest plans are treading on a few toes
fields.body:
Government officials are considering plans to finance further links between US and UK universities in a bid to instil the American entrepreneurial spirit among UK academics.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is convinced that cross-Atlantic academic alliances will help translate the UK's strong research record into future profit-making hi-tech and e-commerce companies.

Brown has asked the treasury's enterprise team to look into the possibility of funding formal Anglo-American university link-ups after last year's announcement of a new institute promoting industry-academic links, run jointly by Cambridge University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Universities such as Oxford and Warwick, that previously failed to secure government funds for their plans for enterprise centres, were outraged when Brown suddenly announced that the government was committing £68m over five years to the MIT-Cambridge institute.

The chancellor's usual prudent public financial constraints and standard university bidding competitions were waived to make way for the institute. And the vast majority of the government's grant - £50m - will end up going to Cambridge, Massachusetts, rather than Cambridge, England. The grant dwarfed the £34m the government distributed to 18 universities earlier in the year to establish eight enterprise centres promoting university-industry links.

Dr David Livesey, who last week was announced as the Cambridge director of the MIT-Cambridge institute, said that details of the project were still being finalised with government officials.

"Although this project is unusual in its conception, origination and funding route, it is accepted by all parties that none of that exempts it from the appropriate disciplines of public accountability and expenditure rules," he said.

Brown instigated the MIT-Cambridge deal following a recent east-coast tour of the US, when he spent time at the MIT campus. According to recent estimates, the 4,000 companies founded by MIT's students and staff generate $232bn (£146bn) in annual sales, equivalent to the 24th largest economy in the world. Worldwide the companies employ 1.1m people. While Cambridge's own explosion of small hi-tech companies has yet to spawn a genuine global heavyweight business, last year's dramatic growth of local electronics firm ARM Holdings has convinced many dealers in stock markets that more commercial successes are in the pipeline.

Receiving £84m in total over five years from UK government and industry funds, the institute will oversee four main activities: an exchange programme for undergraduates on business and e-commerce courses; joint research into improving the entrepreneurial spirit in UK companies; senior management courses; and leading a national network with other university enterprise centres.

Other UK universities, though, are concerned that the MIT-Cambridge model should not be imposed elsewhere in the academic sector. Universities such as Nottingham and Bristol, for example, have forged their own links with US universities as part of enterprise centres.

One driver for linking up with US universities is that they are at the forefront of internet-based distance-learning courses in the growing global higher education market. The London School of Economics last year announced a partnership with the US universities of Columbia, Chicago and Stanford to supply the academic content for online distance-learning courses. Publishing and media companies such as Pearson and News International are understood to be courting universities in an attempt to strike up partnerships to secure a place in the market.

The threat of powerful US based virtual universities, primed to exploit the world's higher education markets, has provoked heads of the large research-led Russell group universities in the UK to forge a consortium with Australian, Canadian and Chinese institutions. Discussions are under way to create an agreement whereby students could move seamlessly from one institution to another during degree courses.

 Dr Lee Elliot Major is deputy editor of Research Fortnight.

"Although this project is unusual in its conception, origination and funding route, it is accepted by all parties that none of that exempts it from the appropriate disciplines of public accountability and expenditure rules," he said. Brown instigated the MIT-Cambridge deal following a recent east-coast tour of the US, when he spent time at the MIT campus. According to recent estimates, the 4,000 companies founded by MIT's students and staff generate $232bn (£146bn) in annual sales, equivalent to the 24th largest economy in the world. Worldwide the companies employ 1.1m people. While Cambridge's own explosion of small hi-tech companies has yet to spawn a genuine global heavyweight business, last year's dramatic growth of local electronics firm ARM Holdings has convinced many dealers in stock markets that more commercial successes are in the pipeline. Receiving £84m in total over five years from UK government and industry funds, the institute will oversee four main activities: an exchange programme for undergraduates on business and e-commerce courses; joint research into improving the entrepreneurial spirit in UK companies; senior management courses; and leading a national network with other university enterprise centres. Other UK universities, though, are concerned that the MIT-Cambridge model should not be imposed elsewhere in the academic sector. Universities such as Nottingham and Bristol, for example, have forged their own links with US universities as part of enterprise centres. One driver for linking up with US universities is that they are at the forefront of internet-based distance-learning courses in the growing global higher education market. The London School of Economics last year announced a partnership with the US universities of Columbia, Chicago and Stanford to supply the academic content for online distance-learning courses. Publishing and media companies such as Pearson and News International are understood to be courting universities in an attempt to strike up partnerships to secure a place in the market. The threat of powerful US based virtual universities, primed to exploit the world's higher education markets, has provoked heads of the large research-led Russell group universities in the UK to forge a consortium with Australian, Canadian and Chinese institutions. Discussions are under way to create an agreement whereby students could move seamlessly from one institution to another during degree courses.  Dr Lee Elliot Major is deputy editor of Research Fortnight.

webTitle: Britannia needs linguists to push 'cool' image

fields.headline: Britannia needs linguists to push 'cool' image
fields.standfirst: The UK will never attract more foreign students unless it puts its language learning in order, starting in our schools
fields.trailText: The UK will never attract more foreign students unless it puts its language learning in order, starting in our schools
fields.body:
A £5m campaign to make Tony Blair's concept of a modern-minded, more pro-Europe "Cool Britannia" attractive to overseas students is all very well, but it will take more than a marketing makeover to make it happen.

The keys to a positive attitude to mainland Europe and to its students lie in openness and exposure to the cultures, people and institutions of other European countries. All these are mediated through language, theirs as well as our own. For this reason the European Union has repeatedly stressed the importance of language learning, both in achieving socio-political objectives such as mutual understanding, respect for pluralism and the development of European citizenship, and in achieving economic aims such as the mobility of capital and labour in a multilingual, multicultural, economic area.

But while language learning is thriving in most parts of mainland Europe, in Britain the market share of "specialist" language learning at A-level and beyond is in decline, with French being particularly hard hit.

The problem is visible in our schools. The increase in the number of candidates taking GCSE in a modern foreign language is not being accompanied by a corresponding all-round increase in the number taking a language at A level.

So what is putting them off? Perhaps the lack of congruence between GCSE and A level in terms of syllabus and methodology has made the transition from GCSE to A level a daunting one for many students.

Perhaps the national curriculum has left less space for students to study two foreign languages than was previously so and thereby undermined early specialisation in languages - a 1997 Teacher Training Agency report certainly identified the dwindling number of dual linguists at GCSE and A level as one of the causes of the shortage in teacher supply.

Perhaps young people are now finding their role models and preferred life styles elsewhere in the English-speaking world, and not aspiring to live in countries where English is not the mother tongue.

Or perhaps the view that the rest of the world speaks English is now being consolidated by the belief that emerging language technologies will soon be able to sort out translation problems in the odd corners of the globe where it is not spoken.

Whatever the causes, the introduction, from next year, of "golden hellos" to entice languages graduates into teaching is a very public admission of just how bad things have become.

The fact that around a third of our modern foreign language teacher trainees are not from the UK further shows how much we are having, in effect, to outsource a significant proportion of our national teacher supply.

The Higher Education Funding Council for England has recognised that languages are expensive to teach and has made more money available through an upward revision of their price band (though not yet for French). Yet the council's recent suggestion that universities should consider "rationalising" language departments collaboratively and on a regional basis has not been thought through and may well lead to further decline.

Language associations believe the funding council has failed to recognise the enormous growth in "non-specialist" language learning over the last decade and therefore badly underestimates the total volume of language learning in universities. These students are not "visible" in the statistical returns made by universities to the council.

As Hilary Footitt suggested in last week's Guardian Higher, what we actually need is a collective, long-term perspective which recognises the need to stimulate demand rather than cut supply if a bad situation is not to become an irretrievable one.

Closing down, selectively pruning or otherwise "rationalising" languages departments will not help "Cool Britannia" one iota, and existing funding arrangements may need further modification to support modern foreign languages through this difficult period.

There needs to be the kind of joined-up thinking which can only be provided by a national policy on modern languages encompassing the various branches of compulsory and post-compulsory education.

Perhaps the forthcoming final report of the Nuffield inquiry will help bring us one step closer to realising that objective.

Meanwhile, we need to take every opportunity to challenge the myth that monolingualism is somehow "cool".

"Cool, mon cul," as French pop star, Zazie, might have said.

 Derrik Ferney is head of languages and intercultural studies at Anglia Polytechnic University and chairs the standing conference of heads of modern languages in universities.

fields.headline: Neighbours from Heaven
fields.standfirst: That sudden intake of breath when you realise the people next door are students could soon be history - they're cleaning up their act
fields.trailText: That sudden intake of breath when you realise the people next door are students could soon be history - they're cleaning up their act
fields.body:
Students are notorious for their noisy, drunken debauchery, but a new study suggests many people think they make excellent neighbours.

Research by Steve Huckerby, a PhD student at Sheffield University, on community attitudes to students found that only one in five locals was hostile towards students.

Many residents reacted positively to having student neighbours. They felt the presence of a student population encouraged better local amenities such as all-night supermarkets and cafe-bars. Others thought they made streets safer at night and provided a ready supply of babysitters. Residents also tended not to stereotype student behaviour. "In cases where people had difficulties with noisy students next door, they didn't generalise this behaviour to [encompass] all students," said Huckerby. "This defies the assumption of most social-psychology literature on disparate minorities."

When residents complained about litter, they would often point to the council as the main culprit for not supplying bins. Similarly, ill feeling about properties being snapped up at extortionate prices was directed towards greedy landlords, not students. Many interviewees sympathised with students, saying they were exploited with high rents and poor accommodation.

Such positive attitudes are also common in Southampton, where students make up almost 10% of the population. Joyce Lewis from Southampton University's public affairs department, believes relations between students and local residents are "very good".

Last year the university received only 19 official complaints. "We don't receive a lot of complaints, but when we do it's more often to do with car parking than noise," she said.

Peter Mulvey, area manager for the community involvement team, said complaints about student behaviour are "almost negligible", and that most of them were about students parking their cars in front of neighbouring houses. The problem has escalated to the point where the university has banned first-year students from taking their cars on campus. The council has also started a resident-only car parking scheme which forbids students from parking in residential neighbourhoods.

James Hudson, the university's assistant accommodation officer, said: "Some people complain because a student has parked outside their house. They feel this is illegal, even though their driveway isn't being blocked. It's a common occurrence but we are trying to resolve it."

Ms Lewis believes an otherwise harmonious relationship is partly due to the university's campaign to improve community relations. It mailed 11,000 homes with a newsletter advertising a 24-hour hotline for residents to register complaints about noisy student neighbours. Some 5,000 student homes received a leaflet with advice like: "Warn your neighbours in advance" if you are planning a party, and "unless you live next door to a vicar it's probably best to hold your party on a Saturday".

Heather Soper has lived in Alma Road for 29 years and she has "absolutely no problem" with student neighbours. "I love living in the city centre for its sheer convenience, students are not too much of a problem, and you have to put up with a certain amount of noise if you want to live in town."

But it is not all plain sailing. Tensions are rife between the elderly residents of White Lodge Nursing Home and their freshmen neighbours. Wafer thin walls separate the two homes and the noise from the students has been a problem since last September.

"It's never been as bad as it is now," said Valerie Martin, manager of the home. "It was one o'clock last night before they stopped banging and slamming; they have no respect that this is a residential home. It keeps people awake at night and they are aware of this. Before Christmas we had it until four in the morning."

Peter Whettingstill, 72, a retired policeman and home resident, said: "Students only improve the business for pubs and off-licences. And if they didn't spend their money on rent, they'd spend it on booze."

fields.headline: Councils, we love you !
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston reveals the latest astonishing Conservative U-turn
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston reveals the latest astonishing Conservative U-turn
fields.body:
Seven years after booting local government out of further education and slamming the door shut, the Conservatives are to perform a startling U-turn today.

Hot on Michael Portillo's conversion to the minimum wage comes an equally surprising change of heart in a Conservative demand that councils should play a crucial role in planning and running post-16 education and training.

Baroness Blatch, Tory education spokeswoman in the Lords, wants local authorities to nominate at least a quarter of members of the 47 local Learning and Skills Councils which the Bill proposes to set up nationwide. And she wants the Local Government Association (LGA) to decide the same proportion of membership of the national Learning and Skills Council.

Her proposal, one of a battery of amendments she is tabling to the Learning and Skills Bill, starting its committee stage in the Lords today, has been greeted by as much incredulity as horror by the Association of Colleges, representing the institutions.

College managements are fiercely jealous of the autonomy they have enjoyed since incorporation in 1993 and are very twitchy of any move which they see bringing them back into municipal clutches. And they have fresh memories that it was a Tory government which granted colleges their freedom, cutting them loose from the local education authorities which had overseen them.

And the same 1992 act which incorporated the colleges, when Baroness Blatch was an education minister, also scrapped local authority representation on college governing bodies.

Any of the governors co-opted onto a board could incidentally be on local councils, but the 1992 act removed the category of governors nominated by local authorities.

Blatch admits that she has listened sympathetically to the Local Government Association and other pressure groups voicing fears that the Bill is democratically deficient in its skeleton form, and that it heaps too much power on the secretary of state for education.

To the suggestion that her party is performing a blatant volte face, Blatch replied: "We wouldn't have created this great monolith of bureaucracy. It's only in the context of a rotten bill anyway, that we are trying to make some firm connection between Local Learning and Skills Councils and local authorities."

David Gibson, Association of Colleges chief executive, said he was "extremely surprised" to learn of the amendment, given the Conservative's record on local government and the incorporation of colleges.

"I understand the need for working in partnership with local authorities which are often among the largest employers in an area," he said.

The 25% proposal was in his view ridiculous, because in many areas there would still be more local authorities than places available on the Local Learning and Skills Council.

"How will they choose? I think people could understand one local authority representative on the council, but 25% is over-egging it and we would oppose it."

Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister, said: "We are looking for people with local government experience in terms of membership of the Learning and Skills Councils, but we are not going to get into a numbers game."
