fields.headline: Dressed to thrill
fields.standfirst: John Crace deconstructs the sartorial styles of top academics
fields.trailText: John Crace deconstructs the sartorial styles of top academics
fields.body:
A fashion writer might observe the Elizabethan flourish, the raised flock and the kick pleat; all I can see is Father Ted. But then what would a bloke for whom M&S is high fashion know. Dianne Willcocks, chief executive of the College of Ripon and York St John, takes such cultural philistinism in good part. There again, as a woman who knows her way round a couture house or two but works in a world noted for its sartorial disasters, she rather has to.

If you want to look a bit of a prat, you don't have to try too hard on formal academic occasions. The gowns and caps that are supposed to embody continuity, ritual and gravitas invariably make the occupants look like an organ grinder's monkey - unless you're Susan Greenfield, of course. But she would look drop-dead gorgeous in a velour shell-suit.

What's more, the robes often don't even fit, as only the very vain or the very large, such as Lennox Lewis, tend to get them properly tailored. All of which explains why you rarely see anyone looking anything other than self-conscious when they are wearing them. But traditions are traditions, and year in, year out academics take their week in the sun at graduation ceremonies with a sheepish grin.

It would be hard to say that the winds of change were howling through the corridors of academe, but a few gentle zephyrs are gusting in isolated areas. "Education is becoming more people centred and I wanted a gown that reflected my personality," says Willcocks. "The college didn't have any ceremonial gowns of its own, so I designed them myself in the college colours of blue and gold. We've had four principals in five years and the gown is also another way of saying I'm making a commitment to the college and that I'm here to stay."

Whether the next chief executive will follow her example and step out in French navy is another matter. My suspicion is it will depend on whether the next incumbent is a man. It is only a suspicion, though.

Elaine Thomas, the principal of Surrey Institute of Art and Design, is another academic with fashion on her mind. And body. Only in her case, the catwalk venture has as much to do with the discomfort of robes tailored for the male physique as a personal flounce of individuality.

"Most hoods are designed to be attached to a waistcoat," she says. "Women have to attach it to a shirt button; ladies with large bosoms are generally OK, but the less well-endowed tend to get strangled."

Women academics are also winning the civvies stakes. Donna Karan, Paul Costelloe, Amanda Wakeley and Christian Lacroix are all regular campus labels, but the blokes aren't letting the women have things all their own way. Simon Schama does cool for a living, while Niall Ferguson does preppy charm.

Even Richard Dawkins has come a long way from that day in the 1980s when he spoke from the floor in an Oxford debate, dressed in a Breton T shirt and ridiculously tight, skimpy shorts. In fact, it's almost de rigueur for any media wannabe who has aspirations to be being Paxmaned on Start the Week to have a standing order for the new-season Armani collection.

But away from the bright lights there are still more than enough horrors to give Anna Wintour nightmares. In the early nineties, Sussex physicists turned up to acknowledge Andrei Sakharov at an honorary degree ceremony in a fetching array of jeans, shorts and T-shirts - including one with a tuxedo imprinted on the front. Lovely. And whatever else Mike Fitzgerald may or may not have done as vice-chancellor of Thames Valley, he deserved the heave-ho for the haircut and earring alone.

Oliver James, the clinical psychologist, reckons that most academics have disconcerting parallels with TV producers.

"They never grow up," he says. "Long after everyone else has moved on, they continue with the same out-of-date fashions they wore when they were students. It is a way of saying: 'I only exist in my mind. What I wear is irrelevant.' "

This may be a little kind to academics, because it assumes they could do better if they tried. Perhaps the last word should go to Elaine Thomas.

"I know of some male academics who wear precisely what their wives leave out for them the night before," she says. Which must mean there are an awful lot of sadistic women going to bed with a chuckle each night.

fields.headline: Girls' football comes of age
fields.standfirst: Cirencester College has started the country's first football training course for women.  Peter Kingston  cheered from the touchline
fields.trailText: Cirencester College has started the country's first football training course for women. Peter Kingston cheered from the touchline
fields.body:
After a playing career spanning five professional football clubs, David Hockaday ought to be a pretty good judge of the game.

So, is it an approving eye he is casting through the Gloucestershire drizzle at the girls passing, dribbling and shooting in front of him?

"My passion is men's football," says the director of the Cirencester Football Academy, at Cirencester college. "But to be honest, aesthetically this is a beautiful game as well."

It resembles the Italian style of football - "there's more time on the ball to express themselves" - rather than the rush-and-chase English male game, he explains. The women's game is less physical in terms of bodily contact than the men's, but very little different technically.

"There's no reason why women can't be as good at ball control as men," he says, and as if on cue, one of the girls lopes gracefully past on the "astroturf", keeping a ball in the air with her feet

If there is a twinkle of pride in his gaze, it is justified by the obvious skills of the 16 girls in their late teens, going through their daily two and a half hour coaching session. They have picked up a lot since the Cirencester Women's Football Academy was launched five months ago at Cirencester College, four years after the male prototype.

"If we had started the women's academy with the men, there would have been no colleges to play," says Hockaday. "The game is really only just taking off now and we've waited until the time is right."

Mind you, some of these other colleges might have preferred a longer wait, particularly Sandwell College, Bristol, whose women's soccer team was mauled 15-0 by the Cirencester girls, who remain unbeaten.

"I think that's been our best result so far," says Louise Slattery from Swindon.

Most of the girls come from this Wiltshire/Gloucestershire border region, but with the completion of an accommodation block next year at the college, this new nursery for the women's game will be attracting students from further afield.

The Women's Academy is open to 16- to 19-year-olds. The deal is that, if selected, they must study another course at the college at the same time. Any of the courses at the college are available. Louise, who is 17, is doing A levels in PE and art. Fellow footballer Vivienne Harvey, 18, is pursuing English, art and sociology A levels. Louise says she is not looking for a career in the game.

"A lot of the girls do want to make careers in football, but at the moment there's no scope in this country professionally and you have to go to the United States."

Vivienne is thinking of staying another year after A levels and getting more qualifications, probably in business and management.

Her commitment to her studies is exactly what the college expects. The girls are penalised if they bunk off a single lecture or class.

"We drop them from the next fixture, and that is a real punishment for them," says Hockaday.

This regime gets full marks from Kate Hoey, the sports minister, who is here officially to open the Women's Academy and is also watching the girls demonstrating their skills from the touchline. She pioneered educational and training packages for young male soccer apprentices to give them something to fall back on if their dreams are shattered.

"The important thing is not closing off options to do other things," she says.

She admits never having been much of a footballer herself, but as a one-time competitive athlete and former PE teacher she has a good eye for the game, and she is impressed. "We will eventually get a professional women's game in this country - it's only a matter of time."

Hockaday agrees. Prejudices against the women's game are constantly being chipped away.

"We brought the boys to watch the girls' first match last term and there were some sceptics," he says. "Within five minutes they were all converts, to a man."

fields.headline: One strike and you're out
fields.standfirst: Colleges are not supposed to have disruptive students, but they do. John Crace checks out the problem, while below, Mervyn Lebor  says successful teachers are reverting to old disciplinary methods
fields.trailText: Colleges are not supposed to have disruptive students, but they do. John Crace checks out the problem, while below, Mervyn Lebor says successful teachers are reverting to old disciplinary methods
fields.body:
For one lecturer, the day a student walked across the classroom to attack another student will remain a vivid memory.

"I had to stand between them to stop them killing one another. Afterwards, one of the guys thanked me for stopping him, but a colleague reckoned I should have let the two of them slug it out."

No doubt this same colleague would have had some sympathy with the lecturer who ended up in court after losing his rag with an apprentice welder and setting fire to his hair. But the prevailing wisdom is that mediation is infinitely preferable to violent retaliation in the classroom. That is, if you can get anyone to admit that violent or disruptive behaviour actually takes place at all these days in colleges.

You can find any number of people to talk about the bad old days. Chris Hughes, chief executive of the Further Education Development Agency (FEDA), recalls life in 1971.

"I was supposed to teach the general academic module at 8.30 in the evening, to a group of apprentices on day release who had been working since 9 in the morning. One of them pulled a knife out before inviting me with mock courtesy to sign the register and join them in the pub. I signed the register."

Another lecturer recalls the racism of 20 years ago. "One student, who was a member of the British Movement, used to spit at black faces in newspapers and textbooks".

Such extremes of behaviour are much fewer and further between these days. The pile 'em high approach is tempered by a willingness to ensure that students enrol on courses that are suited to their needs. But the sector is not made up entirely of angels. Anywhere you get large numbers of 16- to 19-year-olds you are likely to find some trouble, and when that group contains students who may feel they have been let down once already by the education system, or might not even want to be at college at all and are only attending to protect their benefits, then you are even more likely to find disruption.

Paul Mackney, chief executive of the lecturers' union Natfhe, accepts there are problems.

"Most colleges have door stewards to contain the possibility of violence, and racism and sexism do go on," he says. "But that's one of the effects of widening participation in education."

In other words, a certain level of disruptive behaviour may be a price worth paying for further education's inclusion policies. The Further Education Development Agency take a similarly pragmatic approach to the problem and have produced a pamphlet, Ain't Misbehaving, to give guidelines on best practice.

One of the key elements to emerge is the benefit of a whole-college approach with clear policies and procedures, and well-trained staff to implement them.

Ross Rospigliosi has been running Plymouth College along these lines for some years.

"We get very little disruptive behaviour," he reports. "On average we expel about three students out of a total body of 20,000 each year. Our rules are made clear at induction: one strike and you're out. We ask for similar standards to those expected in the workplace."

When Ruth Silver took over as principal of Lewisham College eight years ago, she was appalled by the grills on the windows and the security turnstiles on the doors, and her first reaction was to rip them out. A student stopped her with the words "Are you crazy, lady? This is the safest place in south London."

Back to tradition

How do teachers deal with disruptive students in the post-16 sector? Would it be acceptable for students to swear continually, create a high level of noise, fight, punch, intimidate other students, act in an insulting or sometimes threatening way to members of staff?

Presumably not, yet there is a growing culture in many institutions of post-school, and therefore voluntary, education where this sort of behaviour is not altogether abnormal at GNVQ Foundation to Intermediate level.

There could be a case for constant counselling. However, this involves vast human/time resources. When the class contains more than 20 students for what is often basic remedial work, it is very difficult for teachers to concentrate on the personal or academic weaknesses of individuals.

Successful teachers are now reverting to tougher disciplinary measures in the hope of establishing a creative working environment within which students can at least concentrate for slightly longer on finishing the "job in hand".

The class layout of desks in a horseshoe, or even tables for group work, recipes for casual chatting since primary school, have been rejected in favour of a more formal pre-60s style of control by desks in rows.

Lecturers are under great pressure to retain students in the class. Student numbers represent financial survival for the college. As the GNVQ model of Key Skills becomes embedded into academic qualifications, so vocational qualifications are now edging towards academic respectability.

But this raising of standards is taking place as a backcloth to a culture of frequent racist and sexist tensions, acts of psychotic violence, open and under-cover hate campaigns. Anger, frustration and aggression flare to the surface, or equally often, bored malaise stultifies a class where students have to do the same work they did under different guises six years earlier at primary school.

Extra teachers and resources for Further Education, or payment related to the sheer stress of bringing the disruptive energies of our youth society into some sort of creative order, would all be highly desirable. I personally find the most productive use of time is the building of relationships with individuals, listening to embittered or resentful voices, as a means of trying to break the cyclic pattern of chronic underachievement.

fields.headline: Jewellery
fields.trailText: Jewellery
fields.body:
W ow! We're talking sparklers, right? Di da di da di da... A diamond is a girl's best friend, and all that. Not necessarily. Jewellery can be made from almost any medium, including traditional metals, such as gold and silver, precious stone, fabric, wood or even plastic. It can be a practical hair slide, or an ornate necklace

Yeah, OK. But how do I get involved? Careers in jewellery generally fall into two categories: retail or production.

Why can't you simply say "flogging it or making it"? We jewellers don't like to express ourselves in too demotic a manner about our business.

What's demo... democracy got to do with it? Nothing. Ye gods, give me strength! Surely you remember Gerald Ratner?

The bloke who announced that he sold crap, and everyone took him at his word? Precisely. No one wants to make that mistake again. Anyway, the making of jewellery is one of Britain's oldest crafts. These days it can be mass-produced by the latest technology, or a customised piece designed and made by a single highly skilled craft worker.

So, what does it take to be a jeweller? The jewellery trade requires many different levels of skills. Designers, for instance, need to be very patient and have an eye for detail. A designer typically provides a detailed drawing, so that the skilled and semi-skilled workers can create the final product. If the designer is directly involved in manufacture, nimble fingers are required.

Doesn't the mass-produced stuff need designers as well? Sure. But with mass-production, a design may need to be modified and restyled rather than created from scratch. Designers can also spend a lot of time researching materials, production processes and trends.

Where do designers work? They may operate on their own, or join forces to form small businesses and workshops. Independent designers and craft workers tend to create exclusive hand-crafted pieces, which are commissioned by an individual. They need to have effective business skills in order to produce competitively priced and marketed jewellery.

Are their other specialities? Yes, of course. People specialise in mounting, setting or polishing jewellery. These all require training and are separate crafts within fine jewellery making. Then there are gemmologists who are concerned solely with gemstone manipulation.

And what about the retail side? Retailers are often concerned with both the sale and the repair of jewellery. They can be part of a national chain that has its own mass-produced supply, or an individual specialist shop.

What's needed? For the solo operations, determination and enthusiasm. In general, a good eye for quality is a must, plus a sound business sense, and as in all retail, the ability to provide good customer service.

And what about qualifications and training? Academic achievement is not essential, although art or CDT experience is beneficial, as are attention to detail and a willingness to learn. There are several routes into jewellery making.

In factories and workshops, training is often on site, under the guidance of an experienced craftsperson. There is a modern apprenticeship scheme for 16- to 24-year-olds. Employees may be released for college courses, or may get their work assessed at their place of employment for a vocational qualification.

What could they get? There are numerous qualifications, such as NVQ levels 1 and 2 in manufacture of jewellery and related products, and NVQ 3 in manufacture ofspecialised jewellery and related products. City & Guilds have a manufacturing jewellery and allied products qualification and the Open College Network does jewellery and art metal work.

That's jolly int... Don't interrupt. There are also degree courses which usually require completion of a foundation course at a college of art and design. So you can these days become a BA in metalwork and jewellery, or in three-dimensional design, or design and applied arts.

Contact information

 Gemmological Association and Gem Testing Laboratory of Great Britain, 27 Greville Street, London, EC1N 8SU, Telephone 0171 404 3334

 Jewellery & Allied Industries Training Council & British Jewellers' Association (for details of NVQs etc), 10 Vyse Street, Birmingham, B18 6LT, Telephone 0121 237 1109

 National Association of Goldsmiths, 78a Luke Street, London, EC2A 4PY, Telephone 0171 613 4445

 learndirect 0800 100 900 may be able to give further information and advice on courses.

fields.headline: Licensed to care?
fields.standfirst: Surely proper training and qualifications and regulation of au pairs should be a government priority
fields.trailText: Surely proper training and qualifications and regulation of au pairs should be a government priority
fields.body:
It's every busy working parent's nightmare! You have just received a hysterical phone call from the nice young au pair with whom you left your toddler this morning. She's had enough and has abandoned the child at the school bus stop. Recent television programmes must have sent shivers down the backs of many parents.

"Affordable quality childcare for all" is one of the current governments' mantras. So, what is "affordable" with a minimum national basic wage of £3.60p per hour? Good quality childcare is expensive. Small wonder that many parents, even some professionally (and expensively) qualified, decide either to stay at home because the finances don't add up or leave their children with "unofficial" carers, like au pairs.

The Concise Oxford dictionary defines an au pair as a "young (usually foreign) woman helping with housework etc. in return for room and board". There is no mention of looking after children. Yet, it is accepted that au pairs will take on childcare duties usually as "mother's helps". And, increasingly they have sole responsibility for young children, sometimes for long periods. A daunting and sometimes dangerous situation for both parties. The care of young children is surely one of the most responsible roles in society today.

So, where is the regulation? It would be impossible to regulate all the unofficial childcare that occurs in the child's own home, as this includes care by relatives, friends, babysitters, as well as au pairs. This would be seen by many as overly intrusive. But isn't it time to debate the responsibility of the numerous agencies that provide these services?

A basic training programme or qualification providing rudimentary knowledge to support the health, safety and well-being of children would at least give parents some reassurance.

There are training programmes and qualifications in abundance. The recently published National Childcare Strategy provides a coherent framework of nationally accredited qualifications for early years education, childcare and playwork. And within this framework, there is the provision of appropriate training and qualifications for au pairs.

Hardly a week passes without some tale of an ill-prepared childcarer unable to cope. Surely there are the means to change this situation or do we all leave the parents to continue to cross their fingers and hope they don't receive that telephone call?

 Joanna Hurren is the Quality Improvement Manager and Chief Verifier for City & Guilds Affinity, the specialist unit within City & Guilds dedicated to the care sector.

fields.headline: What's in a logo?
fields.standfirst: Janet Jones laments the passing of her college's name
fields.trailText: Janet Jones laments the passing of her college's name
fields.body:
Once upon a time we had a name. Now we have a logo. Once upon a time we had a librarian. Now we have a learning resources manager. Once upon a time there was teaching. Now there is guided learning.

To start with our name: once upon a time, a very long time ago, in the middle of the 20th century, our name was there in black on white. All alone. Over the years the colours crept in. There was yellow in our "site" in SW2 and in SW4. And in SW9. In SW8 there was green. I think SE27 was colourless for longest. Eventually green and red were everywhere.

The decorations crept in too. Stripes. Yellow stripes. Green stripes. Red stripes. The stripes got bigger and bigger. Our name got smaller and smaller. By the time we got to the turn of the century, if you turned the stripes sideways (90 clockwise) you realised (unless you were me who only realised today) that the stripes represented the initials of the college. First initial green stripes. Second initial red stripes.

These stripes got about: onto signboards outside "sites" scattered across the south of one of our great cities; onto newspapers delivered to homes across urban square miles; onto a double-decker bus that chugged fumefully around some of the most deprived areas of the western world; onto all kinds of promotional papers; onto internal paperwork - (that'll have to wait for another column or six); onto cups and saucers and plates.

But the thing about all these stripes was that they were never alone. Our name stood by them. It did not matter that people like me failed to realise that if you turned the stripes - or the signboard or the bus or the cup - 90 clockwise, you could read the initials of the college. We could always read the name.

This week, I see, we have lost our stripes. That doesn"t matter either. But along with our stripes we seem to have lost our name. And to people like me a name does matter. Without a name... well it's pretty basic really.

What do we have instead? From the cover of our latest publication, moving us into the millennium, I understand we have new initials. These initials are more upright than the stripes. However, the first initial is a capital letter and the second is not. And our name is no longer standing by.

If you look closely, it has been engulfed by our new initials. "College" is just about there for those of us with glasses. The Other Word is even smaller. (The reason The Other Word is so small could, I suppose, be because in PR terms it is not a helpful name: it is not associated with being either erudite or salubrious.) I fear most of us will see a white splodge on red. Or, possibly, a red splodge on white.

Maybe we should cheer along with the fans on the terraces:

"Not quite

Get it right
We support
The red and white"

and not worry too much about the words. It's only guided learning after all.

Over the years the colours crept in. There was yellow in our "site" in SW2 and in SW4. And in SW9. In SW8 there was green. I think SE27 was colourless for longest. Eventually green and red were everywhere. The decorations crept in too. Stripes. Yellow stripes. Green stripes. Red stripes. The stripes got bigger and bigger. Our name got smaller and smaller. By the time we got to the turn of the century, if you turned the stripes sideways (90 clockwise) you realised (unless you were me who only realised today) that the stripes represented the initials of the college. First initial green stripes. Second initial red stripes. These stripes got about: onto signboards outside "sites" scattered across the south of one of our great cities; onto newspapers delivered to homes across urban square miles; onto a double-decker bus that chugged fumefully around some of the most deprived areas of the western world; onto all kinds of promotional papers; onto internal paperwork - (that'll have to wait for another column or six); onto cups and saucers and plates. But the thing about all these stripes was that they were never alone. Our name stood by them. It did not matter that people like me failed to realise that if you turned the stripes - or the signboard or the bus or the cup - 90 clockwise, you could read the initials of the college. We could always read the name. This week, I see, we have lost our stripes. That doesn"t matter either. But along with our stripes we seem to have lost our name. And to people like me a name does matter. Without a name... well it's pretty basic really. What do we have instead? From the cover of our latest publication, moving us into the millennium, I understand we have new initials. These initials are more upright than the stripes. However, the first initial is a capital letter and the second is not. And our name is no longer standing by. If you look closely, it has been engulfed by our new initials. "College" is just about there for those of us with glasses. The Other Word is even smaller. (The reason The Other Word is so small could, I suppose, be because in PR terms it is not a helpful name: it is not associated with being either erudite or salubrious.) I fear most of us will see a white splodge on red. Or, possibly, a red splodge on white. Maybe we should cheer along with the fans on the terraces: "Not quite Get it right We support The red and white" and not worry too much about the words. It's only guided learning after all.

fields.headline: Taking it personally
fields.standfirst: Do relationships between men and women always have to end in tears? This weekend, speakers from both sides of the Atlantic will meet in London to debate sexual intimacy. Here, two writers ask if the personal must be political
fields.trailText: Cathy Young: 'Not all bad behaviour is the product of sexism. Sometimes personal conflicts are just personal'
fields.body:
In her book Rebels in White Gloves, a portrait of the women who graduated from Wellesley College in 1969 along with Hillary Clinton, Miriam Horn tells the story of how a US attorney, Kris Olson Rogers, decided to come out of the closet as a former abused wife.

Rogers began to see her bad (but non-violent) marriage in a new light when, soon after her divorce, she read material from a battered women's shelter which defined abuse very broadly - from lies and infidelities to "not giving support, attention, and compliments". As an exercise in consciousness-raising, she read this checklist at a seminar for women lawyers and asked how many had experienced such treatment from spouses or partners. About 80% raised their hands.

Many feminists would see this as an admirable illustration of the principle that the personal is political. Men's private ill-treatment of women, they argue, is both a consequence and an instrument of patriarchal oppression, and it's only by opening their eyes to this reality that women can free themselves.

But there's a problem with this interpretation. If the same list of abusive behaviours were read to men, or lesbians, surely just as many hands would go up.

Inasmuch as feminism sought to change relations between the sexes, it had to subject the personal sphere to political analysis. In the past, personal relationships were shaped, to an extent, by laws which gave men authority over women and later by social norms dictating that wives should take care of the home and husbands should be providers and leaders.

But the rightful challenges to these laws and norms did not necessarily presume male malevolence or female innocence. Even Betty Friedan, in The Feminine Mystique, saw middle-class men less as oppressors than as victims of housewives who were obsessed with domestic perfection and social status.

Today's feminism often focuses obsessively on the evil that men do to women. Certainly, the women's movement deserves credit for shining the spotlight on such issues as rape, battering and sexual abuse in the workplace. However, to treat such offences - which western culture condemned severely long before feminism - as an assertion of patriarchal gender norms, or as a male "war against women" is inaccurate and simplistic.

This analysis does not account for sexual assaults on men and boys, or for sexual and physical violence in same-sex couples - or for the fact, confirmed by numerous studies, of women's aggression in domestic combat.

The preoccupation with personal wrongs suffered by women at the hands of men also politicises less extreme offences. As Miriam Horn put it, pondering the odyssey of Kris Rogers, it turns "the confused misdemeanors inevitable in a relationship into stark crimes". It reduces feminism to a vehicle for women to vent their frustrations with men - frustrations caused less by gender oppression or sex differences than by the inherent messiness of relationships - and to blame their personal unhappiness on patriarchy.

This approach also encourages a woefully one-sided view of intimate conflict. In her new book, All About Love, the American feminist cultural critic Bell Hooks asserts that "most men use psychological terrorism as a way to subordinate women".

Yet men might have a different, equally valid, view of which gender excels at psychological terrorism. In the US, the campaign to protect innocent women from bad men has led to egregious invasions of private life.

If a couple has a loud quarrel that turns into a minor shoving match and a neighbour calls the police, the man can be prosecuted for domestic violence and sent to counselling (with a heavy dose of feminist ideology), even if the woman insists she is not abused.

Many companies, nervous about lawsuits, require co-workers who begin dating to report their relationship to a sexual harassment officer and formally attest that neither feel coerced or harassed.

Growing numbers of women who welcome the opportunities won by feminism - authors such as Daphne Patai and Katie Roiphe, groups such as the Women's Freedom Network - are rebelling against this regime. Ironically, too, the feminist politicisation of the personal can easily become a weapon for conservatives (as President Clinton's troubles showed spectacularly).

Some traditionalists, such as the young writer Wendy Shalit, cite feminist claims of women's misery and men's brutishness as proof that women have been harmed by equality and the loss of paternalistic protection.

Can sexist stereotypes and prejudices in personal life be criticised? Of course. However, the critics should address not only men's but women's non-egalitarian attitudes, such as unwillingness to consider lower-status men as suitable mates. They should show humility and respect for the choices of women and men who prefer traditional roles. Finally, they should remember that not all bad behaviour is the product of sexism - that sometimes personal conflicts are just personal - and that, when it comes to inflicting private misery, women and men generally give as good as they get.

 Cathy Young is the author of Ceasefire! Why Women and Men Must Join Forces to Achieve True Equality and a speaker at Sex Wars on Saturday at the ICA, London. Tickets: 0207 930 3647. www.SexWars.org

webTitle: Equality is a long way off

fields.headline: Equality is a long way off
fields.standfirst: Do relationships between men and women always have to end in tears? This weekend, speakers from both sides of the Atlantic will meet in London to debate sexual intimacy.
fields.trailText: Do relationships between men and women always have to end in tears? This weekend, speakers from both sides of the Atlantic will meet in London to debate sexual intimacy.
fields.body:
Another cable channel was launched in the US this month. Oxygen has been advertised as the first integrated internet and television network by and for women, and is the brainchild of Oprah Winfrey and the Hollywood team which created the sitcoms Roseanne and Murphy Brown. The day begins with Inhale, a yoga show, followed by a live, studio "chat-session". Ka-Ching is a lunchtime money-management programme, followed by a "girl-power" slot. Actress Candice Bergen (who plays journalist Murphy Brown) interviews celebrities on Exhale, to end the day. The producers don't seem to think women need or want a news or public affairs programme.

Is Oxygen the face of 21st-century feminism, proof positive that all that work for women's liberation has evaporated into an ozone of self-help and SheCommerce? (another Oxygen show.) Perhaps. But it's more likely that the corporations which back the network - Microsoft, America OnLine and Moët-Hennessy Louis Vuitton - prefer to sponsor programmes about our bodies and bank balances, than investigate the sweatshop side of the fashion business, say, or the high rate of blindness among women who put microchips on motherboards.

Conservatives love to blame feminists for the fact that a movement for equal pay and self-determination seems to have morphed into a support group for the upwardly mobile, but the operative word is "seems". The personal is still political. It's just that the political is, well, political, after all. The same folks who criticise feminists for overemphasising the personal, spent much of the 90s trying to topple a president over a blow job.

At the opposite end of the power-pile, no lives are more politicised than those of poor women. With the eradication of federal standards when it comes to dispensing welfare benefits, many states penalise women who deviate from prescribed behaviours by docking all or some of their benefits. A woman's benefits may be cut in 21 states if she balks at naming her child's father or misses a health visit in eight states, or fails to seek birth control in five states.

After years of struggle for legal abortion and to end involuntary sterilisation, "welfare reform" is a huge leap away from freedom of choice. But those feminists, in groups like Wisconsin's Welfare Warriors, and the Kensington Welfare Rights Union in Philadelphia, are unlikely to bask in the spotlight of Oxygen. It's been three years since the passage of the welfare law, and they have yet to get any sort of national attention on Microsoft (MSNBC), Disney (ABC), or Time Warner/Turner (CNN) TV.

Women are in the public debate these days, and I'm not just talking about Oprah and co. The sex is no longer banished, but some political perspectives get short shrift. At last count there were two nationally syndicated, women columnists who proudly identify as feminists, yet the roster of conservative women with national newspaper columns and television slots expands: Jeanne Kirkpatrick, Mona Charen, Linda Chavez, Cathy Young.

All these are syndicated columnists who hold office in the Women's Freedom Network, a libertarian outfit with ties to the Catholic Right, or the Independent Women's Forum, a 90s platform for anti-feminist pundits of the Washington-insider set.

These groups field influential teams to praise welfare reform, damn affirmative action, and among other things, oppose the Violence Against Women Act (which opens federal courts to women when they have no confidence in their state.) Corporate money flows into their think-tanks and media projects, and Wall Street pays big fees to hear Thatcher's ideological daughters embrace lower taxes, deregulation, smaller government. They share values.

On the other side, feminists deserve some credit for germinating the idea that a cable network could be "for and by women". But the bigger ideas of what was once a liberation movement have been almost entirely shut out. By way of a reality check: a British female columnist recently suggested steps to basic sexual equality: reorganise the workplace, establish a state-funded system of free childcare, raise wages to livable minimums. No supporter of this agenda has a national voice in the US.

The personal element of the feminist agenda hasn't eliminated the political, it's just the easiest half of the equation to market. Equality will require more effort. But you didn't think justice would come easy. Inhale/Exhale. Did you?

fields.headline: Customers' complaints
fields.trailText: • The Fosters of Thirsk, North Yorkshire, opted to pre-pay for their new mobile by credit card, but the phone swallowed £20 twice and refused to work. Mr Foster said: "We made so many calls to the company and were put on to   so many departments, until we felt we were the ones being a nuisance." After trading standards intervened, the phone was found to be faulty and the Fosters were reimbursed the £40, plus compensation.

Mr Foster said: "We made so many calls to the company and were put on to so many departments, until we felt we were the ones being a nuisance." After trading standards intervened, the phone was found to be faulty and the Fosters were reimbursed the £40, plus compensation.

 The Walshes of Stokesley tried for three months to cancel a broken mobile but received monthly demands for standing charges of between £13 and £19. After trading standards in tervened, compensation was agreed but has not been paid.

 The Mitchells of Knaresborough bought a phone on a cheap-rate offer which included international calls -to phone an aunt in the US. Without warning this facility was stopped. Mrs Mitchell said: "They wanted an extra £15 a quarter, which was never in the contract. We got in touch with trading standards, and now auntie's back on."

webTitle: Get me to church on time, by hatchback if necessary

fields.headline: Get me to church on time, by hatchback if necessary
fields.trailText: Brides do not dream of setting out on married life's journey in a neighbour's small hatchback. Nor of going to their wedding reception on a tram.
fields.body:
Brides do not dream of setting out on married life's journey in a neighbour's small hatchback. Nor of going to their wedding reception on a tram.

But these were the only options left to Dawn Feldman, 35, of Timperley, Greater Manchester, when a taxi company let her down even though she had made the booking four months in advance and had confirmed arrangements a few days before the ceremony.

Panic set in when the car had not arrived half an hour after the arranged time despite two calls. So Mrs Feldman had to pile herself (in smart red dress) and her bridesmaid daughter into the hatchback and race through busy traffic, arriving hot and bothered and missing out on her wedding photographs. She said: "I ran up the steps but another bride was having her wedding picture taken. So there were two brides on her photos."

Then Mrs Feldman, her husband, David, and guests rode to their reception on a tram which was so crowded the couple could not even sit side-by-side.

The Feldmans sued Trafftax of Trafford and were awarded £150 in damages and £100 expenses at Altrincham county court. They will use the money to rerun the ceremony.

"I was excited," said Mrs Feldman, a mother of three. "The sun was shining and the neighbours were all outside our home, wishing us well."

Peter Bolton, the company's boss, said: "Most people are happy to spend £100 on a wedding car but Mr Feldman just wanted a £4.50 tax ride."

fields.headline: 'Spy' lecturer is suspended
fields.trailText: Hull university yesterday suspended a senior lecturer in economic history accused of being a recruiting agent for the East German secret police during the 1980s.
fields.body:
Hull university yesterday suspended a senior lecturer in economic history accused of being a recruiting agent for the East German secret police during the 1980s.

Robin Pearson will be removed from teaching duties for five terms and his salary reduced to cover the cost of a replacement. But he will be expected to continue research and resume teaching in October 2001.

David Drewry, the vice-chancellor, announced the suspension after an internal investigation into Dr Pearson's role in setting up exchange arrangements with the university of Leipzig in the late 1980s.

"The investigation was confined to matters relating to Dr Pearson's conduct as a lecturer at Hull. These concerned events several years ago, but affect the present relationship of trust between Dr Pearson, his students and colleagues. The investigation did not look at any issues relating to national security," the university said.

The case arose after allegations last year in the BBC documentary The Spying Game. Dr Pearson, 44, was accused of being an agent for the Stasi, the East German secret police, for 12 years until 1989, spotting Britons who might be approached to work for the communist regime.

After the allegations, the government said Dr Pearson and four others accused of spying, including the 87-year-old great-grandmother Melita Norwood, would not be brought to trial. The official solicitor said no action would be taken because "sufficient is known about the cases to make it clear any prosecution would fail".

A university spokesman said Dr Pearson's suspension would last until his current students graduated. Future students could be expected to have taken account of the allegations. Dr Pearson has consistently refused to comment on the allegations, but apologised to his colleagues for the disruption they caused.

Yesterday, in a statement released through his solicitor, he said: "The university has made a decision which was only communicated to me on Saturday morning and which I believe to be unjustified."

Neither side would comment on the size of Dr Pearson's pay cut during suspension. The university spokesman acknowledged: "It is going to be a penalty to have money deducted from his salary for that length of time."

fields.headline: Shedding light on science
fields.standfirst: TV recreates decisive experiments
fields.trailText: Some people pot geraniums, some mend bicycles. But in a garden shed in north London Ken Campbell has been recreating for television the six scientific experiments that changed the world.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
Some people pot geraniums, some mend bicycles. But in a garden shed in north London Ken Campbell has been recreating for television the six scientific experiments that changed the world.

Mr Campbell is best known as an eccentric actor and theatre director, several of whose performances have lasted for 24 hours, but he also has a passion for science.

He is presenting a series, starting next weekend on Channel 4, which looks at the geniuses who established principles which are now accepted without question - such as Isaac Newton's proof, in 1670, that light perceived as white is made up of the spectrum of colours, and Marie Curie's discovery of radium, which led to the beginning of nuclear physics.

Mr Campbell's experiments have now moved on to the transmission of sound, an interest he shares with two of his subjects, Newton and Michael Faraday - although they would perhaps not have attempted to make water in a potty vibrate by throwing the voice, something which ventriloquists have told him is impossible.

Although the mathematics involved in the series were far beyond Mr Campbell, the equipment used was often so simple that it could be recreated in a garden shed.

The programmes combine the shed experiments with interviews with scientists and science historians, and film made in the original settings of the experiments, including the cathedral in Pisa and a monastery garden near Prague.

The experiments selected were:

Newton's work on light in 1669 and 1670, which he called "the crucial experiment";

British astronomer Arthur Eddington's photographs of the 1919 total solar eclipse, which helped prove Einstein's general theory of relativity, which stated that the gravitational pull of planets and stars was accompanied by a perceived bending of light as it passed them;

Faraday's doughnut, a home-made apparatus of an insulated iron ring, connected on one side to a battery and on the other to a meter, by which he demonstrated that the current passing through an electro magnet could move the needle without any direct physical contact;

Marie Curie's years of dangerous work to isolate, in 1910, the unknown element radium from tons of the compound pitchblende, which may eventually have caused her death from leukaemia;

Gregor Mendel's study of 30,000 pea plants grown in his monastery garden in the 1850s, which established the principles of genetic inheritance;

Galileo Galilei's work, which proved that Aristotle was wrong, and that heavy objects do not fall faster than light ones. But in a garden shed in north London Ken Campbell has been recreating for television the six scientific experiments that changed the world. Mr Campbell is best known as an eccentric actor and theatre director, several of whose performances have lasted for 24 hours, but he also has a passion for science. He is presenting a series, starting next weekend on Channel 4, which looks at the geniuses who established principles which are now accepted without question - such as Isaac Newton's proof, in 1670, that light perceived as white is made up of the spectrum of colours, and Marie Curie's discovery of radium, which led to the beginning of nuclear physics. fields.headline: Gripes soar on mobile phones
fields.trailText: Final proof of the triumph of the mobile phone was issued yesterday, with the dubious compliment that customer complaints have entered the big league dominated by second-hand car dealers and double glazing firms.
fields.body:
Final proof of the triumph of the mobile phone was issued yesterday, with the dubious compliment that customer complaints have entered the big league dominated by second-hand car dealers and double glazing firms.

So many complaints of poor aftercare, poor reception and dodgy billing have been made to trading standards officers that the office of fair trading has created a complaint code for mobiles, which has immediately made the top 10 of most frequent types of grievance.

"The sales side of mobiles has taken off at such an extraordinary pace that customer care is getting left behind," said Gordon Gresty, head of trading standards in North Yorkshire, where mobile cases have shot to eighth place out of 75 OFT categories. "Mobile phone companies simply aren't matching their aggressive advertising with their after-sales service."

The phones have seen the biggest retail expansion of any sector this winter, with pre-pay mobiles in particular topping thousands of Christmas present lists. Ownership in Britain went from 1m in 1990 to more than 24m last year, with technological developments like pocket internet access continuing to fuel sales.

"Firms are trying to keep up or just defend their market share, and they can't always cope with the customer side," said Katie McCulloch, editor of Mobile Choice magazine. Her complaints file includes a company whose helpline was so harassed that one customer was advised by an operator to "go fuck yourself", while another was given unwanted credit top-ups by a phone apparently programmed never to say no.

"Demand for pre-pay has been beyond anyone in the industry's wildest dreams," she said. "But they should have been better prepared for the Christmas rush, because it happened on a similar scale last year."

The OFT said that it was difficult for watchdogs to pounce straight away on a market expanding so rapidly. A spokesman said: "You find with any new technology that the issues take time to bed down. We give advice on our website, and trading standards departments soon get to know the issues at the grassroots."

Mr Gresty said trading standards were on the brink of considering a "name and shame" policy because of the scale of the problem, with mobile phone complaints catching up on the traditional villains found in the categories "home improvements" and "large white goods". Dodgy used cars still dominate most local complaint leagues, but in North Yorkshire mobiles are likely to overhaul double glazing in the coming year.

The companies acknowledge that sales growth has been phenomenal but say customer care is a crucial side of any business which values its reputation.

A spokeswoman for BT Cellnet said: "We have just opened a big new customer care centre in Bury exclusively for pre-pay phone users. "That doesn't suggest a company which isn't dedicated to customer care."

fields.headline: Labour's compulsory disorder
fields.trailText: Almost all benefit claimants will be compelled to attend interviews with personal advisers from April, but officialdom will not say so.
fields.body:
Almost all benefit claimants will be compelled to attend interviews with personal advisers from April, but officialdom will not say so.

As the government edges closer to American-style workfare, it appears so anxious to play down the harsh reality that use of the word "compulsion" has been banned.

In what must count as one of New Labour's most imaginative euphemisms, the requirement to attend interviews, on pain of losing benefit, is to be known as "full participation".

From April claimants have to attend, on demand, interviews with a personal adviser under what used to be known as the "single work focused gateway". The gateway now has the simpler, if not exactly clearer, name of One.

The idea is to ensure that all jobless people get information from a single source about employment opportunities, training and in-work benefits. Failure to attend an initial interview could result in new claimants getting no benefit, while missing a subsequent appointment could incur a penalty of £10 a week.

An internal circular issued by Moraig Lamond, of the communications division of the department for education and employment, says: "When the prospect of the One service was discussed, there was universal support in principle but concern at the prospect of making meetings compulsory for groups such as lone parents, carers and the disabled."

Most concerns have been allayed, but some organisations remain anxious about use of the word "compulsion", the circular states. "The term 'full participation' is considered to be a better and more helpful description and should be used from now on."

Lorna Reith, chief executive of the Disability Alliance umbrella group, said the circular had got it the wrong way round. "Our concern is that people do not know what the rules are, or the consequences that follow from them. If it is compulsory, it should say it is compulsory.

"We look forward to all sorts of new ways of describing cuts in benefits to make them palatable."

webTitle: Advert site to provide web games

fields.headline: Advert site to provide web games
fields.trailText: Parents who cannot afford video games costing upwards of £40 could benefit from a new web site which will depend on advertising to provide games for free.
fields.body:
Parents who cannot afford video games costing upwards of £40 could benefit from a new web site which will depend on advertising to provide games for free.

The site allows users to download games which will be titles that were top of the gaming charts in the previous 12 to 18 months.

The London-based video-games developer Pure Entertainment, which has purchased the licences for several well-known titles, will finance the project through advertising.

Its chief executive, Harry Holmwood, said: "Video games are now the world's biggest entertainment industry. Games are among the most searched for things on-line.

"By providing instant, on-demand access to top-quality games, and eliminating the cost to the user, we hope to attract significant traffic by getting more and more people into playing games."

"As well as appealing to current enthusiasts with top-end titles, we'll also appeal to those who have never bought a game in their lives."

As well as titles developed exclusively for the site, users will also be able to access many of the most successful back-catalogue games along with puzzles, news, reviews, hints and tips from the world of gaming and on-line competitions.

Mr Holmwood added: "The quality of games internet users can download will be as good as you can buy in the shops.

"The playability of the games means that visitors will return to the site for repeated visits."

The site will ask users to fill in questionnaires and employ the latest tracking methods to assess users' tastes and habits to help target advertising more accurately on the internet.

The company recently floated on the Alternative Investment Market (AIM) of the stock exchange, raising over £11m to launch the site, and is currently in talks with on-line retailers and internet service providers.

The freeloader.com site will go live on May 1.

fields.headline: Yellow submarine makes happy return
fields.standfirst: The raising of Mary Rose it was not. But the 25-tonne yellow submarine salvaged from oblivion yesterday is to be no less lovingly restored by Liverpool Architecture and Design Trust.
fields.trailText: The 51ft steel sub was built by apprentices at the Cammell Laird shipyard as one of the main attractions at the city's garden festival in 1984, but was left to rust in the undergrowth when the festival site closed three years ago.
fields.body:
The 51ft steel sub was built by apprentices at the Cammell Laird shipyard as one of the main attractions at the city's garden festival in 1984, but was left to rust in the undergrowth when the festival site closed three years ago.

Mike Storey, Labour leader of the city council, said: "It is time the yellow submarine set sail again in Liverpool. It will be a major addition to the city centre when it is fully restored and should prove a huge tourist attraction for thousands of visitors from overseas."

Rainwater seeped out of the rear portholes as the rusting vessel was lifted by crane on to a trailer yesterday and taken to a council depot for its makeover as a certain Beatles number rang out from a council van en route. It was unclear where the revamped submarine would be permanently parked but suggestions ranged from the Albert Dock to junction 6 of the M62.

Mr Storey said: "No decision has been made but we will be asking the people of Liverpool where they would like to see it."

Other treasures to be rescued from the garden festival site, now owned by Wiggins developers, include a Blue Peter galleon, a statue of a sacred bull, and a pagoda. The festival was opened by the Queen, who climbed aboard the submarine in the John Lennon peace garden.

As part of the then environment secretary Michael Heseltine's "golden chain" of regional garden festivals it was designed to showcase regional potential, and ease a growing sense of disenfranchisement among Liverpudlians after the Toxteth riots.

webTitle: Italian art find may go for £2m

fields.headline: Italian art find may go for £2m
fields.trailText: An Italian old master painting, unrecorded but recognised instantly by a Sotheby's specialist when he was sent a photograph by its British owner, could fetch up to £2m at auction on July 6.
fields.body:
An Italian old master painting, unrecorded but recognised instantly by a Sotheby's specialist when he was sent a photograph by its British owner, could fetch up to £2m at auction on July 6.

The oil on copper is The Holy Family with the Infant Saint John the Baptist, by the baroque artist Orazio Gentileschi, who was called to the English court of Charles I in 1626.

He is believed to have painted it in the first decade of the 17th century, when he was working in Rome. According to an inscription on the support of the copper panel, it was in the collection of the Viscounts Powerscourt in Ireland. Its whereabouts then remained unknown until it entered the collection of the present owner's family more than a generation ago.

Richard Charlton-Jones of Sotheby's discovered the painting in a private collection only recently after being sent the colour photograph.

He said yesterday: "This is one of the most beautiful and best preserved Italian 17th century paintings to have been discovered in recent years. Given its beauty and importance, it seems extraordinary that it has remained unrecognised for so long."

Gentileschi's decorations for the Queen's House at Greenwich, south London, are now, much damaged, at Marlborough House.

webTitle: Scots cast doubt on arts bodies

fields.headline: Scots cast doubt on arts bodies
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: The future of Scotland's four national arts companies and its arts council has been questioned in a report on its cultural identity.
fields.body:
The future of Scotland's four national arts companies and its arts council has been questioned in a report on its cultural identity.

The document, on the results of a consultation on the Scottish executive's planned national cultural strategy, not only found that people were fed up with funding crises afflicting the companies, but also questioned whether they should even be called national, because they neither reflected the Scottish nation nor performed nationally.

Most of the 1,000 people consulted called for a funding review of Scottish Opera, Scottish Ballet, the Royal Scottish National Orchestra and the Scottish Chamber Orchestra. They thought the Scottish arts council should become more of an enabler and supporter rather than a powerful organisation with its own agenda, or should be abolished.

Last week a report by the Scottish executive on Scottish Opera said the company was brought to within 24 hours of closure by arrogant and irresponsible management.

The consultation document was based on written responses and public meetings held over seven months. Yesterday Rhona Brankin, deputy minister for culture and sport, said the exercise had identified a number of key themes for the executive to look at more closely.

The report found concern that Scotland's cultural image had too much emphasis on tartan and shortbread. - Kirsty Scott

webTitle: One in four shoppers buy organic

fields.headline: One in four shoppers buy organic
fields.trailText: More than one person in four eats some form of organic food, although higher prices are still putting many customers off, according to a survey published yesterday.
fields.body:
More than one person in four eats some form of organic food, although higher prices are still putting many customers off, according to a survey published yesterday.

Organic food is seen as healthier, safer and tastier. In the survey of 2,000 people for Health Which? magazine, 29% said they replaced some of their staple food with organic alternatives. Fruit and vegetables were the most popular purchases, with 18% saying they sometimes bought organic. One in 10 occasionally bought organic meat, dairy products and bread.

Of those who chose organic alternatives, 60% gave health as their main reason, while half said they liked the lack of pesticides in products.

Forty-six per cent thought organic food contained more vitamins and minerals, while 9% were worried about genetic modification and 6% about the link between BSE and its human form, variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

Organic alternatives tasted better than traditionally farmed food for 29%. Only 8% "went organic" because they thought the farming practices were better for the environment.

Only 2% said they always ate organic food, the higher cost being the main reason for customers sticking to traditional products. For 45% of people who did not buy organic, price was the turn-off.

Mary Weston, coordinator of Organic Livestock Marketing Co-operative, said: "It does cost more to grow and farm things organically. But demand is shooting up, and if customers stick with it prices will come down."

webTitle: American or Czech, it's still Bud

fields.headline: American or Czech, it's still Bud
fields.trailText: Czech and American companies, which have been trying to stop each other using the trade marks Bud and Budweiser since 1911, yesterday heard that the names belong to both breweries despite the "danger of confusion"
fields.body:
Czech and American companies, which have been trying to stop each other using the trade marks Bud and Budweiser in legal actions since 1911, yesterday heard three court of appeal judges rule that the names belong to both breweries despite the "danger of confusion".

Lord Justice Gibson said the name came from a town in Bohemia once named Budwis but now called by its Czech name, Ceske Budejovice.

Budejovicky Budvaris is the successor of a brewing firm established there in 1895 while Anheuser-Busch Inc set up business in Missouri in the 19th century and began calling its beer Budweiser in 1875.

Lord Justice Gibson said: "When the Czech brewery sought to expand its sales into the United States in the early part of the last century, battle was joined."

Legal action over the use of the trade mark Budweiser continued in the early 1970s when both companies began to market products in the UK.

More litigation was triggered when the Czech firm successfully applied to register Bud as a trade mark.

The companies are fighting over the same names after both made further applications to register them as trade marks for different beers and lagers.

Lord Justice Gibson said both companies had been using the names Budweiser and Bud since the 19th century and agreed that both sides' appeals against registration by their rivals should be dismissed.

webTitle: Scooter deal hit by loss of Geri

fields.headline: Scooter deal hit by loss of Geri
fields.trailText: The departure of Geri Halliwell from the Spice Girls led to an Italian scooter firm refusing to pay the last instalment of a sponsorship deal, the high court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The departure of Geri Halliwell from the Spice Girls led to an Italian scooter firm refusing to pay the last instalment of a sponsorship deal, the high court heard yesterday.

Aprilia World Service, which sponsored the girls' world tour in 1998, fell out with the group after Ginger Spice's departure allegedly left its advertising campaign for the 50cc Spice Sonic scooter in tatters.

The girls sued for £212,500 when Aprilia refused to pay the final instalment of the £400,000 deal. Aprilia hit back by suing for what it claims is £1.1m in lost profits caused by the logos of the five girls on their scooters not matching up to the four girls left in the group.

Andrew Sutcliffe, representing the Italian company, told Mrs Justice Arden that Aprilia became involved with the group three months after their second album, Spice World, was released in October 1997.

Aprilia says it entered into a contract not knowing that Geri intended to leave, even though she had told the group.

The company said in a statement: "Aprilia, having incurred an equally large amount of costs in preparing marketing material and having launched a limited edition Spice Sonic scooter, therefore decided not settle the balance of sponsorship fees."

When the company was sued, it brought a counter-claim for misrepresentation and breach of contract.

The case continues today.

fields.headline: Ex-army chief denies Rwanda genocide
fields.trailText: A former Rwandan army chief accused of genocide in his homeland denied being involved in the slaughter of more than 100,000 people when he appeared in a London court yesterday.
fields.body:
A former Rwandan army chief accused of genocide in his homeland denied being involved in the slaughter of more than 100,000 people when he appeared in a London court yesterday.

Tharcisse Muvunyi, 46, was arrested at the weekend by police acting on a warrant from the international criminal tribunal for Rwanda, set up by the United Nations after the country's civil war in 1994. He is the first person living in Britain to be indicted by Rwanda.

Muvunyi - known as the Commander - was remanded in custody after a 30-minute appearance at Bow Street magistrates court. He has 15 days to appeal against a transfer to the tribunal, which is based in Tanzania.

His solicitor, Michael Fisher, told the court: "He denies taking any part in the killings, massacres and genocide in Rwanda in 1994. He never took part in these acts, he did not instigate them, he did not incite others to commit them. As a professional soldier, he was as shocked and appalled at the genocide as any other right-minded person."

The Rwanda tribunal said yesterday that Muvunyi faces five counts of genocide and crimes against humanity. He was the military commander of two provinces between April and June 1994, when more than 100,000 Tutsis were killed by soldiers allegedly acting on his orders. More than 800,000 people were killed during the civil war.

Muvunyi has lived in Lewisham, south-east London, since March 1998, when he arrived on a train at Waterloo. His wife and three children were already in London, and the family were granted permission to remain in Britain until 2002 while their application for political asylum was processed. Their status in Britain is not affected by his arrest.

In court yesterday, Mr Fisher argued that Muvunyi had tried to prevent the genocide, without success, after the civil war intensified. "It was impossible for my client, with his limited resources, manpower and equipment, to prevent the horror and disaster that followed. He did everything that he could in his power to prevent these atrocities from occurring."

The court heard that the date of birth stated on the tribunal's arrest warrant differed from Muvunyi's by four days. But the magistrate, Nicholas Evans, rejected the argument of his solicitor that he was not the man identified on the document. Mr Evans also rejected an application for bail, saying there was a substantial risk that Muvunyi would flee.

Yesterday's proceedings were relayed in French to Muvunyi, who wore jeans and a dark blue puffa jacket, by a translator standing in the dock next to him. He spoke only to confirm his name. When Mr Evans explained that he would be detained, he dabbed his face with a handkerchief.

Muvunyi's legal team are now considering an appeal. Mr Fisher said outside the court that Muvunyi could appeal for judicial review on the grounds that the magistrate's decision to approve the warrant was wrong in law, or could seek to prove at the high court that he was being unlawfully held. The case could end up at the House of Lords, meaning it could be weeks or even months before Muvunyi is handed over to the UN tribunal.

If there is no challenge, the home secretary, Jack Straw, would make arrangements to transfer Muvunyi to the tribunal. It is understood that Mr Straw has no discretion to refuse a handover on compassionate grounds, in the way he decided to prevent General Augusto Pinochet's extradition to Spain. The process of transferring suspects to UN war crimes tribunals is simpler than extradition. In any case, Britain has no extradition treaty with Rwanda.

Alphonse Umulisa, 37, who lost his parents and six brothers and sisters in the genocide, was at Bow Street for Muvunyi's court appearance. Mr Umulisa, now a student in London, said: "I'm glad that he can go to court. It's the only way I can find out who killed my parents."

fields.headline: Fraud squad to investigate TransTec
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The former treasury minister, Geoffrey Robinson, faces a full-blown fraud squad inquiry into claims that his collapsed TransTec engineering group deliberately inflated applications for government grants during the late 1980s.
fields.body:
The former treasury minister, Geoffrey Robinson, faces a full-blown fraud squad inquiry into claims that his collapsed TransTec engineering group deliberately inflated applications for government grants during the late 1980s.

Investigators at the department of trade and industry yesterday handed their files on the case to West Midlands police.

In another ominous development for the ex-paymaster general, the Northern Ireland Office said its industrial development board (IDB) was reviewing files relating to grants totalling £6.9m for TransTec's plant at Campsie, in the west of the province. The board had said it would take no action until a concrete allegation was received.

The decision to pass on the DTI's grants investigation to the police comes just a few days after a departmental team interviewed Max Ayriss, the former accountant of the Birmingham-based group and the man who first alleged fraud in relation to government subsidies.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, announced the internal investigation on January 23, and two days later listed the £1.3m of grants paid to TransTec between the mid-1980s and mid-90s.

The DTI, which is not a prosecuting authority for fraud cases, said yesterday that, in the light of the interview with Mr Ayriss, "the DTI has handed over to the West Midlands police information relating to grant payments made by the department to subsidiaries of TransTec plc and the information revealed by the department's inquiries into these matters."

Mr Ayriss alleged that between 1986-88 claims for subsidies for technical innovation were falsified to inflate the amount of money TransTec was spending to develop a new electric-spark drill. He alleged that nearly £500,000 of the £1.3m in DTI grants that TransTec received was fraudulently obtained.

Mr Ayriss also alleged that Mr Robinson had planned to let out a building on Birmingham's Coleshill industrial estate after buying it with £30,000 of DTI aid, purportedly for the expansion of TransTec, a move that was against the spirit if not the letter of the law.

Last night the government shifted its stance on demands from the Conservative opposition for a parallel inquiry by the authorities in Northern Ireland into the much larger Campsie grants. The Northern Ireland Office said: "The ... IDB is not aware of any allegations of fraudulent grant claims in relation to TransTec", but added, for the first time, "the IDB is reviewing its files."

Peter Mandelson,the Northern Ireland secretary, had to resign a previous cabinet post in December 1998 because of an undisclosed home loan from Mr Robinson.

Mr Robinson, who resigned as paymaster general over the Mandelson loan affair, has denied any wrongdoing in relation to TransTec.

fields.headline: Keeper crushed by elephant
fields.standfirst:
Port Lympne tragedy refuels controversy about Aspinall wildlife parks

Howletts & Port Lympne Wild Animal Parks
fields.trailText: A zoo-keeper was crushed to death yesterday by an elephant in his care at a Kent wildlife park owned by the millionaire conservationist and gambler John Aspinall.
fields.body:
A zoo-keeper was crushed to death yesterday by an elephant in his care at a Kent wildlife park owned by the millionaire conservationist and gambler John Aspinall.

Darren Cockrill, 27, was found with multiple injuries in the stall of a 14 year-old female Indian elephant called La Petite, who had been at the Port Lympne wildlife park, near Hythe in Kent, for less than three months. Despite attempts to revive him at the scene, he was pronounced dead on arrival at hospital.

The park was closed while police and local health and safety inspectors began an investigation.

Mr Aspinall is renowned for his unorthodox views on animal welfare and zoo manage ment. He insists on close social contact between his keepers and the animals in their care, believing that this and the development of a bond of affection and trust is crucial to animal welfare.

"Bonding" begins early in the animal's life, in the hope that it will be carried on to adulthood, allowing the keepers to check for signs of injury, illness or pregnancy, and reducing the occasions on which the animals will have to be immobilised or anaesthetised, which is routine practice in other zoos.

Mr Aspinall's methods are also intended to give the keepers an insight into the individual personalities and social relationships of their animals, and provide emotional and intellectual stimulation for the animals. But the policy, which sees keepers regularly entering the cages of large and potentially dangerous animals such as gorillas, elephants and tigers, has been blamed by some for the high number of deaths and injuries at Mr Aspinall's zoos.

In 1994 a keeper at Port Lympne's sister wildlife park, Howletts in Canterbury, was mauled to death after entering the cage of a Siberian tiger in his care, prompting the local council to ban keepers from entering the tiger cages. In 1996 an appeal by Mr Aspinall against the decision was upheld by an industrial tribunal, and the practice resumed.

A statement from Port Lympne and Howletts countered accusations that the practice is unduly dangerous: "Going in with animals of large and potentially dangerous species involves some risk, but it is our belief that the benefits far outweigh the dangers. The practice has now been going on for over 40 years at Howletts and over 25 years at Port Lympne.

"There have been several tragedies in that time, something which no zoo can guarantee to avoid in all circumstances."

Mr Cockrill, who lived at the zoo and had eight years experience as an elephant keeper, assumed the care of La Petite when she arrived in November from an Austrian safari park.

"It seems he may have trusted La Petite to be as reliable and friendly as the other [elephant] cows which had been in his care and known to him for seven years," said a zoo spokesman.

Mr Aspinall, who is in South Africa, said: "Darren was a top quality keeper, one of the best, and the Port Lympne elephant section is the best in the world. This is a severe blow to us all. My sympathy goes to his mother, father and girlfriend."

Ray Lewis of Shepway district council, whose health and safety department will lead the investigation, said: "The details of the death are unclear. We have a team of three looking at the incident together with the police.

"Port Lympne is one of the biggest tourist attractions in the south-east and it is one of the top zoos. In fact they don't even call it a zoo, it is a wildlife park, the animals are slightly more free," he said.

La Petite was one of three cows brought to Port Lympne from Gansendorf safari park for mating. The intention was that she would remain at Port Lympne following mating, while the other two elephants would return to Austria.

Port Lympne and Howletts have 32 elephants. Port Lympne also recently took in five elephants from a zoo in Rotterdam, where they had fought with other elephants.

Aside from his views on conservation, Mr Aspinall has courted controversy in other areas of public life. A close friend of the late Sir James Goldsmith, he stood as a Referendum party candidate at the 1997 general election, contesting Michael Howard's Folkestone constituency.

A former marine, Mr Aspinall accumulated his fortune largely from gambling. In July last year he was diagnosed with cancer of the jaw.

Catalogue of deaths and injuries to staff and visitors

A number of keepers and visitors have been killed or injured by animals at John Aspinall's two wildlife parks in Kent: Port Lympne and Howletts.

1980 A tigress called Zeya was shot after killing two keepers at Howletts. Brian Stocks and Bob Wilson, were mauled to death within weeks of each other.

1984 Mark Aitken, a 22-year old keeper at Port Lympne was crushed to death by a bull elephant called Bindu. A fellow keeper suggested at the time that his death had been the result of an "affectionate hug".

1989 Matthew McDaid, aged two, had his arm ripped off by a chimp called Bustah at Port Lympne after reaching into the animal's cage to stroke it. Keepers had to use drugged darts to retrieve the limb, which the chimp used as a weapon to beat them off. In 1996 the boy received £132,093 in damages at the high court in London.

Five years later Bustah struck again, pulling the finger and thumb from the hand of a volunteer worker at Port Lympne.

1994 Trevor Smith, a keeper at Howletts, was killed when a two-year-old Siberian tiger pounced on him. Canterbury council subsequently banned keepers from entering tiger cages, a decision overturned on appeal.
