fields.headline: Report 'may stigmatise' Pinochet
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The disclosure of the medical report that found Augusto Pinochet was unfit to stand trial would leave the former Chilean dictator "open to opprobrium and the risk of being stigmatised as mentally defective", the high court in London heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The disclosure of the medical report that found Augusto Pinochet was unfit to stand trial would leave the former Chilean dictator "open to opprobrium and the risk of being stigmatised as mentally defective", the high court in London heard yesterday.

In the second bid for judicial review of Jack Straw's announcement that he is "minded" to halt extradition proceedings against the general, lawyers for the Belgian government rejected arguments put forward by General Pinochet's legal team that he was entitled to have the report's contents kept confidential under the European convention of human rights.

Nigel Pleming QC, for the Belgian authorities, said it was being submitted on behalf of the general that the report contained "highly personal and sensitive data", including information about his mental health, and that the disclosure of such data "may dramatically affect his private and family life, as well as his social and political situation, by exposing him to opprobrium and the risk of being stigmatised as mentally defective".

Mr Pleming urged Lord Justice Simon Brown, sitting with Mr Justice Latham and Mr Justice Dyson, to reject the argument, and allow the Belgian authorities access to the medical report.

"It is not intended to show it to his friends and family. We are not seeking any form of publication to the world.

"We are seeking no more for Belgium than the secretary of state has already afforded to the solicitor general and the director of public prosecutions in the UK," the court was told.

Yesterday's hearing followed Mr Justice Maurice Kay's decision last week to throw out the first application for judicial review by the Belgian authorities and six human rights groups.

He ruled Mr Straw had acted "lawfully, fairly and rationally" in refusing to disclose the confidential medical reports.

Yesterday Mr Pleming accused the home secretary of acting in breach of natural justice, misdirecting himself in law and acting contrary to the principles of comity among nations by refusing Belgium a proper opportunity to know details of the report.

Richard Drabble QC, appearing for the human rights groups, supported the Belgian government's argument, saying: "No satisfactory thought has been given to the procedural interests of anyone other than Senator Pinochet."

Mr Drabble said the home secretary should have entered into a procedure where there was a means of protection for the victims. Disclosure of the report to the Spanish and Belgian authorities would have been a "sizeable step forward" for the victims.

The hearing continues today and the three judges are expected to announce their ruling later this week.

fields.headline: Partner sought after acid death
fields.standfirst: Doctor died after drinking drain cleaning fluid
fields.trailText: Police want to speak to the partner of a hospital doctor who died a slow and agonising death after drinking sulphuric acid.
fields.body:
Police want to speak to the partner of a hospital doctor who died a slow and agonising death after drinking sulphuric acid.

Detectives in the west midlands named the man as Andrew Gardner, who has not been seen since the death of Karenina Longe, with whom he lived in Birmingham.

Dr Longe, 27, was taken to the Heartlands hospital, where she worked as a senior house officer in the accident and emergency department, on Saturday afternoon after drinking what police believe may have been drain cleaning fluid. She died early on Sunday.

Detective Chief Inspector Graham Bennett said it was unclear how Dr Longe came to swallow the acid but it did not seem as if she had been forced to take it. "One of the possibilities we are looking at is that the acid may have been put in a drink."

He said the couple had had a stormy relationship which had "taken a turn for the worse" in the past week. Dr Longe had moved out of the rented home they shared in the Sheldon district and moved back into hospital accommodation.

The couple had met 18 months previously and Mr Gardner, who was unemployed but had worked in the blood transfusion service, moved to Birmingham in September 1999 with his 15-year-old son from another relationship.

Mr Bennett said: "Paramedics arrived at her house in six minutes and did what they could for her. She was still conscious. It would appear that the original call was made by her boyfriend.

"But he did not then go in the ambulance with her to the hospital. The last time he was seen was at the house. We believe he holds vital information."

A postmortem had not shown how Dr Longe, known to her friends as Karen or Nina, had swallowed the acid.

Mr Bennett said: "There are no bruises on her body that would suggest she was forced to drink it.

"It is a normal acid that can be taken from any builder's or plumber's merchants and is used to clean drains. We later found a quantity of this in the house.

"We have also removed cups and mugs from the house to discover if there are any traces on them. One of the possibilities we are looking at is that the acid may have been put in a drink."

Mr Bennett said a very small quantity could prove lethal but he did not know how much Dr Longe had drunk. "Any toxic substance would mean a very slow and painful death."

Dr Longe had dual British and Nigerian nationality. Mr Bennett added: "From our inquiries she is a mature, intelligent lady with no financial problems.

"Their relationship was at an end or coming to an end and Nina had moved out earlier in the week.

"She had visited the house again on Saturday morning, possibly to pick up some of her belongings."

Mr Gardner was born in Zimbabwe and is believed to have contacts in that country and in London. He is described as 5ft 11in tall with short cropped dark hair.

"Their relationship was at an end or coming to an end and Nina had moved out earlier in the week. "She had visited the house again on Saturday morning, possibly to pick up some of her belongings." Mr Gardner was born in Zimbabwe and is believed to have contacts in that country and in London. He is described as 5ft 11in tall with short cropped dark hair.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Police question Dando suspect
fields.body:
Police question Dando suspect

Detectives hunting the killer of Jill Dando have interviewed a suspect after tracing him over the internet, Scotland Yard said yesterday.

The man, who allegedly obtained the television presenter's home address through an online electoral roll, was questioned last week after his details were supplied by an internet company. Sources said he was not a "strong" suspect.

High jinks cost £4,000

A businesswoman convicted of being drunk on an aircraft was yesterday fined £2,000 and ordered to pay £2,000 costs at Croydon crown court.

Heather Tagg, 33, was found guilty last month of being drunk on a Virgin Atlantic Airways flight from Newark, New Jersey, to Gatwick. She was cleared of assault.

Dying for a smoke

Irish people who smoke die seven years younger than their non-smoking compatriots, according to a study by Ireland's Society of Actuaries.

Using information from 500,000 life insurance policies, the society found that from the age of 40, a smoker's prospect of death in any given year was twice as high as that of a non-smoker.

Hospital attack remand

A 21-year-old man was remanded in custody yesterday accused of attacking a healthcare worker in the grounds of a hospital.

Dean Locke, who is unemployed, of Bristol, appeared before a stipendiary magistrate in the city. He is accused of causing Alison Shortman, 39, grievous bodily harm with intent on Friday at the city's Southmead hospital.

fields.headline: Theatre to step up tours
fields.trailText: The Royal National Theatre is to double its touring programme, sending more of its bigger productions out on the road, and will launch more co-productions and bring regional shows to London, its director, Sir Trevor Nunn, said yesterday.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
The Royal National Theatre is to double its touring programme, sending more of its bigger productions out on the road, and will launch more co-productions and bring regional shows to London, its director, Sir Trevor Nunn, said yesterday.

"We believe passionately in building on our relationship with the regions," he said. "It is a two-way traffic: it brings new blood into our theatre too."

An independent report for the Arts Council has predicted a bleak future for most regional theatres, with the virtual abandonment of expensive original productions and long periods between touring productions.

The touring programme will increase from 11 to 16 weeks this year and to 20 weeks next year. The new regime will be launched with a co-production with Sheffield Theatres of The Heiress, based on Henry James's novel Washington Square, with Alan Howard and Maggie Steed. It will open in Sheffield in April before a national tour, and go on to the Lyttelton in London in June.

A new production of Hamlet, with Simon Russell Beale, will be directed by John Caird and will go on a world tour.

The National still hopes for Broadway runs for some of its most praised productions, including The Merchant of Venice, but Sir Trevor admitted feeling bruised by the refusal of Equity in America to allow the National's award-winning Oklahoma! to cross the Atlantic.

webTitle: Union giant fears swing to the left

fields.headline: Union giant fears swing to the left
fields.trailText: Fears are growing among leaders of Britain's largest union, the 1.3m-strong Unison, that discontent with the government and a low ballot turnout could deliver victory to a leftist outsider in the contest for a successor to Rodney Bickerstaffe as general secretary.
fields.body:
Fears are growing among leaders of Britain's largest union, the 1.3m-strong Unison, that discontent with the government and a low ballot turnout could deliver victory to a leftist outsider in the contest for a successor to Rodney Bickerstaffe as general secretary.

The election of Roger Bannister, a local union official from Knowsley backed by a coalition of leftwing groups, would trigger an internal crisis in the public service union and lead to damaging conflict with Tony Blair's administration, his opponents argue.

It had been assumed that victory for Dave Prentis, Mr Bickerstaffe's deputy, was a foregone conclusion.

He has the overwhelming backing of Unison's executive and officialdom, and a commanding lead in branch nominations.

But Mr Bannister - a member of the Socialist Party, successor to Labour's one-time Militant Tendency - is widely regarded as having run an expectedly strong campaign and the prospect that he might be elected to one of the most powerful jobs in the trade union movement is causing alarm in Downing Street.

Promising to take no more than his existing pay of £22,500 - rather than the £69,545 available to the union's general secretary - Mr Bannister has been able to capitalise on the demoralisation of many public service workers and the continuing squeeze on their pay and conditions.

By contrast, the more mainstream Mr Prentis is attracting criticism from those in the union who believe that the Unison leadership has pulled its punches with the Blair government over pay, contracting-out and the private finance initiative.

"The current leadership is too close to the government and at least as concerned with not upsetting Tony Blair as they are with a vigorous defence of jobs, pay and conditions of service," Mr Bannister said yesterday.

He also questioned Unison's annual £1.5m donation to the Labour party and called for the union to back some non-Labour candidates in local and parliamentary elections.

Mr Prentis, who most insiders agree remains the favourite, countered: "As long as I'm around, Unison will not be in the pockets of any political party and that includes the Labour party.

"I will criticise the government when it's wrong and I'll stand up to the government for Unison members and Unison policies".

Supporters of Mr Prentis, who also has some leftwing support in the union, believe that fewer than 15% of members may have yet voted - the ballot closes on February 18 - and that Mr Bannister could attract at least 100,000 votes.

But they are hoping that his Militant past - he was expelled from the Labour party in 1986, along with the deputy leader of Liverpool council, Derek Hatton - will undermine his support.

A third candidate, Malkiat Bilku, a Hillingdon striker, is not expected to poll strongly.

webTitle: Woman who cried rape faces £500,000 libel bill

fields.headline: Woman who cried rape faces £500,000 libel bill
fields.trailText: A pharmacist who accused a colleague of raping her was ordered to pay him £400,000 damages yesterday in what is thought to be the first successful libel action of its sort.
fields.body:
A pharmacist who accused a colleague of raping her was ordered to pay him £400,000 damages yesterday in what is thought to be the first successful libel action of its sort.

Lynn Walker, 33, faces a bill of more than £500,000 after a jury of eight women and four men at the high court at Newcastle upon Tyne found that she had libelled and slandered Martin Garfoot, a senior pharmacist who worked with her at a branch of Boots in North Shields.

Mr Garfoot, 46, married with two teenage children, sued Ms Walker after she told senior managers at Boots that he had performed oral sex on her, attempted anal sex and then raped her. She also alleged that he had subjected her to a campaign of verbal and physical abuse.

After the verdict it emerged that Mr Garfoot, from Whickham, Gateshead, had offered to accept £25,000 to settle the case out of court, but Ms Walker had refused all attempts at settlement.

Ms Walker, who was not in court to hear the verdict, was ordered to pay Mr Garfoot's costs on the indemnity basis: a higher than usual costs award which usually reflects court disapproval of the way a litigant has conducted the case.

As a rape complainant, Ms Walker's identity was kept secret throughout the case, but last night the judge, Mr Justice Hooper, allowed her to be named. It was "a very unusual case, and it is in the public interest to remove the restriction", he said.

Ms Walker did not go to the police but made the allegations orally to two senior managers 11 months later and repeated them in writing.

Mr Garfoot, who was moved to another Boots branch after the allegations while she remained, sued her for libel and slander, claiming the allegations "severely damaged" his reputation.

During the seven-day hearing, Ms Walker, from Low Fell, Gateshead, told the jury that she wished she had passed out during the attack "because the memories would not be so bad".

She said: "We had been working late and we were the only two people left in the shop. I went into the staff-room to close a window, and when I turned around Mr Garfoot was there. He grabbed my shoulders and spun me round to face him and tried to kiss me. I was completely startled.

"He pushed me to the floor and got on top of me. He tried to kiss me and put his tongue in my mouth. He was sweating profusely, his shirt was clammy, and I could feel his beard against my face."

She said that he performed a sexual act that caused her "excruciating pain, like nothing I have ever felt before. He then raped me."

The jury heard that in the months after the alleged attack Ms Walker went on a staff trip with Mr Garfoot, accepted lifts to work from him, spent time alone in areas of the shop with him, and called at his home to pick up work documents.

Edward Garnier QC, for Mr Garfoot, told the court: "The only inference that can be drawn is that the jury have decided she is an out and out liar."

Mr Justice Hooper refused an application by Ms Walker's counsel, Andrew Monson, for permission to appeal against the amount of damages above £75,000, but she can ask the appeal court itself for permission. He said: "Her assets are limited, and she will need time to pay up to the amount of £75,000."

In a statement afterwards Mr Monson said: "When the defendant hears the result she will be devastated, not least because she faces financial ruin. She may appeal on the size of the damages awarded."

A spokeswoman for Boots said: "We are reviewing the implications of this decision, and that's all we can say at the moment."

In what is thought to be the only similar case, a civil servant in the immigration service last year sued for slander a co-worker who accused him of raping her in a relationship, but the jury failed to reach a verdict.

webTitle: Irvine sets date for new damages law

fields.headline: Irvine sets date for new damages law
fields.trailText: Changes to the law to encourage more libel cases to be settled cheaply without a full trial will come into effect on February 28, the lord chancellor announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Changes to the law to encourage more libel cases to be settled cheaply without a full trial will come into effect on February 28, the lord chancellor announced yesterday.

Newspapers will be able to avoid full-scale defamation actions by making an "offer of amends" - agreeing to publish a correction and apology and pay appropriate damages and costs. The court will fix the payouts if the parties are unable to agree.

If the offer is turned down, the paper will be able to use it as a defence when proceedings go ahead, and to argue for a smaller sum to be awarded in damages.

There will be a special quick procedure for a judge to dispose of a claim without a jury if there seems no realistic prospect of success, or no defence to the claim.

The judge will be able to award damages of up to £10,000 and to order the defendant to publish a summary of the judgment.

Claimants may be forced to have their case dealt with by this new procedure even if they want to go for a full hearing, if the judge decides the compensation which can be awarded is adequate.

The changes will bring into effect those parts of the defamation act 1996 which are still outstanding.

The lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, said: "I am sure litigants unfortunate enough to become involved in defamation proceedings will agree that the new procedures present a marked improvement in terms of speed and efficiency for dealing with these actions."

The procedures will not apply to complex libel actions like those brought by the former Tory ministers Neil Hamilton and Jonathan Aitken, or the one by the historian David Irving against Penguin Books being heard in the high court.

Andrew Stephenson, senior partner of the libel firm Peter Carter-Ruck & Partners, said he was uncertain how effective the offer of amends would be in the majority of cases - those where more than one allegation had been made or where there were arguments over what had actually been alleged.

But he said that the changes could encourage more people to sue.

"It may lead to more claims by people who would otherwise have been put off by a very expensive process."

fields.headline: Stand-off at Stansted
fields.standfirst:
Hijack drama Eight hostages released as negotiations

More about the Stansted hijack

live ITN video feed from the hijacked aircraft
fields.trailText: Negotiations at Stansted airport with the armed hijackers of an Afghan airline Boeing 727 were continuing last night with no immediate prospect of an end to the crisis, despite the hopes raised by the release of eight of the plane's 165 passengers since it landed early yesterday.
fields.body:
Negotiations at Stansted airport with the armed hijackers of an Afghan airline Boeing 727 were continuing last night with no immediate prospect of an end to the crisis, despite the hopes raised by the release of eight of the plane's 165 passengers since it landed early yesterday.

Talks with a group of about six hijackers demanding the release of a rebel Afghan leader, Ismail Khan, were described by police last night as "fairly calm and business-like".

But the Afghan government, run by the hardline Taliban movement, stated unequivocably yesterday it would not consider any deal and said they expected the British government to deal forcibly with the terrorists.

British officials made it clear that they hoped the quiet negotiation, which has worked in previous hijack situations at Stansted, would prove successful again.

Tony Blair, who was woken at about 1am to be informed that the hijacked plane was on its way to the Essex airport, has to re-establish the credibility of the international community's policy of no-deals with hijackers. The policy was severely undermined by the Indian government's decision to give way by releasing prisoners in a similar hijack six weeks ago.

The plane, belonging to the Ariana airline, has been under the control of the hijackers since 5.30GMT on Sunday morning. They took control of a flight from the Afghan capital, Kabul, which was supposed to land at the remote northern town of Mazar-e-Sharif 40 minutes later.

Instead, the plane was diverted by the hijackers, going on an odyssey that included Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan and Russia before arriving at Stansted at 2.01am yesterday.

The duty foreign office minister, John Battle, gave consentfor the plane to land at Stansted, the designated Lon don airport for hijack incidents. The hijackers are believed to have first asked to go to Heathrow.

During the day, they released three men, three women and two children. Armed police and troops, almost certainly including an SAS team, remained on standby as the plane sat on the south side of airfield last night. Police refused to say what demands, if any, the hijackers were making but said negotiations were being conducted in English. The hijackers are believed to have released nine hostages in Moscow and 10 in Tashkent.

At about 11.50am yesterday two men, both aged 26, a 17-year-old woman and two young children were released and taken to an Essex police station. The children, the woman and one of the men were from the same family.

Three hours later a man and two women were released at the same time as hot food and soft drinks were taken on board. When the plane landed there were 122 men, 20 women and 23 children on board, including 14 crew and the hijackers. Aviation officials said 35 of those belonged to a family heading for a wedding in the north of Afghanistan.

Earlier, at about 6.30am, a generator had been handed over to the hijackers to allow the plane to be air-conditioned. Tea bags, toilet rolls and baby food was also handed over. Negotiations continued on into the evening, with requests for fresh water and for the toilets on the plane to be cleaned.

At midday assistant chief constable John Broughton said they were entering "a critical stage of negotiations". But the stand-off continued into the evening. Three specially trained negotiators were believed to be conducting talks with the hijackers.

The Essex police officers were under the overall control of the chief constable, David Stevens, but police were reluctant to give away too much information about the talks.

The incident, the third major hijack situation at Stansted since 1982, severely disrupted flights.

Ryanair, the major carrier out of Stansted, cancelled all its early flights. The British Airports Authority closed part of the runway, making it impossible for larger planes to take off. But the airport was back to about 90% capacity by early evening.

The Taliban leader, Mullah Mohammad Omar, issued a statement read by the movement's ambassador to Pakistan in Islamabad saying it would not negotiate with the hijackers. Describing the hijackers as terrorists, Omar said: "We will not negotiate with them. We will not accept their demands."

Officials at Stansted said they believed the recent hijack in India, which ended in Afghanistan with the hijackers escaping and some of their demands being met, may have encouraged similar actions.

But the Indian minister for information, Shri Arun Jaitley, defended the decision: "One difference is that the last hijack was in a place where commando action was ruled out. While commando action is ruled out, you have to settle."

webTitle: Dissidents to step up campaign of terror

fields.headline: Dissidents to step up campaign of terror
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Renegade republicans threw the crisis-ridden peace process in Northern Ireland into fresh turmoil last night when they threatened to step up their campaign of terror.
fields.body:
Renegade republicans threw the crisis-ridden peace process in Northern Ireland into fresh turmoil last night when they threatened to step up their campaign of terror.

The Continuity IRA (CIRA), the only republican terror group yet to call a ceasefire, said it was behind Sunday night's bombing of a Co Fermanagh hotel, the first major blast since the Real IRA killed 29 in Omagh in August 1998.

The CIRA, which wants to wreck devolution, said last night: "We intend to continue to progress our war effort regardless of how British rule in the six occupied counties is remodelled. This progression shall continue until such times as there is a British declaration of intent to withdraw."

The group has previously chosen the most delicate times in the peace process to detonate bombs. It is now working with the Real IRA, with dissident republican terrorists now totalling more than 100.

The group's statement is the latest blow to mainstream republicans. The IRA is struggling to contain defections to the dissidents, while coming under intense pressure to begin decommissioning.

John Hume, the leader of the Social, Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP), underscored the growing isolation of mainstream republicans when he called on the IRA to dispose of some Semtex to save Northern Ireland's fledgling power-sharing executive from suspension on Friday. He appealed to the IRA's patriotism to decommission some of its three-tonne cache of the high explosive to "show their deep respect for the will of the Irish people."

Mr Hume said the difficulties would be swiftly overcome if the IRA dumped some Semtex and told General John de Chastelain, chairman of the international commission on decommissioning, where to find it. In an article in the Irish Times, Mr Hume said: "I ask for them to demonstrate for all to see their patriotism and desire to move the situation forward by strengthening the peace process through beginning voluntarily the process of decommissioning."

His remarks wounded Sinn Fein because Mr Hume was a crucial ally in bringing republicans into mainstream politics.

Sinn Fein, which has seen even staunch supporters in the US media turn against republicans on the arms issue, appears astonished at how isolated republicanism now is on decommissioning. One government figure referred to "a spontaneous consensus which has taken them by surprise."

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, who met Mr Adams yesterday, is preparing to suspend the new institutions if there is no progress towards decommissioning from the IRA before Friday. The bill providing for the restoration of direct rule will today begin its swift passage through Parliament.

A flurry of meetings involving the Irish government and the IRA is under way in an effort to secure another IRA statement before Friday, the day before David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, meets with his party's ruling council. Mr Mandelson would be prepared to accept evidence of serious progress and is believed to be hoping for a start date and timetable.

Even if it is achieved, it looks to be too little for Mr Trimble. He promised the 860 delegates to party council in November that he would quit as first minister if there was no start to IRA decommissioning before it reconvened this Saturday.

Although Mr Mandelson is loath to suspend the institutions, sparking a possible Sinn Fein legal challenge, he believes Mr Trimble's resignation would be much more damaging. Seamus Mallon, the deputy first minister, would also have to leave office.

The Good Friday agreement then requires for the assembly to vote two successors in on a cross-community basis. Under the current arithmetic, that would be impossible and the only move then would be to call fresh elections to the 108-seat assembly.

One government source said that would plunge the peace process into chaos, with hardliners elected in droves.

Sinn Fein's challenge to suspension would revolve around such a move being outside the terms of the agreement. The only date it contains is May 22, the aspirational deadline for all paramilitary weaponry to be decommissioned.

fields.headline: Brain surgery deaths 'avoidable'
fields.trailText: Brain surgery patients are dying needlessly because Britain has too few consultant surgeons and a drastic shortage of specialist beds, according to a report to be published today.
fields.body:
Brain surgery patients are dying needlessly because Britain has too few consultant surgeons and a drastic shortage of specialist beds, according to a report to be published today.

The Society of British Neurological Surgeons says urgent action is needed, as many neurosurgical units are often working beyond safe limits and discharging patients too early from specialist beds.

The report called for an increase in specialist surgeons and beds.

Critics claim that the combined effect of previous recommendations on staffing and bed levels made in 1993 are not yet being met and an increasingly elderly population is adding to the problems faced in neurosurgery.

Barry Jackson, president of the Royal College of Surgeons, said: "Last year a working party from the royal college drew attention to a crisis in the provision of services for head injuries, with patients dying unnecessarily or suffering long-term consequences due to inadequate funding.

"This report makes it clear that almost all neurosurgical units are frequently working beyond their safe capacity for the same reason. The situation is urgent."

Neurosurgeons deal with brain and spinal conditions, and much of their work is conducted on an emergency basis, treating tumours, haemorrhages and brain and spinal injuries caused by accidents.

Some 29,000 of the 49,000 operations carried out last year were classified as emergencies or life-threatening.

The Safe Neurosurgery Report 2000 found that of the 37 neurosurgical units in the UK, some have just one third of the beds they need to operate safely while 16 still have no designated neurosurgical intensive care spaces.

The report said that 30 neurosurgical beds and four dedicated neurosurgical intensive therapy beds per 1m of the population are needed to deliver safe practice.

The report also recommended that all neurosurgical units should provide 24-hour cover with a minimum of six consultant surgeons per 1.5 million people.

webTitle: Grassroots snub Hague plea for more women MPs

fields.headline: Grassroots snub Hague plea for more women MPs
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague's campaign to increase the number of Tory women MPs has been a dismal failure, according to a survey which found that 85% of the party's prospective candidates for the next election are men.
fields.body:
William Hague's campaign to increase the number of Tory women MPs has been a dismal failure, according to a survey which found that 85% of the party's prospective candidates for the next election are men.

Intensive efforts by Central Office to overturn the party's image as a bastion of white, middle class men have failed to influence local selection committees which are repeatedly turning down women.

London Tories have only managed to select two women candidates in the party's 22 vacant seats, a success rate of just 9%. One of the women is the former MP, Lady Olga Maitland, who has been selected to fight Sutton and Cheam which she lost at the last election.

In the East Midlands, the party is fielding one woman in the nine vacant seats. Pauline Latham will fight Broxtowe where Labour enjoys a majority of nearly 6,000.

In all the Tories have managed to select just 20 women across the country in the 133 seats up for grabs, which works out at 15%. Labour has yet to select candidates for its seats, but it has 101 women MPs, who form nearly a quarter of its parliamentary party.

The survey will embarrass Mr Hague who has pledged to increase the number of Tory women MPs. Central Office recently established a Network for Conservative Women to overcome male dominance throughout the party. In a stark admission, the party said: "Women are badly under-represented in elected positions throughout the party, particularly at Westminster."

Mr Hague also made clear that he was committed to promoting women when he said: "We have to show that the days of not admitting women to places like the Carlton club are over."

Labour seized on the findings of the survey. Tessa Jowell, minister for women, said: "It seems that, despite William Hague's warm words, the Conservative party is failing to ensure more women are selected. The Tories in parliament will still be reminiscent of a London men's club." One Tory woman, who is struggling to find a safe seat, said that the blue rinse brigade of elderly Tory volunteers repeatedly blocked women. "There are the older women who cannot understand how a woman can have a career and a family," she said. "Some of the harshest questions come from women who often look down their noses at me."

The hopeful candidate said was unsure about whether the party should introduce positive discrimination, which could guarantee at least one woman on every final shortlist. "I would not want to get to the final round as a token woman. But reaching the final stage in that way would give me the chance of winning round the broader membership."

webTitle: 'Odd couple' MPs caught up in Labour feud

fields.headline: 'Odd couple' MPs caught up in Labour feud
fields.standfirst:
Reading pair say they are victims of smears as wrangling threatens to split local party
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: An alleged smear campaign involving Reading's two MPs has become one of the Labour party's most brutal and damaging internal battles.
fields.body:
An alleged smear campaign involving Reading's two MPs has become one of the Labour party's most brutal and damaging internal battles.

Jane Griffiths, the Labour MP for Reading East, claims she is the victim of "deliberate and systematic" smears. Her supporters allege these are the work of party activists backing the Labour MP in the neighbouring constituency of Reading West, Martin Salter, who aim to oust her from her seat. In turn, Mr Salter has insisted that he is being smeared by allegations, which include entirely false claims of serious criminal convictions made against both MPs.

The internecine wrangling threatens to split the local party. Ms Griffiths, a former GCHQ translator, has threatened legal action against the perpetrators. She told the Reading Chronicle: "There are people whose ego is too big for their own talent and when the advancement they seek doesn't happen they seek to take it out on someone else." The feud has also come to the attention of party bosses at Millbank, who suspended the reselection process in Ms Griffiths' constituency last October.

The battle is not, however, about Old and New Labour - although Ms Griffths and Mr Salter, a former union shop steward and self-proclaimed leftwinger, have on occasion taken different stances on local issues. Its roots lie in a simple personality clash, which supporters on both sides have turned into a full-scale war.

On May 2, 1997, the two MPs looked like a match made in heaven. They are the same age, now 45, with birthdays just two days apart, and both had won seemingly unwinnable seats for the first time after working side by side for many years on Reading borough council, where Mr Salter was deputy leader and Ms Griffiths chaired the arts and leisure committee.

But Reading is unusual in that it has just one local Labour party for two constituencies. This has divided loyalties between two MPs very different in style.

Move out
"They're like the odd couple,"according to one activist who knows both MPs well. "Martin is a big, bruising, bluff sort of a bloke with the common touch and very forthright, whereas Jane has more of the human, personal touch and a stronger sense of her own principles. They were never going to be bosom buddies."

Mr Salter's decision to move out of the MPs' shared office in Westminster last November was cited as key evidence of a split. In fact, both MPs put in a joint request for new offices last June and, as party officials have been at pains to point out, the two previous Reading MPs never shared a Westminster office.

Rumours
A string of stories in local and national press about Griffiths have included a run-in with a former landlord over a £2,000 debt; a mix-up over £600 owed for the use of a Commons dining room by the all-party Japan group, and a county court summons for a £1,911 unpaid debt due on a loan secured on her former marital home, which she says her ex-husband did not tell her about. She was also attacked as a "fat cat" by Tories for staying on as a borough councillor after being elected as the local MP, collecting £1,589 in expenses for attending only three meetings in two years, and employing her partner, Andrew Tattersall, as her researcher.

But far more damaging rumours have also been circulating Westminster. Ms Griffiths, it was said, does not use a car because of a string of drink driving convictions. In fact, she has never learned to drive. Mr Salter, it was falsely alleged, has convictions for grievous bodily harm and possession of cannabis. In fact, neither MP has ever been involved with or convicted of any crimes.

Although many in the local and national party regard Griffiths as a good constituency MP, activists in her home ward - where she was a borough councillor for 11 years - decided last October to look for an alternative candidate for the next general election. Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, suspended the reselection process only days later. The local press reports as fact that the suspension is due to allegations about the MP's personal finances. This claim was apparently compounded by Griffiths' surprise decision to resign from the Commons public accounts committee last October. Yet Millbank has refused to give a reason for the suspension to anyone other than Ms Griffiths.

Both MPs signed a joint statement last week dismissing the rumours as "anonymous tittle-tattle" and "complete and utter nonsense". But Mr Salter's supporters are privately claiming that he has become unfairly embroiled and have pointed the finger at another local party member said to have designs on Ms Griffiths' seat. They claim that "a whispering campaign" by the Griffiths camp is "trying to drag Martin into her problems".

Damage
Nevertheless, Ms Griffiths has borne the brunt of the damage. One insider said: "Jane's clearly been affected by it, as anyone would be. The papers have made her out to be a really awful, dodgy individual, which she patently isn't. She is the subject of a concerted effort to make her life a complete misery. She's got a lot of sympathy." Meanwhile Mr Salter said: "Both Jane and myself have clearly been the subject of malicious gossip and innuendo by sad individuals with nothing better to do with their lives."

fields.headline: It's a small underworld
fields.trailText: The Vice | Gormenghast | To The Ends Of The Earth
fields.body:
Monday nights are going through a bit of a purple patch at the moment, with two strong dramas up against each other in the nine o'clock slot. Inconceivable as it may be to the schedulers that anyone would actually want to watch both of them - they doubtless appeal to different "tribes" - ITV's The Vice and BBC2's Gormenghast are just about the best that their respective channels have to offer at the moment, so it's a shame they've fallen prey to the usual divisive programming practices.

The Vice delivers the most convincing glimpse into the underworld currently available on British TV. The new two-part story Betrayed centred on a high-tech brothel, kitted out like a designer dentist's, where girls in white lab coats await the pleasure of well-heeled clients. After a few tantalis ing shots of Joe (David Harewood) getting a rub-down, the doors were kicked in and the inevitable raid began. David Schofield was on chilling form as brothel-keeper Harrison, the extent of whose operation - luring girls from Bosnian refugee camps, having them raped and beaten, their passports stolen - emerged in harrowing detail over the next hour.

There's nothing wildly original about The Vice - sex rings, after all, have been a staple of ITV police drama since the 70s - but for once this is a thriller that's genuinely thrilling, with the tension held at snapping point and a handful of performances way ahead of anything else in their league. Linchpin Ken Stott is all weaselly energy as Inspector Pat Chappel, while Harewood plays the hapless sidekick (complete with obligatory marital problems) with rare conviction. Caroline Catz, as PC Cheryl Hutchins, should be the template for all future female crime-drama roles, a character who's allowed to get her hands dirty without being either hard-boiled or weepily vulnerable.

But it was two guest turns who stood out. Elizabeth Berrington played the prostitute's-maid-turned-snitch with a wild-eyed desperation, while Branka Katic (star of last year's Warriors) stole the show as the vice squad's star witness, liberated from the brothel to face the terrors of the courtroom. As the Portishead theme music jangled over closing shots of a burning tower block, one could only hope for the days to speed by until next week's conclusion.

Meanwhile on BBC2, Gormenghast finally got into its stride for the last episode. After three weeks of being a decidedly mixed blessing, uncertain in its tone and with a few great performances overpowered by a more general shout-fest, it suddenly turned into what it should have been all along - dark, chilling, powerful drama. There were no comic schoolmasters, no dithering Dot Cotton, no freaky twins this week - and once Warren Mitchell had been dispatched (thus releasing the audience from one of the worst-judged performances in the whole show) we could settle down and concentrate on what is, after all, a fairly simple story. Jonathan Rhys Meyers, in full jackbooted fascist regalia, seemed, at last, to get the measure of Steerpike; his scenes with the older, more desperate Fuchsia (Neve McIntosh) were the highlight of the series. The closing moments, with Steerpike bobbing around a flooded room, fighting for his life with a catapult, had the authentic taste of a Mervyn Peake nightmare.

Earlier in the evening, Channel 4 revisited the legend of the great Victorian explorer Sir Richard Burton in the first of a new series of To The Ends Of The Earth. Burton, with mentally unstable sidekick John Hanning Speke, set off in 1856 to discover the source of the White Nile, then one of the world's unsolved geographic mysteries. Their journey, dogged by disease and personal animus, was repeated by Burton's biographer Michael Asher, in a re-run of that well-worn television conceit that we can somehow get closer to our subject by going where he went, seeing what he saw, smelling what he smelt. In this instance, the journey proved enlightening for Asher but frustrating for the rest of us. Hints were dropped about Burton's avant-garde sexual tastes (arriving in Zanzibar he'd whipped out a tape measure and noted a local man's penis which "when quiescent numbered nearly six inches") - but after that we got lost in an unremarkable travelogue. Burton - the man who not only translated but practised the erotic smorgasbord of the Arabian Nights and the Kama Sutra - is a figure crying out for more thorough investigation.

The closing moments, with Steerpike bobbing around a flooded room, fighting for his life with a catapult, had the authentic taste of a Mervyn Peake nightmare. Earlier in the evening, Channel 4 revisited the legend of the great Victorian explorer Sir Richard Burton in the first of a new series of To The Ends Of The Earth. Burton, with mentally unstable sidekick John Hanning Speke, set off in 1856 to discover the source of the White Nile, then one of the world's unsolved geographic mysteries. Their journey, dogged by disease and personal animus, was repeated by Burton's biographer Michael Asher, in a re-run of that well-worn television conceit that we can somehow get closer to our subject by going where he went, seeing what he saw, smelling what he smelt. In this instance, the journey proved enlightening for Asher but frustrating for the rest of us. Hints were dropped about Burton's avant-garde sexual tastes (arriving in Zanzibar he'd whipped out a tape measure and noted a local man's penis which "when quiescent numbered nearly six inches") - but after that we got lost in an unremarkable travelogue. Burton - the man who not only translated but practised the erotic smorgasbord of the Arabian Nights and the Kama Sutra - is a figure crying out for more thorough investigation.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Eve's Bayou (Kasi Lemmons, 1997) 10pm, SkyPremier

Set in Louisiana in the 50s, writer/director Kasi Lemmons' film introduces a seemingly perfect family: doctor Louis (Samuel L Jackson), his wife Roz and their three children. However, this has been prefaced by the words "the summer I killed my father I was 10 years old," spoken by daughter Eve, and cracks in the facade appear after she sees her father having sex with another woman. Slowly, the build-up to a violent denouement unfolds, via detours into the stories of various family members.

Camilla Redmond Bound (Larry Wachowski, Andy Wachowski, 1996) 10.30pm, FilmFour

It's interesting to see what the Wachowski brothers were doing before The (massive) Matrix, even if it's pretty disappointing. The arresting pulp-plot has Jennifer Tilly and Gina Gershon (pictured) in a lesbians-against-the-mob pairing, with Joe Pantoliano a laughably nasty boss. With a little more humour and a little less heavy contrivance it might have made a great cult movie, but instead it's like a cheap and tacky Thelma and Louise.

The Lightship (Jerzy Skolimowski, 1985) 1am, Carlton Cinema Psychotic Robert Duva

ll and his ugly escapee henchmen hijack a lightship off the Norfolk, Virginia coast, but the captain is impassive Klaus Maria Brandauer and the baddies have run their flag up the wrong pole. Good, glowering performances and a suspenseful clash of light and dark, good and evil, in a drama reminiscent of Huston's Key Largo.

The Set Up (Robert Wise, 1948) 4.40am, Sky Cinema

Knock-out boxing drama shot in black-and-spotlight-white, with unbeatable Robert Ryan as a veteran rebelling against local hoods' pressure to throw a fight (a prototype for Bruce Willis's Butch in Pulp Fiction): elation at victory in a brutal bout turns to terror as he faces retribution. Audrey Totter is the woman sick of the viciousness of this "sporting" life. At times despairing, but finally uplifting.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
It's hard to believe that a German mine disaster could have spawned one of television's classic children's series, but that's the story told by Bob Monkhouse in Thunderbirds Are Go! - Sci-fi On Strings (9.0pm, Radio 2). Gerry Anderson got the idea for International Rescue (pictured) after seeing the efforts to release the miners. His puppet heroes eventually became familiar to youngsters in 60 countries. By the way, they rushed around in those improbable vehicles because the puppeteers could never find a convincing way of making them walk.

Native Americans discovered long ago that they could offset the painful effects of poison ivy by eating the plant's leaves. As Geoff Watts reports in The Enemy Within (9.0pm, Radio 4) this simple remedy may offer a guide in some of our most intractable ailments, where the body's immune system has turned against itself. It's early days, of course, but researchers believe that swallowing a specific collagen could counteract rheumatoid arthritis.

fields.headline: Old bad guys never die
fields.standfirst: Crime, they say, doesn't pay. Try telling that to ex-arch villain G Gordon Liddy. After being released from prison for masterminding the Watergate break-in, he became a talk-show legend and now stars in a new US drama playing... yes, an arch villain. He talked to  Danny Leigh

fields.body:
In recent weeks, Nashville cable station TNN has undergone a change in direction. Not that America's premier "country lifestyle" outlet has abandoned its Dukes Of Hazzard re-runs, or cancelled its coverage of pro bull riding ("with the angriest bulls ever"). No, what's new is its first original series in two decades, the implausibly titled 18 Wheels Of Justice, starring onetime Diet Coke model Lucky Vanous as a federal agent undercover in the knavish world of monster trucks, pursued by a shaven-headed crimelord whose face you may have seen somewhere before.

Meet G Gordon Liddy, actor. This is, should there be any confusion, the same G Gordon Liddy who currently hosts a successful talk-radio show comprising equal parts down-home advice and far-right bombast; the same G Gordon Liddy whose Stacked And Packed wall calendar ("featuring America's most beautiful women, heavily armed") is available from his website for $14.95, and who moonlights as a guest speaker at corporate head offices across the US. The G Gordon Liddy now known to his many fans as The G-Man, a cartoonish, tell-it-like-it-is posterboy for an audience still mourning the loss of Reaganomics and the Red Menace.

Only it wasn't always this way. Prior to spooking himbos on cable TV, George Gordon Battle Liddy wasn't always a laughing matter. Let's review: a bullied child from Hoboken who later described listening to Hitler's speeches on longwave radio as "the first time I felt hope", young Liddy soon graduated from the juvenilia of eating dead rats (apparently aimed at curing his fear of rodents) to the mid-60s FBI. While in Hoover's pay, he developed a penchant for burning himself with cigarettes to hone his "will", cited Nazi experiments as blueprints for ammunition tests, and generally secured a reputation as - to quote Jonathan Aitken's apologetic biography of Nixon - "not the sort of hard man to do things by halves".

From there it was but a short leap to CREEP (Committee To Re-Elect The President), his ill-fated 1972 attempt to ensure Tricky Dicky's return to government. With Liddy at the helm, said gaggle of exiled Feds and Latin American secret policemen conceived an MO ranging from the petty (hiring hippies to urinate on the carpet at the Democratic Convention) to the downright filthy: illegal surveillance, attempted sexual entrapment, plans to assassinate investigative columnist Jack Anderson. The finale, of course, came with the arrest of five CREEP minions during a slapstick "black bag job" at the Democratic National Committee's offices in Washington's Watergate building. For Liddy - who nobly if pointlessly refused to implicate his President in the break-in - it was a ticket to the District of Columbia Jail; upon arrival, he duly regaled the largely African-American inmates with The Horst Wessel Song, marching anthem of the SS.

Quite a past. Which is why, even in his latter-day incarnation as a professionally splenetic shock jock, it's a surprise to find him mugging his way through a show about intrepid truck drivers. Not that Liddy himself - scrupulously polite despite his obvious disdain for the British press - thinks there's reason for raised eyebrows.

"Yes, this is my first regular role," he announces down the line from Washington, sounding, at 69, older than your average übermensch , "but I have made previous cameo appearances. There was Miami Vice, and from there I went into Airwolf, and MacGyver, Perry Mason, and, ah... let's see..." He hesitates, unable to recall the name. "Another truck thing."

"The producers contacted my son, Major Raymond J Liddy," he goes on, "and informed him they were looking for someone they could credibly present to the audience as an absolute criminal psychopath. And they picked me - because that way I don't have to act."

You sense it's a line he's used before: he even leaves a brief pause for a laugh. So, how's he finding life as a pantomime villain? There's a slightly longer hiatus in the conversation. "Well, Mr Leigh," he murmurs, "I wouldn't say pantomime villain. I'd say genuine villain."

Nonetheless, for a man who craves (and, at least among his constituency of firearms enthusiasts and conspiracy theorists, commands) legitimacy as a serious political commentator, 18 Wheels Of Justice seems an odd means of expression. He takes a sharp intake of breath.

"As far as I'm concerned, it's an additional way of earning a living, and something I enjoy doing. And it's important to me for the show to do well, because anything I undertake I want to do well. Anything I deem worthy of my time in the first place, I want to succeed."

Indeed, it's not the first time he's gone extra-curricular to supplement his radio income - previous enterprises include the now defunct G Gordon Liddy Academy of Corporate Security and Private Investigation. Yet it's only when he gets onto the evils of US liberalism that any real vigour enters his voice. Mention John McCain, the rapidly ascendant great white hope of modern Republicanism, and he gleefully swoops into soundbite mode.

"With Al Gore and Bill Clinton on their way out," he declares, "what I take from the rise of Senator McCain is the American people obviously wanting to take a really good, long, hot shower_ with lots of soap."

You can understand his heart remaining in politics. Dispensing the right-wing hyperbole is, after all, what basically gets him noticed; as, for example, when he boasted on-air of using cut-outs of Hilary Clinton for target practice. Many people, I suggest, would find something.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
Body Chemistry 9.30pm, BBC2
Manners maketh the man? No, hormones are what make the difference, as a group of men who were once sort-of women demonstrate in the second part of this series on the substances which build muscle, change moods and so on. Body Chemistry spends a lot of time in California where lots of people are injecting themselves with hormones. Some scientists think they may soon be able to extend the human lifespan by 50 years or so. Some don't - scientists are not in the business of agreeing with one another. While a longer lifepossible, scientists have delivered new forms of oestrogen which will help women after the menopause without increasing their chances of getting breast cancer

Adoption On Trial: Nobody's Child 9pm, C4

The first of a series of programmes which examine the British adoption system - or the British lack of adoption system. In the first programme we meet Ella, Adam and Eddie, who have spent a combined total of 33 years in children's homes and foster placements. Eddie was told there was a possibility of him being adopted. Six years later he was told that the plan had fallen through, but nobody thought to tell him.

Geri's World Walkabout 10.20pm, BBC1

Geri Halliwell goes to Salisbury Plain to meet the first woman to be trained by the Army to fight on the front line, and also visits Rio to meet a 20-year-old chart topper, Valeria, who became HIV positive at 16. Then to Manilla...

fields.headline: Brown defiant in Welsh deadlock
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and Gordon Brown's 11th hour refusal to blink over the Welsh budget crisis last night condemned their former cabinet colleagues, Alun Michael, to the near-certainty of defeat in a no confidence motion in Cardiff tomorrow.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and Gordon Brown's 11th hour refusal to blink over the Welsh budget crisis last night condemned their former cabinet colleagues, Alun Michael, to the near-certainty of defeat in a no confidence motion in Cardiff tomorrow.

As opposition parties in the Welsh Assembly combined to warn that there was no way back for Mr Michael, the embattled first secretary in Wales, the one hope of averting another devolution crisis lay in the possibility of a last minute deal with the Liberal Democrats.

The stage is now set for tomorrow's vote and a 31-28 defeat for Labour. Some Welsh politicians predict that Rhodri Morgan, narrowly defeated by Mr Michael for first secretary last year, will soon emerge in the post, possibly in a Lib-Lab coalition on the Edinburgh model. Four-party power-sharing has also been mooted.

Yesterday the Lib Dems' assembly leader, Mike German, went to London in the hope of seeing the chancellor to argue for the cast-iron guarantees Labour's critics have been seeking to underpin £1.2bn of EU funding for west Wales and the valleys.

But Mr Brown echoed Downing Street's accusation that Mr Michael is the victim of "silly games.

"The opposition have got their facts wrong," he told reporters and Mr Michael was right to say that his £8bn Welsh budget for 2000-2001 is adequately funded to match the first tranche of EU funds, promised over a six year period at the Berlin summit.

Plaid Cymru's acting leader Ieuan Wyn Jones said Plaid had repeatedly challenged Mr Blair since the assembly elections to make good his promise that he would not let Wales down. "We are seeing New Labour abandoning Wales with its patronising view of farmers and its refusal to acknowledge the rural crisis. "

Mr German, who could end up in an assembly cabinet, said his party is determined to make devolution work and is looking for four-party power-sharing for the benefit of Wales.

fields.headline: Evelyn Capel
fields.standfirst: Early woman priest active in postwar Germany
fields.trailText: In Stuttgart in 1922, a German evangelical minister, Friedrich Rittelmeyer, having been inspired by lectures given by Rudolph Steiner, founded the Christian Community, a movement for religious renewal with a priesthood of women as well as men. In June 1939 in London, Evelyn Capel, who has died aged 88, became the first English woman priest ordained within it to celebrate the sacraments.
fields.body:
In Stuttgart in 1922, a German evangelical minister, Friedrich Rittelmeyer, having been inspired by lectures given by Rudolph Steiner, founded the Christian Community, a movement for religious renewal with a priesthood of women as well as men. In June 1939 in London, Evelyn Capel, who has died aged 88, became the first English woman priest ordained within it to celebrate the sacraments.

A writer, lecturer and traveller, she had the rank of colonel in the Allied Control Commission in postwar Germany, helping to rebuild Christian groups and churches of all denominations. Later, she helped to establish the Christian Community in South Africa.

She was born in Stow-on-the-Wold in Gloucestershire. One of five sisters, she came from a non-conformist religious background, and was brilliant at school - she was first in all England in her school certificate. She read modern history at Somerville College, Oxford, and became a management trainee with the catering firm J Lyons, where a lucrative future beckoned.

But Capel had already come across Steiner's ideas and, after becoming acquainted with the Christian Community through Kenneth Walsh, she joined, training at its Stuttgart seminary and becoming fluent in German. Soon after ordination she returned from London to the seminary in Germany, but, with the approach of the second world war, moved to Holland, catching a flight back to England three days after the declaration of hostilities.

She was one of the small group of priests in this country who ensured that the Christian Community's communion service was celebrated every single day from the time the community was banned in Germany in 1941 until it was able to make a new start in 1945.

During the war Capel travelled around Britain to support the community's scattered congregations around. With peace, she was one of the first priests to go to the continent to visit the community's congregations. In her Allied Control Com mission work she was associated with Walsh, who developed the idea of twinning German and British towns as a way of building social, cultural and commercial bridges between the two countries.

In 1951, Capel married Samuel Derry, the manager of Rudolf Steiner House. Her London base was Temple Lodge, Hammersmith, which has become a unique place among Christian Community centres, with its publishing house (Temple Lodge Publishing), bookshop, guest house and vegetarian restaurant, which, in 1993, won a Time Out magazine award.

Derry died in 1960 and, in 1967, Evelyn married Herbert Capel. She was a prolific writer; her books include A Woman In The Priesthood, which is housed in the House of Commons library.

Capel was a wonderful pastor, helping people in crises, always recognising their free individuality, and a lively, humorous lecturer. Only two years before retirement, aged 84, she gave a course on spiritual counselling in Sao Paolo, Brazil.

Her husband predeceased her. She had no children.

The Rev Evelyn Francis Capel, priest, born March 23 1911; died January 5 2000

webTitle: Waste firm attacks 'quick fix' plan for incinerators plan

fields.headline: Waste firm attacks 'quick fix' plan for incinerators plan
fields.trailText: Plans to license up to 165 large incinerators to replace unsightly rubbish dumps were attacked yesterday by a waste operator as a "quick fix".
fields.body:
Plans to license up to 165 large incinerators to replace unsightly rubbish dumps were attacked yesterday by a waste operator as a "quick fix".

Peter Jones, a director of Biffa, accused ministers of failing the "joined-up government test" by not being able to coordinate policy. A company report said: "The history of the waste industry is littered with ambitious 'technology solutions'."

The company is backing Friends of the Earth, which has issued a long list of planned incinerators showing that London and the south-east will be particularly hard hit, with plans for a huge incinerator at Belvedere in south London.

Five incinerators are planned in the Manchester area and there are schemes across the rest of the north-west from Chester and Liverpool to Carlisle to Blackpool.

fields.headline: Craig Claiborne
fields.trailText: The food writer and restaurant critic Craig Claiborne, who has died aged 79, played a key role in raising food to its status as the dominant art form of the late 20th century. His judgments, in the New York Times, were taken as seriously as Olin Downes's conservative music reviews. Thanks to Claiborne, "gourmet" entered the popular American vocabulary.
fields.body:
The food writer and restaurant critic Craig Claiborne, who has died aged 79, played a key role in raising food to its status as the dominant art form of the late 20th century. His judgments, in the New York Times, were taken as seriously as Olin Downes's conservative music reviews. Thanks to Claiborne, "gourmet" entered the popular American vocabulary.

From 1957 to 1986, with a break from 1970 to 1974, he was the NYT food editor. Such posts had usually been held by women, who devoted their midweek pages to recipes for busy housewives. Claiborne's appointment was unorthodox, even adventurous; he was the wrong sex, and his predilections were unashamedly European - a great leap for a native of Sunflower, Mississippi.

After graduating in journalism from Mississippi state college, and wartime naval service, Claiborne worked in public relations until moving to France in 1949. During a second spell in the navy, at the time of the Korean war, he resolved to become the NYT food editor, and after qualifying at the École Htelière de la Société Suisse des Hoteliers, in Lausanne, worked briefly at Gourmet magazine.

Claiborne's kitchen experience hardly extended beyond his Swiss qualifications - he moved from an unsophisticated, provincially-fed childhood to haute cuisine without having experienced well-grounded home cooking. So when asked to include reviewing in his NYT responsibilities, he established a system for evaluating restaurants which entailed several anonymous visits with different companions, and detailed notes on cuisine, décor and service. These were distilled into a one to four star rating.

The criteria were practical and essentially economic: how do the food and service compare with the cost of dining? His unemotive style gave his reviews an authority which, at the upper end of the restaurant market, soon included the power of life or death (which he did not apparently abuse).

Claiborne's career began with an unapologetic preference for French haute cuisine. The first New York restaurant to win his whole-hearted approval was Le Pavillon, a survivor of the 1939 world fair. After its move to Fifth Avenue, it became an exclusive club for Windsors, Hearsts, Fords, and titled Europeans. There Claiborne met the chef, Pierre Franey, and they formed an expert/salesman team, which established reputation and market value within a context of rampant snobbery.

In 1974 they wrote an NYT article outlining a dinner for eight, which, cooked at home, would cost $900. The sum was deliberately inflated with copious quantities of caviar and a wine list which included the most expensive vintages of Montrachet, Romanée-Conti and Dom Perignon. Without these, they admitted, the cost "might deflate to about $90".

The pair reached the apotheosis of excess in 1975 at a $4,000 banquet for two at Chez Denis, Paris. This astronomical sum was achieved by ordering a profusion of courses, which, according to the proprietor, would easily have fed 10. As a publicity stunt, however, it was eminently successful, calling down the wrath of everyone up to and including the Pope.

But it was in the area of domestic cuisine that the Claiborne-Franey partnership had its greatest impact. When confronted with the American food industry, Claiborne's lofty standards nose-dived. Of the pre-cooked frozen foods then coming onto the market, he wrote, "1958 is loaded with promise - especially for cooks on the run. The past 12 months [have] initiated a trend that is sure to be developed more fully - the packaging of dishes with a so-called continental touch that can be heated and brought to the table within minutes - to the awe and delight of guests with educated palates." Such lapses in taste would come to embrace even the Big Mac.

In gourmet guise, Claiborne's enthusiasm for pseudo-foods surfaced regularly in his cookbooks (his many books include a 1982 autobiography, A Feast Made For Laughter). The classic beurre blanc, for example, is assembled with meticulous care from shallots, white wine vinegar, seasoning and a pound of butter; Claiborne dispensed with both its difficulty and its delicacy by substituting six tablespoons of butter, a cup of heavy cream, an egg yolk, two tablespoons of lemon juice - and tabasco sauce.

With Claiborne's assistance, the word "gourmet" would ultimately lose its character -and even its snob appeal. Inedible glop would be relabelled with the magic word, and sold for double the price. We are still eating the consequences.

Craig Claiborne, food writer, born September 4 1920; died January 22 2000

fields.headline: Sir Frank Layfield
fields.standfirst: His outstanding legal mind dissected the planning issues of nuclear power, urban development and local government finance
fields.trailText: In 1982, the planning lawyer Sir Frank Layfield, who has died aged 78, was invited by the then Conservative government to preside as inspector at the public inquiry into the central electricity generating board's proposals to build a pressurised water reactor, Sizewell B, alongside the Magnox Sizewell A at the Suffolk nuclear power station. It was the third major inquiry conducted by Layfield, following his work on the Greater London development plan and into local government finance.
fields.body:
In 1982, the planning lawyer Sir Frank Layfield, who has died aged 78, was invited by the then Conservative government to preside as inspector at the public inquiry into the central electricity generating board's proposals to build a pressurised water reactor, Sizewell B, alongside the Magnox Sizewell A at the Suffolk nuclear power station. It was the third major inquiry conducted by Layfield, following his work on the Greater London development plan and into local government finance.

The Sizewell B case became, at 340 days, the country's longest-lasting and most expensive public inquiry, and it gave Layfield the opportunity to deploy talents that won him widespread respect, if not universal support. In 1987, four years after the first hearing, he published his 3,000-page report, which concluded that the PWR would be in the national interest. Eight years later, in a different energy world, it began its commercial operation.

For many years before he retired in 1992, Layfield had been pre-eminent at the planning and local government bar. At the height of his practice, there were few major planning inquiries at which he did not appear. He had an exceptional ability to master the detail of complex inquiries, requiring not only a clear understanding of planning law and policy, but also a firm grasp of the many technical issues they raise. Perhaps even more importantly, he was a masterful, thorough, effective - but courteous - cross-examiner. Many thought his skills unparalleled.

Layfield took silk in 1967. Within two years he was invited by the then Labour government to chair the public inquiry into the Greater London development plan, which became the longest planning inquiry of the day, with his report, delivered in 1973, criticising, among other things, the then extant motorway ring scheme around London.

Soon afterwards, Layfield was called upon again to chair a committee of inquiry, this time into local government finance. This lasted for 18 months and many of its recommendations were thought at the time to be radical.

Layfield was born in Toronto, came to England at the age of 11, and was educated at Sevenoaks school. Joining the army in 1940, he served in the Royal Corps of Signals in the Middle East, India and Burma. After the war, he spent time at the ministry of town and country planning - where he was concerned with the establishment of new towns - and with a firm of planning consultants.

He then read for the bar, was called in 1954 and became a pupil of Arthur Irvine, latterly solicitor-general in Harold Wilson's second administration, from 1967-70. Layfield became a tenant in 1957 in the chambers of Scott Henderson QC, and from there built up an extensive practice in the field of planning and local government. His initial success was due largely to his specialist knowledge of the planning system, which few at the bar in those days shared.

Following his work on the local government finance inquiry, Layfield was knighted in 1976. He appeared at most major planning inquiries, and on many private bills in parliament (including Windscale), representing ICI when it successfully pushed through its Boulby potash mine in a national park, No 1 Poultry, in the City of London, Cow Green reservoir and the Paddington to Heathrow rail link. He was accorded the rare honour for a practising barrister of being elected an associate of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors, on the council of which he sat for many years, and an honorary fellow of the Incorporated Society of Valuers and Auctioneers.

Layfield never forgot his initial grounding in the common law, and took an appointment in 1979 as a crown court recorder. In 1974, he was elected a bencher of Gray's Inn. In 1975, he became head of his chambers (on the retirement of Sir Joseph Molony), and in 1990 led his colleagues into their new accommodation at 1 Serjeants Inn, from where he retired.

He brought to his private life all the enthusiasm and charm which marked and promoted his professional success. Following service in the war, he joined the Honourable Artillery Company and ended up a major. He commanded a platoon of the HAC, which acted as the guard of honour to the Queen on one of her visits to the City. To the end, his shoes always shone. He was a keen and active liveryman. He played tennis and squash.

Friends remember with nostalgia many a game of squash before an inquiry in the City - and even in the middle of the night during a long inquiry at Billingham. He was an enthusiastic walker, often covering sections of the Cleveland Way during inquiries in the north-east.

In Patricia Harvey, whom he married in 1965, he chose the perfect wife, and was devoted to their two children. When he and Pat moved to a Georgian house at Beckley with a large unkempt garden, Frank devoted to his garden all the enthusiasm and attention to detail which he had brought to everything else, double digging all the borders in the process. His kindness and humour brought him many friends.

He is surved by his wife, son and daughter.

Sir Frank Henry Burland Willoughby Layfield, barrister, born August 9 1921; died February 2 2000

fields.headline: Sarah Caudwell
fields.standfirst: Witty barrister who turned her cases into crime thrillers
fields.trailText: Sarah Caudwell, who has died of cancer aged 60, was a barrister who turned to crime writing when she ran out of good crime novels to read. It was an open secret that her full name was Sarah Caudwell Cockburn; her father was the writer Claud, while her mother, the journalist and actress Jean Ross, was generally regarded as the model for Sally Bowles in Christopher Isherwood's Goodbye To Berlin - although Jean always repudiated the comparison on the grounds that, unlike herself, Sally was frivolous and not interested in politics.
fields.body:
Sarah Caudwell, who has died of cancer aged 60, was a barrister who turned to crime writing when she ran out of good crime novels to read. It was an open secret that her full name was Sarah Caudwell Cockburn; her father was the writer Claud, while her mother, the journalist and actress Jean Ross, was generally regarded as the model for Sally Bowles in Christopher Isherwood's Goodbye To Berlin - although Jean always repudiated the comparison on the grounds that, unlike herself, Sally was frivolous and not interested in politics.

Sarah's first book was Adonis Murdered (1981), in which Julia, an absent-minded barrister, lures a handsome young tax inspector - later foully murdered - to her hotel room in Venice. Julia is mistakenly arrested for the crime and sends wordy and witty letters to her Lincoln's Inn friends. The book was a success, particularly in America, where it was regarded as quintessentially English; it was subsequently translated into Swedish and Japanese.

It is no coincidence that the titles of all Sarah's books contain classical references. She was educated at Aberdeen high school for girls and the local university, where she read Latin and ancient Greek. She then read law at St Anne's College, Oxford, where she was a fast-talking undergraduate, puffing at her pipe and sometimes composing humorous verse.

One such occasion began with a party in Balliol College, Oxford, where she made overtures to a don whom she considered to have "a good profile". He resisted her efforts to further the acquaintance. But the don, who lectured in English, was known for his habit of watching television and, a few days later, Sarah sent him a verse:

I cast aside my modesty, I laid aside my shame/ And on my knees I offered love - or something much the same/ You brushed my powder from your sleeve, with elegant precision/ And murmured: "Conversation is killing television."

In the early 1960s, Oxford was still a surprisingly reactionary place; women, for example, were not allowed to become members of the university debating society, the Oxford Union. Encouraged by Sarah, who was watching from the public gallery, Rose Dugdale, who later became rather more notorious for her links with the Provisional IRA, and I dressed up as men and walked into the debating chamber to draw attention to the anomaly.

Our move attracted a lot of publicity, but didn't result in a change in the rules, so we canvassed for support and finally got the restrictions removed. Then the problem was who would speak. Few women had experience of debating, but Sarah had some skills from her Aberdeen days. So, as one of the first women to be invited to participate in a debate - as a member of the union rather than as a guest - she spoke and made everybody laugh.

Called to the Bar in 1965, she left in the mid-1970s to become deputy legal adviser to the trust division of Lloyd's Bank. But it was her life as a junior chancery barrister that formed the basis of her books, and several of her friends from those days can be discerned, thinly disguised, among her fictional characters.

When doing the groundwork for her books, Sarah favoured the direct approach. Once on a visit to Jersey, she disconcerted bystanders by sitting at the bar of her hotel, puffing at her pipe and demanding, "Where in Jersey could I lure someone to his death, preferably on a beach?" She was researching The Sirens Sang Of Murder, a story of treachery, tax-planning and witchcraft partly set in the Channel Islands, and published in 1989.

For many years Sarah lived in Barnes, near the Thames, in south-west London, with her mother and aunt, Peggy. The neighbourhood figured in her second book, The Shortest Way To Hades, as the location for a suspicious death among spectators on boat race day.

Her latest book, The Sibyl In Her Grave, the story of a sleepy Sussex village riven by murder and rumours of insider dealing, is due to be published in America by Delacorte Press in July.

Sarah remained witty and optimistic to the end. She is survived by her aunt Clare Hughes (Billee) and by her half-brothers Alexander, Andrew and Patrick Cockburn.

Sarah Caudwell, barrister and writer, born May 27 1939; died 28 January 2000
