webTitle: Husband-hiring hastens the spread of Aids in Rwanda

fields.headline: Husband-hiring hastens the spread of Aids in Rwanda
fields.trailText: Josephine Nyinawankusi lost her husband and four of her five children during the genocide that swept Rwanda in 1994. She is so desperate to replace her lost family, she says, that she is prepared to risk her life to do so.
fields.body:
Josephine Nyinawankusi lost her husband and four of her five children during the genocide that swept Rwanda in 1994. She is so desperate to replace her lost family, she says, that she is prepared to risk her life to do so.

"Life in Rwanda without a husband or children is not a life," she said. Yet with so many men killed during the genocide, or later imprisoned for their part in it, she has little hope of finding a new husband.

"Husbands are very scarce these days but at least I can still have children," she said.

To do this, though, Josephine will have to share sexual partners with other women like her and in so doing put herself at great risk of contracting the Aids virus.

"I know about Aids but a family is more important," she said.

The practice of sharing men, known as kwinjira , has become so widespread in rural areas of Rwanda since the genocide that health officials say that it represents the greatest challenge to their efforts to combat the spread of Aids.

Josephine lives in Ntongwe town, in Gitarama district in central Rwanda, scene of some of the worst excesses in 1994, when as many as 800,000 people died. In some parts of the district adult males make up a mere 20% of the population.

"Kwinjira is something like male prostitution," said Sam Abbenyi who works for the international aid agency CARE. The women's "sexual needs are satisfied and they hope that they'll be able to have children to replace those killed during the genocide".

But the very real danger of kwinjira in a country where 11% of the population are estimated to be HIV-positive is the uncontrolled spread of Aids - or Rwanda's "new genocide" as Ildephonse Kamali calls it.

Dr Kamali, who works in the Kabgayi hospital outside Gitarama town, said that as many as 50% of the Aids tests he administers are turning up positive results. All of which is no surprise to the director of the National Aids Control Programme, Innocent Ntaganira: Aids patients take 60% of hospital beds and more than 200,000 Rwandans - 50,000 of them children - have died of the disease.

Dr Ntaganira said that rates of HIV infection spiralled because "war and Aids are well known allies. Huge displacement of people away from their homes meant that rural communities came into contact with urban communities where the incidence of HIV infection was much higher." Thousands of women were raped.

Urging restraint on people who have survived the worst ethnic extermination since the second world war is difficult, said Dr Ntaganira.

"Survivors of the genocide have become hedonistic. Why should they fear a disease which might kill them in 10 years' time" when they have survived mass slaughter?

"In the case of women, if Aids is the risk they have to take in order to rebuild their families then that is a risk they are prepared to take."

The spread of Aids and of kwinjira are also fuelled by poverty. With an annual income of $180 (£110) per person, Rwanda is ranked by the World Bank as the world's third poorest country. Seventy per cent of all households fall below the poverty line.

Yet with so many men killed during the genocide, or later imprisoned for their part in it, she has little hope of finding a new husband. "Husbands are very scarce these days but at least I can still have children," she said. To do this, though, Josephine will have to share sexual partners with other women like her and in so doing put herself at great risk of contracting the Aids virus. "I know about Aids but a family is more important," she said. fields.headline: Nigeria contemplates breakup
fields.standfirst: Rising regional forces have Africa's giant thinking the unthinkable
fields.trailText: The end of military rule nine months ago has unleashed a store of bitter resentments in Nigeria that have fueled ethnic massacres, the rise of militant regional organisations and a rush to introduce sharia law in the Islamic north over the virulent protests of Christians.
fields.body:
The end of military rule nine months ago has unleashed a store of bitter resentments in Nigeria that have fueled ethnic massacres, the rise of militant regional organisations and a rush to introduce sharia law in the Islamic north over the virulent protests of Christians.

It has all raised a question no one has dared contemplate seriously since the bloody civil war over Biafra 30 years ago: is it time to dissolve Nigeria?

The recent troubles come on top of long-standing grievances and divisions.

The east, which tasted separation briefly as Biafra during the war, provides the country's massive oil revenues but has little to show beyond devastating pollution. The south-west - home to 20m Yorubas and the commercial hub, Lagos - claims to have been robbed of political influence by decades of northern-dominated military rule. The northern Hausa-Fulani protest that southerners own the economy.

Years of military rule and plunder have taken their toll on Nigeria's standing in the world. But at home a grand conspiracy by their compatriots is what the various of Nigeria complain of most.

At the heart of the south-west's burgeoning ethnic nationalism is the Oodua People's Congress (OPC), a Yoruba separatist movement founded six years ago to oppose military rule. It is blamed for much of the killings of hundreds of Hausas and eastern Igbos in and around Lagos in recent months, provoking retaliatory massacres of Yorubas in other parts of Nigeria.

The OPC is scorned by many businessmen and mainstream politicians. But the organisation's popularity has surged among the mass of poor in Lagos keen to find someone to blame for their plight. One of its leaders, Gani Adams, is a folk hero after eluding capture even though the police put a price on his head for leading ethnic killings.

The OPC has some prominent supporters. Its treasurer is Beko Ransome-Kuti, a former political prisoner of the military whose late brother, Fela Kuti, was Nigeria's most famous and politicised singer.

"This concept called Nigeria is of very doubtful viability," Mr Ransome-Kuti said. "There is just nothing you can call one Nigeria and the earlier we appreciate that the better or we'll end up in dire straits ... Everything revolves around the ethnic factor.

"The north wants to control everything. The OPC is here to make sure that the south-west, or the Yorubas, are emancipated from northern oppression." Regional rivalry is partly driven by differences over how Nigeria is governed. The north, with few resources, backs big government and shared national wealth, particularly the oil revenues. It relies on the civil service to provide jobs and views the fashion for privatisation as a threat to its hegemony over vast state enterprises.

The south-west is scornful of the pervasive federal administration, blaming it for corruption, inefficiency and the collapse of much of Nigeria's infrastructure.

Mr Ransome-Kuti says the OPC favours a return to the handful of largely self-governing regions that existed when the army first seized power in 1966. If it cannot win agreement on devolution, he says the organisation will declare independence.

But if the south-west were to win even a measure of autonomy it would help galvanise the demand for self-government among the splintered ethnic movements in the oil-rich Niger Delta. That is one of the north's great fears because oil underpins the economy.

The OPC's rise has provoked the creation of a rival organisation, the Arewa People's Congress, to "safeguard northern interests". Its chairman, Sagir Mohammed, accuses the OPC of "unleashing terror". When the police offered a 100,000 naira (£6,000) reward for Mr Adams's capture, the APC doubled it.

"Our motto is to preserve the territorial indivisibility of the country," Mr Mohammed said. "No matter how peaceful you may want to be, you may find you have been pushed to the limit and you are forced to respond with violence. The OPC's long-term objective is the balkanisation of the country. This is a threat to our nascent democracy."

Southern suspicions have been fuelled by the spread of sharia law. Although Islamic courts have existed for years in the Muslim north, they have heard civil cases only. Now one state, Zamfara, has made sharia the principal criminal code and used it to close bars, segregate schools and transport, and enforce a dress code. Five other states with significant Christian minorities are moving in a similar direction.

Underpinning the rise in Yoruba nationalism is disappointment with President Olusegun Obasanjo's democratic government, which took office last May, and fears of a return to military rule.

Mr Obasanjo, whose status as a Yoruba and a former military ruler puts him in both camps and neither, has been attacked by all sides. The north complains his government has too many Yorubas; the south-west protests that he constantly bows to northern pressure on issues such as sharia.

Mr Obasanjo has skilfully neutralised the army for now. But the OPC says that if the government fails to deliver, the military will be back.

"I know some of their fears," said the president. "I tell them that you don't solve that problem by severing ties. You solve that by strengthening the institutions that prevent a repeat of the past.

"I will admit that people have reason to be suspicious. The ethnic differences are there. Religious differences are there. But there are more important things to worry about, like injustice and poverty."

webTitle: Samoa gripped by ministerial murder trial

fields.headline: Samoa gripped by ministerial murder trial
fields.trailText: A sensational political murder trial in this microscopic south Pacific island nation is expected to take a dramatic turn today when a person known only as witness E takes the stand.
fields.body:
A sensational political murder trial in this microscopic south Pacific island nation is expected to take a dramatic turn today when a person known only as witness E takes the stand.

The secret witness's testimony is considered crucial in the prosecution's case against two former cabinet ministers, Leafa Vitale and Toi Aukuso, who are on trial for murder.

The two parliamentarians, who respectively held the portfolios of women's affairs and public works, are charged jointly with the murder of the former public works minister, Luagalau Levaula Kamu, in revenge for Mr Vitale losing his portfolio to the slain minister.

Mr Kamu, 44, was killed last July with a single shot from a M16 assault rifle just after he had been speaking at a function to mark the 20th anniversary of the ruling Human Right Protection party (HRPP).

Mr Kamu was briefly leaving the stage to take a telephone call from his daughter when the shot rang out.

The trial, which is currently in its fourth week, is seen by his critics as comeuppance for Mr Vitale, who for the past decade has led something of a charmed life.

He has been the subject of a number of official inquiries and insurance investigations during the past 10 years, including for death threats allegedly made by him against two newspaper editors and several senior public servants.

Mr Vitale was also allegedly involved in an elaborate insurance scam in 1989, whereby he faked his own death in Honolulu in order that his family could collect the payout, a matter for which he is still wanted for questioning by the FBI in the US, which has no extradition treaty with Samoa. Only one previous case brought against him has ever gone to court - and it was dismissed.

Mr Vitale's son, 34-year-old Elitise Leafa Vitale, has already pleaded guilty to murdering the late cabinet minister, and is serving a life sentence for the killing.

Members of Elitise's family have been given asylum and new identities in New Zealand, to protect them from possible retribution from associates of the elder Mr Vitale, according to a diplomatic source close to the case.

Name suppression and unprecedented court security have also protected the identity of witness E, a low-level underworld character who is expected to testify that he was hired last year to kill Mr Kamu. His nerve failed him, however, after twice staking out the parliamentarian's home.

Ministers of the HRPP have described the violence as a tragic one-off occurrence. But the opposition coalition of Tui Atua Tupua Tamasese Efi has linked the situation to what Mr Tamasese has described as modern Samoa's "web of corruption", involving too many "deals, too much jealousy and too many people owing and expecting favours".

webTitle: Mexican police hold hundreds of students

fields.headline: Mexican police hold hundreds of students
fields.trailText: Police were yesterday occupying the National Autonomous University of Mexico after a raid in which more than 600 students were arrested. The police action has ended nine months of strike, but its consequences are still unclear.
fields.body:
Police were yesterday occupying the National Autonomous University of Mexico after a raid in which more than 600 students were arrested. The police action has ended nine months of strike, but its consequences are still unclear.

President Ernesto Zedillo said in a national address that that "it was with great sadness" that he gave the go-ahead for Sunday's dawn raid on the university's sprawling campus, which has been barricaded up by students since April. It was, he said, the unavoidable consequence of the strikers' intransigence.

Television pictures showed helmeted police catching the strikers off guard, rousing some from makeshift beds and herding them into buses.

Opposition politicians accused the government of mishandling the stand-off, which was sparked by a proposed increase in tuition fees, but developed into a radical protest against the Mexican political system and global capitalism.

In recent weeks any development at the university, known as Unam, has dominated national news, even relegating the forthcoming general elections to the inside pages.

Jorge Castaneda, a political analyst, said: "There is going to be a lot of fallout from this."

He added that the government might benefit initially from appearing to have solved the problem, but said this would change as events behind the news emerged.

"It is really a major failure of the Mexican state that it had to fix it in this way, even if there was no choice in the end, and it didn't turn out that badly," Mr Castaneda said.

Despite fears that police intervention would spark violence comparable to the massacre in 1968 of hundreds of students at a peaceful rally, the raid ended without reported injuries or resistance from the strikers.

Meanwhile, relatives of the detained students staged noisy demonstrations around the city demanding "freedom for the political prisoners".

"The kids being held are not only worthy of our support but also of our admiration. Resistance will be organised from elsewhere," said Jesus Lopez, whose son, a science student, was arrested.

But while the legacy of 1968 makes storming the campus controversial, public frustration over the lost academic year for the university's 270,000 students reduces the likelihood of a mass outcry.

"The Mexican far left has an uncanny talent for snatching defeat from the jaws of victory. They had won everything and now they have lost it all, just like the Zapatistas did in 1994," Mr Castaneda said.

The strike began as a protest against a planned increase in annual tuition fees from a token few cents to the equivalent of about $140 (£87), but continued long after the university authorities backed down on the fees.

By the end, students calling themselves the "mega-ultras" saw themselves as rebels ready to go down for a more glorious cause.

Rumours that a raid was imminent gathered force after clashes last week at a university-affiliated preparatory school left dozens injured and 251 detained. But the main justification for the raid was a January referendum showing overwhelming backing among students and teachers for a return to the lecture hall.

"I am sure that the National University will emerge strengthened with new ideas and projects to benefit Mexico," Mr Zedillo said.

But Mr Castaneda was not so sure. "The tendency will be to let the UNAM rot away."

webTitle: Garibaldi asked by Lincoln to run army

fields.headline: Garibaldi asked by Lincoln to run army
fields.trailText: A frayed postcard in a Turin archive has revealed one of the most audacious gambles of the American civil war. Abraham Lincoln offered the command of the northern forces to Giuseppe Garibaldi, unifier of Italy and terror of the Pope.
fields.body:
A frayed postcard in a Turin archive has revealed one of the most audacious gambles of the American civil war. Abraham Lincoln offered the command of the northern forces to Giuseppe Garibaldi, unifier of Italy and terror of the Pope.

The US president, his forces hammered by the Confederate army, turned in desperation to Garibaldi, spawning one of the great what ifs of history.

Rumours of Lincoln's offer have circulated for a century and been denied by American scholars, but the document proved it was no myth, said Arrigo Petacco, a historian.

He stumbled across the faded blue postcard, from Garibaldi to King Victor Emmanuel II telling the king of the offer, last week while rummaging in 90 boxes of material donated by Italy's exiled royal family.

Garibaldi caught the world's imagination in 1860 after invading Sicily with 1,000 lightly armed redshirts. They defeated 12,000 Neapolitan troops, took the island and, determined to unify the Italian peninsula, invaded the mainland. They occupied Naples and unleashed a wave of support.

According to Mr Petacco, the rebel, who in the 1850s had led an army in Uruguay and travelled through the US, was also a mason. The international masonic lodge successfully lobbied for him to be granted American citizenship.

Garibaldi was ready to accept Lincoln's 1862 offer but on one condition, said Mr Petacco: that the war's objective be declared as the abolition of slavery. But at that stage Lincoln was unwilling to make such a statement lest he worsen an agricultural crisis.

"Later they offered Garibaldi the command of one unit, rather than the whole army, but at that point it was too late and he had gone on to do other things," Mr Petacco said. "In Italy we always knew, but there was always a lot of scepticism in America. Now we know for sure."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Bus explosions rock Sri Lanka
Bombs exploded on two buses in south-eastern Sri Lanka yesterday, wounding at least 45 passengers and six bystanders.
fields.body:
Bus explosions rock Sri Lanka
Bombs exploded on two buses in south-eastern Sri Lanka yesterday, wounding at least 45 passengers and six bystanders.

The blasts in the town of Bibile, about 100 miles east of the capital Colombo, are the latest in an upsurge of explosions across Sri Lanka. [AP, Colombo]

Town calm after racial violence
Hundreds of police have been deployed to restore order in a small town in southern Spain after a weekend of violence sparked by a killing blamed on a Moroccan.

A tense calm descended on El Ejido, where 22 people were injured in two days of clashes between residents and North Africans. [Reuters, Madrid]

Hamas leader freed by police
Palestinian police yesterday released a leading official of the Islamic militant group Hamas in a conciliatory gesture for national unity by the authorities.

Abdel Aziz Rantisi, arrested during a crackdown on militants, was released after 22 months in custody. He had been brought to court a few times but was never formally charged. [AP, Gaza City]

Gang beats gay man to death
A gang of neo-Nazi skinheads beat and kicked to death a 35-year-old man in the centre of Sao Paulo because he was gay, Brazilian police said.

The skinheads used brass knuckles and chains to kill dog trainer Edson Neris da Silva on Sunday. [AP, Sao Paulo]

webTitle: Colombia anti-drugs aid raises army fears

fields.headline: Colombia anti-drugs aid raises army fears
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton's budget includes a $1.3bn (£840m) package to help Colombia battle against its thriving narcotics trade, but many fear that the money will aggravate the violence and suck the US deeper into a vicious civil war.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton's budget includes a $1.3bn (£840m) package to help Colombia battle against its thriving narcotics trade, but many fear that the money will aggravate the violence and suck the US deeper into a vicious civil war.

The main focus of the aid plan, which includes support for judicial reforms and human rights protection, is a massive boost for the Colombian army, which has been strictly controlled since 1994 after it was involved in torture and other human rights abuses. More than $600m will be used for drugs interdiction programmes, including equipment and training for three elite counter-narcotics battalions, and the construction of radar bases and intelligence networks. Thirty hi-tech UH-60 Blackhawk and 33 Huey helicopters will be lent.

Colombia produces more than 80% of the cocaine sold in the US, and narcotics production has more than doubled since 1997, but leftwing rebel groups say that the aid is merely an excuse to step up counter-insurgency operations.

"The problems here are about the social order. Hunger, poverty and exploitation are not solved with rifles and machine guns," said Manuel Marulanda, the head of the 15,000-strong Revolutionary Armed Forces (Farc). But in the remote Amazon jungles where Farc fighters protect drug installations in return for "war taxes", the distinction between anti-narcotics operations and counter insurgency missions will be hard to maintain.

Human rights groups say that as anti-drugs units push into rebel-dominated regions, the civilian popu lation will once more be caught in the crossfire. In the past decade, about 35,000 people have died, and some 1.7m civilians have been driven from their homes.

Although US law forbids military aid to units involved in torture or other abuses, human rights groups are calling for tighter monitoring.

According to Amnesty International, although the army's human rights record has improved, some sections continue to support rightwing militias accused of torture, kidnap and murder.

fields.headline: Croats choose Tudjman's successor
fields.trailText: Croats voted yesterday to choose a successor to President Franjo Tudjman, who died in December after dominating the country's political life for a decade.
fields.body:
Croats voted yesterday to choose a successor to President Franjo Tudjman, who died in December after dominating the country's political life for a decade.

The vote was the climax of five weeks of dramatic change. On January 3 a centre-left alliance of Social Democrats and Social Liberals trounced Tudjman's conservative Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ) in parliamentary elections.

In the first round of the presidential elections on January 24 the Social Liberal leader, Drazen Budisa, and the candidate of four small centre parties, Stipe Mesic, beat Tudjman's nationalists into third place, but neither won a majority, forcing a second round.

By 11am yesterday more than a quarter of the 4.2 million eligible voters has cast their vote in the runoff between rivals both promising to steer a course away from Tudjman's authoritarian legacy.

"This was not a battle between policies, nor even between personalities, but rather between faces," said Mirko Galic, the editor of the weekly magazine Globus.

Their faces could hardly be more dissimilar. Mr Mesic, 65, whose Croatian People's party is a junior partner in the new coalition, has been compared to a hedgehog, with bushy eyebrows, short spiky hair, and close-cut beard.

Drazen Budisa, 51, who is clean-shaven, has been compared to a hare: stiff-backed and rather jumpy.

Mr Mesic is also quick to take offence, and has publicly threatened an army general who said he would not serve under him, and a newspaper editor who alleged that he had been a police informer.

"I voted for Budisa," said Krunoslav Izakovic, a railway worker. "Mesic speaks more loudly, but we don't need a loud president. We need someone who will do his job."

"I chose Mesic," said Biljana Lulic, a mother of four children. "He has no skeletons in his closet and he would be more decisive as president."

Asked if Croats needed another paternalistic figure such as Tudjman, she said: "We don't need someone to protect us, or to comfort us, we need someone to represent us."

Mr Mesic has been more outspoken on Bosnia, insisting that the Croats there should stand on their own feet, and stop relying on Zagreb for economic or political support.

Croats in Bosnia were given dual citizenship by Tudjman - a move described by a western diplomat as "a knife in the back of the Dayton peace accords" that ended the Bosnian war in 1995.

Bosnian Croats were expected to favour Mr Budisa, who could not be expected to abandon them to the same extent as Mr Mesic. There are fears in the Mesic camp that the Croatian vote in Bosnia could swing the result in Mr Budisa's favour.

fields.headline: Missile shield to cost $2bn
fields.standfirst: Pentagon seeks funds for project despite allied warnings
fields.trailText: The United States defence department yesterday anticipated approval for its controversial plan for a national anti-missile shield - including upgrading the early warning radar station at Fylingdales in north Yorkshire - by presenting a $2bn (£1.25bn) budget for the project.
fields.body:
The United States defence department yesterday anticipated approval for its controversial plan for a national anti-missile shield - including upgrading the early warning radar station at Fylingdales in north Yorkshire - by presenting a $2bn (£1.25bn) budget for the project.

William Cohen, the defence secretary, has said President Bill Clinton would not make a decision without further consultations with Washington's European allies, most of which fear that the project could threaten their security and encourage a new arms race.

However, Mr Cohen made it clear at a conference on international security in Munich, Germany, last weekend that it was a question of when, not whether, the US would go ahead.

Geoffrey Hoon, Britain's defence secretary, told journalists at the conference that he had received "no requests yet" from the US to use British facilities. Any decision would be "considered on its merits".

However, Pentagon officials said the budget would allow "the bulldozers to roll" and "concrete to be poured" - prohibited under the 1972 anti-ballistic missile (ABM) treaty - for what their budget proposal calls "worldwide unspecified locations".

They are known to include Fylingdales and another early warning station at Thule in Greenland. The US missile defence project will also include Menwith Hill, in north Yorkshire, one of the US national security agency's largest eavesdropping centres.

The defence procurement minister, Baroness Symons, told Lord Judd last month that Menwith Hill would be the base for a new "European relay ground station designed to provide early warning of ballistic missile launches". She said it was part of the space-based infrared system "deemed by the US to be necessary, irrespective of of any decision that may be taken on [US proposals for] national missile defence".

The US plans to build 100 ground-based interceptors at a site in Alaska, a decision that will require amending the ABM treaty. Washington insists that it is designed to deter "rogue" states such as North Korea, Iran, Iraq and Libya.

The Russians, whose large missile arsenal could break through the proposed system, are indicating that they could reach a compromise with the US on changes to the treaty. However, the US project is strongly opposed by China which has far fewer long-range missiles and is concerned about the implications for its security and Beijing's relations with Taiwan.

France and Germany have publicly warned that the move could unleash a new arms race. Rudolf Scharping, the German defence minister, told the Munich conference that the US should consider the "political price" of the project and its effect on Russia, China and India.

Dan Plesch, director of the the British American security information council, said yesterday: "The Pentagon's unilateral preparations are needlessly dividing Nato."

Dave Knight, the chairman of the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament, urged Mr Hoon to consult parliament on the American project.

"Any delay will only encourage the US in their belief that they can press on regardless of any implications for international relations," he said.

fields.headline: Yugoslav minister shot dead
fields.standfirst: Defence chief is the second ally of Milosevic to die recently
fields.trailText: Yugoslavia's defence minister was shot dead last night as he ate in the restaurant of a Belgrade football stadium, the latest and the highest-ranking victim of a spate of gangland-style political killings.
fields.byline: Dusan Stojanovic in Belgrade and  Owen Bowcott
fields.body:
Yugoslavia's defence minister was shot dead last night as he ate in the restaurant of a Belgrade football stadium, the latest and the highest-ranking victim of a spate of gangland-style political killings.

Pavle Bulatovic, who had held the post for seven years, was the second prominent ally of President Slobodan Milosevic to be gunned down in the city in less than a month.

The Serb warlord Arkan died in the lobby of the Intercontinental hotel, in Belgrade, on January 15.

Immediately after last night's killing, the government went into emergency session and declared Mr Bulatovic had been the victim of terrorism.

"The federal government states with deepest sorrow and sadness that Pavle Bulatovic, the federal minister of defence, was killed this evening in Belgrade," a statement on Yugoslav state television, said. "The federal government gives its full support to the relevant state organs in their uncompromising struggle against terrorism."

The statement added that the government expressed its "gratitude and respect for the contribution that Pavle Bulatovic gave in the defence, affirmation and development of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia and sends deepest condolences to his family."

Police said the killer struck at 6.55pm local time, firing with an automatic weapon from the stadium's football pitch through the restaurant window.

Mr Bulatovic, 51, was a senior member of the Socialist People's party, a Montenegrin party loyal to Mr Milosevic, which is in opposition in Montenegro, but is in government at the federal level.

As well as being a close ally of Mr Milosevic, Mr Bulatovic was very close to Momir Bulatovic, the Yugoslav premier. The two men were not related.

Born in the Montenegrin village of Gornji Rovci, he was married and had three children.Bulatovic was largely a figurehead, with all the major decisions being made by Mr Milosevic.

From 1992 to 1994 he served as Yugoslav interior minister in the government of Milan Panic, a Serb-born businessman who was later sacked by Mr Milosevic.

It was not immediately clear whether the minister, who was hit from behind, had died at the scene or later in hospital.

The independent Studio B TV company reported that two men sitting at the same table were wounded and were taken to a military hospital nearby.

A few hours after the shooting, the table where Mr Bulatovic sat was still covered with blood and the floor was littered with debris.

More than a dozen prominent people, some close to Mr Milosevic, have been killed in Belgrade in the past 10 years. Most of the killings have never been solved.

Other recent victims have included Dragan Simic, a young and ambitious police colonel, who was shot dead in a Belgrade car park last year; Slavko Curuvija, a prominent independent journalist and publisher critical of the Serbian authorities, who was gunned down outside his Belgrade apartment block last year during Nato air strikes against Yugoslavia; and Milorad Vlahovic another police colonel and the assistant head of the Belgrade homicide department who was also shot dead in a car park last year.

Miodrag Vlahovic, a political commentator in Montenegro's capital, Podgorica, said that the killing of Mr Bulatovic could be the result of a "conflict of interests" concerning business dealings between senior Yugoslav officials.

"The country in which the defence minister was killed like that in a restaurant is a real banana republic. There is no doubt about that," Mr Vlahovic said.

fields.headline: No: 1572 Little Weed
fields.body:
Yes, good news isn't it? Don't you mean age, appearance, status, etc?

At last the government is doing something right: It's nothing to do with the government.

It's been a scandal for a long time: We've missed it certainly.

Conflating cannabis with heroin and cocaine. Ah, I think you've got the wrong end of the plant.

You're not doing a trenchant defence of the drug tsar's volte-face on cannabis use? No, this is a jokey thing about the return to TV of Bill and Ben, the Flowerpot Men, and the enhanced role given to Little Weed.

Who on earth are Bill and Ben? Ah, you are clearly under 35. Bill and Ben are two men (or boys) constructed out of flowerpots: they live in a garden (where?), forever hiding from the unseen gardener the fact that they are alive - something known only to Little Weed (and to devoted viewers of Watch With Mother). Are they brothers, friends, lovers? We are never told. The series, which ended in 1971, occupies the same edgy dramatic territory as Kafka, Beckett and Pinter - Bill and Ben, their identities confused, talk in riddles ("flibadob", "flobadob") because life itself is a riddle.

Fascinating. And now it's coming back: Yes, hurrah, in a new series of 13 10-minute programmes made by Cosgrove Hall. The New Flowerpot Men should be back on the Beeb by the autumn.

Any changes planned? Principally the part of Little Weed. In the macho 1950s Weed was a drudge, passive and rather pathetic. Now, she will be empowered, a good-time grrrrrl, no doubt keen on bedding plants. (Is Cameron Diaz available?) Her part will also grow: instead of just saying "weeeeeeed" she will fully explore the psyche of the female sunflower.

Not to be confused with: The Woodentops - a sunny sitcom compared with the threatening world of the Flowerpot Men.

Do say: "Was it Bill or was it Ben made that filthy suggestion to Little Weed just then?"

Don't say: "People in glass houses shouldn't do remakes."

All cannabis users say: "Weeeeeeeeee-eeeeed."

fields.headline: Prisoners in paradise
fields.standfirst: After four years in a foreign jail, what would you choose? More of the same, with a chance of early reprieve, or transfer home, with no hope of a reduced term? As a former Bangkok inmate fights for release from a Kent prison,  Emily Barr reports on a Briton who has put his faith in Thailand
fields.trailText: After four years in a foreign jail, what would you choose? More of the same, with a chance of early reprieve, or transfer home, with no hope of a reduced term? As a former Bangkok inmate fights for release from a Kent prison,  Emily Barr reports on a Briton who has put his faith in Thailand
fields.body:
Jonathan Wheeler has lived in Bang Kwang prison for five and a half years. The story of how he got there is so familiar that it is a cliche. He was trapped in a gambling debt and threatened with death unless he carried a package out of Thailand to pay it off. The dealers tipped off customs and while Wheeler was stopped the people with the serious quantities of heroin slipped through. Wheeler's life - working in a bar on the island of Ko Samui and kick boxing for a living - was over at the age of 33. He was sentenced to 50 years.

He could be home by now, but he has chosen to stay in a prison that is described as "among the very worst in the world". After four or eight years, depending on the length of the sentence, Thai authorities allow prisoners to transfer to a jail in their home country. US and Australian prisoners are put on parole almost immediately. British law, however, states that all prisoners must serve half their remaining sentence, which, given the draconian nature of sentences imposed in Thailand, often means a great many years.

Sandra Gregory, a teacher from Yorkshire sentenced to 22 years in 1993, chose to take that route, returning to Britain after four years at Bang Kwang. Last weekend, her supporters held a candlelit vigil outside Downing Street to mark the start of her eighth year of incarcera tion. But despite her parents' high-profile campaign for her pardon, she is unlikely to be eligible for parole until December 2003.

Wheeler has declined to follow Gregory's example because he believes that despite the grim prison conditions he is better off in Bangkok, where there at least is some hope of early release. And he is not alone: Brian Mounsey, 41, could also be home by now, but has decided to stay and apply for a pardon or a reduction in sentence. There was great anticipation on the king's 72nd birthday in December, traditionally a cause for an amnesty. In the event, all drugs prisoners were excluded.

Jonathan Wheeler's mother, Sheila Bucket, believes her son is making the right choice by staying put. She is only too aware that the prison is "disgusting, with rats and cats and cockroaches", but says that "they have a funny kind of freedom out there. They have the big yard, and they're outside for most of the day. A girl from England sent out money from her church, and so they've built a hut in the yard."

Wheeler could have come home 18 months ago. "People who have done that tell him they wish they hadn't," says Bucket.

Gregory, 34, came home almost three years ago. Until recently, she was imprisoned in Durham prison, alongside Rosemary West. She is now in Cookham Wood, in Kent. "She's not in a good way," says her mother, Doreen. The Gregorys describe Sandra's continued incarceration as "a huge waste of everybody's lives". Under British law, her crime would have merited a four-year sentence. Doreen Gregory points to a recent case where a couple received sentences a third of the length of Sandra's, for smuggling 30,000 times the amount of heroin. The British government, however, is declining to write a letter to Thai authorities supporting their call for an appeal.

Sources within the foreign office suggest that a reform of the law, to bring it into line with that of the US and Australia, might be creeping on to the agenda. Officially, however, the idea is not entertained. The last thing the government wants is to be seen as soft on drug offenders; prisoners and their relatives argue that they have been punished many times over and that they are no danger to society.

For Paul, the question of a transfer did not arise. Paul (not his real name) carried drugs out of Thailand, and was given a 100-year sentence. After four and a half years in Bang Kwang, he was pardoned on the grounds of terminal illness. Now, aged 29 and HIV-positive, he has been home for 13 months. He looks well, on a battery of drugs. "It's been hard, coming back," he says. "I'm still not working or anything. You get used to being in an environment you know. My best mate was still there. I didn't want to leave him."

When he was sentenced, Paul had been living in Thailand for five years, but found the arrival in prison utterly bewildering. "I walked through the gates, and you don't know if you're coming or going. There's just people shouting at you. There's one guard with a glove on doing anal searches. He comes to me and I go, 'There's no way you're doing that.' I said, 'OK, you can do it, if that's the rule, if you change your glove. I am not having that glove...' Literally, the fingers were brown on it."

Once Paul was diagnosed as HIV-positive, he focused on his own survival. Around 10% of Bang Kwang inmates are infected. "If I'd had the medicine that I'm using now," he says, "there's a good chance that a guard would take half of it away, and sell it on. Or someone's going to stick a knife in my back to take it."

Conditions in Thai prisons, while bad for everyone, are made bearable if the prisoner has support from outside. "I didn't realise at first that you could buy fresh food," Paul recalls. "The first morning, I thought, how am I going to eat that? There's red rice, which is like brown rice but the lowest grade. And there's hairy fishhead soup. I took some, and I just thought, I'm going to die."

"Five months after he got there, Johnny trod on something and the cut became infected," his mother recalls. "I thought I was going to lose him. But if you can pay the money, you can always get to the hospitals. There's a really bad flu bug in the prison at the moment. TB is rife, and there's leprosy. They sit outside and scrape it off." The British embassy provides vitamins, and Prisoners Abroad also helps as much as it can.

Paul admits that he took heroin in prison. "You have to do something," he says. "I wish I hadn't. I felt better when I wasn't. But it's so tempting. I didn't share needles," he adds, "until I knew I was HIV-positive."

It is chilling to realise that Paul, with his terminal illness, is almost the lucky one. "The financial rewards will never be worth it," he says. "Never. It's really dumb, and I was really dumb. fields.bodyText: Jonathan Wheeler has lived in Bang Kwang prison for five and a half years. The story of how he got there is so familiar that it is a cliche. He was trapped in a gambling debt and threatened with death unless he carried a package out of Thailand to pay it off. The dealers tipped off customs and while Wheeler was stopped the people with the serious quantities of heroin slipped through. Wheeler's life - working in a bar on the island of Ko Samui and kick boxing for a living - was over at the age of 33. He was sentenced to 50 years. He could be home by now, but he has chosen to stay in a prison that is described as "among the very worst in the world". After four or eight years, depending on the length of the sentence, Thai authorities allow prisoners to transfer to a jail in their home country. US and Australian prisoners are put on parole almost immediately. British law, however, states that all prisoners must serve half their remaining sentence, which, given the draconian nature of sentences imposed in Thailand, often means a great many years. Sandra Gregory, a teacher from Yorkshire sentenced to 22 years in 1993, chose to take that route, returning to Britain after four years at Bang Kwang. Last weekend, her supporters held a candlelit vigil outside Downing Street to mark the start of her eighth year of incarcera tion. But despite her parents' high-profile campaign for her pardon, she is unlikely to be eligible for parole until December 2003. Wheeler has declined to follow Gregory's example because he believes that despite the grim prison conditions he is better off in Bangkok, where there at least is some hope of early release. And he is not alone: Brian Mounsey, 41, could also be home by now, but has decided to stay and apply for a pardon or a reduction in sentence. There was great anticipation on the king's 72nd birthday in December, traditionally a cause for an amnesty. In the event, all drugs prisoners were excluded. Jonathan Wheeler's mother, Sheila Bucket, believes her son is making the right choice by staying put. She is only too aware that the prison is "disgusting, with rats and cats and cockroaches", but says that "they have a funny kind of freedom out there. They have the big yard, and they're outside for most of the day. A girl from England sent out money from her church, and so they've built a hut in the yard." Wheeler could have come home 18 months ago. "People who have done that tell him they wish they hadn't," says Bucket. Gregory, 34, came home almost three years ago. Until recently, she was imprisoned in Durham prison, alongside Rosemary West. She is now in Cookham Wood, in Kent. "She's not in a good way," says her mother, Doreen. The Gregorys describe Sandra's continued incarceration as "a huge waste of everybody's lives". Under British law, her crime would have merited a four-year sentence. Doreen Gregory points to a recent case where a couple received sentences a third of the length of Sandra's, for smuggling 30,000 times the amount of heroin. The British government, however, is declining to write a letter to Thai authorities supporting their call for an appeal. Sources within the foreign office suggest that a reform of the law, to bring it into line with that of the US and Australia, might be creeping on to the agenda. Officially, however, the idea is not entertained. The last thing the government wants is to be seen as soft on drug offenders; prisoners and their relatives argue that they have been punished many times over and that they are no danger to society. fields.headline: Lambing perils
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Somerset
fields.body:
Somerset

The first thing I was shown was a barn stacked with bales of hay grown without fertiliser in the fields of Pear Ash farm. The fields are simply spread with muck every other year, and limed to correct the acidity. Looked at closely, the grasses were mostly very fine. It was easy to believe that such sweet-smelling hay is a delicacy to a lamb.

Pear Ash farm has 250 acres high up on the edge of the remaining woods of the once great forest of Selwood, not far from the church at the centre of the village of Pen (modern signposts give the name as the single word: "Penselwood"). On balance, animals take more goodness out of the land than they put back in. A farmer needs the traditional feel for managing pasture and meadow. He must watch the weather and rate of growth, and be a good judge of when to graze a field and when to rest it. And shepherds still need to guard their sheep as of old. Foxes bark, nightly, in the surrounding woods.

After lambing in the shelter of barns or poly-tunnels, the young spend a few days in loose boxes, bonding with their mothers, but must then take their chance, day and night, out in the fields. One particular fox returned methodically to take a lamb every night for several weeks until he was shot. As many as 30 or 40 lambs from a flock of 500 or 600 may be lost to foxes.

There is an ingenious way of delivering the sheepnuts that enrich the diet. In wet weather, even the lightest tractor can quickly turn a field into a quagmire. So the resident horse is employed to pull a light trailer called a "Snacker". It has a hopper and revolving drum set to deliver a measured ration every five or six feet. The farmer can operate the trailer and throw down hay-bales at intervals. No damage is done to the land, no fumes are released into the atmosphere, each animal gets its share, and the relative quiet enables the farmer to hear the faintest bleat of a lamb in distress.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: It was not true to say, as we did in our front page lead, Bombers hit hopes for peace, yesterday, that "the last bombing to hit Ulster was the attack on Omagh by the real IRA on August 15, 1998". There have been at least 15 incidents, not confined to one faction, involving bombs of various kinds since then. These have included the murders of Rosemary Nelson, March 15, last year, and Elizabeth O'Neill, June 5, last year.
fields.body:
It was not true to say, as we did in our front page lead, Bombers hit hopes for peace, yesterday, that "the last bombing to hit Ulster was the attack on Omagh by the real IRA on August 15, 1998". There have been at least 15 incidents, not confined to one faction, involving bombs of various kinds since then. These have included the murders of Rosemary Nelson, March 15, last year, and Elizabeth O'Neill, June 5, last year.

In a piece headed Farming? This is milking, page 20, February 3, we said, "There is one problem. The government has to find another £8m in 'matching aid' to release the Euro cash - modest when you consider the £5bn annually going into farming." Too modest, in fact. The figure should have been £800m not £8m.

In our interview with Luciano Berio, pages 16 and 17, Friday Review, February 4, we quoted him as saying, "Now one of the problems in Italy is the government..." He meant to say simply, "The government's [or successive governments'] attitude towards music."

It was wrong to say in a story headlined Papal apology riles Vatican hardliners, page 15, February 4, that the Vatican persecuted Galileo for "suggesting the world was round". He was persecuted for continuing to teach that the Copernican system, in which the earth travels around the sun, was "literally" true.

On the Vodafone/Mannesmann map of Europe on page 24, February 4, the country shaded and labelled as Hungary is in fact Slovakia.

Solvers of our Crossword, February 4, were required to misspell the name of the Antarctic explorer Roald Amundsen and thus could only arrive at the correct solution incorrectly. He became Admundsen in 17 across. Sorry.

One of the photographs illustrating Orhan Pamuk's piece about the fear of earthquakes in Istanbul, Saturday Review, page 3, February 5, showed the Blue Mosque (with its distinguishing six minarets) not - as it was captioned - Agia Sophia.

In an article about the Scotsman, page 9, Media, January 24, we mentioned the competition it was facing as London-based newspapers began to sell aggressively in Scotland. In that context we said, "The Guardian's coverage of the Edinburgh Festival is the most comprehensive of any title." We should have made it clear that we were not taking into account the coverage of the Scotsman itself which produced a daily 24-page tabloid devoted to the festival throughout its duration.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: Delaying tactics by US frustrate Brown debt plan

fields.headline: Delaying tactics by US frustrate Brown debt plan
fields.standfirst:
Debt relief: special report
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's target of a fast track to debt relief for 25 of the world's poorest countries is being thwarted by the US treasury, according to Whitehall sources.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's target of a fast track to debt relief for 25 of the world's poorest countries is being thwarted by the US treasury, according to Whitehall sources.

During two weeks of infighting at the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, Britain has been putting diplomatic pressure on the Americans to drop their opposition to early debt relief for countries with effective poverty reduction plans.

But last night it seemed the US treasury had won the day, with the World Bank expected to announce that a final loan write-off for Uganda had been delayed for several months, although the country is seen as a textbook example of economic and social reform.

Government sources said yesterday that this set a worrying precedent for Mr Brown's plan to get 11 countries through the IMF and Bank debt relief programme by Easter. They said Britain and its allies, Norway, Sweden and the Netherlands, were having to fight every inch of the way at the Fund and the Bank to overcome US delaying tactics.

"You get the feeling that it is going to have to be fought through country by country, and that wasn't what was supposed to happen at all," a senior government official said. "If we are going to take this long over Uganda, there is a real concern over how long the others will take."

Mr Brown has been the driving force behind international efforts to speed up debt relief, after the original blueprint - the heavily indebted poor countries initiative (HIPC), introduced four years ago - proved too slow and not generous enough.

His pre-Christmas pledge to get 25 countries through a revamped HIPC by the end of 2000 was designed to give the international community a set timetable to work towards. In exchange for debt relief, poor countries have to produce plans which show how the money will be used to reduce poverty.

Britain's problems with the US treasury spring from the administration's fraught relationship with a coalition of right-wing Republicans and left-wing Democrats on Capitol Hill.

 The World Trade Organisation yesterday took the first tentative steps towards repairing the damage from its disastrous conference in Seattle when it agreed to start talks on lowering barriers to trade in two key sectors within the next six weeks.

The WTO said negotiations would start in just over a fortnight on services and on farm produce by the end of March. The talks represent a considerable scaling back of the WTO's ambitions.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: FSA advertises claim deadline
fields.body:
FSA advertises claim deadline

The financial services authority is launching an advertising campaign to warn nearly 1m potential personal pension misselling victims of the March 31 deadline to make a claim against their pension company - and possibly gain five-figure compensation.

About 1.1m pension buyers have already registered a claim in the second phase of the misselling review which concentrates on younger consumers - typically now aged below 50. They have collected £3bn in redress.

The FSA believes there could be up to 976,000 outstanding claims from others who were sold personal pensions between 1988 and 1994. The FSA Pensions Helpline is on 0800 003 007.

EC wades into car debate

The European Commission yesterday warned it would clamp down on any carmaker which tried to prevent British consumers from buying cars more cheaply on the continent.

The warning, from competition commissioner Mario Monti, came as the commission reported that Britain was still the most expensive country in which to buy a car.

Its latest survey showed that car prices in Britain are 35% higher than the average for the community as a whole. The biggest gap was for an Alfa 145, which cost 65.1% more in Britain than in Denmark.

The survey, based on prices on November 1 last year, showed that a Rover 214 cost £10,953 in Britain and only £6,785 in France. A Ford Focus cost 56.4% more in Britain than in Denmark, while a Volkswagen Golf cost 53.5% more then in Finland.

The commission said that the fact that certain carmakers had reduced their prices in Britain was "an encouraging sign", but added that the cuts had been offset by the 2.4% rise in the value of the pound.

It said manufacturers often added a 10% supplement for right-hand drive cars bought by Britons from continental dealers. Volkswagen had in some cases charged an extra 14%.

It added that the most complaints it received about the obstacles dealers put in the way of car buyers from another country came from Britain.

Retail sales rise 4%

Bargain hunters pushed sales 4% higher in January than a year earlier, according to British Retail Consortium's sales monitor.

Customers flocked to furniture stores to carry out home improvements, while pharmacies benefited from a bumper month for sales of flu remedies and tissues.

The figures came a day before the Bank of England's monetary policy committee started its two-day meeting to set interest rates and could give rise to further concerns about the economy overheating.

However, government figures have shown little sign of rising prices in shops, with retailers increasing sales by bringing in markdowns.

Bridget Rosewell, chief economic adviser to the BRC, said: "The Bank will probably want to put up interest rates but that ignores the fact that retailers are only making extra sales by cutting prices. They've had a very weak 1999 and a pretty tough Christmas."

webTitle: Granada surfs into Home and Away

fields.headline: Granada surfs into Home and Away
fields.trailText: Media and catering group Granada yesterday announced a £56m investment in Australia's Seven Network, the company which makes "sun and surf" soap Home and Away.
fields.body:
Media and catering group Granada yesterday announced a £56m investment in Australia's Seven Network, the company which makes "sun and surf" soap Home and Away.

The deal gives Granada a 9.1% stake in Seven, and will see the groups combining production assets to form a joint venture to be based in Melbourne and Sydney.

Seven is the largest producer of entertainment, sports and news content in Australia.

Neighbours, Home and Away's long-running ratings rival, is owned by another British media group, Pearson.

Granada chief executive Charles Allen described the deal with Seven as "a major strategic move for our international media business".

"It catapaults us into pole position in the Australian TV production market and puts us in a strong position to take part in the rapidly developing digital TV, pay TV and new media industry in Australia."

Granada also has production companies in the United States and Germany. Foreign companies are not permitted to own more than 20% of Australian TV companies.

Seven Network is the rights holder for the Sydney 2000 Olympic games as well as having the exclusive rights to broadcast the Australian open tennis championships.

The network also operates a cable sports channel and has a number of internet ventures. Granada will nominate a representative to the Seven board.

Granada's contract catering business also announced a £40m three-year contract to supply Eurostar trains, scoring a victory over the incumbent, French supplier Wagons-Lit, which rebid for the franchise.

The contract will be operated through a joint venture, Momentum, with Italian group Cremonini. Shares in Granada were 11p higher at 569.5p.

webTitle: Old boys trapped by their networks

fields.headline: Old boys trapped by their networks
fields.standfirst: Growth, not size, matters
fields.trailText: After winning the bidding war for Mannesmann and ruffling a lot of German feathers in the process, Vodafone AirTouch's chief, Chris Gent, will be spending time in Düsseldorf this week trying to win the peace.
fields.body:
After winning the bidding war for Mannesmann and ruffling a lot of German feathers in the process, Vodafone AirTouch's chief, Chris Gent, will be spending time in Düsseldorf this week trying to win the peace.

It will not be an easy task, not least because of the problems of integrating two business cultures within what will be the world's fourth-biggest corporate group.

There will be others within the telecommunications industry, however, who will be watching Mr Gent's progress with interest, even envy. Many of the Gent watchers will be in the boardrooms of former state-owned telecoms monopolies still looking to come to terms with post- deregulation life in the private sector.

Where once their sprawling organisations held undisputed sway and Vodafone was simply a gleam in Sir Ernest Harrison's eye, the mobile phone companies have made huge inroads into the telecoms market. And this is not just the one serving commuters who cannot live without telling their colleagues they are on the way into the office or their partners they are on the way home.

The introduction of WAP (wireless application protocol) will mean that new-generation mobile phones will be able to receive anything from news bulletins, sports results and restaurant ratings to email and, eventually, music and video clips.

Even the traditional strength of the once-state-owned corporations - their fixed-line networks - is under threat as they are forced by national regulators to open these to upstart competition.

Little wonder that the likes of British Telecommunications, France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom, under chief executive Ron Sommer, are doing some serious strategic thinking.

BT is said to be on the brink of its biggest shake-up since privatisation; the German group, which bought mobile operator One2One last year, is rumoured to be dusting off its plans for an alliance with Telecom Italia - now owned by Olivetti; France Telecom has just shelled out for Global One - its alliance with Deutsche Telekom and US group Sprint. Both France Telecom and its Dutch equivalent, KPN, are hotly tipped as bidders for Britain's Orange.

Indeed, events at Global One illustrate a crucial problem facing the former state sector - and not so former in the case of Deutsche Telekom where Berlin still holds two-thirds of the shares. While the alliance was destabilised by Deutsche Telekom's bid for Telecom Italia because it infuriated France Telecom, it was Sprint's agreement to merge with MCI WorldCom which broke up the partnership and gave France Telecom full control.

BT's own global ambitions had earlier suffered a similar setback when WorldCom thwarted the British player's planned merger with MCI.

The problem is not one of size. Vodafone, via the AirTouch and Mannesmann acquisitions which give it access to the US, Germany and Italy (where Mannesmann brings in Omnitel), and Spain through the share stake in Airtel - and Mr Gent firmly expects to knock out BT's own holding - is a very formidable presence.

But Deutsche Telekom is no minnow. Its market capitalisation - the shares have more than doubled in the past nine months - is now close to £160bn.

France Telecom - another company to enjoy a big run-up in the share price - is worth just over £100bn.

Even BT, where the share price has fallen sharply since the beginning of the year, is worth £70bn. Vodafone before Mannesmann was worth £104bn; after the merger its value is more than three times that of BT.

But there is the question of growth. Mr Gent remains convinced that the best returns for shareholders lie in mobiles rather than in the integrated fixed-line and wireless approach favoured by Klaus Esser at Mannesmann - and the bulk of investors backed his conviction.

The best prospects are in the fastest-growing areas of the telecoms market and they come unencumbered by the baggage of the past - a huge fixed infrastructure or a civil service-style bureaucracy.

To remedy that imbalance some of the traditional businesses are trying to show off their high-growth areas. Deutsche Telekom is to float its internet business, T Online, this spring and then mobile phone business T Mobile.

BT boss Sir Peter Bonfield has been quoted as saying that his company is looking at breaking out the figures from the different businesses such as Cellnet and Concert, and might even consider listing these separately.

At least one strand of the Deutsche Telekom strategy is clear. The German group has said it will use T Online shares to fund acquisitions.

After all, internet entrepreneurs are more likely to accept shares in a similar company than equity in a more broadly based business.

The problem is somehow to get the share price bounce which should come from highlighting the fast-growing areas of the business against making sure that the original company derives the maximum benefits from the new ventures.

It is a dilemma that needs a quick resolution. Just in time for the next step change in the industry - the third-generation mobile phones which will be able to process the sort of data required for television pictures and films.

The day of the household without fixed telephone links is already on the horizon. The old boys will need to shape up.

webTitle: £60m loss fails to dampen BA's spirit

fields.headline: £60m loss fails to dampen BA's spirit
fields.trailText: British Airways yesterday announced a third-quarter loss of £60m, but BA chief executive Bob Ayling defiantly responded to the news by saying there were "encouraging signs" that the corner had been turned.
fields.body:
British Airways yesterday announced a third-quarter loss of £60m, but BA chief executive Bob Ayling defiantly responded to the news by saying there were "encouraging signs" that the corner had been turned.

The size of the pre-tax loss was better than most City forecasts of £70m-£90m. The figures were welcomed by analysts and shares initially rose before dipping from 309p to end at 296p.

Mr Ayling was able to report the first upturn in passenger yields, the best measure of an airline's underlying profitability, since the fourth quarter of the 1997-98 financial year.

After almost two years of decline, revenue per passenger kilometre rose just over 3% from the previous year to 6.06p. The next crucial stage for BA will come with publication of its annual accounts, due out in the spring. City analysts have forecast that the company's losses could be as high as £250m but they might be as low as £150m.

Mr Ayling said that passenger revenue yields rose 3.2% during the quarter, after a fall of 7.1% and 5.2% respectively in the first and second quarters. He said that BA was "reading the market correctly".

"BA had a very difficult year last year with over-capacity in the market, but the cuts in costs and investment in the profitable sectors of the market mean that we are beginning to turn it round."

Pre-tax profits for the first nine months of the year were £180m, down more than 40%, with the least profitable winter quarter to come. This means that BA is on course to record its first full-year loss since it was privatised in 1987.

BA's yield and profits have been plagued in the past 12 months by rising fuel prices and competition on north Atlantic routes, prompted by over-capacity. By dropping less profitable routes and switching to smaller aircraft with more high-paying business passengers, BA hopes its yields will rise.

Mr Ayling said that yields would be improved further by innovations to boost numbers in BA's economy class, and revamping business class with fully reclining seats. Prices in the new cabin will be 20% higher than regular economy class and are expected to draw business travellers who cannot pay a full club fare.

Commerzbank analyst Chris Tarry said: "Positive moves are being made even before BA starts to see the benefit of the new products coming on stream."

SG Securities analyst Ian Wild said: "The general background is of a sharply depressed, intensely competitive industry, where too many aircraft are being delivered, there are too many passengers and the oil price is rising."

BA has achieved its £1bn cut in costs, plus a further £225m forced on it last year when its fortunes began to spiral. This has led to the loss of 1,000 jobs through voluntary redundancy to be completed by the end of March.

Mr Ayling said that a further 6,000 jobs will have to disappear over the next three years. "But this will be by natural wastage and a curb on recruitment." He thought that staff morale was improving and that better times lay ahead.

fields.headline: Ministers reject coal subsidy plea
fields.trailText: The government rejected coal industry pleas for subsidies yesterday, prompting fears of a new round of closures and redundancies.
fields.body:
The government rejected coal industry pleas for subsidies yesterday, prompting fears of a new round of closures and redundancies.

The once-mighty industry, now reduced to 17 deep-mine pits and facing a flood of cheap imports, has asked for exchequer subsidies of around £20m a year for the next three years.

But Neil Hurst, deputy director general of energy at the trade and industry department, said none of the options the industry has presented "has been identified as the way forward".

The industry, led by RJB Mining, which bought the bulk of the English coalfields for £815m in 1994, has demanded short-term subsidies to close the gap between production costs and selling prices.

Alternatively, it has suggested support for investment in long-term supplies (development work) or financial incentives for generators to fit filters reducing sulphur dioxide emissions at power stations.

But Mr Hurst's comments led industry executives to warn that half of the remaining deep pits and thousands of jobs were at risk in a rerun of the crisis in 1997-98 that brought swift government intervention.

RJB, which employs 8,000 miners and owns 13 of the pits, will close Ellington in Northumbria on February 25 after talks with the once-jailed Italian entrepreneur Giovanni di Stefano - a friend of murdered Serbian warlord Arkan - collapsed.

Clipstone, Notts, will close in September with the loss of 200 jobs. But others such as Prince of Wales, Pontefract, visited on Friday by Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, are getting £20m of investment.

Mr Hurst insisted that ministers were sympathetic to the industry's plight and pressing ahead with plans to create a level playing field so coal could compete with fuels such as gas.

He said the overturning by ministers of applications to build 4.3 gigawatts of gas-fired power stations had protected more than 10m tonnes of coal burn - at a cost of 6,000 new jobs in the power industry. The ban on gas would, he hinted, soon be lifted.

Mr Hurst said increased competition in power generation would force down wholesale prices and enable low-cost coal producers offering flexible supplies to compete more effectively.

New entrants planned to fit filters which could raise coal burn by 6m tonnes a year.

He insisted that world prices - once down to $19 a tonne - had risen 15% recently, enabling British producers to be more competitive. But they argue that imports are heavily subsidised.

Last week, due to problems in France, whose stations provide up to 7% of power here, and the UK domestic gas and nuclear power industries, coal burn rose 36.4% to a record high of 1.107m tonnes, proving its indispensable flexibility in keeping the lights on, they said.

fields.headline: Oxford Molecular wields jobs axe
fields.trailText: Biotech services firm Oxford Molecular yesterday unveiled plans for job cuts and the closure of offices as it admitted it was heading for a £26m loss for the year to December 1999.
fields.body:
Biotech services firm Oxford Molecular yesterday unveiled plans for job cuts and the closure of offices as it admitted it was heading for a £26m loss for the year to December 1999.

Up to 55 of the 300 staff are to leave the company whose co-founder, Professor William Richards, resigned a month ago following a profits warning in November. Two offices in the US will be shut.

Oxford Molecular's software solutions division is blamed for much of the crisis, with pharmaceutical customers being slower than expected to ousource their information technology requirements.

Chairman Douglas Brown said the reorganisation, which had started at the end of 1999, would cost around £6m to implement.

An operating loss of £11.6m will be incurred after a charge for amortisation of goodwill of £2m had been incurred resulting from the acquisition of chemical design interests.

Oxford Molecular has expanded fast through acquisition. Cambridge Drug Discovery is to be sold off and the software business will operate from only two major centres in the US.

There will be a 33% reduction in the space occupied at the Oxford headquarters with 20 redundancies there. Thirty-three people in the US software business will be leaving.

The share price fell 4p to 27p.

fields.headline: Pfizer seals $90bn blockbuster
fields.trailText: American pharmaceuticals firms Pfizer and Warner-Lambert yesterday cemented a $90bn (£56bn) merger to create the world's second-largest drugs combine in a deal which will almost certainly trigger new takeovers in the industry.
fields.body:
American pharmaceuticals firms Pfizer and Warner-Lambert yesterday cemented a $90bn (£56bn) merger to create the world's second-largest drugs combine in a deal which will almost certainly trigger new takeovers in the industry.

The deal ends a punishing three-cornered fight and means that American Home Products, which had planned to merge with Warner-Lambert, has been jilted at the altar for the third time. The company will, however, pick up a consolation payment of $1.8bn which will help fund lawsuits related to two of its former diet products.

The merger will create a company with a brand portfolio including the impotence treatment Viagra and the cholesterol-busting Lipitor with revenues of $28bn a year and a research and development budget of about $4.7bn a year. Henry McKinnell, president and chief operating officer of the new group, said the merger "will make us not just bigger but better".

But thousands of people in the combined 87,400 workforce are likely to lose their jobs as the new group attempts to shave $1.6bn off its costs in the next two years. The combined company will keep Pfizer's name and its New York headquarters although Warner-Lambert's base in New Jersey will become the centre for consumer products such as Listerine and Bain de Soleil.

The first, and most high-profile, casualty of the deal emerged yesterday. Lodewijk de Vink, the Warner-Lambert chairman and chief executive, will quit after the bitter contest picking up a pay-off which could top $250m once his share options are taken into account.

The deal is the third blockbusting merger in the pharmaceuticals sector in as many months. In December, Pharmacia & Upjohn announced a $27bn merger with Monsanto, while last month Britain's two big players, SmithKline Beecham and Glaxo Wellcome, pulled off their long-anticipated deal to create the world's largest drugs company.

Analysts said yesterday the trend will almost certainly continue. American Home Products, whose portfolio also includes the hormone replacement treatment Premarin, said it would now sell its crop protection unit and experts said this should take place by the end of June.

webTitle: You can all join in, says Durlacher

fields.headline: You can all join in, says Durlacher
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report

Durlacher
fields.trailText: Internet investment specialist Durlacher yesterday launched an online share trading service offering retail investors a chance to buy into firms it has invested in. The news sent its own stock soaring.
fields.body:
Internet investment specialist Durlacher yesterday launched an online share trading service offering retail investors a chance to buy into firms it has invested in. The news sent its own stock soaring.

Durlacher shares, which were trading at £2 last August, surged a further 9% to a new high of £30.80 in early London trading.

Nothing-ventured.com offers the now usual services - real-time trading, share prices, company news and email alerts - but also the chance to take part in flotations of hi-tech companies Durlacher has nurtured.

For select investors who understand risk and have a minimum of £25,000 to spare, there will be the chance to take a stake in certain start-ups in Durlacher's portfolio before they go public.

Geoffrey Chamberlain, chief executive of the stockbroker turned internet investor, said he wanted to level the playing field by giving individuals the same chances as institutions to trade quickly and invest in private companies.

"We want to counter charges that the private individual has been disadvantaged," he told journalists. It will cost £50 a year to join Nothing-ventured, plus commission on deals.

Mr Chamberlain said he expected that Nothing-ventured would present the first initial public offering by some time in early March. - Reuters

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: It was left to technology stocks and a few confused banking shares to resist the downward pull exerted on the leading shares by anxieties over interest rates yesterday.
fields.body:
It was left to technology stocks and a few confused banking shares to resist the downward pull exerted on the leading shares by anxieties over interest rates yesterday. The FTSE 100 finished at a new 14-week closing low of 6,118 on a day of heavy trading.

The Techmark 100 surged ahead again boosted by fresh Nasdaq strength and supplied the main index's top four gainers - Misys , up 126p to 1,085p, CMG, up 500p at £56.05, Sema , up 120p at £16.09, and Sage , up 36p to 861p.

Bank shares, out of favour of late, also provided some of the day's winners. The three- way tussle for NatWest caused yet more unpredictable movement in its two Scottish predators, with Royal Bank of Scotland up 28p to 992p as banking analysts continued to back its bid for NatWest while Bank of Scotland gained 6p to 593p, before the market heard the rumours of Phillips & Drew's support for its bid. Meanwhile, their takeover target fell by 37p to £10.92.

Lloyds TSB , due to report a bumper set of profit figures on Friday, also gained 7p to end at 610p after speculation at the weekend that it was ready to bid for either of the Scottish banks.

Vodafone , fresh from its victory over Mannesmann, inflicted most of the losses on the index with arbitrageurs blamed for much of the fall. By right, the shares should be rising as institutional investors clamber to snap them up to meet their market weightings in new shares. The telecoms company lost 3.3% of its value to end at 334p and hitting the index for as much as 20 points.

Among other losers on the day were Marks & Spencer which retreated 14p to 269p as speculation about a bid by opportunistic retailer Phillip Green abated. British Airways also lost 13p to end at 296p despite reporting a better than expected set of figures.

With interest rates expected to be raised later this week, the City is braced for a volatile trading week, which is also spattered with results from major companies such as Reuters , whose shares held steady at £10.07p yesterday despite speculation that it might excite the market with some fresh news accompanying its results today.

Outside the main index, Scoot.com was again a strong gainer in the FTSE Mid 250 index, rising 40.5p to 264p.

PizzaExpress shed 49p to 812p after profits figures were followed by news of a Warburg Dillon Read ratings downgrade.
