Outside the main index, Scoot.com was again a strong gainer in the FTSE Mid 250 index, rising 40.5p to 264p. PizzaExpress shed 49p to 812p after profits figures were followed by news of a Warburg Dillon Read ratings downgrade.

fields.headline: Awaiting delivery
fields.trailText: Ford is heading for a strike in Britain after pay talks broke down yesterday. The possibility of industrial action comes as the motor manufacturer is drawing up plans to restructure its entire European operation, writes Nicholas Bannister.
fields.body:
Ford is heading for a strike in Britain after pay talks broke down yesterday. The possibility of industrial action comes as the motor manufacturer is drawing up plans to restructure its entire European operation, writes Nicholas Bannister.

Union officials said Ford executives had failed to make a new or better offer to its professional staff, who have already rejected an 11% rise over three years and a 1 hour reduction in the basic working week.

Shop stewards representing 4,000 of the group's 7,000 professional staff meet on Thursday; a strike would bring all Ford's UK plants to a halt.

Professional staff represented by the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union and the Transport and General have already voted in favour of industrial action in pursuit of their pay claim.

An MSF official said: "In the ballot 63% voted in favour of strike action and about 90% voted in favour of action short of a strike."

The professional staff, who include engineers, designers, IT and clerical staff, want parity with the hourly paid workers' deal of a 15% rise over three years. They also object to Ford's plan to merge their pension fund - which has a £505m surplus - with that of the hourly paid workers, which is £155m in deficit.

The MSF spokesman said: "We fear that Ford will use some of the surplus to pay the increase to the manual workers, and that the company will raid the pension scheme to fund the possibility of redundancies.

"On the issue of a bad time to strike, it is always a bad time, as there is always some threat of closure. But the staff want justice."

A Ford official said the unions had been made aware of the state of the business at the start of the talks. She said yesterday's meeting had been "a useful session to clarify the items the union want to discuss". She added that no further meeting was planned.

 BMW yesterday warned that it would have to rethink its £1.7bn modernisation of Rover's Longbridge plant if the EC failed to approve a £141m aid package by the end of the summer.

webTitle: Banks' endgame that will change little

fields.headline: Banks' endgame that will change little
fields.trailText: Bandwagon hope for bidders
fields.body:
Bandwagon hope for bidders

National Westminster's attempts to repel the Scottish boarders are entering their final stages. Although the arguments will run for a few days more, investors are in the throes of making up their minds.

Thanks to the British takeover code the battle has not been as interminable as the three-way banking bid war which racked France for much of last year and eventually ground to a bore draw.

There was another difference, however. The Banque Nationale de Paris/Société Générale/Paribas affair was an attempt, however misguided, to restructure the industry in France. The NatWest battle, whatever the outcome, will not fundamentally change the nature of banking in Britain.

Bank of Scotland, which at least deserves recognition for ambition, not to say outright audacity, saw an opportunity presented by investor disenchantment with NatWest and took it. Royal Bank of Scotland had little choice but to respond. It could not risk its closest competitor gaining the (different) advantages each sees in acquiring NatWest.

Nothing wrong with that, and the two banks can claim they have superior management records although it is by no means automatic that such superiority would transfer successfully to NatWest. Each has argued fiercely that it has a better vision than the other (and NatWest's incumbent management) for the future but neither has presented a case compellingly better than its rival.

As for NatWest, large parts of its defence have rested on annexing chunks of the bidders' strategies. Its best chance lies in splitting those voting against its being allowed to retain its independence. Yet it will have little to crow about if it escapes with less than 50% support.

Over the next couple of days both bidders will be desperate to get a bandwagon of acceptances rolling in order to bring on board those investors who cannot decide between the offers but don't believe NatWest deserves to get away.

Mobile war

Last weekend, in Munich, Bill Cohen and Geoff Hoon, US and UK defence secretaries, signed a ringing declaration to enable British contractors to penetrate the lucrative (and growing) American market. The Yanks are already over here and, as the recent Boeing advertisements underline, sending more troops and equipment. But can the Brits (and Europeans) compete on home ground?

Today the Archer consortium, effectively run by BAE Systems, will make a critical decision - on 56,000 VHF radios ensuring secure data and voice communication on the battlefield: next-generation military mobile phones - that could determine whether Britain retains a capability in defence technology or opts for a US solution.

BAE faces the unenviable task of choosing between two of its Archer partners: Racal (being bought by the French) and America's ITT. Racal argues that it offers a cheaper, proven version; a tactical internet system; up to £1bn in domestic orders and exports; and at least 1,100 skilled British jobs. ITT offers a version already in use by the US army.

The radios, replacing 1970s Clansman kit shown to be wholly inadequate in Kosovo where they could be overheard by Serbs, are eight years overdue but Racal says they could enter service well ahead of the 2003 timeframe set by the MoD. The crucial issue for the armed forces, however, is not whether they are European or American: it is that they arrive on time and work.

Gold fever

Suddenly gold is back in favour. The price rocketed by $23 late on Friday and was up another $10 yesterday.

So are gold bugs getting their revenge on central banks whose sales did so much to drive down the price to a 20-year low last September by subtly suggesting that inflation might be getting out of control and that the precious metal remains the safest haven?

It is a nice thought but unlikely. The explanation appears to lie in the decision by gold producers to reduce their forward sales - that is, selling gold they have yet to produce. News that the Canadian company Placer Dome, the world's fifth-largest miner, on Friday that it was suspending its "hedging" programme pushed the market higher on Friday, and yesterday AngloGold, the world's number one producer, said it had been reducing its hedge position during the past four months.

Analysts reckon that the reduction in forward selling is offsetting the impact of central bank gold sales, thus pushing up the price - rather than any perception of central bank complacency on the inflation front. Still, the recovery in price might attract attention from investors worried that equity and bond markets are looking just a bit on the toppy side.

fields.headline: Arms and the businessman
fields.standfirst: Africa, with its 14 ongoing conflicts, is the supreme test of whether the goverment can promote trade and human rights at the same time
fields.trailText:
The case of Kenya

fields.body:
The case of Kenya
In 1998 (the most recent year for figures for arms exports), the department of trade and industry approved licences for the sale of machine-gun parts, rifles and ammunition to Kenya. It is difficult to imagine how these are consistent with the aims of preventing conflict and eradicating poverty as stated by Clare Short's department for international development and pursued with £34m of bilateral aid to Kenya in 1998-99

With one hand, the government seeks to cut the external debt of poor countries, on condition resources are not squandered on weapons of war. With the other, it supplies or does little to prevent the supply of aircraft and arms to the same countries.

It is in Africa - 14 ongoing armed conflicts, 8m displaced people - that the incoherence of arms and aid is most apparent. This is perhaps why a new effort is being made inside Whitehall to make policy towards sub-Saharan Africa more "joined up".

As part of the 2000 comprehensive spending review - which means the treasury is in the driving seat - Clare Short is leading a policy review on conflict prevention in sub-Saharan Africa to "consider how the UK's objective for conflict prevention in this region can best be defined and delivered. The review will also consider the scope for applying conclusions to conflict prevention worldwide".

Meanwhile Robin Cook is repackaging foreign policy, replacing the vexing word "ethical" with the message that the UK's national interest is the global interest and vice versa. Such language of enlightened self-interest should appeal more to other ministers, notably those in defence and trade, who never quite took to the ethical dimension. Can Labour combine the promotion of human rights and encouragement to trade within the same policy? Africa is its supreme test.

UK investment in sub-Saharan Africa totalled £4.9bn in 1997. Trade is concentrated on South Africa, Nigeria, Ghana and Kenya. Together they account for 72% of exports to Africa, which were worth £2.7bn in 1999. (This represents 1.8% of total UK exports for January-November last year.) The short-term national interest might seem limited to seeing that these dominant African economies are stable and maximising trade in specific sectors, such as arms.

But the UK's long-term self-interest also lies in such huge potential markets and sources of natural resources as Angola and the Congo, countries blighted by violence. South Africa shows how, once seemingly intractable conflicts have been resolved, things come good for UK plc too. The British trainers helping to integrate apartheid-age enemies into the South African army, paid for by the ministry of defence and the foreign office, represent the kind of initiative which could be more widely applied with additional funds. Such training cannot be supported by Clare Short's department despite recognising its importance in countries emerging from conflict.

British interests go wider than commerce. Governments in modern democracies where media are strong have an interest in responding to what electorates judge to be wrong: brutal wars and extreme poverty head the list. Public opinion has an ethical dimension. Following it, the government has to do what it can to reduce war and conflict in Africa.

Labour has recognised that if you want to reduce conflict, you have to reduce poverty. At its crudest, former fighters are unlikely to sit playing cards if they are hungry. In Sierra Leone, the UK has led the way in paying for demobilising ex-combatants. What is good for development is good for peace. The decision by Gordon Brown and Clare Short on debt will help make a number of countries, from Uganda to Mozambique, more stable as well as less poor. As a motor for peaceful development, universal primary education could also help reduce conflicts.

The spending review is an opportunity to increase funds. Whitehall departments are already involved in promoting human rights and the democratic control of some armies in Africa. The treasury should allow them more money to carry on the work.

The review has its limits. It is not tackling tension between spending on Africa and commercial policy. Despite Robin Cook's assertion about the coincidence of global and national interests, the maxim is being taken to heart in some departments more than others, notably the department of trade and industry. The trade secretary, Stephen Byers, won praise from African governments in December for seeking to make the World Trade Organisation more open to their opinions. But there are too many counter-examples showing the DTI promoting exports or investment oblivious to the fact that there are wars going on. In 1998, Clare Short and the foreign office were calling for peace in Sudan. The DTI's best advice to British companies was that "the oil sector in Sudan is one of tremendous opportunity", failing to mention that the Sudan government depends on oil to pay for its wars. Two years later, the DTI's website is still offers similar advice.

The problem is that trade and investment are promoted with little or no regard for their impact on conflict. The problem is not the arms trade as such. We see it that way because defence exports are big and comparatively speaking the UK economy depends heavily on the manufacture and sale of arms. Commercial policy, most evidently on arms, is too rarely based on stabilising large potential markets in the future. Maintaining the defence sector sometimes rides roughshod over the government's own criteria for licensing arms exports.

Such tensions show up clearly in Africa policy, to which senior government ministers give far less attention than their counterparts in the US or France. The debate is whether ministers focus more on the arms the UK wants to sell today or on the peace and markets it might want in 10 or 20 years. They should choose the latter and start rowing in the same direction.

Edmund Cairns is a senior policy adviser at Oxfam

fields.headline: Slice of book, anyone?
fields.standfirst: One day they were eating paper, the next floating in offal. Adrian Searle on the days when artists still knew how to shock
fields.trailText: One day they were eating paper, the next floating in offal. Adrian Searle on the days when artists still knew how to shock
fields.body:
Last week Michael Craig-Martin reconstructed his 1972 installation of a hidden electric fan and viewing mirrors in the Whitechapel Art Gallery. It is part of the exhibition Live in Your Head, a survey of British experimental and conceptual art of the late 60s and 70s. He wistfully recalled the python-print flared corduroys he had in those days, and said, "This stuff didn't have an audience then. Maybe six people other than the artists involved. No one knew what the rules were, or whether or not what they did was art. Nor did they know how to present it. Every student now knows the rules of presentation."

John Stezaker, who is showing works derived from postcards of Westminster and Big Ben, describes it as "the most repressed, anorexic art movement ever, with no appeal whatever to desire or to the unconscious". When the Hayward mounted its exhibition The New Art in 1972, which included works by more than a dozen of the artists now at the Whitechapel, it was one of the worst attended in the gallery's history. But the Whitechapel has been full since the exhibition opened last Friday. The British public has largely overcome its disdain for modern art.

So what was the experiment? What were the concepts? Preoccupations included time and duration, abjection and transience, dematerialisation and nothingness, process, social context and individualism, the self and its construction. All human life is here, except painting and sculpture, unless you count Bob Law's painting, which doesn't belong anyway, and Derek Boshier's tiny minimal sculptures, photographed out of scale in various locations.

The New Art, or whatever it was (the curators don't seem especially clear on the matter, but then it was an epoch of uncertainty), was also art made in the shadows of Joseph Beuys, Yves Klein and Piero Manzoni, art influenced by anti-art and post-object artists in New York and California. Art derived from a varied and not always coherent mix of linguistics and structuralist thought, from Marx, Adorno, Walter Benjamin and Alain Robbe-Grillet, from feminism, behaviourism, drugs and dissidence. How all this concerted thinking worked its way into the photographs of Keith Arnatt, who stood outside the public library in Newport, Gwent, in his loon pants, carrying a placard with the words "I'M A REAL ARTIST", I don't know. Arnatt went on to make an exhibition proposal that read, "Is it possible for me to do nothing as my contribution to this exhibition?" Indeed it was.

Craig-Martin's notorious 1973 philosophical self-interrogation about a glass of water on a shelf, which he said was an oak tree, belongs as much in the pages of Flann O'Brien as it does in the canon of post-Wittgensteinian thought. "What I have done is change a glass of water into an oak tree without altering the accidents of the glass of water," Craig-Martin wrote. "What accidents?" he asked himself. "Yes. The colour, feel, weight, size. How long will it continue to be an oak tree? UntiI I change it." Nothing has changed. Here's the glass, here's the oak tree, perhaps.

The possibility that the work was simply absurd shouldn't be discounted, although humour was often inadvertent, dressed up as heavyweight thought.

All this was very confusing for an art student. When Victor Burgin, whose work appears in this show, bounced into the studio at Trent Polytechnic in his Cuban heels and Marsha Hunt hairdo to lecture on the difference between Saussurian langue and parole, at least I was learning that books were to be read, if not always understood.

John Latham, lecturing at St Martin's School of Art in the mid-60s, propagated the alternative notion that books were to be eaten. He invited a few students for an impromptu "at home" one Sunday, during which they were invited to tuck into the pages of critic Clement Greenberg's Art and Culture - grim fare, some might say, for starving students. Unfortunately, it was a library book, and Latham's attempt to return the masticated pulp got him the sack. I know that library, and the commemorative No Eating sign that to this day hangs on the door. You can't actually eat the regurgitated book at the Whitechapel, but you can look at its remains, along with all the relevant documentation, in a museum vitrine.

Latham's gesture was in part an attack on the god-like status accorded Greenberg in the sculpture school at St Martin's, where Antony Caro and his traditional metal-bending chums ruled the roost. The dissident students under that macho regime - Gilbert and George, Bruce McLean and Richard Long (who'd previously been chucked out of art school in Bristol for absenting himself on long walks and traipsing mud through the nice clean studios) - went on to make work in direct resistance to the dominant school.

One of the things the exhibition barely hints at is how antagonistic this world was. The artist-protagonists, who taught part-time up and down the country, forced students to take sides, but they alienated just as many. There were suicides. The intimidation tactics used by both the supposedly liberal colleges on the one hand, and the likes of the conceptual art group Art & Language on the other, were astonishing in their crudity and destructiveness. Now the kind of mind-set and tactics we can observe in Live in Your Head have grown into academic orthodoxy.

Art & Language is here, with a series of filing cabinets you're not allowed to open, and reams of impenetrable typed codes stuck to the wall. Its spoof codifications hang alongside Susan Hiller's classified sets of collected postcards of rough seas around the British coast. The postcards are great, while Hiller's mind-numbing numbering of them now looks redundant. But Hiller was attempting to apply her training as an anthropologist to sociological ephemera, and her Rough Seas can now be read as a precursor to Tacita Dean's work. Even if we regard a lot of this as a necessarily flawed experiment, it did at least attempt new, if not exactly original, ways of working.

An apparently more politicised art was going on at the same time, although most of it has lost its agit-prop power. A mistrust of aesthetic form (and formalism) led to some pretty arid, preachy-looking documentary art, even if the issues still have resonance. Looking at Rasheed Araeen's For Oluwale, which re-presents an article from the Guardian about a Nigerian immigrant, David Oluwale, who was hounded and tormented by Leeds police in 1971, and found dead in the River Aire, one is left with a terrible feeling that nothing changes.

Conrad Atkinson's A Shade of Green, an Orange Edge collected quotations from everyone from Belfast children, then home secretary Reggie Maudling and Jonathan Swift, in a work focusing on Bloody Sunday. Atkinson's work was never any good, except as documentation. But Maudling's "For god's sake bring me a large Scotch. What a bloody awful country", juxtaposed with a child's "Trouble everywhere, blood, everything turning wild, people like wild animals", remains chilling. I guess the inclusion of John Dugger's banner, which hung behind Salvador Allende during a mass rally in support of Chilean resistance in Trafalgar Square in 1974, is included to give political perspective. Dugger now makes banners in California for corporate clients.

But there are moments here which still have a certain power and endurance. Stuart Brisley's 1972-3 film Arbeit Macht Frei ("Work makes you free" - the words emblazoned over the gate at Auschwitz) is an utterly chilling sequence of performances filmed by Ken MacMullen and Anna Flanagan. The work, in which Brisley vomits, seems to drown under ice and floats in a pool of offal, is harrowing, fixating, distressing.

It is also a formally beautiful work, in which his head, like a death mask, rises through bubbles and scum and the grainy flicker of disturbed sleep, ending in a scream. It owes more to Antonin Artaud than Austrian Aktionism. It provides an antidote to all the wanky stop-frame landscape films and photos, the studious polytechnic-speak of would-be art intellectuals, the innocent S&M fun and games of Cosey Fanni Tutti and Genesis P-Orridge, of whom John Peel wrote: "They're mad - but we need more of this kind of madness." We got more of it. In fact, we've had more of it than we can eat. Ah! Unhappy days, unhappy days.

 Live in Your Head is at the Whitechapel Art Gallery, London E1 (0171-522 7878), till April 2.

But the Whitechapel has been full since the exhibition opened last Friday. The British public has largely overcome its disdain for modern art. So what was the experiment? What were the concepts? Preoccupations included time and duration, abjection and transience, dematerialisation and nothingness, process, social context and individualism, the self and its construction. All human life is here, except painting and sculpture, unless you count Bob Law's painting, which doesn't belong anyway, and Derek Boshier's tiny minimal sculptures, photographed out of scale in various locations. The New Art, or whatever it was (the curators don't seem especially clear on the matter, but then it was an epoch of uncertainty), was also art made in the shadows of Joseph Beuys, Yves Klein and Piero Manzoni, art influenced by anti-art and post-object artists in New York and California. Art derived from a varied and not always coherent mix of linguistics and structuralist thought, from Marx, Adorno, Walter Benjamin and Alain Robbe-Grillet, from feminism, behaviourism, drugs and dissidence. How all this concerted thinking worked its way into the photographs of Keith Arnatt, who stood outside the public library in Newport, Gwent, in his loon pants, carrying a placard with the words "I'M A REAL ARTIST", I don't know. Arnatt went on to make an exhibition proposal that read, "Is it possible for me to do nothing as my contribution to this exhibition?" Indeed it was. Craig-Martin's notorious 1973 philosophical self-interrogation about a glass of water on a shelf, which he said was an oak tree, belongs as much in the pages of Flann O'Brien as it does in the canon of post-Wittgensteinian thought. "What I have done is change a glass of water into an oak tree without altering the accidents of the glass of water," Craig-Martin wrote. "What accidents?" he asked himself. "Yes. The colour, feel, weight, size. How long will it continue to be an oak tree? UntiI I change it." Nothing has changed. Here's the glass, here's the oak tree, perhaps. The possibility that the work was simply absurd shouldn't be discounted, although humour was often inadvertent, dressed up as heavyweight thought. All this was very confusing for an art student. When Victor Burgin, whose work appears in this show, bounced into the studio at Trent Polytechnic in his Cuban heels and Marsha Hunt hairdo to lecture on the difference between Saussurian langue and parole, at least I was learning that books were to be read, if not always understood. John Latham, lecturing at St Martin's School of Art in the mid-60s, propagated the alternative notion that books were to be eaten. He invited a few students for an impromptu "at home" one Sunday, during which they were invited to tuck into the pages of critic Clement Greenberg's Art and Culture - grim fare, some might say, for starving students. Unfortunately, it was a library book, and Latham's attempt to return the masticated pulp got him the sack. I know that library, and the commemorative No Eating sign that to this day hangs on the door. You can't actually eat the regurgitated book at the Whitechapel, but you can look at its remains, along with all the relevant documentation, in a museum vitrine. Latham's gesture was in part an attack on the god-like status accorded Greenberg in the sculpture school at St Martin's, where Antony Caro and his traditional metal-bending chums ruled the roost. The dissident students under that macho regime - Gilbert and George, Bruce McLean and Richard Long (who'd previously been chucked out of art school in Bristol for absenting himself on long walks and traipsing mud through the nice clean studios) - went on to make work in direct resistance to the dominant school. One of the things the exhibition barely hints at is how antagonistic this world was. The artist-protagonists, who taught part-time up and down the country, forced students to take sides, but they alienated just as many. There were suicides. The intimidation tactics used by both the supposedly liberal colleges on the one hand, and the likes of the conceptual art group Art & Language on the other, were astonishing in their crudity and destructiveness. Now the kind of mind-set and tactics we can observe in Live in Your Head have grown into academic orthodoxy. Art & Language is here, with a series of filing cabinets you're not allowed to open, and reams of impenetrable typed codes stuck to the wall. Its spoof codifications hang alongside Susan Hiller's classified sets of collected postcards of rough seas around the British coast. The postcards are great, while Hiller's mind-numbing numbering of them now looks redundant. But Hiller was attempting to apply her training as an anthropologist to sociological ephemera, and her Rough Seas can now be read as a precursor to Tacita Dean's work. Even if we regard a lot of this as a necessarily flawed experiment, it did at least attempt new, if not exactly original, ways of working. An apparently more politicised art was going on at the same time, although most of it has lost its agit-prop power. A mistrust of aesthetic form (and formalism) led to some pretty arid, preachy-looking documentary art, even if the issues still have resonance. Looking at Rasheed Araeen's For Oluwale, which re-presents an article from the Guardian about a Nigerian immigrant, David Oluwale, who was hounded and tormented by Leeds police in 1971, and found dead in the River Aire, one is left with a terrible feeling that nothing changes. Conrad Atkinson's A Shade of Green, an Orange Edge collected quotations from everyone from Belfast children, then home secretary Reggie Maudling and Jonathan Swift, in a work focusing on Bloody Sunday. Atkinson's work was never any good, except as documentation. But Maudling's "For god's sake bring me a large Scotch. What a bloody awful country", juxtaposed with a child's "Trouble everywhere, blood, everything turning wild, people like wild animals", remains chilling. I guess the inclusion of John Dugger's banner, which hung behind Salvador Allende during a mass rally in support of Chilean resistance in Trafalgar Square in 1974, is included to give political perspective. Dugger now makes banners in California for corporate clients. But there are moments here which still have a certain power and endurance. Stuart Brisley's 1972-3 film Arbeit Macht Frei ("Work makes you free" - the words emblazoned over the gate at Auschwitz) is an utterly chilling sequence of performances filmed by Ken MacMullen and Anna Flanagan. The work, in which Brisley vomits, seems to drown under ice and floats in a pool of offal, is harrowing, fixating, distressing. It is also a formally beautiful work, in which his head, like a death mask, rises through bubbles and scum and the grainy flicker of disturbed sleep, ending in a scream. It owes more to Antonin Artaud than Austrian Aktionism. It provides an antidote to all the wanky stop-frame landscape films and photos, the studious polytechnic-speak of would-be art intellectuals, the innocent S&M fun and games of Cosey Fanni Tutti and Genesis P-Orridge, of whom John Peel wrote: "They're mad - but we need more of this kind of madness." We got more of it. In fact, we've had more of it than we can eat. Ah! Unhappy days, unhappy days.  Live in Your Head is at the Whitechapel Art Gallery, London E1 (0171-522 7878), till April 2.

webTitle: FSA to move on 'pump and dump' traders

fields.headline: FSA to move on 'pump and dump' traders
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
FSA
fields.trailText: The internet's huge, hyperactive gossip and rumour machine looks almost certain to come under scrutiny from the financial services authority amid rising concern about its power to move share prices and even to distort markets.
fields.body:
The internet's huge, hyperactive gossip and rumour machine looks almost certain to come under scrutiny from the financial services authority amid rising concern about its power to move share prices and even to distort markets.

Scams such as "pumping and dumping" - in which internet noticeboards are abused by rogue share promoters - will be investigated by a special FSA think-tank.

The terms of reference for the e-commerce investigation team - which will draw on all relevant expertise within the authority's Canary Wharf headquarters in London's Docklands - are still being drafted. It is thought certain, however, that the vast, unregulated bazaar of tips and gossip will come within its scope.

Alarmed by the ability of cyberspace's rumour mongers to talk up stocks in which they might have built up large positions, thus making a mockery of laws on market abuse, the "thematic" inquiry into e-commerce, established last month by FSA chairman Howard Davies, is likely to seek remedies for the plague of misleading information.

Tony Hobman, the chief executive of Proshare, the organisation that promotes private share ownership, said potential investors should use information on internet bulletin boards with caution.

"We have seen a great leap forward in the public's interest in share dealing, but people should not pile into the stock just on the basis of a tip they read online," he said.

"The dark side of net trading is that it is easy to do, and when dot.com stocks are rising so dramatically it can be very tempting to get involved.

"Investors need to fully understand what they are doing, research the companies they think about buying into and spread their risk."

Fuelling official concern is the explosion in potential regulatory cases involving the internet and e-commerce.

Three months ago, of the 50 to 60 files opened each month by FSA investigators, 10% related to the internet. The figure now is 15%, with further increases expected.

But the authorities are hobbled to an extent by protection in the human rights act for freedom of expression. A source said there was no real legal "grip" enabling the FSA to come down hard on the internet gossip machine - although it is believed that official surveillance of the internet is being stepped up.

It is understood that the FSA will steer clear of any attempt to regulate opinions not given in what is known as the "course of business", however malicious or unfounded these opinions may be.

The thinking seems to be that companies themselves are both equipped for monitoring comments about them on the internet and responsible for doing so.

Furthermore, there is a feeling inside the authority that "market separation" - under which it is clear to even the average investor which areas of online comment and advice are "safe" and which are not - might be a natural development, and one that is not wholly undesirable.

But a hands-off policy is not an option, not least because of the damage that fast-moving rumours - often corrupted by the self-interest of the rumour-monger - could do to the integrity of financial markets.

More than one in five execution-only share trades will be conducted over the internet by the end of March, the Association of Private Client, Investment Managers and Stockbrokers predicts.

"We can easily see one-quarter of all trades taking place online by the end of this year," said the organisation's head of information, Brian Mairs.

He added that online share trading had doubled every quarter since the start of 1999. In the fourth quarter of 1999, 2.3m execution trades were carried out in Britain, 155,000 of which were on the net.

The e-commerce inquiry is one of four investigations being begun by the FSA; the others will cover mortgages, incentives for companies to comply with FSA rules and the implications for investors of a low-inflation environment.

Many firms running internet bulletin boards have pledged to expel individuals who post false or inaccurate information on their message boards.

fields.headline: Play time
fields.standfirst: Moby ***** L2, Liverpool
fields.trailText: Pop stars used to judge how hip they were by whether they appeared on magazine covers. Nowadays the peak of hipness is being asked to model for Calvin Klein.
fields.body:
Pop stars used to judge how hip they were by whether they appeared on magazine covers. Nowadays the peak of hipness is being asked to model for Calvin Klein.

This year the chosen ones are Macy Gray and Moby. The allure of the chic soulstress is understandable, but a vegan, environmentalist, skinhead, Christian, anarcho-punk turned dance icon, named after a whale? Curious indeed, but CK is merely following the rest of the world (Moby is also nominated for a Brit) in realising that this unique artist is a genius.

It's nine years since New Yorker Moby defined house music with Go; his groundbreaking musical path has since involved phuture house, punk, speed metal and 40s delta blues. There's no question that this is Moby's moment.

Like his records (1999's Play album and 1995's Everything is Wrong), the gig is extraordinary, even transcendental. It begins with the supposed computer music boffin assembling an authentically sweating band (a scratching DJ, Scouse drummer and a blonde rock chick bassist). It inspires hordes of Liverpudlians to sing about "troubles with God". It ends with a topless Moby standing aloft a buzzing keyboard, fending off enquiries concerning his knickers.

When he's not leaping about or unveiling a remarkable talent as a multi-instrumentalist (bongos, guitars, synths, electric pads), Moby makes a surprising raconteur. Hilariously, he tells about being refused admission to trendy Liverpool club Cream the night before, as his records played inside. He puts down hecklers witheringly ("You'll have to get someone to translate") and thrills the natives by piling into Echo and the Bunnymen.

What he doesn't do is preach. In fact, he's remarkably self-effacing. "I'm probably not the best person to comment," he says of the pulverising Bodyrock, "but I think this is kinda sexy."

Sexy is one description, shamanistic is another. Moby's music sounds instantly 2000 but also invokes the eerie atmosphere of an ancient pagan ritual. Feel So Real begins as folk, shoots through time as a rave anthem and ends in blistering punk with Moby shouting "Love!" Maybe this is what they mean by religious Ecstacy.

His Brit nomination is for Best International Male Solo Artist. God knows if he'll win it, but the title would suit him down to the ground.

webTitle: Philips & Drew backs BoS for NatWest

fields.headline: Philips & Drew backs BoS for NatWest
fields.trailText: Phillips & Drew, one of the top 10 shareholders in NatWest, is backing Bank of Scotland's £23bn bid for the beseiged clearing bank in a move which could sway the outcome of the four-month battle.
fields.body:
Phillips & Drew, one of the top 10 shareholders in NatWest, is backing Bank of Scotland's £23bn bid for the beseiged clearing bank in a move which could sway the outcome of the four-month battle.

P&D is the first of the major investors in NatWest to reach a decision. It is understood to have decided to put its 2.3% shareholding in NatWest behind BoS because it prefers its management.

While the backing of P&D, a week before the St Valentine's day deadline, will give BoS a much-needed boost, Royal Bank is also thought to be confident that it has won the support of other leading NatWest shareholders.

As the long-running contest draws to a close, the two Scottish banks had been eager to win a public endorsement from a major NatWest shareholder in the hope that it could set a "bandwagon" in motion and prevent the vote being split, which would prevent either of the Scots claiming victory but allow NatWest to escape.

Even with the P&D decision, a split vote was still considered a possibility last night as all three sides continued their last-ditch "charm offensives" on NatWest's shareholders.

The Scottish banks are hoping that NatWest's management, boosted by Gordon Pell from Lloyds TSB, will hear enough negative sentiment from the bank's long-suffering shareholders that they end up recommending one of the bids to their shareholders.

The fight is so finely balanced that both Scottish banks are lobbying private shareholders, even though many of the individuals are former or existing NatWest staff.

P&D, NatWest's seventh-largest shareholder, has not hidden its admiration for BoS and once held a 15% stake which it acquired when Standard Life sold off its major shareholding in BoS four years ago.

All three banks will now be scrambling to win the backing of Prudential, NatWest's largest shareholder with a 5% stake, along with Mercury Asset Management and Schroders, which met NatWest's management yesterday.

Legal & General and Barclays Global Investors, the two "index tracking" fund management firms, are also considered to be important, as is the decision by Standard Life, the Edinburgh-based group which has ruled out backing NatWest but is refusing to admit which one of the two Scottish bidders it will support.

All the big shareholders in NatWest also hold stakes in the two Scottish banks, which Michael Lever, a highly regarded banking analyst at HSBC who has backed NatWest, believes should make them focus on the "lopsided equation between the additional rewards they are assuming and the considerably higher risks they are running".

fields.headline: Commission of note
fields.standfirst: London Sinfonietta Queen Elizabeth Hall, London ****
fields.trailText: There isn't a phase of Stravinsky's endlessly protean development that has not spread its influence on succeeding generations of composers, for he dominated 20th-century music in a unique way.
fields.body:
There isn't a phase of Stravinsky's endlessly protean development that has not spread its influence on succeeding generations of composers, for he dominated 20th-century music in a unique way.

The works he composed in the 50s, when his style was shifting from neo-classicism to his very personal version of serial technique, have left their mark on history in a less conspicuous but no less significant way. It was a selection of small-scale works from that period, all written around the very different landmarks of The Rake's Progress and the ballet Agon, that provided the theme of the London Sinfonietta's triple-decker programme on Sunday.

They were interleaved with works by three British composers, all of whom, in platform interviews with the Stravinsky biographer Stephen Walsh during the concert, declared a debt to Stravinsky of one kind or another.

Knussen's continuing advocacy of this still difficult and unfamiliar music is remarkable. Though a work like the Septet, literally on the cusp of neo-classicism and serialism, responds to a standard Stravinskian approach, the Three Shakespeare Songs (intelligently sung here by Mary King) and the little memorial pieces like the Double Canon and the Epitaphium need a studied coolness and care to bring out their hard-edged qualities, which was what these Sinfonietta performances provided.

As well as a revival of Geoffrey King-Gomez's Magritte Weather, there should have been two new British works, both Sinfonietta commissions, to set off this rather austere sequence. Knussen's own score was not completed in time; instead the Sinfonietta gave lustrous performances of his Ophelia Dances and the Two Organa.

Julian Anderson's Alhambra Fantasy did materialise, and a remarkable score it turned out to be. Though it was apparently inspired by a visit to the Alhambra palace in Granada, and elements of Moorish and Sephardic music are woven into the score along with Spanish folk songs collected by Lorca, there's no trace of picture-postcard realism about Anderson's piece. It spits out ideas at a dizzyingly rapid pace in its first half, all vividly coloured and driven with irrepressible rhythmic energy, then slows dramatically and revisits the same material at a more leisurely pace. The structure may not quite work - the idea of a highly compressed series of variations followed by a single lengthier one is perhaps more intellectually than aurally satisfying, and the piece runs out of steam a little towards the end - but there is so much that is startling and immediate about the writing that such nit-picking seems beside the point.

fields.headline: The limits of knowledge
fields.standfirst: Insider dealing is a crime not a hobby
fields.trailText: Leader: Insider dealing is a crime not a hobby
fields.body:
Imagine the public outcry if there had been no successful prosecutions for muggings for nearly a decade. Yet that is the case with insider dealings in the city. Everyone knows it goes on - witness how share prices rise so often in advance of take-over bids - yet the last successful prosecution happened nearly nine years ago.

The subject has erupted into public discussion because of two incidents. First, revelations that Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, was buying shares in advance of tips in the newspaper: and, second, when the wife of entrepreneur Philip Green bought £25m worth of shares in Marks & Spencer days before Mr Green announced that he might bid for the group.

The second example would look like a straight case of insider dealing, except that nothing is that simple in this area. Green claims his wife was merely acting "in concert" with him to support a takeover. This is not illegal. Mr Morgan claims he didn't know that the Mirror's Slickers column was tipping the same shares (Viglen) he had purchased in the following day's issue. It is very difficult to prove what actually went on inside someone's head - which is why so many cases have failed to satisfy the criminal law. The financial services bill trundling through parliament will have a new (civil) offence of "market abuse" policed by the financial services authority, with power to fine wrongdoers and make them pay restitution to victims.

Judgment will be made on the "balance of probabilities" rather the "beyond reasonable doubt" criterion of the criminal law. If these provisions aren't watered down they will go a long way towards persuading richer people that insider dealing is a crime and not a hobby. Scrutiny of journalists will be intensified by the new laws, but newspapers should avoid getting to that stage by having tight rules about when journalists can trade and full disclosure when they do.

The financial services bill trundling through parliament will have a new (civil) offence of "market abuse" policed by the financial services authority, with power to fine wrongdoers and make them pay restitution to victims. Judgment will be made on the "balance of probabilities" rather the "beyond reasonable doubt" criterion of the criminal law. If these provisions aren't watered down they will go a long way towards persuading richer people that insider dealing is a crime and not a hobby. Scrutiny of journalists will be intensified by the new laws, but newspapers should avoid getting to that stage by having tight rules about when journalists can trade and full disclosure when they do.

fields.headline: Pirc starts social responsibility index
fields.trailText: The potentially huge cost of lapses in corporate conscience for business and shareholders has prompted investment consultancy Pirc to launch a ratings service to assess firms in terms of social responsibility.
fields.body:
The potentially huge cost of lapses in corporate conscience for business and shareholders has prompted investment consultancy Pirc to launch a ratings service to assess firms in terms of social responsibility.

The corporate responsibility service follows high-profile and expensive miscalculations by businesses such as the Brent Spar incident for Shell, Monsanto's miscalculation of the introduction of genetically modified foods and Marks & Spencer's decision to axe several British suppliers.

The move dovetails with political and business thinking that firms failing to meet public expectations in terms of operating behaviour will be punished by consumer boycotts and a loss of confidence.

It also coincides with the introduction of regulations forcing pension funds to disclose their thinking on socially responsible investment issues.

Alan MacDougall, managing director of Pirc, said: "There is growing consensus that the success stories of the new century will be those inclusive companies which look after their employees, the environment and other stakeholders."

The service will initially target the UK's largest companies in the FTSE 100 and gauge issues such as employment, community involvement, the environment, human rights and governance; it will also assess whether firms have policies for stakeholder issues.

fields.headline: Decibel overdrive
fields.standfirst: Ian Dury and the Blockheads Palladium, London ***
fields.trailText: One of the great things about Ian Dury and the Blockheads is that they still look as though they were playing the pub circuit only last week. Another is that they will probably never stop reeling with the surprise and joy produced by the success of 1998's excellent Mr Love Pants album.
fields.body:
One of the great things about Ian Dury and the Blockheads is that they still look as though they were playing the pub circuit only last week. Another is that they will probably never stop reeling with the surprise and joy produced by the success of 1998's excellent Mr Love Pants album.

Put them in a venue as plush, amply chandeliered and laden with entertainment history as the Palladium and you expect a particularly ebullient take on the greatest hits set. You don't expect that Dury's cocky, comical lyrics will be all but drowned out.

Dury looked surprisingly well, given that he now suffers from cancer as well as the after-effects of polio: once helped on stage, he perched on a shabby box and smiled gleefully at his friends. His voice sounded gutsy as ever. The problem was the Blockheads, or rather, the excessive volume they chose to play at.

To be fair, they are on superb form: their sound is energetic, taut and brassy, and benefits from their decades of playing together without being tainted by the complacency of fame. The guitars scorched, the Hammond chugged and the saxophones glittered. But it was hard not to feel that they should have toned it down a bit. Extending a couple of songs with big solos is one thing; tacking them on to everything is self-indulgent and tedious.

The few times they did restrain themselves - in the quiet intros to The Passing Scene and Sweet Gene Vincent - Dury immediately gained in presence. Granted, he is no poet: a lot of the delight of his lyrics lies in their syncopation with the Blockheads' individual brand of funk-rock. However, even if you know the songs so well that you've stopped making up the lyrics to Reasons to Be Cheerful and can recite Billericay Dickie backwards, you want to be able to hear the words when played live. In this atmosphere, the three new songs - even the quintessential number Mash it Up Harry - stood little chance of affecting the audience.

Dury himself didn't seem unduly troubled: he tapped his foot, swung his white silk scarf, slyly pointed at band members to signal his admiration of a solo and rummaged in a bag of tricks for things to play with: coloured handkerchiefs, a magic wand, maracas (also inaudible). At the end, he told a cheering audience, "hearing you lot will keep me going another five years", which is just about the nicest, most heart-warming thing a pop star could say to his fans.

webTitle: AOL teams up with Nokia and Ericsson

fields.headline: AOL teams up with Nokia and Ericsson
fields.standfirst:
ISP to provide content for internet mobile phones

E-finance: special report
AOL
Nokia
Ericsson
Vodafone AirTouch
fields.trailText: AOL Europe, the internet service provider, yesterday moved to kickstart the market for web services over mobile phones by teaming up with handset manufacturers Nokia and Ericsson to develop online content.
fields.body:
AOL Europe, the internet service provider, yesterday moved to kickstart the market for web services over mobile phones by teaming up with handset manufacturers Nokia and Ericsson to develop online content.

Trials of AOL services will initially focus on the delivery of news, email, weather reports and stock quotes beginning in Germany, Britain and France at the end of this month.

Andreas Schmidt, president and chief executive of AOL Europe, described the advent of mobile internet as a "historic growth opportunity" for the company. It expects one-third of Europeans to be accessing the internet via wireless application protocol (WAP) mobile phones by 2004.

Vice president of the group Christopher Hill said: "We are trying to bring the AOL experience to mobile devices. In the next year or two it will probably be impossible to buy a mobile phone in Europe that is not internet enabled."

The companies will also cooperate to ensure that AOL Europe's mobile portals are compatible with Nokia and Ericsson's future WAP technologies.

Nokia launched its first WAP phone in Britain in November but Ericsson is still some weeks from the launch of its first internet enabled handsets. The market is expected to take a leap towards the end of the year with the introduction of a technology called general packet radio service, which provides speeds up to 10 times faster than existing mobile internet access.

AOL Europe, which has 4m customers, is a joint venture between America Online and German media group Bertelsmann. Their relationship is rumoured to be on uncertain ground with the American company keen to buy its partner out of the venture. A potential flotation of AOL Europe in Frankfurt has also been strongly tipped.

Analysts believe AOL Europe will also look to establish a relationship with one of the world's leading network providers - the merged Vodafone-AirTouch- Mannesmann is an obvious choice.

Mannesmann had been manoeuvring to do a deal with AOL Europe as part of its defence against the Vodafone takeover bid.

As mobile phone internet access becomes a reality, content providers are anxious to position themselves as leading players in the market.

Rupert Murdoch, chairman of News Corporation, recently met directors of Nokia on a fact-finding mission and is known to consider mobile phones a key distribution route in the coming years.

OneTel, an Australian mobile phone company in which Mr Murdoch has a 25% stake, is among the bidders for licences in the next generation of mobile phones in Britain which will offer the highest speed access yet and enable high quality video reception. The so called "third generation" licences will be auctioned next month.

Microsoft chairman Bill Gates has also stressed the need for the American software company to develop programs to run on mobile phones. Mr Gates, who recently became the company's chief technologist, is understood to be preparing a major deal with BT and a number of high-profile business alliances.

Internal memos revealed last week that the group wants to announce a series of important deals - possibly with groups such as AT&T, Sprint and AirTouch, as well as BT - at the end of this month, when Mr Gates addresses a trade show.

fields.headline: Piano trio on message
fields.standfirst: David Newton Pizza Express, Soho, London ***
fields.trailText: A lot of casual punters tune out of traditional jazz piano trios before they've had a chance to deliver their message. Broadway tunes, unfolded with understated swing and propelled by tasteful rhythm sections, often say "warm-up band" to irregular listeners, who are waiting for the main attraction to blast them out of their seat with a sax.
fields.body:
A lot of casual punters tune out of traditional jazz piano trios before they've had a chance to deliver their message. Broadway tunes, unfolded with understated swing and propelled by tasteful rhythm sections, often say "warm-up band" to irregular listeners, who are waiting for the main attraction to blast them out of their seat with a sax.

David Newton, the Scottish pianist who was launching his new CD Halfway to Dawn, has had to carry this baggage around for a lot longer than his classy accomplishments deserve. He has proved such a superb accompanist (of singers, particularly) that he has been almost sidelined into that role. Meanwhile, Newton's affections for traditional thematic development, familiar song structures and the sometimes treacherous waters of the mainstream have maybe encouraged lazy listening to his achievements as both player and composer. But he repays close attention, particularly here.

Newton's idea of an acoustic piano trio is nowhere near as loose, impressionistic and open-ended as Keith Jarrett's has been, or Brad Mehldau's, or Bobo Stenson's - and his forthright song-based lyricism doesn't generally catch the charismatic mysteriousness all three can bring to a room. But his current trio with bassist Matt Miles and drummer Steve Brown is a little gem of group empathy in pursuit of straight-ahead swing.

From the off, when Newton introduced Bright New Day with offhand chords over Miles's bass vamp, the pianist's storytelling skills were evident, the casual theme building into a soft roar of insistent trills, punchy chordwork and sudden sprinting runs. Newton also made a shapely narrative out of the obliquely funky ballad Wishful Thinking, phrasing in half-stated figures as if nervous of damaging the keys.

On drums, Brown (a tall, hawk-nosed young man with an eager grin, who sits at a low-slung kit with the cymbals set at elbow-level) is a delight. He has an urbane understatement and sidelong wit that adds zip and buoyancy to the sounds around him. Alert to every approaching detail, he fills out melodies with hissing hi-hat snaps and briefly jolting rolls, drops back to minimalist rimshots and erupts into fizzing cymbal swing with an effect like a door suddenly swung open to a busy street. An unfashionable treasure.

webTitle: I deserve a pay rise but my boss keeps fobbing me off

fields.headline: I deserve a pay rise but my boss keeps fobbing me off
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

I have been in my current part-time job for 18 months, during which time it has changed from solely secretarial work to include a lot of web design and web site maintenance work.

In September last year I asked my boss to look into giving me a pay rise to reflect my new responsibilities.

He went abroad for a few weeks and we had a meeting in October about it, as he had cancelled the two meetings I'd set up previously due to other commitments. At the meeting he said that he did not have any objection in principle and that he could see how much my job had changed. He asked me to get together a 'justification' and a graph showing how much more time I spend on web work, and how much I estimated it would grow in the future, along with examples of similar external jobs and their pay.

I was also asked to get together internal company information on the various pay structures and to highlight how my job crossed over them. I supplied this within days.

In November he told me that his managers would need six to eight weeks more in which to make a decision about this. I did say at the time that I was not very happy about that as quite some time had lapsed since I had first mentioned it.

In early December I asked again if he knew what was happening, only to be rather curtly brushed off with a comment along the lines of 'it is in hand'. Five months have gone by since I first asked about this during which time I have supplied the information asked for (in October) and waited for an amount of time I feel is excessive considering that I am asking for a rise in the region of about £2-4K per annum (although I did not specify this amount, it would bring my wage in line with other similar jobs that I outlined to my boss).

I also now feel aggrieved that I do not know what is going on, and there is no sign of a resolution to this. My personal attitude to my job has plummeted as I feel undervalued. I even wonder if they are hoping I will leave.

I think my employers are not used to part-time secretarial staff asking for pay rises and they are not really sure how to deal with it. Also, as they have set pay structures, they must be aware that my job does not fall neatly into any existing hierarchies.

I work for a very large multi-national pharmaceutical company (a growth industry) so can see no justification for being treated like this - it really can't be that they can't afford it. I am in the process of looking for another job but as I want to work part-time this may prove hard to come by.

Am I flogging a dead horse here, and should I take the hint and leave, or should I take the matter higher and risk alienating my co-workers, in particular my direct boss?

The solution

Your letter serves as a reminder to me, just in case I should ever forget, just how short-sighted some managers can be. You have done everything right and obviously have the insight and analytical skills to figure out what their problem is. In other words, you sound like a real asset to the company, but your managers can't see beyond their own prejudices to recognise this.

This leaves you with three options. Firstly, you can swallow your feelings of being undervalued and ignore the whole thing in exchange for the part-time job you want (if not at the salary you want). Secondly, you can give up and simply look for alternative employment. Finally, you could go above your boss and take the matter higher - with the associated risks that you identify.

My advice? I would try options two and three simultaneously. Start looking for alternative employment but at the same time, take the matter higher. This way, if you still get fobbed off, or if the tensions with your colleagues become unbearable, you might have a fall-back plan of a new job.

The best way to go above your boss without alienating him/her is to send a memo outlining what has happened (how you did what was asked, the time that has passed etc). End by sweetly suggesting that as your boss clearly does not have the time to give the matter consideration and you do not wish to keep pestering them for an answer, you feel that it would be better to take the matter to a more senior level. In other words, provide your boss with a reasonable explanation for his/her lack of action that can justify your going above him/her. Such a letter may in itself, galvanise your boss into activity.

Incidentally, I don't think that your employers are hoping you will leave - I just don't think it has crossed their minds that you might consider leaving. If you did, I suspect it would be a huge shock that might well jolt them into giving you an appropriate salary increase. So, if you do get another job offer, it is always worth giving it one last go with your present employer to see if the realisation that others want you (and are prepared to pay) brings them to their senses.

Good luck. I have a feeling you'll get there one way or another.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)
